A rich beer with incredible aroma and a complex, fruity and malty flavour. The alcohol content is masked so effectively behind the layers of flavour that it can sneak up on you. One of my all time favourite beers.

Dark brown color, looks just like coke actually. Off-white head, no lacing. 
Aroma of raisins, plum, some chocolate and grapes. The taste is complex, yet its easy to drink. Malty caramel and light bitterness.

UPDATED: SEP 8, 2013 This is my "go to" beer. Always amazes me how they pack so much deliciousness into such a small bottle. Pours a lovely dark brown with generous tan head. Aroma just draws you in. Taste is devine, dark fruits, spices, candy, slight bitterness. Alcohol so well hidden. My #1 for sure. Too easy to drink though!

UPDATED: SEP 27, 2014 Flaske kjøpt på Vinmonopolet Lambertseter. Mørke brun farge, lite skum. Moderat karbonert.Smaker karamell, brunt sukker, rom. Sterk , med 11%. Bør kanskje deles med en venn.En sinnsykt god øl

This heavy pitch black beer with 11.1% alcohol is actually very good even though I often get put off by such strong beers, i liked this better than the 8. Heavy still not oily, with an incredible taste sensation, so complex it transforms inside the mouth and makes you wonder. (at refridgerator temp) Non-creamy and rather fuzzy head that also bear alot of taste like the rest.

UPDATED: FEB 19, 2013 Dark brown pour with a small tan head. Aromas of malt, yeast, brown sugar, and dried fruit. Very bold flavor with the 11.3% abv being noticeable on the first sip but this beer really comes together when it warms up just a tad. It becomes so delicious, warming, and complex. Any sharpness to it mellows out.. Impressive and worth a try. Ill be drinking this one again.
Brown,fast fading tan head.Nose of malt,fruit,brown sugar & alcohol.More of same in palate with added toffee. Very complex but poor looking

caramel, roasty, earthy, woody, alcohol, brown, black, hazy, tan foam, light sweetness, lightly bitter, lightly sour, medium body, thin feel, lively, long finish.  Overall this is one of my favorite of the Trappist beers.  I have yet to try the world renowned Westvleteren but that will change in just a few short days.  If you want a fantastic beer that you can find in the state readily then this is your beer!
Pours a gorgeous, deep, dark brown with lots of sediment and a thin, foam head. An overwhelming aroma of raisins and plum. Oily, medium body and a bitter, dark fruit and burnt toffee flavour.

330ml bottle. Dark mahogany pour with not much head, but what there is has pooled in a strange pattern that ripples due to the string of bubbles rising from the etching in the bottom of the classic Rochefort glass. 
The nose is greeted with aromas of drying purple fruit and spice with an edge that recalls brandy sipped by a warm fire on a cold winters night. 
Flavours of intense purple fruit are the first to show up, quickly rolled under the spice and brandy from the nose. Finishes with a not unpleasant warming sensation that will have to do since Im without a fireplace this evening.
Bière puissante, qui développe des goût complexe en bouche. Que ce soit en entrée ou en sortie cette bière diffuse tous ses arômes puissants. Attention cest une brune très forte.

Dark brown appearance with a creamy and resistent beige head. Toffe, caramel and sweet wine aroma. Alcohol  perfectly integrated.

Dark brown colour. Big beige head. Aroma is overwhelming sweet: plums, raisins. Taste is sweet, dark fruits, chocolate. Oily mouthfeel. Long sweet finish with just a tiny bitterness. Heavy body Fantastic beer, huge amount of flavours, great balanced.

Smells of raisin, plum, grape and hints of leathery spice and bit of booziness. Tastes of vanilla, chocolate, raisins and a bit of a red wine-like character. Supremely drinkable considering the depth of flavor and alcohol content. Stamped 270716 and 07:55

Bottle Top Hops. Amazing Belgian quad. So much dark fruit. Plum,
fig and raisin. Aroma is subtle but the flavor is incredibly dense and dynamic. Body is straight syrup.

Awesome. Great nose, deep colour with good head and lacing. Full strong taste with smooth juicy palate of berries, fruit and syrup.

From an 11.5 oz bottle into a Chimay glass. Clean taste but man, there is a punch that sneaks up. Especially when it hits the back of your tongue. Boom! Yeasty and potent with lite spices. Carbonation is low and alcohol afterbite is minimal.

UPDATED: OCT 7, 2012 Taste ran a little hot, with the alcohol a little to prominent and covering up the flavor of the beer. Otherwise a good beer for sipping with complex flavors.

Good smell, the taste is really strong as I thought. The aftertaste is left for a while. Right now this is the 7th best beer in the world and I might not agree completely. Certainly it is good but not that I want to buy it again. Definitely worth trying.

Bottle into a cervoise goblet.

A: Pours a dark brownish purple, like a dirty grape, with lighter hues around the edges. Quick tan head that subsides into a nice film ring.

S: A little boozy with some slight dark fruits. Raisins and figs. There is a nice sweetness at the backend that rounds it out.

T: Nice dark berries on the tongue. Raisins, blueberries and figs all present. A sugary sweetness takes over from there which is really nice. There is some slight toffee or caramel as well. Finally there is a little heat that warms the throat.

M: Creamy and smooth. Nice carbonation with some nice sweet berries left on the palate.

O: Delicious. I really enjoyed every aspect of this beer and the dark fruits played off the sweetness nicely. Will revisit many times in the future.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 09-13-2011

UPDATED: JAN 6, 2013 Color is like  muddy coffee with solid head , reddish - brownish . Aroma is refreshing, bubblegum, cherries,  fermented fruits, molasses, melon, extremely rich aroma. Taste is like melon, grape juice, warming alcohol. Palate is well balanced and smooth, no bitterness. Well deserved 100 out of 100.   



We are doing Trappistes Rochefort 10 vs. St. Bernardus Abt. 12. Color is the same and the head is the same - orange brown and a bit cloudy. Aroma of Rochefort 10 is dark fruits,  caramel, melon, flowers. St. Bernardus aroma is chocolate,  earthy, nuts. Taste of Rochefort 10 is light sweet and amazing, so complex. Taste of St. Bernardus is (surprisingly) salty at the beginning then bitter and not so balanced actually. Rochefort palate is medium body, soft carbonation, oily texture. St. Bernardus is medium body , oily texture ,  average carbonation.  For me and my girlfriend Rochefort is the winner - its much more complex on the nose and taste.  Next time I will buy two Rocheforts rather then one St Bernardus and one Rochefort.

Bottle - Pours murky dark brown with a beige head (decent retention), Full body, Smells of dark fruits, figs, cherries - Taste malty good with figs, currants and caramel. Overall, there arent too many, if any Abt beers as good as this one.

Poured dark witha rapidly diminishing frothy tan head. Vinous dark fruit and malt aroma. Medium body, flavour is sweet yet smooth dark fruit, raisin, cherry, some mildly caramelised malt. Dry, sweet medium aftertaste.

330ml bottle. This one was a real treat, left it to age in my cellar for about a year. Sweat, dark sugar, raisins, a wine-like alcohol and very smooth. Just beautiful in every way.

Not really sure what the hype is about. I like the aroma and appearance but the taste is average at best. Really taste the Raisin, Plum  & Fig notes in the body along with spice notes that bring in Anise & Clove.

UPDATED: AUG 2, 2013 My all time favorite, this time aged for 18 months on bottle, to see what it would do to the taste. Age does do very good to this wonderfoul liquid. It brings up more of the complicated flavors like molasses, even more dark sugary raisins and liqourice than before. This while the high alcohol percentage isnt noticeable as much as before, and carbonation is also noticably less. Makes the beer an even greater pleasure to drink than before. It doesnt get better than this for me, personally.

-RoyB, Amsterdam

Very strong, full bodied beer. Pours very dark, wild foam that never really seems to go away, slightly yeasty alcoholic smell, with hints of fruit. 

Taste is full, warm, sweet and fruity, but also yeasty and alcoholic. 

A beer with a lot of flavours and a nice appearance, but a certain lack of subtlety. Great, but not the best.
Veramente fantastica, così densa da sembrare liquorosa, buonissima, non adatta se si guida, i suoi 11 gradi si fanno sentire

Enjoyed in a snifter. Murky plum brown appearance. Scent is dark fruits. Plums and raisins. Dark burnt sugar and birch wood. Taste is pretty sweet. Oily and full of brown sugar. Hints of cedar and other fruits.

Ar: Restrained currant, light oak, tobacco, strawberry, and molasses.
Ap: Deep brown-red, cloudy - medium-large light tan head with good retention - thin, but solid, cap of foam.
T: Medium-sweet raisin and dried cherry up front - dark caramel, treacle, and   some milk chocolate - clean alcohol heat - light bitterness with a finish of burnt caramel and dried strawberry.
P: Medium-full body, high carbonation - rich - finish is medium.
O: A truly breathtaking beer - rich, satisfying, complex, layered, and so much more.
bottle. pour is dark amber with great foamy head that lingers through. aroma of dried fruit and nuts. taste is syrup mouth fell withs all the fruit cake taste coming on the end

Dark brown with little head. Sweet aroma with dark fruits. Taste is of dark fruits with a slightly nutty finish. Just enough carb. One of the most luxurious silky palates ive experienced.

Pours dark with sediment.  Smells of fruit, raisins, alcohol, and some slight chocolate.  Taste is as complex as they get.  This one is highly rated for a reason.  I even gave my mother a sip--who turns her nose up at anything but Coors Light--and she was wowed by it.  You dont have to be a beer snob to enjoy this one.  Its just plain good.

Dark color and an incredibly full and complex body. Aroma is spiced, with many fruity notes. In the mouth delivers toasted malts, red fruits, spices, and many others. Soft carbonation, it leaves a moderate alcoholic finish. I love eating something with a strong taste with this beer.
It really is a treat that this beer is widely available, makes my mouth water thinking about how good the Westvleteren must be.
discovered this many years ago, quite heavy but a lot of depth to the flavours. Not for everyone but well worth a look
Just as good as wesvleteren 12, just more commercially available. Dark, complex, delicious with and uncommon buzz after finishing a couple. Try it or you cannot call yourself a beer buff.

I am a sever point giver , this is for me untill now the very best beer in the world , en wat a buzz , slmooth & easy on the edge of sweet and then in the final aftertaste you feel the fine hebes tickle your tongue , heavenly , CHEERS

Sweet smell. Malt raisin and mild hint of citrus. No head. Dark brown color. Medium light carbonation. Long complex layering of flavors. Sweet raisin fig and tart. Slightly nutty. No noticable alcohol. A little bit of warmth after a minute or so.

Dark brown; aromas of dark fruit, cigar box, cloves, spices, alcohol; thick, beautiful, smooth, creamy mouthfeel; sweet, rich malt, spicy, yeasty, dark fruits, cherries, raisins, perhaps some vanilla; alcohol is well disguised; a complex and practically faultless beer.
resin, alcohol, brown, cloudy, medium bitterness, light sweetness, full body, soft carbonation, toast,
UPDATED: JAN 20, 2017 Nice head, murky golden brown color. Medium bodied. Sherry sweetness. Tart tending toward bitter at the finish. Pleasant alcohol presence. This is an awesome beer.

Poured into a chalice. Dark brown color with a frothy finger of tan head.
Smells like alcohol, rye bread and chocolate.
Taste: alcohol, malt sweetness, nuts, more alcohol. Super delicious.
Soft texture, like a cloud. Low carbonation. Amazing.
It is no exaggeration to say this is one of the best beers in the world.

Bottle (330ml from Peckhams, Glasgow):
Lots of depth to it and plenty going on. Starting with some dark fruits, mainly raisin and plum along with a lot of spice and some burnt sugar. There is some alcohol to begin with and some chocolate with a bit of caramel too.

Dark brown colour that has maroon tinges in it and is topped with a bubbly tan head that starts about a thumbs width tall and halves in size where it stays for upwards of a couple of minutes.

Dark fruit and a lot of sweetness; there is dates, plum, raisins and sugar to name but a few. There is also maybe just a slight bit too strong an alcohol burn from it towards the end.

Medium bodied and very smooth indeed with medium to strong carbonation, a lot of spice and great depth with some alcohol but this is hidden well for the most part.

Almost perfect beer, if only it were ever so slightly weaker in the alcohol department it could be classed as unbeatable. It had it all, a great mix of flavours and with plenty going on and a huge alcohol content that was hidden a lot better than I would have imagined.

UPDATED: APR 26, 2013 33cl. Pours very dark brown with a good head. Has lots of sediment in it. Extremly complex flavors: chocolate, fruits, malt, a bit rosted and somewhat bitter. Perfect aftertaste. One of the best beers in the world

Colore marrone scuro impenetrabile, cappello di schiuma bianco opaco che si sgretola dopo non molto. Allolfatto intenso odore di caramello e malto. In bocca dolce, quasi stucchevole ma mai noiosa. A must have beer! Avoid too low temperatures. Classic quad! 11.3% Abv, will start giving you a buzz on the second bottle. Overall, my favorite quad style beer, better than the chimay blue

Wow very flavorful. Aroma is a sweet carmel little roastiness. Pours a dark redish milky dark brown. Lot of frothy foam with some lacing. Taste is very strong thick like milk taste is very earthy malty toasty raisin. Overall very good.
Great flavor with just enough sweetness. A little carmel and complex flavors while the alcohol stays in the background.

Bottled,Pours dark brown with a beige head.Aroma of raisins,dates,chocolate and roasted malt and licorice with hints of dark chocolate,brown sugar,spice,spruce,dried fruits,alcohol,stone-fruits and yeast..One of the best!
Bottle from Belgium in a Box; cant really add anymore to this, that hasnt already been said great complex beer really rewarding. Ive had two top ten RB beers this week.

UPDATED: SEP 15, 2012 drank this more when i began with beer drinking. yesterday i drank it again and i was like WAAW ive never remembered it this good? maybe it was a bit older? or maybe it just proves everything i always had a hard time believing in ( a persons taste does get way different ) anyway, this was nicely sweet, bitter, candy, sugar,... but al so rediculously good balanced ! and then theres this sweetish , candi-like aftertaste.. simply WAAW. it does deserve its high place i guess ! also a nice quadruppel colour, with fading foam wich never goes away completely. why havent i tasted these good things in it before? need to drink this more again :^p

UPDATED: JAN 27, 2013 Bottle at Huppel the Pub, Den Haag. Black pour with a frothy bubbly head that seemed to last forever. Amazingly creamy, almost dairy aroma. When fresh it almost smelled like Baileys! The smoothness carries over into the flavour which is probably explained by the relatively heavy carbonation.  A wonderful smooth balanced bitter and rich taste. The bitterness sits nicely on the palette too and the relatively high alcohol content does not  dominate this beer. Fully deserves its high rating.

Pours a dark, hazy, blackberry colour.  Head is effervescent, leaving a thin, uniform white ring around glass. Aroma is exactly like toasted raisin bread, with a bit of banana, apple, vanilla.  Maybe some cloves.  Not as sweet a taste as the aroma lets on.  Incredible balance of sweet, bitter and salty. Palate starts out with an oily coat for the tongue, follows through with a syrup feel, and finishes with a great alcohol warmth in the chest. Only light carbonation, quite fine.  This beer is pretty goddamn amazing.

My first time with this beer, thanks to Oz for supplying it. Smell is somewhat boozy but I also get a bunch of fruit notes as well. Nice pour with a really nice head. Dark berries, grapes, dark chocolate aroma. Very nice sipper, the alcohol does not overwhelm, just a hint of  burn going down, but the dark chocolate bitterness adds a nice touch at the end. A really great beer!

UPDATED: DEC 26, 2012 S: Very complex but the layers are easily perceived due to the excellent balance: tart, dry apple and grape up front - a bevy of dried dark fruits, raisins and figs - strong caramel malt character that brings an old ale to mind. I could sniff all up on this forever. A: Dark, dark, dark brown and when held up to the light it reveals a chocolate color. The head is fantastic - upon pour it is a mix of small and large bubbles fizzing away at each other, when it settles it leaves a film of creamy retention. When swirled, alc legs appear. There are pretty large pieces of sediment floating around and IÃ¢â¬â¢m ok with it. T: The darkness comes through by way of the dried fruits that have taken the prominent place away from the tart apple/grape first detected by the nose. It really does have an old ale feel, which is a big check-plus in my book. Alcohol is completely hidden and I wish it were more present - I would love the warming sensation added to this. The caramel character is much more molasses like - real dark and gooey. P: Pretty full bodied brew, nothing like an imperial stout, but the fullest Belgian IÃ¢â¬â¢ve had. Long lasting finish and the carbonation doesnÃ¢â¬â¢t get in the way of the experience. O: I havenÃ¢â¬â¢t had very many Ã¢â¬â¢hyped-upÃ¢â¬â¢ brews before, but this one met and overcame all expectations. The only reason IÃ¢â¬â¢m not giving it a perfect score is because I havenÃ¢â¬â¢t tried enough beers yet and I do not know what perfect is to me yet, but this is surely the closest IÃ¢â¬â¢ve come. Please pick up a bottle, IÃ¢â¬â¢m off to listen to Mahler 9.

Enjoyed via a bottle from Ottos in Shorewood, WI. Pours a dark brown/black with a medium tan head. It laces the inside of the glass. Smells of raisins, tobacco and oak with a slight effervescence. The taste is of chocolate and oak with a slight carbonation to it. Super smooth finish with little to no boozy taste.

UPDATED: OCT 31, 2012 Just awesome. Aroma of dark fruits, some bread, sugar, belgian yeast. The main pluss with this beer is the balance. Its just fantastic to have 11,3 percent alcohol and being not notable. The best beer Ive ever had!
Bottled. Pours cloudy brown with big light brown head. Smells nutty malty, peach and roasted malt. Tastes nutty malty, sweet fruity and abit buttery.

Bottle. Pours a murky, brown with no head to speak of, honestly looks kinda like ice tea. Nose is slightly fruity and boozy with some malt. Mouth is dense with sweetness, raisins, figs and malt, some bread at the end. My first sampling of a Rochefort. Very nice.

Bottle at home. 
Aroma; earth, leather, raisin. 
Very dark amber hazy color. 
Sweet taste, sugar, malt, spice, pepper , damn it is good!!
One of the best I have tasted.. :)

A beer like this needs to be compared to a fine port. Dark and ripened, plums, grades and even stone fruits; well round a breadiness as well as a creamy banana mouthfeel make me want to never drink #8 again.
mmmmm. i dont know Belgian beer really. This was beaten by Pannepot for me on the night but was truly smooth and luscious

Smells really fruity (apple, raisin, maybe a little banana) with some spice, caramel, a little alcohol.

Similar fruit flavor, with a lot of dark caramel and raisin-ish malt flavor, which finishes a little sweeter. Some spicy flavor, and some solvent alcohol -- not an unpleasant amount, though. Really nice... I am drinking it too fast ;)

Drank 12/26/11; Stamped "010616 08:06". Doesnt look like a date... Maybe just a batch number?

UPDATED: MAR 19, 2016 Time to rerate this. My palate is significantly more refined at this stage, and having tried Westvleteren XII, I feel its time to give this a fair shot. Originally 8 4 7 1 13. Aroma is figs, raisins, bubblegum, booze, sweet, caramel, toffee, complex and rich. Appearance is dark brown, light brown head, poured rich. Taste is figs, dark fruit, raisins, rich, a touch of booze, caramel, toffee, a lot like Westvleteren. Mouthfeel is medium body, crisp carbonation, rich fig aftertaste. Overall, Im glad I retried this one, its very tasty, although just slightly behind Westvleteren in goodness for the style.

Like a strong blue cheese, this beer always surprises me with its depth of character. Dark fruits on the nose with a hint of spice. In the mouth the plum and raisin notes domiate initially, but the flavour develops and matures like no other in to a deep and nutty oily sweetness. One of my favourites.

Pours a slightly muddy brown color with a mocha colored finger of fizzy foam that bubbles with aromas of dark fruit; prune, raisin, fig, cocoa... alot of the same on the palate with great complexity of flavors. Great mid palate sweetness touched with cola nut, a light bitterness and great mouthfeel !

Baste formação de espuma fina de com âmbar , coloração marrom escuro. Aroma, malte, caramelo, toffe. Sente-se uma leve doçura , corpo médio , e muita carbonatação

Bottle at ultime atome in brussels. Wonderful yeastprofile that blends with  light roast and some dark fruit. Smoth but dry and very drinkable for such a big beer. one of my favorite beers to enjoy winter time.

Bottle sample at a tasting in our place. Thanks beerandbeyond. Expiration date 29.11.11. Had this beer before in October 2011 and found similar basic traits. Pours cloudy brown with a bubbly light tan head. Wine, chocolate liquor aroma, sweet and heavy taste. Full body, sweet aftertaste. Old but I kinda had fun.
Pours dark brown with a medium off white head which disappears pretty quickly.  Aroma of chocolate and malt.  Complex flavours of chocolate, caramel, brown sugar, spice and malt.
(Bottle). Tart and sweet malt aroma with hints of raisins and orange. The taste is smooth and soft with elements of malt, figs, raisins and yeast. Tasty beer!
bottle 33cl @ home. huge head. licorice aroma, some Belgian yeast. dark chocolate, licorice in the flavor. wow

330 ml bottle from Premier Wine and Spirits (Halifax).  Pours a murky, slightly orange-ish dark brown with small tan head.  Aroma is brown sugar, toffee and dark fruit.  Flavour is sweet and rich with brown sugar, raisin, plum and cherry.  A little alcohol warmth in finish, but very subtle for the 11.3%.  Gentle carbonation; thick, silky mouthfeel.  Nice.

2007 bottle @ DHVL. I cant believe I hadnt rated this yet! Pours deep brown with a medium white head that recedes to discrete lacing. The nose is spicy raisin cake, hot blueberry syrup and freshly-baked brown bread. Spicy. The taste is raisin chocolate bread, toasted cocoa and a bit of boozy wood. Full, big body. Legs on the glass. Overall a great beer, though not exactly how I remember it.

33 cl bottle.
Dark color, good foam.
aromas of dried fruits, some malt.
Full body & high complexity.
Sweetness , some bitterness. Noticable alcohol, but pretty good balance.
Very enjoyable

From a 33 cl bottle into a Trappist goblet. Hazy dark pour with little head. Aromas of caramel and raisins.  Fine bubbles in the mouth. Perfect balance of toffee sweetness and bitter hops. A fabulous quad.

pours a deep hazy brown with amber highlights and a thin tan head that leaves some nice lacing.caramel, nuts, spices and lots of dark fruit and a subtle alcohol great the nose before exploding in the flavour to create one of the most smooth, delicious and complex beers ive ever had. the 11.3% ABV is hidden so well you wont even notice it until you feel a little tipsy after the 3rd sip. amongst the great trappist range this beer is probably the best.

Love the aromas of most of the Belgian ales and this is no exception. With a hint of spices alongside a fruity, almost mollasses-like aroma. The colour is the signature cloudy hue and the flavour delivers even more than the aroma promises. A true exponent of Belgian brewcraft and style and a beer worth grabbing anytime that you can. Best consumed very slowly at around room temperature.

Very nice dark colour with a small head that quickly dissipated. Tastes nice and sweet,leaving a warm alcohol feeling in the throat. Nicely carbonated. Aroma of dark fruits, bittersweet chocolate and dark caramel

11.2 oz bottle poured into a tulip.

A: Pours a very dark ruby red color with good clarity and little yeast floaties on the bottom of the glass. The head is initially a three finger light mocha color with huge bubbles and a bubbling carbonation show, ultimately settling into a one finger head with a nice creamy texture. Little lacing is left on the glass.

S: Very vibrant. Chocolate, raisins, currants, plums, cherries, green pear, cloves, and spices all intermingle with great complexity; every smell provides a subtly different aroma.

T: The first sip brings waves of darker dried fruits, leaving a fantastic chocolaty finish and aftertaste. The initial sips give way to more of a flavor very reminiscent of cherry pie filling. At various points afterward, I can also pick out light licorice, hints of grassy hops, fig newtons, chewing tobacco, brown sugar, spices, and other subtle hard-to-identify flavors. Stunning complexity with a fantastic lingering aftertaste. This is freakin heaven, plain and simple. The alcohol is as perfectly integrated as Ive ever seen in a beer, warming the body without being palpable on the flavor.

M: Amazingly smooth until the midtaste, where the yeasty astringency builds dryness on the tongue, giving it surprising drinkability. Alcohol lightly stings the tongue in conjunction with the carbonation. The dryness becomes a bit excessive at times, but otherwise it feels fantastic on the palate

O: Plain and simple, a triumph of brewing finesse. Faint niggles here and there cant even come close to ruining this beers immense glory. Magnificent.

330 ml bottle. Pours a dark brown with reddish hints and medium light tan head . Aromas of caramel, spices, and roasted malts. A bit more presence than the 8. Complex flavors of malts and spice, brown sugar, dark fruits and a little citrus. Definite alcohol edge not present in the 8.
Nice trappist beer. Much better than the numbers 6 and 8. Great body and aroma. Not great foam.

UPDATED: NOV 13, 2012 Bottle at home - 27/07/12.
Pours murky brown with a finger of off-white head that soon dissipates.
Nose is dark dried fruits - cherries, plums, prunes, raisens and sweet caramel.
Taste married aroma, rich, fruity and complex with candied sugar and a pinch of cocoa.
Medium bodied verging on full with a low level of carbonation that was just right.
Great tasting quad.
Original rating 8 - 4 - 8 - 5 - 17.
------- at the Rochefort 10 Mass Online Tasting, bottle at home (from the supermarket at Brussels Midi) - 13/11/12.
Room temperature having been removed from the beer cupboard an hour or so before drinking.
Pours opaque dark mahogony brown with a huge tan heaf that quickly subsides. Small bubbles and carbonation present on the surface. A small part of the original head remains as an off centre pond after 3 or 4 minutes.
Rich caramel on the nose, dark fruits, toffee, prunes, sweet plummy tones, light floral tones, dark sugars and a whiff of booze in the background.
Tastes of rich warming dark fruit tones. Dark toffee, sugars, booze is amazingly well balanced for 11.3% unlike any other beer ! A little nuttiness, sweetness is just right, not overbearing the dark fruit flavours are sweeter in the taste than on the nose, figs, dates, sweet plums. Goes up from 8 to 9.
The carbonation was a little too prickly to start and I was going to drop from a 5 to a 4, however after 10 minutes or so it had pretty much vanished. Soft and warming in the finish. Still a 5.
Overall I enjoyed this beer more on the 2nd rating. I think warming it and letting the carbonation die off helped. A great beer that costs relatively little in Belgium. The alcohol is sooooo well hidden, rich dark fruits, warming and a touch of booze - overall score goes from 17 to 18. Total 4.2 to 4.4. To the next one !
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text: Nice Quad flavor. Pleasing aroma.  Dark color with thin, light head. Overall great beer.

2011 bottle @ home. Dark brown appearance with a tan head that dissipates somewhat quickly. Dark chocolate, candy sugar, dark caramel, dark fruits, plum, raisin, Belgian yeasty aroma. Creamy, slightly thick mouth feel. Dark caramel-chocolate, dark candy sugar, raisin, dark plum flavor. Dark candy sugar, chocolate aftertaste. Booze is hidden super well. Some days this is my absolute favorite beer of all time.
2004 bottle @ De Heeren van Liedekercke. This has always been one of my all-time favorites, but to try an aged bottle was a different experience. Drinking an 04 version was full of plum, raisin, fig, and rich dark fruits. Theres light booze but it has tons of fruits and just delicious. Ive had Westvleteren 12 on more than a handful of occasions at this point and I have come to realize that Rochefort 10 is more complex than it and only lacks the rarity factor of Westy 12. For quite a while this was my top rated beer, but I downgraded it from a 5.0 to a 4.8 during an introspective period. Fuck it, Im putting this mofo back to a 5.0 aka my top beer (well, at least for now) based on my experience at De Heeren. Why havent I put a case of these away in the cellar every year?Sorry for the brevity! Ima gonna write a thesis on this beer this year!

muddy brown color, lots of sediment settles to the bottom, aroma of maple syrup, brown sugar, dark fruits, bread, yeast, flavors of maple syrup, brown sugar, dark fruits, prunes, cherries, dates, plums, toffee, coffee, licorice, bread, oak, booze, fully body, finishes slightly dry, possibly the most complex beer Ive ever had, very enjoyable

Smell of sweet dark fruits, syrupy coats the tongue, sweet strong taste that lasts into aftertaste. A bit of maple/brown sugar aftertaste. Decent head, minimal lacing. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle no. 160216-07:39.  Beautiful dark brown pour with a fluffy beige head. The aroma is powerful with dark malts, Belgian candied sugar, brown sugar, plums, prunes, bread, yeast, and a very subdued, almost invisible alcohol note considering how big it is. The body is bold and smooth.  The taste is sweet at first with an explosion bitterness evolving at the end.  It is marvelously balanced and something that is wonderful to sip. I gave the taste my first ever "10," because I believe this is the Quad that all other Quads aspire to be.
A bit low on aroma (I am very picky...) I did not feel the 11% alc in the taste which is a sign of a very well balanced beer. Deep inspiring color. Great beer! One of the best I had in my life!
The best beer i have drink ever! No other trappist beer not even close to this one!!!

Not my favorite beer by far.  Not a huge fan of the style and tried not to let that get in the way.  Have had other Quads that I do like better.  It was decent, but for the price I'd definitely go another way.

From notes. Bottle, pours a dark amber. Strong aroma of rum and raisins. Wonderful sweet caramel tones mix with tastes of raisins and licorice. Smooth body. Its not my favorite Trappist quad, but its still a lovely beer.

A - Hazy to the point of being Murky. Dark brown and a very cool yellow and brown when held up to light.

S - Molasses, brown sugar, oatmeal raisin cookies, yeast, alcohol, musty grapes, and chocolate malt balls (whoppers, Maltesers)

T - Dark fruit, candy sugar, anise, chocolate brandy, roasted caramel malt. Wonderful taste at the back end, dry, yeasty, dark bread with a hint of pepper and some alcohol to warm the soul. Very complex and wonderful from start to finish.

M&D - decent Carbonation that tickles the throat, smooth but lighter bodied than I expected. Even with its strength I could easily drink more than one and feel great about it.

Really, how much is there to say about a beer already rated by well over 3000 people? The bubblegum and licorice is what I liked most about this, its just a great beer and inspired me to read up on the Trappists while drinking. I slightly prefer the huit.

Trevlig och ganska bubblig trappist. Fina kola och belgiska kryddor. Ganska spritig med en touch av karamell och kola.

UPDATED: OCT 5, 2012 Nothing left to say.. Super aroma of darkness and complexiticy - Like an vine & tobacco store. Very tasty, but despite the volume not that thick or sweet. Absolute a great brew like other trappistes, but nothing surprising and unique in flavours - just very good and really well balanced.

An absolutely phenomenal beer... a distinctively amazing Belgian beer! Pours a black body with a thin yellowed white head, lovely strong bready quality to the aroma with fruity highlights. Tastes wonderfully thick bodied with a loaded mouth feel. Upfront taste is quite bitter yet fruity, leading on to a medium style bready bitterness, ebbing off to a soft and clean minor fruit and almost bubblegum like experience. This, simply, is an amazing beer and a must try! Cheers!

UPDATED: OCT 24, 2014 Pours dark brown, with a dense little head that does not seem to fade away at all - a perfect appearance. The aroma is diverse. Sweet caramel and syrupy maltiness combines with rich spiciness and dark fruitiness; notes of raisin, plum, licorice and even a hint of chocolate. This certainly does not lack nuances: every time I have this, something new seems to appear. Taste is really strong and potent; alcohol is masterfully hidden. Initial sweet maltiness slides into a long, rich and slightly bitter finish. Raisins and other dark fruits have the strongest presence in the taste but there is much variety. Hoppy notes give a little balance in the aftertaste but this is definitely a malts-driven ale with yeast adding depth. The palate is full bodied with a thick, smooth mouthfeel. A true classic that needs to be enjoyed slowly.

Pours a very dark amber-brown color with a small amount of tan head that lingers a bit.  Delicious aroma of plums, raisins, and brown sugar.  As it warms the aroma turns to lighter red fruit and toffee.  Taste is amazing.  Slight fruity sweetness and brown sugar up front and it finishes incredibly smooth with a nice warming alcohol effect.  Leaves a lingering toffee and even chocolate like taste in the finish too.  Great beer, I love how the beer seems to change throughout.  Everyone needs to try this at least once.

Pours very dark with a thick tan head that slowly fades into minimal lacing.  The aroma is lacking for such a hyped beer in my opinion. The taste however doesnt disappoint.  Its rich and complex while finishing pretty smooth with a hint of the potency left on the tongue.  Each sip is unique as its medium bodied and rather tasty.  While I wouldnt put it in the top 10 in the world, it is quite good and a must try for Belgium lovers!

Alcohol omnipresent, yeasty mouth, overall good, recommended to be the perfect companion to a meat dish in winter. Wine afthertaste

UPDATED: AUG 22, 2013 Wine-like aroma, mahogany brown with little head. Sweet taste with finish of grape and plum. All time favourite!

UPDATED: OCT 17, 2015 I had read about it, finally tried and I have to say it lived up to the hype. One of the best beers out there. Thanks for all the rates on here for rating this beer so high, it go me to try it and I am so thankful! One of the best.
Up there with the best beers i have had this is a fantastic belgian beer. Nice alcohol warmth and sour berry flavors. Highly enjoyable,

One of my faves, rated for the first time on RateBeer. definite five stars, the yardstick to be measured against for all other Belgians (and other beers too). Delicious and warming, a nice sipper, very relaxing. Love this!

Pours brown with tan head. Aroma of raisins and brown sugar. Taste is much like the smell. Very tasty beer overall. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
This was extremely great to try. I think I will have another one while I am sitting here.

Part of a blind taste with Westy, Achel, and St Bernardus.
Dark brown pour with little head retention. Smell is prune, date, raisin. Taste is ashy, not as complex, almost a bandaid flavor. Great mouthfeel but a bit of heat. Odd finish. 

As it warms, smell gets toffee/fruit/candy. Still has an odd finish, sharp and offensive up front. Ends up with a barleywine feel to it. 

This was the most like Westy, but I wouldnt say either are the best Belgium beer, and I wouldnt say it is close to the best beer I have had.

Pours a very dark, murky brown color. 3 finger tan head and lots of foam rise up. Head retention and lacing are extremely good, especially for such a high alcohol beer.

Smell is heavy on candied belgian rock sugar. Sweet molasses, burnt biscuit, and roasted malt are also present. Hops arent present but a distinct high abv beer booze aroma is. 

Taste is big on astringent alcohol, balanced by sweet candied sugar and syrupy burnt malts. A strong,smoky, dry scotch-like flavor which is uncommon for the style is dominant. 

Mouthfeel is medium bodied and well carbonated. Head contributed a smooth creaminess to beer. Finish was semi dry and astringent. 

Overall this beer was good but a bit too heavy on the booze side. Strong, malt forward flavors make this a complex beer, but I think it needs to age acouple more years before its at its prime drinking state.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle. Very sweet aroma of raisins, prunes and brown sugar.
Thicker body than the Rochefort 8, but still only about medium bodied.  Raisins and toffee and bitterness up front, licorice flavours too (thats probably why I dont enjoy it as much as most seem to).  The after taste is complex, seeming to alternate between sweetness and bitterness.  Hides the alcohol well, which is no mean feat given that it is 11.3%.  Very good beer, but I definitely prefer the 8.
