En bref, je lai dit : "hors norme", "hors classement", "hors catégorie".

11.2 oz bottle. Nice, big foamy 2-finger khaki head. Reddish color, totally opaque and dark brown-looking with all the particles and sediment in the body. Pretty neat-looking, actually. Lighter, smooth carbonation. Dry texture. Very nice light sweet taste (not at all in a sugary or syrupy sort of way). Complex aroma... Dark fruit, hint of molasses, surprisingly little alcohol taste. Good sipper.
wonderful flavor, very smooth and definitely taste a rich raisin taste. I was glad to have found it!

Mouthgasmic! High medium head with a fruity yet bitter aroma. Medium opaque brown. Flavor is of malty and nutty with sweet plum undertones. Not hoppy at all! Finishes just a touch dry with a bit of a tangy zip from the high alcohol content. Almost like a mild oakey scotch. Wish i had more!

2010 bottle from my basement. not sure where I got it. Pours a cloudy dark mahogoney color, nose is dried plums, dates, and figs. first sip is sweet malty flavors of a great quad, vinous chocolate notes. finish is smooth with velvety mouth feel. great beer.

33cl Bottle, been with me for a while, best before 15th Nov 2011. Poured into a Westmalle chalice on 4th June 2011.

Lovely dark ruby red body, a very thin cream coloured head sat on top, it became a wispy half covering fairly quickly becoming almost just a collar in places.

The smell is malty, as is the main flavour in the first sip. As the beer warmed a chocolate touch came into the taste, sharp and dark, some coffee notes as well. The alcohol sits just below the surface and pops up towards the end of the mouthfeel, just to remind you it carries a punch if you try and drink it too fast or without due reverence.

I can see why this beer is scored so highly, very impressive on all accounts.
In my honest opinion, the best trappist beer out there.  Pours dark, taste complex and rich, smells phenomenal.  Very very good.
Sweet fruity aroma.  Deep raisin and molasses flavors.  Full body with a good head.  Alcohol and yeasty finish.  An amazing beer thats so complex - - and 11.3% to boot.

Pours a deep dark red, aroma of resiny alcohol. taste is of fruits, dried fruits, raisins, bananas and some cherry, there is some alcohol kick but it happens thereafter and you dont notice it as being  over 11%. Really nice

A - dried fruit and caramel
A - dark with frothy head
T - sweet and alcohol
P - full and soft
O - good, but not great

Wonderful everything. It's no wonder this is so highly rated. Don't hesitate to try it. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle. Rich brown with lighter head. Candi, caramel, some molasses, dark fruits (plum, prunes, raisins), bread. Masterfully crafted. Body is medium carbonation, maybe a little light.

Pours a deep plum purple color with aroma of plums and sweet raisins.  Taste is a mix of high alcohol and sugar.  Almost like when you put too much sugar in a cup of coffee but add 11% alcohol to it.  A very complex beer that changed as I drank it.  With such a high alcohol content, I expected the beer to be hard to swallow but it was surprisingly smooth.
UPDATED: JUL 20, 2012 Very dark brown beer with a light brown foamy head. There is a multitude of fruit scents. Full flavour with a distinct presence of alcohol.

bouteille 33cl dans un verre à cet effet
de couleur brune rougeâtre avec un petit collet blanc assez persistant qui laisse une dentelle sur le verre
au nez elle dégage des arômes de malt, dalcool de caramel et de fruits rouges
gout sans surprise qui sapparente au nez : cassonade, malt caramel, alcool, fruits rouges, raisin,  figues et levures elle est très bien équilibrée
corps medium avec une carbonation selon moi un peu trop intense, personnelement je préfère de plus petites bulles pour ce type de bière mais cest sont seul (et pas très grave dans ce cas)
excellente bière

Bottle.  Pours brown, with a thick head and a fair amount of yeast sediment.  Rich aroma, mostly of caramel, and a touch of yeast.  Very complex flavor - brown sugar, caramel, dark fruits, raisin, banana, alcohol, and some yeast on the finish.  Maybe its just this bottle, but a little bit overcarbonated, which detracts from the mouthfeel.  Still, a first-rate Trappist ale.

Pours a dark cloudy brown with two finger tan head. Good retention. Smells like dark exotic fruits, molasses, raisins and a hint of vanilla. Taste like fig, spices, toasted brioche and a little wood and earth. Med-full body. Med-low carbonation. Silky texture. Sweet, spicy and warm after taste. Really good stuff!

Bottle. Drank fresh. A heavyweight of Belgians for sure. The scent was a complex mix of molasses, brown sugar, dough, and yeast with some grape-like acidity to finish. The pour was a dark brown similar to the color of a coconut shell with a frothy light tan head and I spotted some floaties in there. The medium bodied, crisp finishing palate also had a very fizzy mouthfeel, and the taste was boozy hot! Definitely want to age this one for a while. Dont get me wrong, I loved the taste, lots of dough and dark fruit, raisin, plum, but also a hot finish.
I think the perfect beer! Nothing wrong with this beer. The absolute pleasure!

Meraviglia. Un bel color mogano scuro con una bellissima schiuma marrone sporco. Laroma si sente appena viene stappata la bottiglia, e invia al cervello immediati messaggi: " bevimi, bevimi". Aroma, che risulta caramellato, liquoroso con sentori di uva passa e una venatura di cioccolato. Gusto complessissimo, pieno e che rapisce completamente la lingua in un vortice vellutato di note caramellate, di prugne, spezie e un casino di altre cose che ora mi scoccio di scrivere. Resta comunque il fatto che se la vedete compratene 2 bottiglie: una la conservate (se ci riuscite) a farla maturare e laltra la bevete, dopo una lunga giornata lavorativa o dopo un esame, lasciandovi trasportare dal suo gusto stupendo. Una delle birre più buone esistenti sulla facciaccia della Terra. Viva i Trappisti!!!
The aroma is amazing. Strong rounded taste, everything is balanced perfectly. A pleasure to go to my favourites restaurant for this beer.

330 ml bottle into chalice, best by 7/27/2016.  Pours very murky dark brown color with a nice 1 finger dense khaki head with good retention that reduces to a thin cap that lingers.  Spotty lacing on the glass, with a decent amount of carbonation streaming up.  Aromas of big plum, raisin, caramel, banana, molasses, clove, pepper, biscuit, roasted malt, light chocolate, and yeast spices.  Awesome aromas with great complexity.  Taste of big molasses, caramel, plum, raisin, prune, pepper, clove, banana, candi sugar, and yeast spices.  Lingering notes of dark fruit, banana, molasses, candi sugar, and yeast spices on the finish for a while.  Fantastic balance of sweetness and spiciness; with no cloying at all.  Medium carbonation and fairly full bodied; with a very creamy and slightly slick mouthfeel.  Incredibly lush and smooth mouthfeel as well.  This drinks way too smoothly for 11.3%, but is still definitely a sipper.  Alcohol is practically invisible, with pretty much no warming noticed.  Overall this is a beautiful Quadrupel.  Big complexity, smoothness, and flavor balance.  Amazing.

Deep brown color and some sweet distance taste. taste stays nice long and thus good aftertaste.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Pours a very dark brown color. Smell is of dark fruits and alcohol. Taste is alcohol up front, dark fruits, spices. Overall not bad, but does not live up to the hype imo.

UPDATED: OCT 7, 2012 Bottle 330 ml [2011]. Appearance: Pours dark brown with a small off-white head. Aroma: Strong notes of dark fruits (really nice!), candy sugar, alcohol. Taste: Dark fruits, warming alcohol (but alcohol is well hidden), caramel. Overall: Very complex beer and one of the most well balanced beer ever tasted.

Aroma: tons of dark fruits - dates, figs, plums, raisins, dark sugars, caramel, toffee, a hint of alcohol, near perfection.  Pours a dark brown with reddish hues, off-white head persists for a while then dissipates to a ring and leaves spotty lacing.  Flavor starts out with more dark fruit - raisins, currants, figs, then dark sugars and syrup start to join in.  Toffee, dark caramel, hints of roast malts, lightly chocolaty.  Alcohol is noticeable, but for being 11.3%, is generally very well hidden.  Body is medium-full, carbonation is fairly lively, smooth on the palate.  Easily one of the best beers out there, and luckily available pretty much everywhere.
What more can I say that hasnt already been said.  Amazing beer!  Cant wait to grab another bottle.  Will definitely be added to the rotation.

Lite gjærlag i flasketuten. Mørke brun, med litt rødskjær. 3 cm skum som la seg ganske kjapt. Dufter av tørket frukt, rosin? Veldig behagelig og balansert duft.  Første som slår meg med ølen er kullsyren, den er det mye i. Behagelig smak av tørkede frukter, litt bitter ettersmak. God munnfølelse, ikke for heftig og fin balanse med kullsyre og fylde. Absolutt ett godt øl

Haaa Yeah !
Bind tasting with Westvleteren / St Bernardus Abt12 / Rochefort 10.
Ranking: #1 West, #2 Rochefort, #3 Abt12.
West is more creamy, fine, spicy, complex and rich than Rochefort.
But Rochefort is not so far from West: maybe a bit more intense, powerful, alcoholic than West, with a dominance of vinous flavours, candied fruits...
Abt12 is too yeasty, not subtle enough to compete against the two other quads.
Rochefort is always available, at EUR 4/bottle. West is sold at EUR 11 and is available when the third Moon of Armaggeddon is eclipsed by the ass of a dark troll. Shit Mate, if youre not a Monk from the place you can only register yourself on a waiting list .... and wait.
So the Quality/Price/Availability ratio ranks Rochefort10 #1: THE BEST BELGIAN STYLE BEER REGULARLY AVAILABLE ON EARTH
A wonderful beer.   Well balanced and perfect.  Until I got my hands on a Westvleteren this was my favorite beer of all time.

So glad this beer is so readily available these days. I remember 5-8 years ago how much more of a difficult find this was. Bought 3 cases at Total Wine the other day. The only quad that comes close to the Westy 12. Love all the unfiltered yeast on the bottom of the bottle...Delicious!

To date, the best Quad and beer Ive ever had. I love the BCS but its such a different style i say this both my favorite beer. Maybe the westvleteren12 will beat it when i go to Belgium but not today. Right now this is the best beer in the world! The complexity is unreal!
Stunning beer - beautiful fruit laden aroma that follows through into the flavour. Almost flawless

Bottle 33cl. A dark nut brown colour with medium high beige head. An aroma of malt, raisin, alcohol and caramel. The taste is medium sweet. A full body, oily and creamy texture, flat carbonation and a long duration. A well balanced beer and a really nice mouth feel.

Pours a bit darker than its Belgian cousins of the same genre - dark burgundy/brown with some hazy clarity.  A massive tan head, maybe three fingers that take a good while to subside.  Nose is big, booze-laden dark fruits with toasted grains, caramel, consistent yeast presence.  Molasses maybe?  Tastes a bit sweeter than Id expected - plum, candied sugars, balanced malts.  This is the taste I imagine when I think Trappist quad.  Its not overwhelming at all to the palate.  No discernible booze burn, just a slick and sweet coating that doesnt completely touch the taste buds.  There is a reason that this has become a staple in the American craft beer scene.
Bottle pours Dark brown with a tan head.  Aroma is of caramel malt and fruit.  Taste is Malt with the sweet fruit and a bit of hops.

Bottle. Cloudy appearance with lots of residue. Little foam that disappeared quickly. Aroma of fruits, plums, spices, hops. Taste is on the sweet side, very complex, lots of different fruits and spices, yeast, chocolate, hints of malt and alcohol. Very nice alcohol warmth in the aftertaste. Excellent beer!

Bottle 330ml.
Pours very dark brown, with some beige head. Aroma is of malts, dark fruits, caramel, alchool. Very complex, as is the taste: plums, dark fruits, caramel, warming alchool. Very well balanced. A great beer.

As good as it gets. Opaque mahogany. Fruity aromatics along with fresh herbs. Full bodied, and in perfect balance. It enters with rich mocha dusted cherry flavors and walks the line between sweet and savory perfectly. Endless mushroom/earthy finish.

Finally!  Deep mahogany edging towards black.  Smells like baskets of dried dark fruit.  Sweet across the tongue, more burnt fruit.  Smooth warming finish, alcohol is very well hidden.  A truly fine beer.

UPDATED: FEB 11, 2013 Bottle, 33cl.
Fruity nose, some caramel hints, nuts.
Brown with tan head, looking attractive.
Huge taste, some roasted, caramelised fruits. You dont taste the 11.3 % alcohol, brownie.

Dark brown - ruby colour with a small light brown head. Nice strong fruity aroma of figs, grape, cherry, some caramel. First sip is kinda neutral, aftertaste goes on moderate bitter and lasts long. Very smooth, almost creamy structure. I expected a big present of alcohol, but it is hidden very well. OK, it is a bit felt thrue the warmth, but thats it. One of the best beers Ive ever tried.

Bottle. Chestnut brown with a tan head. Extremely inviting fruit malt nose. Festive candy fruit on the taste. Brilliant flavour. Invigorates the palate with its complexity. Sweet clean finish. A real pleasure.

A great beer! Great Appearence and great taste. Hints of fruit and a great head. Almost like heaven! It is a devils beer because the alcohol is so well hidden. caramel, raisins and chocolate. Nice bitter.

Bottle. Pours mostly clear brown with medium, fizzy off-white head; good retention and spare lacing. Aroma is Belgian yeast, biscuit and caramel malt, figs, earthy hops, and spice. Flavor is sweet malt forward, light hops, and average fruit esters; yeast and booze taste throughout; dry finish. Medium body and carbonation with high warmth.

I finally had a bottle of this when my friend brought it over to commemorate our first homebrewing session. After the disappointment of 6 I was relieved that this was delightful. Delicious notes of plum, fig, prunes, and cinnamon with the right warmth in the finish. Slightly thin body yet still velvety. Very nice!

Delicious. The aroma is caramel, raisins, and maybe a touch of cinnamon. The beer is deep brown with a fading cream head. The taste is sweet, caramel, malt, dark fruit like raisins, cinnamon, and alcohol the. Body is fairly thick with a velvety smoothness and a warming alcohol sensation.

Bottled. Darkest of the 6,8, 10 collection. Has a taste of plum and raisin inmpressive taste. Very nice finish. It tasted best when former Judo student Ronda Rousey wins the Strike Force Belt with an arm bar.
Great aroma and color. Strong taste and great finish. By far the best beer I have tasted. Highly recommend!!

The big brother of the trio and for good reason. Dark brown color in the glass with a big head. The aroma has caramel, figs and plums. The taste is big with more fruits and a richness that could come from the roasted malts. The alcohol is hidden well considering the amount. I would like to sample this one a few more times.

Apparently Ive never rated this before, though Ive had it a few times.  Bottle, this one is at least 2 years old.  Pours an opaque gradient brown/dark brown.  Tastes definitely of raisins and plums, dark fruits, spiciness.  Really just an exceptional beer, one of the best in the world.

Pours dark brown with a 1-inch creamy head.  Smell is fresh with a dark fruit note.  The taste is also dark fruit, with the alcohol coming through at the end.  An excellent and sophisticated beer.  I would highly recommend it.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

A - pours dark cola brown with 2 finger light tan head that lasts. S - nice complex aromas. Dark dried fruits, dried bananas plums, caramel sugars, floral hops. Hints of smoke, bourbon barrel aged. M - nice strong bodied. Moderate carb. Complex palate. Amazingly long lasting flavor. a little sticky mf, lightly syrupy T - dark dried fruits, Carmamelized sugar on the nose. Oaky notes, caramel, plums on the palate. Hints of bourbon, smoke, Belgian yeasts. Long lingering malty caramel oaky, dark fruits and plums. O - very good Belgian ale, complex and long lasting complex and subtle. Not as great as I expected 7/7+
Simply the best beer I have ever tasted. Its pleasent rich flavour is always a treat.
Its really good, but still prefer the nº 8. Its a bit too intense in flavour for what I expect in a beer like this, and Its possible to notice the alcohol. Quite dark, not bitter.

Bottle from Sicilianos in Grand Rapids, MI.  Pours thick, cloudy, and brown.  Some sediment in the bottle.  Aroma is delicious Belgian ale with some dark fruits.  Taste is full of subtle notes; sweet, spicy, and overall goodness, with a dry finish.  No real hint of that 11.3% ABV; very impressive.  These monks know what theyre doing.

Bottle shared by kevinsenn. Dark nut brown with a moderate head. Smells Belgian - mild and nice with a bit of (not unpleasant) vegetable rot. Sweet and very full-bodied, coats your tongue with a thick sugary oiliness. Again, in a good way. How can I describe this... Its quite delicious. Not boozy at all, despite the alcoholic strength. Lovely stuff.

UPDATED: MAY 16, 2012 For this brew I would like to repeat the review I wrote for the Trappistes 8...only the taste is a bit more impressive.  At 11% abv, I would expect a bigger alcohol taste...but the balance is really impressive.
Was not disapointed in this World class trappist ale. A little pricey was the only drawback ( $14 a bottle at WOB in Tampa). Otherwise its all GOOD!

pours very dark brown with a full tan head that lingers .aroma is  dark fruits  burnt sugars  malts  , taste starts sweet  with caramels and dark fruits then a nice acidic tartness creeps in followed by  a slight bitterness providing a lingering finish that prevents the rich start from becoming overpowering and cloying  . Very neatly done . Medium to full carbonation initially that settles down to provide a full bodied perfect mouthfeel .Deals with the 11.3% abv very well  - just a nice warmth coming through as a swansong . A truly first class beer  .

UPDATED: APR 26, 2012 Tasted 2006 vintage bottle into tulip, thanks gregwilsonstl! Poured a dark reddish-brown color with a thin layer of tan foam, somewhat persistent with excellent Belgian lace. Aromas of pretty much every type of caramelized sugar youve ever experienced, some perfumey hops and alcohol, plum sauce, sticky toffee pudding, bourbon-soaked fruitcake. Rich malty sweet flavor, tart noble hops balance, raisins, brown bread, warming but otherwise well-concealed alcohol. Heavy body, sticky and syrupy mouthfeel. Low carbonation, but some nice spritziness from the bottle fermentation. Long-lasting sweet, fruity and tart aftertaste. A phenomenal beer.

I know this beer is supposed to be awesome and all but I just couldnt get into it.  Love the background behind it, just felt like once I drank it I was glad I had tried it but will probably not be seeking it out anytime soon.  I agree with the previous statement that it almost drinks like a whiskey.
UPDATED: MAR 31, 2014 Transfering data from personal beer file. I drank this beer a long time ago. Ill update this rating if I have the chance to drink it again.
Drank out of a 6 or so year old bottle.  Very thick and caramelly.  Very hard for me to drink and I love dark and heavy beer.  This borders on tasting like a whiskey.

Bottle at North Bar, Leeds. Oh sweet feckin WOW. Pours a deep brown, purple Ribena tinges, off  white head that lingers. Aroma is astounding - raisin biscuits, booze, dark fruits, touches of caramel and shortbread. Taste is equally joyous - raisin, a tart fruitiness, dark fruits/raisins, burnt sugar and caramel, but with a bit of a bitter aftertaste that, with the tart flavour, balances the sweet favours and stops it becoming cloying. SO RICH. Long, sticky-ish aftertaste, medium-full bodied. Slight overcarbonation is the only downside I can spot with this one, and even that goes away with time. Nice alcohol burn reminds you of just how formidable this is. This is a truly brilliant beer, one of my absolute favourites. Believe the hype.

Currently drinking while typing. Upon pouring you will notice great aromas appearing from the glass, primarily scents of plum, raisin, Belgian yeast, sweet Danish bread, brown sugars, sweet malts and caramels. It doesnt create much of a head at all, of what it does it is an initial soapy bubbly texture which is of a tan brown colour. It soon dissipated into a subtle skimming of fine bubbles that sits on top of a deep chocolate brown murky vessel. Wonderful flavours of soft sweet brown sugars, plum, raisin, breads, Belgian yeasts, well masked booze, cereals, toasts, subtle hops, winter berries and a lasting fresh caramel and cereal malt flavour in the finish. Great full feel in the mouth with incredible smoothness and a subtle carbonation which is absolutely perfect for this beer. In summary this is absolutely brilliant despite the fact this beer never really produces a great head, the flavours and aromas are very complex combined with a smooth and good feel. Although it isnt the same as a Westvleteren 12 you cannot argue with the more reasonable price tag and availability. Highly recommended!

Bottle poured into snifter.  Alluring dark amber/brown in color, barely translucent.  Ample inch-wide soapy head on top, slightly tannish.  Wonderful aroma.  Notes of pepper, fig, oaky vanilla are balanced by a nice subtle touch of Belgian yeast and spice.  Very boozey on the nose.  Complex yet not overpowering at all.  Very soft and sticky on the palate, low carbonation.  Taste mirrors the aroma very closely.  Bold and complex yet not a kick in the mouth.  More dark fruits, raisin, yeast/spice,  and great warming effect from the alcohol, yet not overly boozey tasting.  High ABV hidden quite well.  A creamy, slightly sweet finish ends the journey.  A true gem of tasty complexity!

From notes.  First reviewed 5/24/2009.  Poured from a 11.2 oz bottle into a tulip.

Quite a strong, dignified pour. A strong brown sugar brown with just a hint of translucence around the edges of the glass. The head does not form right away, but after a patient and proper pour, a healthy foam arrives. Gentle lace clings to the glass.

Strong malt and yeast character in the nose, somewhat caramelly but more vanilla and spice flavors. The alcohol can be subtly noted.

Taste: An extremely complex malt flavor greets the palate. Each sip, particularly with changes in temperature, reveal something new. Figs, vanilla, and caramel are the most obvious flavors, but I have gotten hints of nutmeg and raisins. The alcohol is well-hidden, but I get a little in the middle of the sip. I am left with a slightly tart and dry finish. 

A smooth, balanced feel. Creamy and carbonated at once, and it has a little bit of an oily texture.

Considering the alcohol content, definitely a little bit too drinkable. I did not even think about it being 11.3% until I had breezed my way through my first.  Overall a great beer. Tough to go wrong with a Trappist.

Definitely one of the best Belgians there is. Rich, nice body and strong head, creamy, malty, with aromas of plum, raisins, a bit of alcohol and even a bit of camembert lurking somewhere. A beautiful creation!

Bottle from Halftime. Going to compare this again in a year to compare how it ages.

dark amber capped by a small silky head that only reduces slightly. Nose is malt, sugar, and yeast. Taste is burnt sugar upfront, slight biscuit, hint of dark fruit. Alchohol rears its head as this critter warms. Silky creamy mouthfeel, medium bodied.

UPDATED: FEB 17, 2015 My 100th rating! 33 cl. bottle @ home. Pours dark brown with a beige head. Despite its impressive appearance the aroma is light footed floral and fruity with some caramel and dark fruits. The taste is multi layered and complex, with lots of dark fruits, caramel and yeast. One of the great beers of the world.

Beautiful dark toffee colour. Its not too sweet, and the flavours are delicate - but there are many of them. Very rich and tasty. A nice mild bitterness seems to wash over the mouth each time. I find the weakest part of this beer is the overwhelming foam that develops on each sip.  Impressed me, though.

UPDATED: JUN 16, 2013 aroma: caramel, chocolate, coffee, toast, alcohol
apparenza: brown, cloudy, frothy, 
gusto: medium sweetness
palato: full body, creamy, average carbonation, long finish, 
alta scuola trappista,seconda solo alla westvleteren ma non per questo merita di essere messa in secondo piano. laroma è fantastico,molto deciso e allo stesso tempo delicato,sicuramente estremamente complesso,classico di questo stile di birra:fruttato,maltato,alcolico.Il gusto è estremamente complesso e lascia la voglia di berne molte altre per comprenderlo appieno. luppolo e malto sono ben bilanciati,col malto allinizio e il finale amaro..dolce,carbonazione piacevole..rispetto alla 8 la trovo più alcolica sicuramente,ma anche più decisa,sia nellolfatto che nel gusto dolce

15/06/2013 lo riconfermo..birra da spettacolo puro..forse la rochefort 8 mi piace di più ma la linea di confine non è enorme! aroma alcolico,caffè,lieviti,malti tostati,classico trappista..scura con schiuma marroncina persistente..gusto davvero speciale e complesso col luppolo praticamente assente,assolutamente caratterizzata da componente maltata..scalda il palato ed è un orgasmo di birra!
Fantastic brew.Dark brown with tan head.  Bread, dark fruit, banana, sugary.  Definitely a beer everyone should try.

Wow!  If beer gets any better than this I dont want to know about it!  Pours a beautiful red brown with a creamy tan haead.  The scent is all dark fruit like plums, raisins, figs and yeasty bread.  The taste follows the scent with the addition of a cola taste.  The beer just explodes in the mouth with the taste just dancing on the tongue.  Overall this brews body belies the fact that it is a heavyweight.  Perfect balance, mouthfeel and taste!  Near lkperfect for me.

330 ml bottle. Pours a dark, ruby-reddish brown with a persistent beige head. Tastes sweet, like dried fruits, dates, caramel and a hint of banana. Alcohol is present on the finish. Body is average, slightly heavy carbonation. Even though it had its flaws, I just couldnt help but give it a high grade, because it was so good...
The best beer Ive ever tried. Quadrupel without any lacks. Great appearance, full body, excellent aroma and long taste.
UPDATED: DEC 25, 2014 Een klassieker wat mij betreft, ik drink m niet voor niets al meer dan 25 jaar. Donker, veel geur en smaak, behoorlijk zoet., kruidig. Mocht van mij wat dikker  aanvoelen.
Bottle. Pours dark witj tan head.  Dark fruit and caramel.aromas.  Very intense fruit and dark sugar flavors..amazing

The best beer in the world deserves an incredible rating. And this beer is your mothers milk in a bottle. This is fermented sex and crack mixed together with some candi sugar. When I was in Bruges I ordered this beer immediately after the westvleteren 12 for comparison, and I can confidently say that this beer (rochefort 10) is noticeably better. Mostly because this beer has more flavour than any other available on the market. The aroma is decadent chocolate with caramelized Christmas fruits. The taste is pure fornication immersed in brown sugar and plum. I was always taught that if you dont have anything nice to say, dont say anything at all. From now on Ill only ever talk about rochefort 10. Its a safe bet, because no-one could have anything bad to say about this beer.
Dark colour. Complex beer, sweet, raisins, dark fruits and some alcohol. A brilliant beer.

Brown sugar aroma, dark grapes, plums. Tawny like a port., and just a little sour. Cola, vanilla, cinnamon spice, cherrywood, maple. Unbelievably complex. 

Appearance is cola: caramel-brown (darkly so). Long lasting finger of head.

Flavor is plums, sour raisins, and again, tawny port. Toasted mocha, wood, tar and charcoal. Lots of horseblanket yeast too, fittingly so.

Feels like a port wine, but chalkier. Wow: what a remarkable beer. Absolutely world class. Im not breaking any news here, but this is one of the best beers Ive ever had.
Bottle. Sweet grapes, earthy, figs, and wood.

Bottle. Chestnut brown with a tan head. Extremely inviting fruit malt nose. Festive candy fruit on the taste. Brilliant flavour. Plum n awe that. Invigorates the palate with its complexity. Sweet clean finish. A real pleasure.

330 ml bottle pours a nice dark mahogany with a small off white head. Smell is of dark fruits, alcohol, and yeast. Huge complexity in the flavor. Very sweet but there is a tinge of bitterness at the end to keep I in check. Theres also a warming sensation from the high alcohol content which I enjoyed. The palate is silky smooth with perfect carbonation. Cant believe Ive waited so long to try this. Phenomenal.

Caramel, raisin, fruity ,alcohol, honey, herbs. Starts very fruity sweet goes bit sour with hints of wood full body taste, finish taste of herbs light bitter sweet at the end. Stays fresh, I prefer a stronger finish.

Pours dark brown almost black with a large off white head. Nose is over ripe dark fruits. Raisins, plums and fresh baked pastries taste is sweet mostly but a good amount of bitter brings it down a notch. Mouthfeel is creamy and soft. Aftertaste is huge and makes this a slow sipper. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
One of Belgiums bests. This beer is near perfect. A bit fizzy and little boozy for my taste but wow what a treat.

Thanks to Mike from Long Room for recommending this beer to me.  It was on a list of must tries, I just didnt realize it.   I was in a dim lit bar, but it looked black and almost same thickness as an imperial stout.  Not much head or lacing with my pour.  Lots and lots of dark fruity aroma, some pepper, some great effervescence, and a tiny bit of bittersweet chocolate.  Taste is very complex, but is overall sweet and spicy with a bit of burn at the end from the high alcohol content.  Probably the best Belgian beer I have had to date.
This is the best Belgian beer Ive had since being here (I am working in the Netherlands for 6 mos).  It has a strong creamy taste at first, alcholic, but not too strong.  A great beer!

Very dark but nicely translucent beer; brownish black colour. Weak head and lots of yeast (one of the few beers I dont pour completely). 
Warm twangy smell, sweetish sour-wood, woodiness, some caramel, milk chocolate. Maybe even some honey in there. Black currants, raisins and an alcoholic glow and a thick spicy haze.
The palate is perfectly balanced bitterness, sweetness and wateriness, with a nice bitter-sour finish which evolves into nuts and herbs. Taste is sweet warmth of dark things; caramel, chocolate, subtle coffee and overripe forest fruits. All with a solid alcohol base. A little too alcoholic for my taste.

Dark mahogany with big, fizzy, tan head, which dissipates quickly / Hot, mild, sweet, cooked dark fruit nose / Full body, sweet and malty, with hot and relatively weak finish / Mild and dull flavors of cooked dates and figs, caramel, and chocolate / Terribly overrated.  My bottle dated 09/2011, if I read the nomenclature correctly.  Should try again from another source.
No necessita cap mena de presentació. Un clàssic dins de les cerveses trapistes.

Pours a very dark reddish color.  Leaves a nice fluffy head that dies slowly.  Aroma is caramel malt and dark fruit.  It has a bit of a sour quality to it.  Lightly sour taste with a touch of sweetness too.  Warming alcohol with a lingering malty flavor.  A very full bodied, big beer.  Theres a lot going on here, Ill have to try again and update.

Bottle 330ml. January 26th, 2012.

Dark brown color with nice tan head, nut and brown sugar aromas, slightly bitter finish with sugary aftertaste. A beer everyone need to taste !

Rating # 36

UPDATED: MAY 2, 2012 probably have had 50 bottles of this in my lifetime.so i guess im rating number 51 or so.poured this one in my founders snifter.pours almost opaque cloudy burgundy with a thin white head.head dissapates quickly.the aromas of yeast,brown sugar,malt,raisins,banana and anise.flavor is sweet and matches aroma.full bodied with light carbonation and a slick mouthfeel with a slightly sweet and bitter finish.this is and continues to be my favorite trappist.aroma and flavors are so complex.for any beer drinker this is something you must try,and for me its over and over again

I have been meaning to get around to this beer for a very long time and finally got off my duff and bought a bottle. I will not wait so long before having it again. +++ Sampled from an 11.2 oz brown bottle this beer poured a murky dark brown color with a medium sized foamy tan head that left a touch of lacing. The aroma was strong toasted caramel with notes of tea, cherry, butterscotch and toffee and a touch of alcohol showing through. The flavor was thick and full toffee and toasted caramel with notes of butterscotch, honey, cognac, cherry, raisin, tobacco, faint dry herbs and a touch of earthiness. Long toffee and raisin finish. Thick and full bodied. The alcohol was fairly well hidden and the flavor was exceptionally complex. Marvelous.

Pours a dark amber. Little to no head. Aromas of dark fruits, vinegar and cherries. Upfront flavor of cherries/plum/raisins and honey. Finishes with a slight alcohol burn. Dark fruits all around. Mouthfeel is pretty delicious. The flavor of the beer just lingers in your mouth. Overall a great beer.
coffee, herbs, basement aromas, smoke, woody, black, sparkling, brown foam, light sweetness, very bitter, heavily sour, flat, thick feel, full body, long finish,

Pours almost black , deep dark brown. Head is dark beige creamy. Aroma  citrusy,  berries, little caramel, hazel nuts, roasty malts. Palate licorice, full bodied thick oily texture. Carbonation  smooth, disctinct berry fruits. Well developed complexity. Aftertaste warming alcohol and roasted malt finishing in a short bitter dryness. Great stuff.

11.5 oz. from Greenwood Market. Big-bodied and full-flavored beer. Smells sweet like like a scotch but doesnt taste cloying. I find it hard to believe this is over 11% ABV as I can barely taste the alcohol. God love the monks.

Poured from a bottle into a Darkness snifter.

A.  Pours a deep deep brown, rich two finger head in an off white color, settles to a 1 finger head and finally rests many minutes later at a 2mm ring.  Mild lacing.

S.  Smells of sweet fruit, bready yeast, doughy 

T.  Tastes very bready, with a slight flavor of coca, figs and slight fruit.

M.  Medium-thick body, high carbonation, thick and chewy, with a soft dry finish

O.  A great beer, very full flavored and filling!  This is a wonderful beer that hides its 10% very well.  Sweet and bready makes for a nice fair and even flavor.  Its great to have such a nice Belgian that is so readily available around the country.  If you see this on the shelf, stop ignoring it and give it a try.  Well worth the $6.00!
medium sweetness, raisin, roasty, caramel, brown, full body, have to say very good, but want stunned
Its like en explosion of nuts, caramel, sweet chocolate and a bit alcohol in your mouth!

Bottle. Pours dark opaque black, huge light brown head. Bananas raisins walnuts, yeast. Medium bodied, banana, brown sugar, tobacco, a little alcohol. Exremely complex beer, crazy flavors in this beer that Ive never had before. Too much alcohol flavor.

Bottle, aged between 6 and 9 months. Pours a dark brown with a slightly gushing beige head. Smells beautifully of caramel, candi sugar, raisin, dark red dried fruits, some nuttiness, and pure goodness. Tastes sublimely of all of the above, with a nice tempering sort of breadiness in the initial wave with a heavy sweetness, and a fair amount of alcohol that comes in sweet rather than harsh. Full bodied. Medium carbonation. Creamy texture. This is simply one of my favorite all-time beers, and I have a lot of difficulty faulting it in any way -- I bring home at least a crate every time I visit Belgium. To give it anything less than top marks would really just be gaming my opinion.

Deep brown with a thin tan head, very sweet, sugarm cholate. Lot of alcohol. Taste very sweet with some malts. Full body, sticky. Great beer!
Also for agging.

Bottle at the Edinburgh Brauhaus. Brown-to-red-via-black with a thin beige head and pretty lacing. Toffee and caramel are prominent in the aroma, with good whiffs of raisin, plum and classic Belgian funkiness. The palate is fizzy yet somehow incorporated into a remarkable, smooth whole. The flavours  present strong hazelnut, fruit, savoury nuts, plum and redcurrant. Having insisted while drinking it that I was underwhelmed, the fact that Ive given it 4.1 while saying that shows just how good this beer is.

Bottle at Brauhaus. Deep reddish black, thin but consistent off-white head. Rich nose, plum, treacle, marzipan, booze. Thick rich palate, perfect yet unusual mouthfeel, hints of chocolate, more red fruit, blackberry, slight tannin on the finish, huge long cassis/syrupy linger. Wow.

33 cl bottle. BBE 23.12.2015.
Originally rated on 20090128. (9+4+9+4+16)
Pours deep dark ruby red, almost black colour with a huge, foamy off-white head. Aroma of strong ripe fruits, plum and raisins, mild liquorice notes, some spices, belgian yeast, dark malts and caramel. Flavour of dark and ripe fruits, raisins, plum, sweetish caramel and sugar, yeast, earth notes, mild spice notes, some liquorice and sour berry notes. Mild sourish palate with a long sweet afertaste. Very complex mesh of flavours that coexist with each other very nicely. One of the best beers Ive ever drank. Majestic.
6448

Thx to BlackIPA, I rec this gem, poured into a stiener, color, was dark cant see through and hazy not filterd, I see, aroma, fruity, belgium yeast flora, slight snap pop in the nose, taste, dark fruits and banana esters in the front, back end the malt came thourg good balance,  slight tartness, overall, awseome would try again! execellent example of a Belgium, love it
user_location: @RED BHUT JOIKIAS!, Paulsboro, New Jersey, USA

text: A very nice "come back  to" beer. Very deep and intense with a deep brown color and offwhite head
11.2 ounce bottle with 7 years. This beer is filled with a large malt character, caramel, alcohol, port notes, and yeast character.  The best Rochefort I have had to date.

Bottle. Pours a hazy opaque brown with a large-grained cinnamon head; it has eyes like good Gruyere. Nose is date, cocoa, and a touch of bourbon booziness. The flavor is an amazing punch to the jaw -- very bright and aggressive dark flavors -- chocolate, prune, fig, date, and a touch of spritzy citrus. Carbonation is prickly and strong. Its good, but I dont know that its the greatest thing since sliced bread.

Dark dark brown, with a small red glow in the edges and a nice off-white foam top. When it enters the mouth it is an explosion of flavors, with caramel and dark  bitter chocolate being the most prominent.

Dark brown almost black pour.  Nice beige head that stays around.  Ripe plum and raisan aroma with some floral notes from the hops.  Complex mouthfeel thats not found in other beers.  A little on the sweet side.  The alcohol level is more noticeable towards the end.  Lingering finish.

Pours a deep chestnut brown with a thick tan head that lasts. Big sweet malt presence on the nose with raisin, fig, and butterscotch. Nice full mouth feel, velvety and smooth, carbonation just right. Dominant flavour is raisins, with underlying tones of molasses, making it quite sweet. Finish is smooth and sweet with the alcohol and sweet malt flavours battling it out, one not really dominating the other.

UPDATED: JAN 29, 2013 April 14th 2012: (33 cl bottle from Kervans; BBD: December 15th 2015; blind-sampled with St Bernadus 12 and Westvleteren 12 as the "triple quad challenge") Pours a clear dark brown with little to medium tan head. Nice lace. Aroma has notes of caramel, banana, alcohol and rotten fruit. Oily texture. Medium carbonation. Full body. A sweet and warming finish. Taste is moderately sweet with notes of raisins.  App: 5/5  Aroma: 8/10  Taste: 7/10  Pal: 4/5  Overall: 16/20

December 31st 2011: (33 cl bottle from Kervans) Pours a dark brown with little, quickly receding toffee head. Aroma is caramel malt. Silky smooth texture, soft carbonation, full body with a restrained, slightly sweet finish. Taste is darkly sweet with practically no hint of the high alcohol content. Very filling yet relatively easy to drink.  Aroma: 8/10  App: 3/5  Taste: 8/10  Pal: 5/5  Overall: 16/20
Aged to perfection, this beer really lives up to the hype. caramel, earthy, flavors, hard to describe, but it is mouth watering, not for the rookie drinker.

Aroma is heerlijk dik, vol zoetigheid. De smaak doet het nog meer, vol karamel met pruim en rumrozijn, en wat kaneel en speculaas. Nasmaak is aardig lang met gecontroleerd licht bittertje. Kraag vol en draagt bij aan de bite. Fijn bier.

Bière brune opaque, coiffée dun généreux col beige. Des odeurs de caramel se manifestent en premier, suivi par des arômes de dattes, de figues et de melon miel. Un goût alcoolisé prédomine, accompagné dune palette dépices; danis, de cannelle, de muscade, ainsi que légèrement poivrée. Le tout circule trés bien et lentement en bouche, pour nous laisser un bel arrière-goût franc et complexe. 
(116-241111)

Wow! Dark brown, cloudy pour, decent beige head. Roasted malt, wine, caramel, floral aromas. God where to start. Beautifully sweet from the toffee, slightly bitter and dry. Incredibly complex and bursting with berries, raisin. 

This rating doesnt do it justice.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours a dark, muddy brown with a thin head that dissipates quickly. Aroma consists mostly of dark fruits. Somewhat sweet.
Full bodied, tastes if caramel, fig, and dark fruit. Alcohol is also very noticeable - warm finish.
Overall, an excellent beer and a must try. Top notch Trappist.

UPDATED: APR 18, 2014 Murky, dark brown body with a little bit of sediment. Nice small tan head. Nice malty aroma with carame and brown sugar. Taste is really good and rich with malts and a small bitter kick in the end. Mouthfeel is alright, soft with medium carbonation. Its still a great beer.

UPDATED: DEC 2, 2014 Bottle from the congress, longton. I first had this in a hotel in rochefort. The full on carbonation is a treat for this mighty fine beer. As someone else said world class 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

330ml bottle. A fruit cake looking brown colour in the glass with light brown foam to match. The foam quickly scatters and seperates. Spices and fruit in the aroma are pleasing on the nose. I could detect cloves, cinnamon, pepper, raisins and prunes, a wonderful melange of aromas. In the mouth it is initially mild and then some warming alcohol kicks in. Full and smooth in the mouth with a creamy texture and flavours to match the fruit and spice in the aroma. Definately a sipper as it finishes long and warm in the mouth with a bit of mouth numbing going on. For a small bottle it packs a big punch. Another Belgian delight.

Bottle. Billowy light tan head, on a deep murky brown. Prune, toffee and a rich toasty candy sugar aroma. Flavor is almost savory at first with toffee cake and dates with a warming finish. World class


---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle. Pours a murky brown thin head. Smells and tastes of caramel, alcohol, raisin, dark fruits, bit malt. This is one of my top beers of all time never had a bad bottle so great.
Very rich and full of live flavor on the palette. Hints of raisin, fig & even some notes of red wine. A wonderful beer.

A new founded taste for Belgian beers and indeed strong beers lead me on a persuit to find this beast of a beer. I found it on Cask on Liverpool Road in Manchester and when I initially tried it, Id had a few pints already so felt I couldnt fully appreciate it, so I went back a week later to try again. From the moment you start pouring this, it is just irresistable, the dark colour with a tan head, the nose of raisins, figs, cherries, sugars, alcohol, its mind blowing. It feels like a very naughty treat, its dangerously good and dangerously strong, you wouldnt guess its an 11.3% beer until you begin to get up and walk after it. Flavour of raisins, dates, bit of plum, maybe chocolate malt. A lively carbonation keeps up with the flavours, it is a pure delight to drink and at £4.80 a bottle (Ive seen prices over £6 elsewhere) a total bargain.
user_location: Chapel en le Frith, Derbyshire, ENGLAND

text: Poured an opaque dark brown with a cream colored head that left tons of lacing. Aroma was raisin and yeast. Taste raisin, dates, a hint of caramel, and a bit of the alcohol at the very end. Smooth on the palate. Very very good.

UPDATED: DEC 5, 2013 Bottle pours unclear brown with a constant rim of beige head. Soft aroma of grain and yeasty fruits with a candy like sweetness. The taste is so smooth and with just the right amount of sugary sweetness, ok maybe just a wee bit much on the sweetness, and some fruit of raisin date and a little red and black grape. There is a lingering grain and yeast that leaves a pleasant date raisin earthy taste. This is easily one of the best Belgians and a signature quad. With warmth the alcohol does show but even that comes on in an pleasantly sweet way.

Ive been dying to try this for a while and was lucky enough to be able to pick a bottle up yesterday. Dark body, with a reddish tan corona. You cant stop the tan head from bubbling up no matter how hard you try. Tons of fruitiness here, figs, cherries, raisins, sugars and alcohol. Theres a burnt caramel with a hint of chocolate. Roast malt flavours. Theres a slight alcohol burn on the tongue which warms you right through - but you wouldnt call this an 11.3% beer on a blind test. Theres a pure sweetness on the tongue which dissipates to a bitter note which lingers on the palate as you feel the beer travel down. The carbonation is lively, helping to open up those flavours. This is delicious. Wow.

What a masterpiece! The pour resulted in a murky dark brown liquid with a pancake of light tan head. The aroma brought cherries, figs, raisins and brown sugar notes. Taste is unbelievable. Sweet malt with lightly toasted notes. Dark fruits and spicy yeast add layer after layer of complexity. The beer itself is full bodied with lively yet creamy carbonation. This is a beer one must enjoy at least once in their lifetime. Cheers to the brothers in Belgium. Perfect beer.

Black, large tan head.
Aroma bready, dark fruit.
As described, raisin and blackcurrant, quite sharp.
Some alcohol burn, not bad for 11.3%.
Medium palate.
Much more interesting than the 6.

Wow.  This one surprised me.  This blows the Rochefort 6 and 8 out of the water.  Similar to the Mahleur 12 due to the comlexity and overall sweetness.  Very dark and fruity, big thick body and medium carbonation.  Raisin and toffee are prevalent. Similar to the other Rochefort beers the tail end dies out in a watery manner and does not coat the mouth like a Mahleur 12 does but this is still exceptional.  Still has coffee notes like the 8 but less present, with more fruit.

It was the first trappist beer I tasted. For me it was a great experience. The beer has a nice brown colour with a thin head that dissapiars in a few time. Aroma is toasted, little caramel and complex additives. Medium sweet tasted that become to a bitterness very nice with a high alcohol presence.  Full body 100 %. You can eat it!! Nice finish. Dangerous!!!!

11.2oz bottle poured into the Rochefort chalice glass.  Deep, dulled, unfiltered cherry brown.  Not much of a head, but some soda-like carbonation keeps coming.  This is a superb beer all the way, full of all the dark fruit and chocolate tastes of a great dark Belgian, with no real cloying alcohol at all.  Pretty amazing.  Mellow raisin, plum, prune..all perfectly in line and complementary of each other.  Smooth brown chocolate malt tones.  Mild balancing peppery hops up front fade into a smooth doughy finish.
Brown pour, light brown head. Aroma is alcohol, nuts and raisins. Flavor is alcohol, fruits and belgian yeast. Yummz.

330ml bottle at BarVolo. Pours dark brown with a thin beige head. Aroma of dark fruits mildly spiced, yeasty and complex. Outstanding aroma. Flavour is exceptionally well balanced and strong in flavor. The alcohol is not overbearing. Reminds me of a complex port wine. One of the few beers worthy of a perfect rating.

UPDATED: OCT 14, 2012 Dark ale with a cream head. Chicory, herbs, fernet and chocolate in nose. Robust body, oily texture,  sophisticated carbonation. Moreover an artisanal quite bitter chocolate on palate. Simply belgian most bitter pralins from the world famous chocoladiers! Hints of orange peel. Drops of licorice. Some of thouse pralins are filled by cognac and cherries liquer as indicated by a long aftertaste. Ive waited for some time with rating this one. It is one of the best trappist beers around, and one of my long time favourites.
Dark brown beer, firm fluffy creamy beige head. Spicy aroma, raisins, plums, brown sugar, some milk chocolate, very fruity. Flavour quite sweet and fruity, dried fruits, currants, candy sugar, some roasted malt tones. Full body and lingering fruity malty finish, where you just start to notice the alcohol. Nicely balanced, one of the great beers.
(From 33cL bottle @ home)

Bottle 33 cl..... It pours dark brown with a large nice tan head..... the aroma is yeast, dark fruits.... the flavor is Belgian yeast, dark fruits, roasted malt, caramel and chocolate..... nice strong, caramel and some port finish....

UPDATED: JUL 4, 2012 Pours a deep thick raisin color. Sediment. Smells like raisin bread, raw dough, a bit of booze and candy. Sweet raisins up front, boozy finish. Thick and smooth. One of the best Ive ever had, regardless of style.

One of the more balanced and subtle beers Ive had. Quite dark. Lots of medium to dark roasted grain but nothing burnt. Yeast, spice, caramel, alcohol, dark fruit, sugar. Very little hop as expected. Lots of carbonation and consistency that coats your tongue and seems to deliver lots of flavor at once without being obnoxious about it.
Despite its high alcohol content, this beer is imminently drinkable.  Roasted malts, a deep plum body, thick, dark, with a healthy head.  One of the best of its style.
caramel, alcohol, licorice, brown/black, brown foam, medium sweetness, full body, lively carbonation, long finish, thick feel. Great meditative beer!

Very dark quad with a small but pronounced head. As for the aromas, the usual suspects are here, but exquisitely balanced. Rich dried fruits, hints of softer blackberry etc. notes, caramel and a slight yeast.

Rich sweet, spiced raisins and plums on the taste. Astringent vinous notes do manifest themselves, but these are rounded off nicely. You are conscious youre drinking something thats 11+% ABV, but thats hard to detect. Mouthfeel is wonderfully smooth, with just the right amount of carbonation. Exceptionally well-balanced, and an exceptional beer.

UPDATED: DEC 30, 2012 Brown color, nice brownish head. The taste remindse me of dark dried fruits and a bit of chocolate and coffee. Heavy sweetness (but not like suger or something), lightly bitter, full body, creamy, average carbonation, long finish, takes some time to drink.
Wouldnt realise the 11.3 % alcohol content, smooth with obvious hints of caramel. Great beer for winter. I prefer the 8 over this if i had to choose
Excellent dark, smooth, and easy to drink Trappist. Very strong, but you would never know it! I wish they made this shit for body deodorant!

Bouteille de 33 cl. Une brune presque opaque, mousse abondante qui sestompe en laissant une particule. Dabord, les arômes fruités se développent : fruits rouges, raisins, figues; puis ensuite les épices, le tout soutenu par un alcool qui réchauffe un peu, on sent quelle est forte mais ça passe incroyablement bien! Superbe sensation en bouche même si elle est peut être un peu moins crêmeuse que la "8". Un must! trouvée à Vanuxeem - Ploegstaert.
Pours a very dark brown and a bubbly tan head. Nose is dark fruits, molasses, sweet malts and alcohol. Flavor is similar and very chewy. Rich mouth feel with booze.

To my fellow Vets on this Veterans Day 2011 - SALUTE!! My gosh, brews like this have me wishing I was born in Belgium! I do believe I have found the sixth beer to go into my top-5 favorites list!!! This is definitely part of my winter holiday food and drink repertoire! Some hearty smoked cheese and smoked wild game (venison, wild boar) are definitely going to be paired up with this hearty brew. I could see this being my go-to brew on those cold wintry night by the fireside and a hearty cigar. The alcohol content (11.3% ABV) is absolutely warming and very well hidden in this delicious brew! Cue the choir!!

11.2oz bottle, aged 3 years.  Random bust open to end the weekend.  High carbonation, slight gusher, no spillage however.  Red/brown hue through the offering, fantastic.  Aromas are wonderfully spiced, cinnamon, clove, some darker fruits, yeasty.  Amazing balanced body.  Cascading flavor, light as a feather, no burn or any indication that this is half the ABV.  The palate doesnt completely follow the nose, not a lot of spice, but some plum.  No bitterness at all, would be this better with more age?  Maybe, but its hard to see what else this could be.  Top 3 Quad on the market and very accessable.

Had this one a couple of times before but never rate it. Here it is:
Pours very dark brown colour with a faint brown head. Intense sweet aroma of dark berries, raisins and dried plums. The taste is a follow of the aroma with heavy cloying sweetness and tha alcohol gets presents in the palate. Complex, full body, oily feel, soft carbonation and sweet long after taste. Quite an experience.

With my first sip of this beer, I saw unicorns and heard angels playing silver trumpets. This beer is in the same league of human achievement as Michelangelos David or a Vermeer or Sainte-Chapelle in Paris.  It bursts with a complex blend of flavours, its smooth, it has a long, long finish, and the alcohol hits you in the back of the head with a heavily padded hammer. This is a magnificent beer, and for me its the gold standard.

Robe brune-rouge opaque, mousse intense mais brève. 
Une odeur franchement vineuse et caramel.  
Se compare à la Rochefort 8 mais encore moins damertume et plus de malt.  Du Caramel, peu de pétillant, alcool bien caché considérant 11.3%!  Un peu de fruit confit mais pas autant que la Weizenbock.  Complexe et sophistiqué.  
Arrière goût de fruit confit et caramel, terreux et chaud avec lalcool qui se pointe le bout du nez.

UPDATED: MAR 5, 2012 Bottle from vinmonopolet. Deep dark colour with a off white head. Rich and complex aroma. Well blended meduim sweet flavour with raisins and plums. A very well hidden alcohol flavour altough it is 11%.

A complex, fruity aroma thats quite lovely, raisins, dates, figs, brown sugar, orange peel, a little funk; rich & warming but not overheated, sweet, layered, tawny port, honeyed raisins, finishes for days. Superlative.
Splendid.  Nice strong plum and blackberry notes. High alcohol content is hidden surprisingly well. About as perfect as a beer can get.

Bottle date of December 2008.  Pours a dark brown with a amber hue.  Fizzy sounding tan head fades quickly.  A good amount of sediment is in the pour.  On smell alone this beer would be in the upper echelon of all brews ever.  It is an amazingly complex mixture of chocolate, raisin, dark fruit, sugar cane, caramel candy, some cola and maybe just a fraction of booze.  I would love to compare a fresher bottle, but the 2008 is drinking so maravalous, I couldnt imagine it being better.  Big complex yet utterly smooth dark fruit, raisin, sugar plum (gives off a holiday type feel), some distant funky yeast notes, some cocoa.  I think the age on this bottle has really smoothed out the booziness as I am not get much of anything besides a slight warming of the belly. Just a truly remarkable beer.  I have only waited so long to drink as I didnt think it would be as good as people have said.  Well, I was wrong and it has far exceeded my expectations.  Damn.

Wow, just an amazing Belgian Ale! Very malty with a nice smooth texture all the way down. Even though the alcohol percentage is high (11.2),  the texture of the beer is so smooth that it almost eliminates the bitterness that you get from higher alcohol beers. Highly recommend this beer!
Why bother trying to write about this beer...others have done a great job already...just buy some and sip and savour it...
The greatest beer I have ever enjoyed in my life. I was skeptical about some of the hype, but it lived up to and surpassed the hype.

Bottle at the Brass Tap, poured into a snifter.  Poured a very dense dark brown with aromas dark fruits, and raisins.  Taste follows aromas, and has a touch of sweetness in the aftertaste, real enjoyable brew.

UPDATED: JAN 25, 2017 A just about perfect Quadrupel. Pours a nice dark glass with slight foam head. Has a simply incredible aroma of dark fruits, chocolat and raisins, with a palate starting nice and sweet and leaving a somewhat red-wine bitterness. Its texture is bizarre and brilliant. A very complex taste with several delightful layers. One of the best Quadrupels around.

This beer was served in a wide mouth goblet. 

Ar- Very nice! This beer has a melange of fruit aromas banana, plums, raisins, figs and cider aromas. Deeply malted caramel and cocoa notes . Alcohol peaks its head out but is not a problem.

Ap- Murky and muddy brown body with ruby highlights. Thin tan head resolves into a ring of foam.

T- Prickly alcohol leads the charge. This beer is deeply layered with bready malted caramel notes smothered in dark fruits figs, plums, raisins. The yeast is a bit peppery but helps out with balance.

P- This beer is full bodied with moderate carbonation. Alcohol is warming and pleasantly hot from time to time.

O- Very satisfying beer drinking experience. It has been years since I drank this beer. RIS may be my current beer craving; however, quad style beers could easily take over.

UPDATED: APR 25, 2012 This was one of the first Trappist quads I started drinking back when I was younger and is still one of the best Trappists ever for me, second only to Westy 12.  This titan of a beer has an unmistakable personality that I havent been able to find in any other beer.  When I get the chance to drink it, I pour it into its wide-mouthed Rochefort chalice with the gold rim.  The brew has a deep, deep ruby color bordering on black.  The head is very off-white and a little splotchy.  It starts out massive and energetic then retreats to a rocky foam that stays through until the end.  The nose is intense and fragrant with fruity yeast, malty dark fruit, some musky, oaky funk and a little dry cocoa.  On the palate, the beer has a lively carbonation with a silky mouthfeel.  It delivers flavors of dark fruit, dates, treacle, fig, plum, sugary malt and christmas pudding.  Those warming, dark fruity flavors really give it a festive attitude and make it prefect for warming up with in front of the fire.  Overall, this beer is bursting at the seems with complexity and is a real work of art, especially for its strength.
Strong dose of alc with all the trappings of a beer religion.  To the tenth degree.  Not sure what to express besides pleasure....  Im only an amateur.

33cl bottle. Poured dark brown, amber along the edges, no head. Murky. Lots of dark fruit, roasty. Hints of many things but Im not sure theyre actually there. Complex. Strong on the palate, leaves a long warm and restrained fruity aftertaste.

My favorite beer in all the world. Couldnt believe the taste when I first tried it on the Belgian beer tour in Brussels. Absolutely wonderful!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Brown color, not much of a foam.
Sweet like honey with all the dark sweet fruits, parading through your tongue.
Very strong alcohol..but amazing taste of it,

UPDATED: NOV 12, 2011 33cl bottle pours very dark with a large "lingering" tan head. aroma is deep and rich, dark fruits and alcohol. tastes massively deep and complex, sweet dark fruits, tons of warmth from the 11.3% and an exceptional balance. a wonderful creamy mouth feel, with a long sweet/bitter finish. fantastic!

By far my favorite Belgian beer. Great dark fruit taste, almost a chocolaty/ spiced palate. Really coats the mouth. The first thing you taste is the dark fruit, fig, raisin then you get a good spice back end and the boozyness goes so well with the fruit. Easy for an 11.3 abv. Great beer!
UPDATED: NOV 4, 2011 This beer is one of my favorite. It?s so tasty and very easy to drink. Pity that it is so strong. Not able to drink a lot

UPDATED: FEB 2, 2012 Dark brown with a creamy head that lasts. Smell of fruit, cinnamon, brown sugar, and some floral. Thick body with good carbonation. Dark fruits and sugars leave a sweetness that finishes well on the palate.

UPDATED: FEB 7, 2012 Bottle. Pours deep, dark brown with tan head. Aroma of subtle chocolate, faint vegitable and apple, some dark roast and dust. Flavor is outstanding, toasted malt, subtle hints of chocolate, hints of licorice, peppery alcohol and signs of dark fruit and perhaps a touch of brown sugar. Mouthfeel is medium body, soft, with fizzy carbonation. Overall, very enjoyable brew!

UPDATED: FEB 4, 2012 Bottle, Pours dark brown with medium off white head. A. caramel, roasty, plums, dark fruits, some alcohol. Some sweetness, really warming. Well balanced complex beer. Really good beer.

Pours reddish brown slightly cloudy.  Good carbonation with a finger head.  Initially the nose had some blue-cheese-starting-to-turn aromas but this faded and it became traditional Belgian notes and dried fruit-apricot, cherry, currant.  Mouthfilling palate and carbonation leaves very long complex finish of dried fig and other dark fruits.
In the st-remy abbey, they know something... Dark brown appearance. Medium to high off-white head. Theres some caramel with plum and raisins...almost perfect

UPDATED: MAR 3, 2016 33cl Bottle.  Almost black with a small tan head. It has this fruity apple, anise, dried plum smell and reminds me of an old whysky. Alcohol runs through my nose. NICE and I still didnt take a sip. The body is thick and smooth. After a sip it came more obvious : there has to be some black grape in it. I feel grapes, sweetness of malt, still some apple and a shocking anise background with master pieced hinch of hops and the bitterness that puts this combination in a great harmony. Of course the alcohol is there and there is no secret ; I mean 11,3% has to be somewhere and still its the first time I dont mind it. Clever ! Magic ! Belgian monks did it again. Its a reference. This beer would be a disaster with more carbonation but its just perfect. Creamy, fruity and malty. I know that many brewers would love to make a beer like this. I know I would call it a lifes success in beer making. GREAT STUFF.   
I dont like dark beer but this one is an exception.
A great fizzy mouthfeel with a sweet fruity aroma yet an alcohol finish that had me tipping my glass too soon after the last drop went down my gullet.
11.2 to Chalice.  Pours dark amber with khaki head.  Bready malt, dark fruits, touch of alcohol.  Sweet and smooth with a warm finish.  Lives up top its reputation.

Dark cola color with full head and lacing.  Big thick taste of caramel malt and dark dried fruit.  Bittering is minimal, replaced by a semi-sweet malt moving to a warm, biting alcohol finish.  One or two is enough for a full evening.

Pours a cloudy dark brown with a good two finger sized head that quickly dissipates. Nose of caramel, chocolate, raisins with strong malt and yeast tones. Taste is superb with caramel malts, a nice fruit note with a prevalent alcohol taste. The balance between the sweetness of the fruits contrasted with the yeast, malt and high abv did come through quite a bit but it makes this a very well put together beer.  I think that this is the beer that all other beers are trying to copy.

Darkbrown hazy colour with not much of a head. Some alcohol in smell, something sweet in the background, some yeast and malt. Dark fruits in the aroma, little like Rochefort 8 but not as much fruit. Very good taste, and I was suprised of how well hidden the alcohol was. Some sweetness in taste, just enough (not to little, not to much). Some malt in the taste. 
A very good beer, but it is a sipper and you need some time to enjoy it. I could not really say what it tasted, but it was good.

Nice dark brown appearance. Great caramel aroma that already warns me this might be just a bit too sweet for my taste, which it is, but the lingering, warm, alchol rich finish more than makes up for that.

I saw this on the cheap at a local liquor store and remembered that I havent had it. Pours a muddy brown with a large amount of head relative to the ABV. The aroma is sweet and bready, with a layer of dark fruit. The flavor is definitely similar, though the fruits mostly stick to the smell. Very doughy, and definitely boozy, though not harsh. I definitely plan on buying this one again.

Tastes wonderfull, my favourite beer. Sweet honey like taste, smooth small head, slight carbonation. My only criticism is that it lacks a small amount of aroma, i would like it to smell just that little bit more enticing...maybe after a few more of these it will :D

Pours black with no head. Aroma of sweet honey floral notes, blueberrys, cane sugar, cinnamon, toffee, dark fruits (raisins, figs),  and notes of licorice. Taste follows the aroma in every way and is bold. Mouthfeel is just like drinking silk, carbonation is perfect. This beer delivers and then some. Alcohol is well hidden. A nice clean somewhat dry finish that works into a candy sweetness. A must try.

UPDATED: FEB 14, 2014 Very good beer, nice complexity.  However I would not put it in the top ten in the world myself.  Something about either the alcohol level or sweetness gives it just a touch of cloyness.
Tasted again in February 2014.  Pretty much agree with the above.  It is very good, but I think there is a touch too much sugar added.  Pretty strong brown sugar, molasses flavors.  Somewhat yeasty.  The alcohol is quite subdued for an 11% beer.

Best Belgium ale I have ever had. Sweet but like a fine port wine. I try to find the older bottles do to the better  taste. This is the best I have found in the USA. It has over 11% ALC/VOL. but is smooth and not water downed like US beers. This is my go to beer.
One of the greatest beers Ive ever had. Aroma is a little subdued. Taste of rich luscious caramel and candy sweetness.

Deep cloudy brown with a reasonable pale head that leaves some lacing. Aroma is raisins, brown sugar, honey, vanilla, dates. Taste is honey, herbs, raisins, dates, brown sugar. Good body, creamy mouthfeel, well balanced and damn tasty!
Great beer. But for me st. Bernardus abt 12 is much better. To sweet and taste alcohol in comperation with st. Bernadus.

Tumman ruskean värinen belgi, jonka päälle muodostuu lähes valkoinen vaahto. Aromissa on toffeeta, lakritsia, hunajaa, hedelmäisyyttä ja mausteita. Maussa on lakritsia, hedelmäisyyttä, mausteita ja hieman makeutta. Mielestäni alkoholi pysyy kokoajan sopivalla tasolla piilossa ja mukana. Paksua ja pehmeää, mutta kuitenkin täräkkää tavaraa. Paremmuutta tämän ja Rochefort 8:n välillä on vaikea päättää.

Dark brown beer with a nice light beige foamy head. Very bubbling. Fragrances of plum, berries, chocolate, coffee, peppermint with licorice hints. Full round body very pleasant in mouth. Although the alcohol % is pretty high its well hidden. Its like drinking a St-Estèphe 1998! You have the feeling of drinking satin or silk. Tiny multiple bubbling on tastebuds. Very complex. Again a Rochefort reussite. Probably the jewel of all beer.

Pleasantly complex plum, raisin and currant notes.  Very smooth.   Refined, but not diluted.  Creamy.  Boozy and warming.  Malt and molasses.  Perfectly balanced.  Really good stuff.  The #8 is less boozy and more fruity than #10.  They are both outstanding beers.

UPDATED: MAR 2, 2013 as close to perfect as beer can get.  rich aromas of brandy, ripe dark Belgian fruits, toffe, molasses, and clove/cardamom.  incredibly smooth, buttery, beautiful warmth and slightly earthy spice component.  raisins, figs, prunes, brown sugar, noisette finish.
This might be my favorite trappist beer of the six brewers Ive tried, when I see it I get it

Pours beautiful. Very large head, pour with care, but sinks soon. Malty balanced by slight bitterness, warm alcohol balanced with sweetness, quite fizzy. Very well composed and rich in all. This is a beer that has it all sweetness, bitterness, warmth, carbonation, beauty. And way too inexpensive where I live.
Pours a dark black with a light tan head, which disappears reather quickly.  Dark malt aromas.  Sparkly attack which fades to alcohol and sweet caramel flavors.  A seriously, seriously great Bier!

Got bored, figured I drink this masterpiece.  Pours dark and hazy mahagony with great white lacing.  Aroma is dark fruits, caramel, brown sugar, raisins, and deliciousness.  Tastes of the same, raisins, caramel, brown sugar, a richness from plums, deliciousness, and not as much alcohol as in the 8.  Palate is a good balance.  Not too heavy, not too fizzy, just enough thickness and CO2 to make your mouth jump.  Just great.

Purchased at West Lakeview Liquors in Chicago, IL; enjoyed while watching week 2 of the NFL season after a horrid Bears loss.  It was either this or MGD, so I decided to just go for this (J/K).  Appearance a very dark and cloudy plum/brown with a rich off-white head that laces to the glass, very creamy.  Aroma is soft but complex, mixture of dark fruit (plums, apricot a bit), some type of natural syrup, definitely a bit of raisin.  Taste is fantastic, theres no way this can be an 11%er, just way too smooth for that.  The raisins and plum make it smooth and suppress the alcohol flavor, theres a sweetness but I cant really tell what it is, maybe equal parts caramel and chocolate but its a Belgian so Id assume the candi sugar was used, and thats what probably contributes to it but I cant really taste it.  Thoroughly complex and enjoyable, in a class of its own for sure.  Expensive ($7.50 for a 11 oz bottle) but definitely get what you pay for.

Deep dark brown with tinge of red and medium tan head.  Aroma brown sugar, caramel, yeast, dried fruit.  Creamy feel with medium-full body, alcohol hidden up front but comes out in the finish, a little carbonation.  Flavors very complex with dark dried fruits, sweet brown sugar, cocoa, warm and dry at the end.  World class.

Pours very dark brown with medium head.  Belgian yeast, bread, and grape/raisin in the aroma.  Flavor is rich, fruity.  Finish is awesome.  Its rich and creamy and tangy with the perfect amount of carbonation.
UPDATED: MAR 23, 2014 Belle robe brune. Mousse peu présente mais l’efferdescence se fait rapidement sentir en bouche.
UPDATED: DEC 18, 2011 Donker bier met stevige bruine schuimkraag. Bier ligt vol in de mond en heeft een heerlijke portachtige smaak. Een van mijn favorieten!

UPDATED: DEC 30, 2011 Bottle. Dark brown pour.  Aroma of raisins and plums.  Tastes very sweet.  Burnt raisin and alcohol.  Thick palate.   A beer to sip and share.
Rerate on Dec 30, 2011
Bottle. Aroma of plum, and alcohol.  Taste is not as sweet as the first time I had this.  Taste is complex.  Id be lying if I said I could pick out any specific flavors.  Palate was not as thick as the last one I tried.  I  do not know if my tastes are evolving or if this bottle is better than the previous one I tried.  Im going to edit the score from a 4 to a 4.3.
Pours a dark brown, aroma is of dark fruits. Dark fruits and alcohol in the taste. Nice warming sensation on the palate. Great beer!

Bottle bought @ Systembolaget and consumed on September 9. Pours a deep brown liquid with a massive beige head. Smell is intense with lots of sun-dried fruit including prunes and raisins. Taste is sweet and reminds me of very ripe grapes, banana, sun-dried apricot, brown sugar and some classic Belgian yeast. A very tasty beer excellent for sipping over a long period of time.

UPDATED: SEP 29, 2011 pour dark and hazy , with a big nut-brown head. leaves a nice lazing.
Big aroma of dark fruits, figs and raisins, but also hints of citrus, caramel, melase.
really sweet, and hides the 11,3% very well. 
It has a medium body, with a fizzy carbonation. It feels like its dissolving in the mouth. 
Thumbs up..

Serving glass: Poured from bottle into Snifter.

Appearance: Extremely dark brown with thin, but lasting, cream colored head.

Aroma: Loads of figs, raisins and plums, with a strong combination of musty yeast and alcohol.

Taste: Pretty similar to the smell - plum, figs and raisins, with an intoxicating mix of the musty and sweet. Cant really explain why this tastes so damn good.

Palate: Low carbonation, thick chewy body. Very smooth and a little warming.

Overall: Wow, an 11% abv beer that is very easy to drink. Just fantastic.

Pours a cloudy dark brown with a almost nonexistent head. Nose of caramel, chocolate, raisins with strong malt and yeast tones. Taste is superb with caramel malts, a nice fruit note with a prevalent alcohol taste. The balance between the sweetness of the fruits contrasted with the yeast, malt and high abv make this a very well put together beer.
UPDATED: FEB 27, 2012 Fruits confits en rondeur. Juste assez deffervescence pour tout nettoyer et recommencer. Complexe mais terriblement accessible.
Bottle at Cafe Buitenlust, Oirschot. Medium to dark brown color, small head. Ok smell, nice full taste. Good carbonation and full body.

I cant remember he first time I had this beer but I definitely am glad I chose to rate it tonight. The beer pours with little to no darkened cream head. There is no lacing in the glass and the beer seems to have no head retention. The aroma is really nice. The smell of plum and raisin are met by carmel malts, strong belgian yeast and a serious hint of alcohol. The beer looks like a brown/burgundy mixture with a very cloudy appearance. 

The taste is full flavored with caramel, malt, and dark fruit playing the most significant role. I taste plums, raisins and some of the most balanced malt and yeast I have found in a beer this high in alcohol. The beer has a sweet flavor but the subtle heat of a serious high alcohol stout. Overall, this beer was impressive but its wide availability made me wonder how it retains such a high rating. Perhaps beer newbies find it to be epic. I find it to be great but certainly not in my top 20 beers.

Pours dark brown and hazy with a small tan head. Sweet coffee and nut-like aroma. Slightly sweet on the palate, you can definitely taste the alcohol. Full bodied and rich with a nice bitterness. I taste coffee, nuts, a touch of chocolate...absolutely delicious.
If you cant get a hold of a Westy and want to see what all the hype is about give this a shot, from those I have talked to the 2 mirror eachother

Snifter. Deep earthy brown colour, cloudy with some sediment. Large head retained well. Aroma of raisins, plums, berries, sugars. Has the same bright/fresh aroma as the 8 that I cant quite put my finger on. Taste reflects the aroma, but also some lemon (almost like lemon pie). Alcohol is warming yet unobtrusive. Gets deeper as it warms. Aftertaste lingers for a long time, wow. Rich deep and complex, thicker than the 8. A masterpiece of a beer, every single sip is fantastic.
From a bottle in Crowne Plaza, Brussels (Belgium) august 2011. Redbrown color with a nice lasting head. Toffee aroma with some fruitiness. Some breadspicies. I love this beer.

UPDATED: OCT 10, 2012 Dark brown with not much foam. Malty, a bit of chocolate, dark malts on the nose. Thick on the palate, intense in flavour. Malts, sweetness, some raisins, alchohol. I could mistake this for an aged semisweet red wine. Dark, sweetish and intense in flavour. Nice to have come across, although too special to be something I would keep in stock.
Edit: i usually keep a bunch of these in stock nowadays.
Bottle. Extreme foam when pored into the glass. Smell almost completely licorice. Chocolate taste with the same licorice, a perfect specimen of belgian beer.

11.2oz bottle poured into a Trappist glass.  Pours deep dark brown with a one finger tan head that lasts.  Aromas are sweet alcohol, and dark fruit.  Taste is smooth, raisin, toffee, not at all bitter.  Mouthfeel is very creamy and full bodied with average carbonation.  So very smooth and rich.  Overall, well worth the money and lives up to its substantial reputation.

Dunkel ergießt sich dieses Bier ins Testglas, begleitet von einer üppigen Schaumentwicklung. 
Medizinartiger Anisgeruch der angenehmen Sorte kündigt ein gehaltvolles Bier an. 
Schwer malzig und alkohollastig geht dieses Bier über die Zunge. Dabei aber nie in Extreme abgleitend. 
Ein Bier mit Qualitäten, welches die 11,3% Alkohol zu handhaben weiß. Ein sehr guter Absacker.Test vom 14.1.2007, Gebinde: Glasflasche

pours dark copper brown with high thick head
aromas of raisin, figs, brown sugar and some orange
flwvour is thick, warm, welcoming and full. no bitterness a bit sugary but a really really nice ending. a pure joy to drink!

Bottle @ Sample 10cl. Slightly hazy, dark brown with an off-white head. Fruity aroma with notes of raisin and prunes. Taste erkompleks with many impressions. Plums, dried fruit and alcohol is common feature.

UPDATED: SEP 19, 2011 I think I have had this one since the end of 09. Figured today was as good a time as any to open it. Bottle poured into my Delirium tremens tulip.

A - Pours deep dark brown with a huge fizzy two finger off white head, dissipating down to a thick film, leaving thin sheets of lacing down the glass.

S - Smells of rich dark fruits like raisins and dates, candied sugar, banana, dulled chocolate, light spice, and some light alcohol heat. Very nice overall balance. I have had this fresh but I think I now prefer it aged for a few years.

T - Flavors are similar to the nose with the addition of a bit more booze. The balance of dark fruits, candied sweetness, and light heat is a nearly flawless. The finish is a bit dry with a mix of sweetness and dulled heat, lingering for a short while. Overall this is one of the best trappist quads you can find. I have had this fresh, and while it is still good, I think it just gets better with age.

M - Heavy body and flavor with moderate carbonation. Full bodied with some dryness. Finish is a mix of dark fruit sweetness and some dulled alcohol burn.

O - Pretty good. I have had a few of these now and I think I prefer it aged. When it is fresh the booze is a bit overpowering but after a few years it really seems to die down. I am glad I stashed this one in my cellar. One of the best for sure.
