Recently got a few 330mL bottles from my sister-in-law. It poured a rich and cloudy shade of brown with a decent white head. Malt sweetness and alcohol dominated the aroma.

The taste, I dont think I can convey better than the phrase my brother used - "chocolate-covered rainbows."

The beer has very little to almost no bitterness with an amazing body and even though its very alcoholic, it goes down the palate with extreme ease.

This is certainly the best beer Ive ever had, period.

11.2oz bottle from Greenwood poured into my Chimay glass. Pours a very dark brown with almost no head. What little is there is dark tan before it totally dissipates. Aroma is quite malty. Sweet cereal, chocolate and a little coffee. Also has a scent of dates. Taste is medium sweet and lightly bitter. Tastes almost like a semi-sweet red wine. Also, holy crap the alcohol! Medium bodied with a very fizzy texture. The carbonation almost makes the beer explode in your mouth. Has quite the long finish on this one. Overall, its pretty good. I think its way overrated but Ill enjoy this glass then probably never drink it again.

UPDATED: JAN 14, 2015 Strongly fruity aroma with strong notes of plums and currants, smoothed over with toffee and molasses. Theres also a vinous touch and suggestions of coconut, licorice, and cocoa nibs that grow more evident with temperature. The interplay between the malt sugars and the dark, fruity esters is superb. There is also a noticeable booze component, like dark rum. The palate is medium to thick, with lively effervescence. Its so fizzy that, frankly, its distracting. The taste is grandly complex with lots of sweet notes, a fruity tart touch, and a boozy bitter. It certainly takes longer to figure this one out than the big Westvleteren. The alcohol doesnt bite, but its definitely perceivable, and it warms your digestive tract. The aftertaste is fruity but also quite earthy. Its kind of hard for me to get through the whole bottle. I much prefer the Westvleteren, which is less boozy and more balanced, but this is the more complex and puzzling brew and, overall, an outstanding beer to my taste equally good as its lesser sibling, the 8.
UPDATED: AUG 11, 2011 One of the greatest Trappist Belgian style ales. Unique dark chocolate and cherries, medium mouthfeel with solid malts

Pours deep brown with a thin dark tan head...decent retention.  Aroma is malty with some roastiness, caramel, and candy sugar but also has some delicate spicy hops to bring a bit of balance.  Flavor follows suit and while it is sweet, its not to sweet or cloying like many big quads...some fig, raisin, candy sugar, and caramel...still a pleasant hint of delicate spicy hops...definitely not too yeasty like some big belgians.  Mouthfeel is silky smooth with a slightly sweet, warming finish.

Bottle from Ninas. Pours a very dark brown colour with an amber tinge. Lacy tan head. Sweet and malty plum and raisin nose. Berry flavours, plum again, black currant, port wine and candy sugar. Alcohol fairly present. Chewy mouth-feel .Medium carbonation. Lingering malt and berries. Quite dry finish. Lovely!

Aroma: Raisins, plums, pears, caramel and some alcohol.
Taste: Anise, chocolate fudge, pear, alcohol, blackcurrant, raisin, even some apple. 
Mouthfeel: I sweet boozeyness that tells you to respect it, full body.

Date: August 4, 2011 Mode: Bottle Source: Apple Valley Liquor, Apple Valley, MN Appearance: Semi-opaque muddy brown and decent amount of head. Aroma: Dark fruit and caramel. Flavor: Consistent with aroma, smooth, light to medium bodied and hint of alcohol at finish. Other: What a beer for my 100th rating!  Huge quad fan and this did not disappoint.  Will be having this one again for sure.

11.2oz bottle.
Dark brown pour with some slight head.  Swirling aromas of dark fruit, bready malt, and spicy yeast.  Flavor is amazing as well - tons of dark fruit like plum and currant.  ABV extremely well hidden, this is dangerously easy to drink.  Man, those Trappist monks sure know how to make beer!
(This beer rating was imported from FB and unfortunately lacks any further comments.)

One of those beers that Ive overlooked for far too long. 11.2 oz bottle into a chimay goblet. Cant find a date but the store sells quite a bit of belgians so I would assume its on the fresher side. A - Deep cola colored body. Khakhi head that dissipates to some dirty edging and some solid lacing. S - Sweet malts, candied figs, and light spices. I cant put my finger on it, but theres this certain candy sweet herbalness going on. Very smooth and well balanced. T - Same as the aroma. Sweet malts, dark fruits, spices and a dash of molasses. The mystery herbalness is there as well. Alcohol is present, but suprisingly low key. The mouthfeel is tremendously smooth and well balanced. O - I wasnt super impressed by the aroma and smell. However, the mouthfeel and body of this beer is perhaps the best I have ever experienced. This is a really well crafted beer, a real classic.

440 ml. bottle.  Pours a dark brown with a medium tan head.  Aroma of dark fruit, chocolate, spices and a bit of coffee.  Taste is malt, fruit, chocolate and spices.  Complex and very interesting.  Smooth and rich.  Hardly noticed the alcohol.  Fantastic!!!

Bottle, shared. Pours an ever-wavering mix of purple, dark red, and brown. Nice light brown head. Bit of lacing. Nose is plum, stone fruits, slight breadiness, rich soil and roots, with a pinot noir-like grape profile. Taste is more tart, with a bit of earthy funk, dark fruits and slight alcohol astringency. Finish lasts considerably. Not life-altering, but close.
UPDATED: AUG 30, 2011 Bottle in trappist glass. Scent of grapes, some alcohol, smoke. Dark brown colour. Taste of grapes, banana, alcohol. Excellent stuff.

Bottle enjoyed at home
Dark brown, big tanned head. Smells of caramel, sweet fruits, prunes, banana, malts and belgian yeast esters. Taste is very fruity and dominated by the total full bodied malts with much sweetness. The flavors are complex and nice. Feel is very oily. Finish has nice bitterness with good hop complexity
Same bottle as pictured. Poured dark brown with aroma of dark fruites. Taste is very similar. Long, slightly dry finish.
Bottle at N00bru2, Pours a hazy chocolate brown with no foam. Smells sweet of prunes and alcohol. Tastes sweet  of dark and aged fruits and ends bitter with alcohool.

Appearance:  very dark red pour, short brownish head, minimal lacing.  Aroma: 	raisins, cherries, plums, red grapes.   Taste: mulled wine, dark fruits in syrup, some yeasty spices.   Finish: malty, fruity, vinous.   Notes: This is the red wine of beers.  Boozy and fruity, with a rich yet smooth palate.  Alcohol is pretty forward, so Ill have to age a bottle for a year or two and compare.

Pours a deep, deep burgundy...almost like wine, no head, some sediment. Aroma is much like a port wine. Smooth across the tongue, gets you on the back sides with some sweet, bitter wine taste...nice. The taste is quite complex and impressive. Me likey.
Like it, dont love it. The high alcohol content comes out in this one which I like, but its deeper and darker than I like a quad beer to be.
Bottle from Alko. Originally rated on 16.7.2010. Nice, complex and quite strong trappist with notes of exotic fruits. Alcohol burns through a bit too much.
Bottle into its respective glass at Cafe Deco in Antwerp.  Black with a creamy yellow/brown head.  Light and sweet aroma.  Lovely creamy taste, but with body, and refreshing despite being 11.3%.

33 cl bottle @ Gastropub Tuulensuu, BBE 29.12.2015
Very strong, spicy and rather unique aroma has some coriander. Some well-aged fruits too. Rich flavour has the same old fruits and overload of coriander with some other spices too. A bit sharp on alcohol with these non-aged bottles. My all-time favourite!
Bottle, pours dark, smell is alright bit of nuts, currants. Taste is of a dark fruit. Alright beer, Easy to drink.
yeast aroma. yellowish pour with big head and lotsa yeast floating around. yeast and some raisin flavour. very thin mouthfeel. very overrated IMO. good beer, but not a great beer.

After being blown away by the 8, it was time for the 10.  Pours darker than the 8, a deep mahogany with a really full head for a quad.  Nose, again like the 8, gives me a fantastic scent of apple cider, with raisons, molasses and a bit of booze apparent as well.  The flavor reflects these notes.  Theres a nice sweetness here and booze is only reflected slightly on the tale end.  Im just amazed at the lively carbonation Rochefort pulls off with this style.  So often, a delicious quad is ruined by the absence of carbonation, but not this one.  It has a full mouthfeel and is just remarkably well-crafted.  I think the Belgian brewers have it figured out: craft only a few recipes, but craft them incredibly well.

Appearance: Murky, Opaque dark brown with thick tan head
Smell: dark fruit, grape-fruit, molasses syrup, candied sugar and subtle scents of alcohol
Taste:  Sweet Toffee, fig, raisin, plum, date, Caramel and dark grape
Mouthfeel: Rich, Full-bodied, smooth and low carbonation
Drinkability: Very good beer. Almost perfect and ideal for special days with cold weather
Bottle. Reddish brown colour with white head. Sweet aroma. Heavy fruity flavour.

What?  I never rated this before??  This really is one of the best beers in the world.  The first thing that strikes you is the unique aroma.  Its banana and clove but unlike other beers.  The color is dark brown.  Not mahogany, not black, but a soil color that masks this beers specialness.  It does pour with a 2 finger head but it thins soon enough to allow you to take a sip.  The taste is elegant like a cognac but as drinkable as any beer.  Its aged perfectly.  Highly alcoholic and full bodied but not boost.  Just nice.  Malty richness and a mouthful of proprietary yeast make this very tasty.

Appearance - Rochefort 10 is very dark and hard to see through at all. Pours with very little head (probably one half a finger). Some yeast specks floating around at the bottom of the glass that I poured it into.

Smell - The smell of the beer is quite sweet and full bodied. I smelled raisins, dates, slight coffee smell and plums. Slightly malty aroma. 

Taste - The beer initially hits the palate with a faint, mellow sweetness that transitions into almost a coffee/caramel taste near the end of the sip. Cannot really taste the alcohol content in the beer, which to me is a good thing.

Mouthfeel - Pretty heavily bodied. The beer was very smooth though and pleasing.

Overall - This beer was quite good. It was not as good as a Rochefort 8 that I had, but it was still exquisite. I prefer the sweetness of the Rochefort 8 over this beers slight coffee taste (as it transitions to the back of the mouth). Overall a good beer that I would try again (if there werent any Rochefort 8s available).
from whole foods from whole foodsfrom whole foodsfrom whole foodsfrom whole foods

UPDATED: FEB 24, 2012 Bottle.  Pours a beautiful dark brown/black; not completely opaque as you can see lots of visible carbonation and sediment.  Huge foamy tan head.  Aroma evolves quite impressively: chocolate, candied sugar, bubble gum, dark fruit, yeast, a hint of alcohol.  Taste is slightly spicy, with dark fuit.  Warming mouthfeel with an appropriate amount of carbonation.  I had very high expectations for this beer and it has definitely lived up to the hype.

Phenomenal beer. Pours dark brown with a reddish/purple hue. Extremely complex flavor/aroma. Caramel toffee with dried dark fruits, figs, dates, prunes, raisins. Alcohol well hidden. Truly exceptional.

Pours smooth with a light eggshel head that fades somewhat quickly. Amber brown and glowing maroons peer out the body. Pretty as hell. Aroma is soft and warming with plums, dried fruits, soft sticky malts and caramel pudding. Yuuuum. Flavors mimic with more of a sticky toffee and caramelized fog character on a surprisingly drinkable body. This is a masterpiece.

Excellent! Dark Brown brew with purple reddish color.  Has a nice head with good lacing.  The aroma is complex with hints of fruit.  The flavor is as complex as the aroma. It hints of chocolate and caramel but has the hints of grapes or wine that leaves an incredibly smooth finish.  Probably the best beer I have had to date.

Bottle.  Pours a very dark brown with a slight reddish hue around the edges.  Somewhat thin, but sturdy tan head.  Aroma has notes of figs and plums along with sweetness and a touch of dark chocolate and alcohol when swirled around.  Flavor is fantastic and complex with some similarities to a port wine.  The 11.3% is not as noticeable as you might expect.  Nice lingering aftertaste with a bit of sourness in the finish.
Quads are one of my favorite and Rochefort 10 blew me away.  Taste is sweet, with hints of fruit, caramel, and malt with a smooth finish.  The best beer I have had to date!
Belgian Quads are my preferred beers, and I go back and forth between this and the St. Bernardus as my favorite.

Received this beer as a gift from graduating students. Poured into my trappist glass. Colour is a dark brownish red. Nice tan head. Aroma was of dried fruit, and sweet malt. Flavour is also malty. It has a very nice trappist Belgium flavours and aromas, one of the best ive had. Overall a great beer, and a great gift!
Love the colour, nice brown with some ruby-red shining though when held against the light. Tastes a bit alcoholic, very sweet. I like the lighter rochefort beers better.

UPDATED: JAN 30, 2013 Take 2 Bottle from Tomlinsons, Inverness [300113]
 I return to this beer after another 1000 or so rates. I was worried I might not like it as much. No way - its still #1, but the Pannepot Grand Reserva is a close second....must open the Westy 12 soon.....Just phenomenol 9/4/10/5/19 4.7

Appearance is dark brown-amber with golden amber edges on glass. Pours with off white head that dissipates to a thin layer. Aroma is exceptional and complex - raisins soaked in alcohol with gentle fruit cake spices, sherry notes, hint of roast malt, dark spice sugar. The flavour enhances the aroma,  so complex and interesting, everything is blended so well with just the right amount of alcohol. Each sip brings something new - I feel as though I am drinking something antique - reminds one of the whiff of resin off old furniture (its not in the beer - it gives a memory of it !). The carbonation is just right, the mouthfeel rich. The finish is complex, warm and smooth with spicy hops and fruity raisin - pure nectar. This beer is incredible, so beautifully crafted and so hard to describe in words, but so wonderful.  10/4/10/5/19 4.8 [240611]

This is as good as it gets.  Aroma of mince meat, chocolate notes, and figs.  Pours dirty brown with a big frothy head.  Tastes sweet of black cherry and dates.  Finishes with amazing complexity.  God bless the monks who made this.

Pours dark brown, coffe like colour with strong heavy head. Aromas of dark fruit, raisins and smoked figs. Sweet,powerfull taste, but alcohol cannot be tasted. Sweet finish. Heavy body, medium carbonation and creamy texture

pours a very dark brown.  aroma of dried dark fruit, toffee, caramel, and yeast.  pleasantly heavy and velvety  mouthfeel.  taste is very malty with hints of bourbon, dark berries, caramel, and a decent amount of alcohol. one of the more vinous beers ive had. absolutely outstanding

Pours opaque brown with a caramel colored head. Smells of belgian candied sugars, dates, raisins, and toffee. Taste sweet figs, raisins, dates, chocolate, toffee and belgian sugars. The alcohol is very apparent in the warming effect that Im getting. Mouthfeel is medium and the finish is sweet and effervescent.

As good as black. Lots of carbonation. Fizzy, dark tan foam. Smell of alcohol, and some bubblegum. Aroma of alcohol, coffee. Some sweet taste, bubblegum. Some properties of wine, maybe a bit cherry aroma. Liked #8 much better.

Pour is a dark brown with a large tan head.  Aroma is dark Belgian sugar with some dark fruit and alcohol.  Flavor is dark fruit to start some anise then comes a bit of earthy malt.  Finish has some spice and brown sugar with again some alcohol.  This is one of those beers that each sip brings something different.  Expensive for a 11oz bottle but a nice b-day gift to myself.

UPDATED: JAN 30, 2012 One of the best beers Ive ever had. It was practically flawless. Sweet, almost candied fruit flavors, with brown sugar, nice malts, beautiful light presence of alcohol. and just enough bitterness to balance it perfectly. Possibly the most balanced beer Ive ever tasted. Gorgeous from the poor all the way through to the finish. The finish is almost like toffee-covered nuts and despite the sweetness of this brew it has almost a freshness at the end. Great brew.

Murky/cloudy dark brown pour with a nice and creamy one finger sized head.  Aroma is of dark fruit, plum, raisin, candi sugar and some licorice.   Full bodied with an extremely creamy and smooth mouthfeel.  Flavor is a bit more muted than the aroma but its all dark fruit with a coupel of Belgian phenols coming through.  I found myself thinking "wow" after every sip... cant believe I waited this long to try this beer which is pretty readily available everywhere.
Deep burgundy coloured. Big aroma of plum, raisins,toffee some sweet malts and yeast. Very malty, velvety texture, very sweet, salty finish. A huge well balanced beer,

Being an uneducated peasant when it comes to ale I thought Id dive in at the deep end and try this one. Completely blown away. Such an abundance of flavours. Lingering aftertaste of spices and malt. This is probably my favourite beer ever. Get it down your gregory!

UPDATED: APR 5, 2012 Bottle. Poured a murcky brown/purplish color with very thin white head. Aroma was is sweet, strong with dark gruits, raisins, cherry, and malts. I detected hints of brown sugar and sweeter spices. The malts really come out when it hits the pallet. The texture is cabonated and creamy.

Bottle 33cl. Nice colour. Hints of toffee, caramel and sweet I cant place. Very soft and rich taste which also have hints of some dry fruit. This is my favourite trappist beer. Absolute great with a long finish.
I enjoy this beer b/c it is very balanced. Id like to try to 6 and 8 next.

Pour ruby/mahogany beige head good lace. Aroma plum, raisins, dark fruit, candy sugar, french toast. Taste sweet and tasty, plum, dates, raisins, candy sugar, brown sugar, caramel, toffee, bready, spice. MF medium rich body almost full with light airy carb that carries beer gently across your palate. Overall a game changer Belgian very good beer well brewed tasty stuff and very rich and flavorful well done.

Bottle split with mcberko. Pours murky black/red with a rich, creamy head. Aroma of plum, blackcurrant, raisin, toffee, mildly candied sugars. Flavour of plum, blackcurrant, raisin, booze - almost whisky-like, roasted malt, yeast. Really smooth and silky yet lively enough on the tongue to maintain presence. Beautiful.

Pours deep, dark, mahogany with a small light brown head. Aroma of plums, raisins, peaches and cream, berries, vanilla, and cake. The taste is very fruity and yeasty with sweet malts and a touch of hops and alcohol. Full bodied, mild carbonation and thick texture with a hint of  well blended alcohol. Beautiful brew, I wouldnt say this is overrated at all.

Found this beer to not quite live up to the hype.  Rich dark fruits on the nose and taste.  A bit sweet and boozy with a very smooth and thick mouthfeel.  Overall a very good beer but not as exceptional as some seem to think.
Very boozy and strong.  Raisins in taste.  This is one complex beer!  Overall Im not a huge fan of this style, but this was better than others that I have had.

a friend of mine/bartender recommended this beer to someone at a bar looking for something belgian and on the heavier side....a perfect match, but when the guy came back he said "yeah its not bad" as if it inspired nothing. my friend said to me "ive never heard that reaction to rochefort 10"  maybe bold belgians are not for everyone but this one is the archetype for the dark abt ale. yes to smooth viscous alcohol, caramel chocolate-heavy flavors lifted and lightened by perfect belgian carbonation. so i agree-its not bad at all.
Nice brew with a sweet aftertaste and smooth finish. Pours a very deep mahogany with a small light brown head.

Shared a bottle of this with, of all people my mother on her birthday.  Had a couple times before, but never rated.  This bottle was pretty aged, I had it for about 2 years and I dont think it was fresh when I bought it.

Pours dark purple, with light dancing carbonation and a TON of yeast.  Smells smooth and sweet.  Palate is very compelx, with dark and dry fruit and a lingering finish.  Theres a lot going on in every sip.  Very tasty.
Bottiglia da 330 ml, assolutamente la miglior birra che mi sia mai capitato di bere in vita mia, ma non è per tutti, essendo molto complessa e ricca..

[330ml bottle, Peckhams Stockbridge, Edinburgh] Deep brown beer with a peaky off-white head. Rich fruity aromas. Deep stone fruit on the taste, with dark malt and a hefty sweetness. Smooth and very well-balanced, almost vinous quality to it. Finish is very long and boozy. Great stuff [25102007]

Bottle served in a tulip. Pours dark amber brown in color with medium sized cream colored head. Complex, strong dark fruit aroma of raisin, plum, caramel, molasses, background vino, and musty funk. Sweet raisiny flavor. Medium body, oily-creamy texture, ultra long finish, malty, sweet, hot, warming finish. Not that Im helping anyone here with nearly 3,000 ratings, but... this is fantastic stuff.

The crown juwel of the Rochefort series. Ive had a bottle, not aged. I do have two bottles aging in my shed for almost six months now. So I guess Ill have to keep them hiding for myself for at least another 5 years. The bottle I had poured out a blackness itself. Dark beer, with a nice head on top and good carbonation going on. Only visible when glass in held in the light because the beer is really dark and murky. Aroma has cloves, grapes, berries, dark chocolate and coffee malts. Body is full round, with no rough edges. There is almost no alcohol present in the aroma nor the taste. Taste is sweetness accompanied by with a chocolate bitterness. This is something to enjoy for over an hour. Love it."

Finally tracked down the vaunted TR-10!  Indeed, an excellent brew with lots of dark fruit punch on the nose and tongue alike.  Pours a beautiful dark gold with persistent lacing.  Carbonation is lively.  High yeast notes.  I enjoyed this elixir, but not ready to vault it into the rating stratosphere.

Dark brown color, small head, silky texture. The beer is sweet and flavored. The high alcohol content is felt, but soothed by the fruity aromas. A taste of grapes/raisins and an aftertaste of coffee.
A fantastic beer that should be tried if you have the chance. Enjoy it in small sips, like a glass of fine wine.

Just as pretty as youd expect, hazy dark brown with an exuberant, everlasting top.  Smells sweet, but with a noticeable cherry fruitiness mixed in, a little booze as well.  Initially kinda tastes like sweet tea, full of caramel and a bitter edge, until a peppery, smoke-laced wave rushes in and evens things out.  The dry middle lasts for a beat or two before being replaced by a black cherry and bourbon fade, a wondrously slow, warm finish to a delicious beer.  (3/25/09)

Pours a rich dark brown into a trappist glass. The head was thick and solid, with silky lacing. The aroma was thick and pungent with light coffee, raisins, chocolate and spice. Flavors of sweet chocolate and dark fruits entice the palate, while the spicy and bitter undertones provide a wonderfully satisfying drinking experience. The scents and flavors went so well together with its overall complexity, its hard to describe it all in one breath. Simply one of the best beers ever made, and one of my favorites!

33cl bottle.  Poured a deep, dark brown with a two finger creamy tan head that quickly fades to a thin cap with sticky lacing all the way down the glass.  Aroma is complex with candied sugars that lead into dark fruits, raisins and plums.  Along with a slight black licorice note and a hint of cocoa.  The taste follows the nose with the dark fruits and sugary malts along with some light rum notes.  The licorice and cocoa peek through in the middle.  The alcohol starts to show through in the finish but is not overpowering.  Light to medium bodied and very smooth with perfect carbonation.  Well worth the price.

11.2 oz bottle. So my original intention was to drink this in a relaxed setting and really concentrate on the beer. However, circumstances provided that my brother and I each had a bottle in Madrid, at a standing table in a bar before heading to a Flamenco bar, so my memory rating is the best I can do. Pours a deep brown with a thick off white head. Very complex nose, lots of dark fruits, nuts, fresh and roasted, figs, raisins, plums, dark overripe fruits, a bit spicy, candi sugar. Flavor is just as complex with the dark fruits and candi sugar really bursting along with the delicate spices and brown sugar. More plums. prune, figs raisins all melding nicely to create a balance with the sweet doughy malts and  sweet bread. Finishes a bit spicy but well balanced and smooth. Medium to medium full body and a softer carbonation. Excellent beer

Starts with an odd "wet dog" aroma.  But gets insanely better from there.  Amazingly smooth, great brown sugar taste.  Very complex.  Definitely expensive but its price shows in how different and unique this is.

Bottle (33cl) from Vinmonopolet, Oslo. Inch-thick offwhite, fine-bubbled head, reducing to a stable thick film. Murky, chestnut brown colour. Staggeringly rich nose of raisin, fig, grape, molasses, malt - so well-blended its hard to discern individual aroma elements. Mouthfeel is very smooth - liquid and carbonation seemingly combine into a higher synthesis. Taste is sweet with dried fruits, perfectly balanced by a discreet acidity, bitterness and a hint of salt. Alcohol is quite hidden taste-wise, but manifests itself as a warming sensation. Long-lasting aftertaste of fruity malt.
Sampled the 6, 8 and 10 in the same session; have yet to encounter a beer that I preferred over this magnificently mellow and complex experience. Everything I want in a beer.

0,33 l. bottle from the supermarket. Bought to celebrate my rating # 100!Want this one to be something special.  Pours a dark brown colour with a small off-white/tan head that holds a small head, but does not leave much lacing. Aroma is a lot of dark fruits, raisins, plums, figs, currants, grapes, good caramel along with toasted bread, yeast, some chocolate, and brown sugar. Taste is a full-bodied combination of dark fruits, plums, figs, raisins, black currants, as well as chocolate, toffee, brown sugar, and caramel. No alcohol in the taste, but a warming feeling in the finish. A bit of sweetness, not much bitterness. Mouthfeel is medium bodied, creamy and a medium carbonation.  Long lasting finish with a returning recall of the taste. I rate this as high as the 8, but the 8 has the same qualities, but with less alcohol. A very rich, complex and delicious beer with a legacy.

Aroma: Fruity and complex: figs, raisins, strawberries, cherries, burned malt & caramel, hints of coffee & cocoa, sweet wheat, sirup, burgundy wine. The winey part is more explicit in the taste, as well as the coffee-cocoa. On the pallate its soo welvety smooth, but still with backbone and stamina.

Bottle. Dark brown, with off-white head. Aroma is a mixture of fruit-esters: figs, raisins, plums w. notes of straw- and raspberries. Faintly vinous. Velvety smooth without getting boring. Very well balanced. Full bodied and nice round after-taste.
Bottle. Pours purplish brown. Tan head. Nose/taste of dried fig, vinous grapes, dates, toffee, raisin, plum, black currants, dates and yeast. Warming alcohol in finish, but still smooth. Full body.
Smells of raisins, port and malt. Tastes of Raisins, port and delicious malt. Awesome beer
Bottle shared at de Paas, complex beer with flavors of raisin, malt , dark fruits and a honey sweetness. Very good balance
Bottle 2010 Vintage. Clear dark ruby red with minimal head. Very rich in both nose and mouth with plenty of raisins, sweet malt, port wine and alcohol warmth.
di colore nero con schiuma crema pannosa. Aroma di malto, uva passa, frutta rossa, alcool ben presente. lunga e persistente.

tastes of raisins, it has nice lacing, thin tan head and plenty of nice malt flavor. better as it warms up. decanted and let sit for ten minutes per beer captured. picked up a bottle at applejack in lakewood co
Bottle. Pours dark cloudy brown with a medium off white head. Aroma is mollasses, caramel, cocoa, plums, and figs. Flavor is figs, grapes, and nutmeg. Medium sticky mouthfeel.

UPDATED: SEP 10, 2013 Almost no head, bit fine color
Deep nose  with prune, sugar, herbs,
Medium body And fine length
Candy, chocko, fruitcake

It smell like plums and pixie dust (sugar candy). Dark brown and cloudy with brown head. I am new to this style and currently not a huge fan, but the taste is very sweet and medium sour. Burny carbonation at the end. Overall I would say that if you like sweet then you will like this. Try it , but for a newbie you will not have a developed a palate required for it.
It is not possibe to describe this beer properly. Just amazing taste. Really one of the best.
Kind of a sour taste to it. I bought this bottle, along with a bottle of 8. I preferred the 8.

Pours totally black with a beautiful tall head which gives perfect lacing. Aroma is as about as complex as can be. Malt, dark fruits, alcohol. The taste is even better which is also very complex with the fruitiness coming out most, raisins, prunes and other dark over ripe fruits. Taste also has roastiness to it with some caramel and a beautifully strong warm alcohol holding it all together. Feels beautifully smooth and soft in the mouth. Seriously, just wow. One of the worlds great beers! I only have one complaint... there isnt enough in the bottle
Una delle migliori birre al mondo! Non posso dare tutti i voti al massimo in quanto spero che possa esista qualcosa di migliore anche se ne dubito! Un capolavoro.

I wont waist your time rewriting all the reviews because they are the almost the same and i agree with them. The one thing I noticed that people are not pointing out was how chunky the sediment was!  As with most bottle conditioned beers such as Rochefort 10, I drink one without the sediment and one with the sediment. The only difference I noticed was the finish was longer with the sediment. But typical Belgian beer, amazing and strong

UPDATED: AUG 14, 2015 Pours pretty much black. Slightly darker than R8. Big foamy off white head. Nose is pretty amazing. Has notes of dried fruit, raisin, prune, yeast, bit of chocolate, but there is an added dimension that R8 doesnt have. Its sherbert, citrous, apples. Its making my tongue tingle. Taste is surprisingly smooth and balanced. Lots of dried fruit, some roasted grain, yeast, but also fresh fruit, plums, some citrous. Finish is quite beery. Sweet malt, hops, fruity. Not easy to drink this stuff though, really potent. 4.3 Re-rate 14/08/2015 Tasted in comparison to a 2 year aged Westy 12, and I have to say this blows it away. Very dark murky brown cloudy looking beer with a thin off white head. Nose is stunning. Sherberty, candy sugar, dried fruit, plum, prune, raisin, spice, coriander, nutmeg, rye bread and bread dough. This is on another level. Taste is dried fruit, prune, plum, raisin, then coriander, spice, heavy black rye bread, candy sugar, grass. An Arabian wave of spices, sweetness, breadiness and tangy hop. The sherbert character is just phenomenal. 4.8

UPDATED: JAN 25, 2012 Fantastic bier. Dark brown, almost black colour with an amazing head. Complex and very rich aroma with alcohol, earthy tones, roasted malt, dried fruit etc. Taste is full and very complex with an amazing bittersweet, light yet full quality. Only wish it was a bit richer in the mouth but still a great, great beer. My favorite Belgian and one of my all-time favorites.

UPDATED: NOV 1, 2013 Aroma: Very complex this one...chocolate, toffee, dried fruits, black licorice, booze, spices, slightly yeasty, fresh bread, candied sugar, vinegar too, kinda like the R8 but not as strong as the other scents are overtaking it. 

Appearance: Deep brown-red thats so close to black...the beer looks absolutely gorgeous with a light, creamy head that takes its time sitting there, eventually leaving some complex lacing on the glass.

Taste: Sweet, spicy syrupyness, candied sugar, spices, black liquorice, pepper, dried apricots and other fruits. The finish is slightly bittersweet, but like no other beer Ive tried. Booze integrates well.

Palate: Prickly carbonation, not as full a mouthfeel as you would think making this very easy to enjoy, Balance superb.

Overall: Phenomenal beer. Full (and a huge variety) of flavour, easy to drink, strong, complex, ages very well...could go on forever. Complexities of 8 and this are similar though this is more alcohol driven and stronger in flavour.

UPDATED: DEC 18, 2013 Dec 2013 update fresh bottle: same as below, just a few more details... Taste is heavy sweet light bitter, mouthfeel quite creamy with low carbonation. Pours brown with thick creamy head and lots of lacing. Still wow!!

Almost certainly one of the best small handful of beers in the world. Wow, what a complex beer. I get dark fruit (plums, maybe raisins), malt (heavy bread). The alcohol backing is well hidden. 
Saved this one for my 100th rating, and man am I glad. Wish I had bought more!

Wooow, when drinking this beer I am in heaven. It has so many good flavors. I have tried hundreds of different beers, but this is the best !
If you love dark beers, just like me, this could be your  favorite to :)
Trappistes Rochefort 10 is the perfect beer ! :)

I was over eager when I opened the 330 ml bottle. I poured and sipped immediately right from the fridge (about 39 degrees F), After realizing that was not the thing to do I let it warm to about 49 to 50 F. WOW!!!!! Poured a dark brownish red with a very nice head that left quickly but left a nice lace on the top. Smelled wonderfully of dried fruits and toasted malts, yum. The the warmer taste was everything the aroma promised and MORE!slight hints of alcohol well covered and balanced with the fruits and carmel notes. Felt med. thick and creamy leving the taste of this ale in the mouth until it was rinsed out with water. WoW cant say enough good things about this except try it.

Doesnt get much better than this, for this style.  Extremely complex, malty, dark fruits, earthy and warming.  Velvety smooth.   Only surpassed by the Westy12, but for the money and availability, this is unbeatable.

Appearance - Black opaque body. Lots of sediment visible when held to light. Small off white head with low retention.

Smell - Slight vinegar scent and pronounced dark fruit sweetness.

Taste - Plenty of complexity. I was seriously caught off guard with this beer. This is the most highly regarded beer (according to BA) that Ive had so far. Very hidden alcohol.

Mouthfeel - Lively on the tongue, despite the general lack of carbonation. Full body.

Overall Drinkability - Highly drinkable. Very smooth, especially considering the ABV.

Serving type: bottle
From beerseek imported ratings, no comment given in original rating. Need to rejudge.

Bottle. Pours murky dark brown with hints of mahogany.  A large amount of khaki head dissipates quickly at first, with a thin film lingering throughout. Moderate lacing.  Nose is leather, anise, toffee, and earth.  Tastes are super complex, with toffee and anise notes giving way to dried fruit and port wine flavors with a spicy alcohol note. finish lingers with hints of oak and vanilla. excellent!
molasses, caramel, vinegar, plums, figs.  amber color with light head. molasses, apples, pears, caramel.  light bodied

Pours a dark, murky brown with a medium foamy tan head. Aroma is dark fruit, cherries, malt and licorice. Flavor is rich and complex with hints of plums, cherries, dark fruits, malt, licorice, coffee, caramel, raisins, and some alcohol. Medium body with medium carbonation and chewy mouthfeel with high alcohol content masked nicely. Great brew.

Bottle; dark cloudy brown with red hues and a moderate tan head; aroma-complex: dark fruits, molasses, caramel, spices; taste-mild sweetness and carbonation, medium bitterness. What a beer! Much improved version of #8.

Pours a murky brown with a small white head. Lots of lacing. Smell of cherries, plums, tart and dark fruits. Taste is cherries, flowers, and yeasty fruits. Palate is medium body with alcohol on the taste. Overall a
UPDATED: NOV 12, 2012 Birra spettacolare, color tonaca di frate, caramello al naso, spezie, gusto complessissimo. Imbattibile.

Bottle purchased from liquor store. poured into weizen glass. A noticeably thick pour, with a whipped creamy head, caramel colour, and sustained longevity. the aroma is robust, earthy, and malty. appearance is, opaque, murky and rich. full palate with a creamy consistency. the taste is bitter, lasting, full bodied with undertones of licorice, cloves, malt and chocolate. a pleasantly lingering almost metallic finish which warms the palate. The Trappistes have once again achieved contact with the celestial hosts and the divine realms

Great, beer... extremely tasty!  The only complaint is that I dont think I could have too many of these.  Very sweet, but extremely complex.  Strong flavours of plum, raisin, etc.  Definitely a treat!

UPDATED: APR 9, 2011 A nice amount of carbonation and a complexity that I havent come across much, with notes of licorice, coffee, chocolate, and malt and a thick, almost chewy consistency.  Certainly a unique and impressive brew, but the alcohol content is a bit much and takes away some of the enjoyment for me.
Pours a nice dark reddish brown with almost no head aroma is very light chocolate and dried fruit. The taste is a little dry with bitter notes and raisin sweet finish.

UPDATED: JUN 30, 2011 Appearance is very solid. Pours a creamy thick head that has a nice texture. Disappears very slowly. The liquid is dark brown/black and looks thick and pure, very strong looking. The aroma is really complex as expected. caramel, raisin, bread, a bit of chocolate and coffee, roasty, list could be continued very extensively. many strong beers have the quality of leaving different taste sensations a bit at the back and bringing out the flavours with the strong alcohol. this does not mean that it tastes highly of alcohol, but flavours have a unique way of coming out when the percentage is high. very nicely fused into. the palate is great, a very creamy texture of the liquid brings out everything very well. just sits very well in the mouth.  A very excellent trappist, right at the top with orval and others.

UPDATED: DEC 7, 2011 Black body with a light brown head. Aroma is strong and amazing: plum, cherry, chocolate. Palate is perfectly balanced, as well as the incredible flavour: fruity and sweet in the right amound with a hint of chocolate, alcohol is very well hidden. A true masterpiece. (10/5/10/5/20)
Pitch dark brown body with a light brown head. Extraordinary strong complex aroma with honey, caramel, dark fruits, chocolate, spices, licorice. Very smooth and perfectly carbonated palate. Incredibly full and complex flavour with chocolate, honey, cereal, plum and blueberries. It deserves the perfect score.

UPDATED: NOV 9, 2011 Got a few bottles of this and I break them out whenever Im in the mood for a great Quad.  I opend the less then 12oz bottle and poured into a glass a murky brown color, the darkest of the big trappist beer.  I smelI is slightly boozy and sweet yeast.  The taste is strong upfront but super sweet and fruity on the end.  This one is my favorite of the trappist collection.  super well balanced and a great over all brew that Im glad I can get it easy.
Ive said it before, Im generally not a fan of belgian beers but this is one of my all time favorite beers.  Very smooth, malty, and fruity.  Alcohol shows up in the aftertaste but not too much.

Wonderful beer, with the plum, raisin, and fig notes very apparent on the aroma along with the heavy malts. Pours a dark brown color. Taste is very similar to the aroma with some alcohol coming through. The finish is pretty nice and it fades off with the heavy malts and the caramel flavor fighting the alcohol.

Im not sure why I had never tried this beer, but I finally did. I think my expectations were too high or I just drank one that was too new.

Poured from a bottle into a goblet, served with yeast (oops). Beer is brown and hazy and some particulates floating in it (my fault its the yeast). Forms a nice thick off white / yellow head that falls away leaving lacing on the glass. Carbonation high. So far so good.

Aroma is a mixture of sweetness and carmel with alcohol and a ton of malt. I think I can smell a slight roast in there as well. Not sure though. Smells pretty good.

Beer is big bodied, no aftertaste at all. There are no hops to detect and bitterness overall is really mild. There is a tinge of alcohol and solvency in the front of the beer and that really disappoints me. Beer gets better and solvency is lessened as the beer warms slightly. Mouthfeel is OK and drinkabiliy is good. I can see how people like this beer but it has not been my favorite Quad.

Serving type: bottle
Great cereal and carmel with dark fruit aroma.. Fantastic and complex taste of deep malty sugars with dark fruits and deep fig flavor. Lived up to the expectations.

Bottle at Dr Jekylls. Dark brown, blacks closest cousin, with a big beige head. Looks just great! Strong aroma of sweet malt and spices. Taste of raisins, alcohol, yeast.. Good long finish with spices staying in my mouth.

Poured from 11.2 oz bottle.  The beer poured with a nice dark brown body and a soft frothy head.   The aroma is distinctly Belguim, a very desiriable quality for a quadrupel trappist ale.  This full flavored beer was evenly balanced and  the 11% ABV is very well disguised.  This beer will catch you off guard with how smooth it is considering the high ABV.  The hint of raisin is one of the notes that comes through this complex beverage.  The smooth aftertaste is the exclamation point that makes you clear out a space in your refrigerator for more!!!

This beer just comes alive with every sip. I love the taniness on the back of the tongue, the complex sweetness, and the sweet but not overpowering finish. I was prepared to be overwhelmed by too much sweetness, but I found it just right for this type of beer. This is one of my favorite beers ever.

Very Somth Beer with no biter after teast.  It has an nute brown teast. I allways highly recommend the Trappiestes Rochefort 10.  This is not a hoppie beer.  If you like IPA do not drink this beer you will nolonger like IPAs

UPDATED: APR 14, 2016 Cereal aroma. Dark Brown hazy with precipitate. Medium dry not very intense finish of bitterness. I guess its made for the malty aromas and taste. I am not impressed. Rerated 10/10-13 @ home. Still quite a lot of malty bitterness. Some dark prune rum notes and flavours.

UPDATED: DEC 2, 2012 Some plum flavours and dried fruits. Tastes quite Christmassy with a thick treacle like taste
Update 2/12/2012 Dark in colour, tastes of port, spice and sherry, overall strong and complex and very rich

(Poured into a Rochefort calice. Thanks to Brother Yan, Trappist  on his spare  time!) The liquid reveals a dark brown robe. The head is creamy and foamy  and  resists somewhat. Nose  is  a complex tangle of dark fruit, ripe plum, Belgian chocolate, black bread, toffee and licorice that evokes fine most beautiful decadence. In the mouth, the excitement alive is a suave  and   brilliant dance which carries richly malty flavors, fabulously fruity, soft and undoubtedly affected by the fullness of silence that resonates within the walls of the abbey. The finish is a great jubilation for the senses. Perhaps it is even the key that opens the door to the garden of delights or one that can remain locked forever in the shelters ultimate subversion**********(Dégusté dans un superbe calice de la brasserie.  Merci au Frère Yan, trappiste à ses heures!!)  Le liquide dévoile une robe brune foncée.  La tête mousseuse est bien crémeuse et résiste quelque peu.  Au nez, un enchevêtrement complexe de fruits foncés, de prunes mûres, de chocolat belge, de pain noir, de toffee et de très fine réglisse qui évoque la plus belle des décadences.  En bouche, leffervescence vivante est une danse suave et savante qui transporte des saveurs richement maltées, fabuleusement fruitées, moelleuses et sans aucun doute touchées par la plénitude du silence qui résonne entre les murs de labbaye.  La finale est une grande jubilation des sens.  Peut-être est-ce même la clé qui ouvre la porte du jardin des Délices ou bien celle qui permet de rester, enfermé à tout jamais, dans le refuge ultime de la subversion.***********(Pil s Calico Rochefort. Vďaka Brother Yan, Trappist na jeho voľnom čase!) Kvapalina odhaľuje tmavo hnedé rúcho. Hlava je krémová a penivé a odoláva trochu. Nos je zloitý prepletenec tmavého ovocia, zrelých sliviek, belgickej čokolády, čierny chlieb, karamelová a sladkého drievka, ktorá evokuje jemný najkrajie dekadencia. V ústach, vzruenie ivý je zdvorilý a brilantné tanečné ktorý nesie bohato sladovej chuti, úasne ovocná, mäkká a nepochybne ovplyvnená plnosťou ticho, ktoré rezonuje vnútri múrov klátora. Povrchová úprava je veľký jasot pre vetky zmysly. Mono je to aj kľúčom, ktorý otvára dvere do záhrady poteenie, alebo ten, ktorý môe zostať navdy zamknutý v útulku konečným podvracanie.

Bottle at CASK pub & kitchen. Got this on MagicDave6s recommendation, and glad I did. Pours a dark cola, with a small off white/beige head. Aromas of roasted malt, plum, dark fruits, cherry and spices. Taste of plum, roasted malt and some spice. Quite a sweet finish, with a bit of heat, but not in an overbearing way. Fantastic!
Dark brown with hints of caramel and dark fruit. Smooth finish with a spicy after taste. I would highly recommend this to a friend.

UPDATED: NOV 20, 2013 [email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */: looks very dark brown, almost black, there is very little head to speak of but it has some nice lacing, it smells or raisins, coffee, chocolate & alcohol, strong & nice smell, the taste is very rich & complex, has dark fruits, coffee, sugar, black bread in it & finishes of with noticeable but complimenting & nice hint of alcohol, bit on the thicker side with some nice carbonation, always enjoy this one, great beer, deserves its reputation & really opens up when it gets a bit warmer, you can safely drink this one even at room temperature, it is even best at near room temperature /// /// been having this again from time to time @ room temperature, it is just such an incredible mess of rich dark fruits, bread, raisins, figs, dates, bread, Belgian yeast, sugar and quite some alcohol and available at your local supermarket at a damn fine price this is incredible, rating this higher. - on par with the better RIS as far as the enjoyment goes but easier to have

Bouteille de 33cl. Produit mythique et/ou mystique brassée par les Pères Trappistes de lAbbaye de St-Remy. La bière est brune, peu de mousse est présente. Le nez offres de délectable arômes dépices, de fruits noirs, de sucre candi, de chocolat. En bouche la bière est tout à fait agréable, ronde, lalcool est peu présente, elle est très longue en bouche. Cette bière se boit tout seule, elle est tout à fait délectable.

UPDATED: APR 30, 2011 Poured out of the bottle into a Trappist glass. Pours a rich, dark mahogany color with a thin off-white head. I tried to keep as much of the sediment out towards the end of the pour, but I still got a little. Aroma is very rich combo of dark fruit, caramel, and a port-like booziness. Flavor is rich and complex, but not over-powering. Well balanced. Flavors of dark fruits, chocolate, bready malt, and alcohol, but again not over-powering. Velvety mouthfeel with slight carbonation. Overall, every bit as good as Ive been told. Ill be getting a few more of these for the private collection!

I think I had tried this once before but never a full bottle. It was very early in my beer drinking career.

11.2 oz bottle. 260814 printed on it.

It pours a dark, deep brown with a slight hue of red. There is a lot of sediment. The head is foamy and off-white/tan with tons of dirty looking sediment. It looks rustic and I like it.

The smell is so great. It just smells like an amazing dessert with mainly dark fruits, kirsch, sherry, loads of caramel, sweet dark bread, some cocoa, perfumey floral notes, rum toffee, spices, and port. It is just a intoxicating perfume.

The flavor is nearly as good. It has a huge kirsch/sherry/port flavor to it with that alcoholic kick, but it is like you are drinking a 18% liqueur clocking in at just over 11%. There is some nuttiness that comes through more-so in the taste that blends with the alcohol , bready malt,and dark fruit notes for a luscious decadent dessert flavor. The caramel also comes though with some sweetness on the back end.

It has an intriguing liqueur presence about it that takes it to a high level. The mouthfeel is smooth but with a prickle of carbonation.

A divine brew.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 03-10-2011 05:07:54

Dark, almost completely opaque, rich pour, with a fair amount of particulate, and a nice two finger head. The aroma and palate are very rich and deeply fruity, sometime with a hint of sweetness, and with a wonderful cozy warming sensation during the after taste from the high ALC.

Dark brown with an off-white head. Aroma is roasted malt, dried fruit, yeasty and spicy. Flavor is rather sweet. Sweet and spicy finish with warming alcohol. Soft, very smooth and full-bodied. Brilliant. 110311

Pour is a dark brown, with a small white head. Nose is of sweet sugary dark fruits. Taste is incredibly smooth, through different sugars, plums, raisins, a little bread flavor and just the right mouthfeel to bind it all together.

UPDATED: FEB 19, 2012 Black body and frothy light brown (and long lasting) head. Aroma has cheese, yeast, coffee, fig. First taste is fairly dry with smooth hops and cream. Foamy mouthfeel also brings the alcohol. Aftertaste has more sweetness.  (3,25 EUR, 33cl bottle) (Rating re-indexed)

Bottle. Pours a brown almost black color with not head. Strong dried fruit aroma with slight booze. Flavor accentuates the plum flavors with strong raisin and dark brown sugar flavors. Winey aftertaste and moderate carbonation. Awesome beer.
UPDATED: APR 12, 2011 dark pour with minimal head. chocolate and coffee aroma. taste is very alcoholic and expands on the flavours in the aroma. good but not as preferable to the 6 and 8.

Has a light bit of aroma, its a dark brownish/purplish color.  Very small bit of cream colored head.  Has a rich Belgian flavor, definitely can taste the alcohol.  Goes down pretty easy, but a little pricey for what you get.

UPDATED: MAR 10, 2011 Dark fruits and oh so creamy. This is one of my new favorite beers. It reminds me of when I was a child out on a school picnics or field trips as a toddler enjoying those little raisin boxes my mother would pack in my lunch. This beer stands on its own. I find it to be very full bodied and very complex. I think I will continue to try this beer over and over throughout the rest of my life. This beer makes me escape into my own mind for a moment and brings me to an unadulterated decadence  of confounded love and respect. I feel like I am ascending towards the clouds were I will rest with no worries as my servants serve me  a variety of exotic fruits off the vein. I am weightless and in need of an innumerable amount of gorgeous goddesses. I think I will walk about  without garments  for the rest of the day.

Dark cider/brown color; Medium slightly creamy body; Aroma of sweet malt, yeast, rich dark fruit, brown sugar, & spice; Flavor of sweet malt, yeast, caramel, dark fruit (notably plums & cherries), raisons, and some toffee; Slight alcohol at the finish; Very nicely balanced and quite complex; Wow - excellent brew.
Pours dark reddish brown to black with thick foamy tan head and lacing.  Notes of raisins and vinegar.  Taste is on the sweet side, like a dessert liqueuer, akin to treacle tart.

UPDATED: JUN 2, 2011 Bottle from RealAle.com. It pours deep murky brown with lively carbonation and a thin tan head. The nose is dark chocolate, caramel, liquorice, yeast and obvious alcohol. The taste is dark chocolate, caramel, wood, tobacco, leather, earth, liquorice, rum and raisin ice-cream, currant and prune, with a long, boozy, slightly sweet finish. It reminds me a lot of boozy fruit-cake. The complexity, balance and depth of flavour are the reason why this beer is an absolute classic.

Pours a very sticky mahogany with a creamy tan head. Big, sweet malt with dark fruits in the nose. The taste is very complex. Butterscotch, sweet malt, dark fruits, a peppery and alcohol bite in the very dry finish. Its huge, smooth, and incredibly complex. I do get some of the 11.3% ABV, but not as much as expected.

The first time I had this, it was cloyingly sweet. Its still rather sweet this time, but not nearly as intrusive.

This is not a beer to chug, its one to savor and try to figure out.

I dont know if Id go with best beer ever, but its quite good and undeniably unique. A must try.
The alcohol in this beer might be a little strong... other than that, its mighty fine.

Excellent.  Aroma of carmel and molasses.  Dark hazt brown with thin tan head.  Taste is very complex.  It is sweet with nice alcohol note.  Molasses, carmel, raisinsare strong with a hint of licorice and roastiness in the finish.  Holds its alcohol well.  Great to sip at the end of the evening.
Dark brown in colour. Smells of dark fruits. Strong alcohol tase with fruits. Very nice beer.

Bottle to trappist glass.  Appearance is dark, murky brown with a brownish white head.  Smell is caramel and belgian yeast, burnt sugar.  Taste is sublime - rich, dark caramel, almost a brown sugar flavor.  Very rich and creamy.  No taste of booze for me.  Very creamy, almost like drinking velvet or silk.  Finish is warm and pleasing.  This bottle was just over a year old.  By far, the finest brew Ive had to date, but the price is hideous ($6.99 an 11.2oz bottle).

Dried fruit and chocolate on the nose. Fully flavoured and more of the fruit and nut bar on the palate. It finishes quite bitter with perhaps a hint of liquorice. Is the bitterness created by the yeast used or did they use coriander?

Poured dark with a golden brown head that surprisingly quickly dissipated. The rich, almost caramel like flavor stays with you longer then some trappistes beers. I can not give a higher score though as the palate was a bit too carbonated and bitty for me.

11.2 oz. bottle in a snifter, courtesy of my friends at Fishpaws in Arnold, MD.  I figured it would be good based on the hype, but this one is definitely worthwhile.  Pours dark brown with little head.  Strong malty caramel aroma with hints of chocolate and raisins.  Extremely complex flavors.  Surprisingly not as strong flavored as I thought it would be with such a high alcohol content.  Very smooth with little aftertaste.  Will definitely try again, as well as the 6 and 8 to compare.
This one had me excited.. $5.99 for 11.2 oz.. I was shocked.. then I tried it: Full-bodied, rich head, notes of blueberry and plum.  This is the best beer in the world!

Pours an opaque dark brown colour, with lively carbonation and a nice lasting white head. The sediment doesnt fall to the bottom of the glass, but stays in there floating. Smell is very complex. A bit like sour cherry, alcohol, spicy yeast, and above all, fruits.  The taste is very similar to the smell, but went above and beyond. Incredibly complex. Roasted and caramel malts, chocolate, fruits (plums, raisins, mildly spicy yeast and some tones of alcohol (surprisingly low for a beer with more than 11% alcohol content). 
Overall, one of the best quads out there!

UPDATED: AUG 26, 2011 Original rating, 2011-02-25, 8-3-9-4-17=4.1.
Dark brown, murky. Light brown head. Smells of raisins, plum, apple, caramel, yeast and alcohol. Overwhelming taste! Flavor is sweet with caramel. This must be the definition of a full bodied beer. The texture is almost oily, soft to lively carbonation. A bit too much alcohol. I guess Im not grown up yet, I actually think I prefer Rochefort 8
[33 cl bottle, from Vinmonopolet Oslo City, Oslo]


Re-rating, 2011-08-25, 8-4-8-4-16=4.0
Finally Im re-rating the biggest of the Rochefort brothers! I suspect that I will like it even better this time.
In a trappist glass this murky, dark brown liquid with its light brown head looks rather nice, so Appearance is up from 3 to 4. I get the same aromas as last time, and more. The dried dark fruits dominate, lots of alcohol, caramel, toasted notes, red port wine, brown sugar, sweet liquorice and some woody oaky notes. Wow. The taste is medium sweet, but isnt there also a tiny hint of bitterness, or is it the alcohol? The flavours are again dried dark fruits, burnt sugar, alcohol, and lots and lots of alcohol in the finish. And then, when I thought the flavours were going to fade away, a wave of sweet caramel hits me. Followed by hints of vanilla, or could it be the oak that I identified in the aroma? Full body medium+ carbonation, oily texture. A fantastic brew with layer upon layer of aroma and flavours, and with a very vinous feel, although I still think that the alcohol is a bit dominating. The beer lacks that more-ish feeling, one bottle is more than enough. By the time the bottle is empty the aromas start to become too sugary sweet and alcoholic, and the flavours get a certain cloying feel. I downgrade Taste from 9 to 8, and decrease Overall from 17 to 16. Strange, it ends up with the same rating as Rochefort 8. 
[33 cl bottle, from Vinmonopolet Oslo City, Oslo]

UPDATED: DEC 14, 2011 dark brown w/ ruby hue and steady bubbles
some tart yeastiness but more raisin and milk chocolate malt
med body and very fizzy
taste is kind of yeasty bread. need to spend more time with this.
This is a great beer. A special beer for sure. Its great to have a few of these. Belgium can be proud of this one. Almost like drinking fine wine but its beer. Great.

Every likes to love this beer, it is a great beer, very complex palate and nose. Dark fruits, plums, and butterscotch on the palate. My only issue with it is that he sweetness isnt balanced very well. Slow sips kind of fix this, i may be to critical due to this beers following however, recommended

pours murky brown with a thin but persistent creamy dark beige head. burnt caramel, sugar candy, and dark ripened fruits with  superb malty structure. great hops, long lingering finish - herbal. belgian micro-bubbly and a hint of spicyness from the yeasts. oily, full bodied. complex, classic and excellent!

UPDATED: AUG 17, 2012 Pours a slightly cloudy dark brown with faint ruby highlights and a smallish off white head that dissipates to a cap. Smells of dark fruit, burnt sugar, a bit of alcohol. Taste is fruity with a smokey funky taste. Some phenolic and bubblegum in there as well. The carbonation is a bit high. Body is thick, mouthfeel is bubbly/creamy. I loved the smell and taste of this one, but I thought the high carbonation did unfavorable things to the mouthfeel.

Nice thick beer. Great taste! The top product from the Rochefort Trappist brewery. Dark color, full and very impressive taste. Strong plum, raisin, and black currant palate, with ascending notes of vinousness and other complexities
What more can be said about this beer. One of the best beers on the planet and easy to find. Always in my fridge. Bravo monks.

Bouteille de 33 cl. Arômes de sucre candi, de pruneaux et de raisins secs. Robe brune aux reflets roux, quelques particules de levure, effervescence moyenne et peu de mousse. En bouche, on retrouve une belle complexité maltée (pruneaux, tire dérable, fruits confis) accompagnée de notes de sucre candi. La levure apporte des notes de pain et une légère touche épicée. Très longue finale relativement sèche et alcoolisée. Très bon, mais il ne sagit pas dun style que jaffectionne particulièrement.

11.2 oz bottle: Pours a dark brown/light black with a nice dark tan head. Incredible lacing and long lasting CO2 release. Aroma is complex with prunes, caramel malt, licorice and other less prominent smells along the 1.5 hour tasting period. Taste is very complex with dried fruit and caramel malts. Palate is very smooth, slightly oily, and thick. Great offering, deserving of ranking among the worlds best.

Pours the color of dark ice tea.  Great lacing.  Great aroma of dark fruit and malt.  Tastes of raisins, plums, and possibly some appricot.  Alcohol is very well hidden.  Bears like this are the reason I love Abt Quads.
Sweet aromas of plum, raisins, and cherry. Cloudy and dark brown color. Very smooth palate, leaving a smooth fruity, wine-like aftertaste. Very tasty!

Poured from a 375 ML bottle.  Pours an unfiltered chestnut brown.  Aroma is plums, raisins and spiced apples.  Taste is similar to the smell, very sweet.  Thick mouthfeel but not too syrupy.  A great quad.

Regular bottle, 2010: one of my favourites of all time, and it did not disappoint this time. aroma is what every belgium should aspire to, coats the teeth in delicious sweet yeast. lightly carbonated as you swirl it around your mouth, very fruity, but unbelievably balanced. taste just keeps on going, becomes more fruity, then you can finally taste some of the alcohol - but its great. still one of the best beers I have ever had.
UPDATED: FEB 14, 2011 Fantastic beer! The alcohol is very noticeable. Very similar to Gulden Draak, only a bit stronger and a slight bitter taste in the end. Overall A+ beer.
This beer is spectacular in every respect.  The alcohol content is a little strong but it is hardly noticeable while drinking.  Goes well with pretty much any dish.

This is considered to be the runner up to Westy 12? If it gets much better than this, I will officially take a sip and get a boner. This beer is fucking amazing. Ive never had anything so complex, yet balanced in my life. This is beyond beer complexity and layering, this is like a well executed Sauternes... you can walk in the fucking flavors.

UPDATED: APR 3, 2012 Bottle from Whole Foods, Orlando. I bought this beer as my first trappist. I can say that this is one of the best beer hands down that I have ever tried. Most notably, the smell was of heavy amounts of fruit and deeply satisfying. Taste was exquisite with strong prune, citrus, other indistinguishable flavors. If you come across one of these, dont hesitate to buy it.
Aroma is pears, peaches, malt, bready yeast. taste plums, raisins, berry fruit, malt bread, slight roastiness, spicy and very complex, layer by layer. full body, pleasant alcohol warmth.

UPDATED: NOV 29, 2011 Very complex brew, quite amazing. Dark fruits, high carbonation, warm alcohol feel. This is very enjoyable when the time is right. Youll get an array of flavors hitting you at once.very nice.

[email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */ bunker. hazy brown with red reflections, small brownish head. sweet aroma, not very strong. taste is dominated by alcohol, liquor and blueberries. full body, average carbonation and astringent finish.
Tasted at home. Smells, tastes and looks divine. Tastes of fruits with a smooth undertone. The alcohol is absolutely present but blends well together with the sweetness of the beer.

I think this is as close to perfection as Ive gotten from a quad so far.  In a bottle from Valumarket.  Pours dark brown with a light tan head.  Aroma is of bread, but complex.  Taste is amazing.  I get raisins, berries, and a bit of chocolate bitterness in the aftertaste.  A bit creamy on the palate.  Ive finished half the glass as Ive written this, trying to analyze its complexities, but the point is: this beer is awesome, get it.

UPDATED: DEC 19, 2012 33cl bottle from my cellar.
very yummy!  Great beer!  very tasty!
One of my Favourite beers, on the same way as the Westvleteren 12 but not so expensive here!! warm, liquer, good palate and better finish.

Bottle, at least two years of age on it.  Pours a dark chocolate brown with a large tanned beige head that falls off slowly.  Light booze notes up front with big ample chocolate and sweet malt behind it.  Medium bodied, some cola, toffee, caramel, touches of chocolate.  Big warming booze starts off early and grows quickly.  Dark fruits, and a lot more age on it than I would have anticipated.  Thins out a bit and is somewhat empty in the middle.  Finishes with some lingering alcohol (though smooth and not harsh at all), and a bit more toast and malt.
This may be it for me!!! Beautiful notes of caramel, figs, etc. Rich, warm, color. Gods beer.
Gateway.  sweet trappist malt.  Perfection!!!!!  Everytime I see this in the store i cant help but buy one.

Incredibly murky and could definitely see sediment.  Strong grape flavor which goes along with the warming alcohol in it.  Not an easy beer to define as far as taste profile because of its complexity but doesnt matter considering how great in every way it is.
Bière délicieuse à déguster avec amour. Son arôme est très prononcé par un taux dalcool élevé. Fort recommandée.

Perfect in every way. I hate giving out fives and probably do it too much but i couldnt stop smiling while i drank this. so complex. dark fruit and bread. full bodied. Leaves a aftertaste that is slightly astringent and sugary. Still trying to figure that part out. It makes my tongue feel kinda strange...not in a bad way. A lot of alcohol but not harsh. the best quad ive experienced. After being opened for a while, the aroma really opens. If you take a really deep breath, you get that hot alcohol. But the bread, nuts and banana is there. God i love this beer.

Pours dark amber with medium head and good lacing.  Aroma has hints of plum, caramel and raisin. Flavor is malt and biscuit. Also has a sweet start and finishes with a light alcohol flavor. overall a very complex and delicious beer.

Pours a dark brown with some ruby highlights. Medium beige head with good retention and moderate lacing.  Aroma is plum, raisin, sweet bread and caramel.  The flavor is remarkably complex, with sweet malt, biscuit, dried fruits and Belgian yeast.  Moderate alcohol burn and an otherwise clean finish.  Outstanding.

A - very dark red with brown
S - kind of peppery and bitter with some figs on the beginning
T - alcohol is not hidden very well to the body and the bitternes is kind of obtrusive. Sweet end on the tongue.
M - lower carbonation that I expected from this beer
D - not so much drinkable at all, but outstanding on 11,3%

Bottle. 11.2 oz. Pours murky brownish amber with specks of sediment suspended throughout. Thick, cloudy, fluffy beige head. Aroma of raisins, plums, figs, vanilla, dark chocolate, yeasty, doughy bread, roasted malts and traces of alcohol. Fuller bodied with a warm, slightly spicy, yet juicy and sweet mouthfeel. Bit of chewiness in the palate as well. Warming dark fruit sweetness in the finish. One of the very best Quadrupels currently produced. Centuries of tradition and care have yeilded this near-perfect Belgian ale.

Pours a milky brown with a beige head. Aroma is full of dark candi sugars raisins, cake and a nice breadlike yeast character. Taste is rich of caramel and biscuit, with a decent warming. Finishes chewy and rich.

Pours a cloudy banana bread brown with a small but dense foamy head for a belgian.  Light aroma of dark plum and brown sugar. Taste is bitter, woody, and full. Pretty sharp bite from the carbonation. A hint of alcohol, butter, and chocolate in the finish.

Pours a dark brown with a caramel colored head, good lacing.  Aroma holds anise, alcohol notes, yeast gives a basement hint to it all, very complex.  On the tongue its sweet, slightly bitter.  Palate is dry and malty, kind of chewy and thick.

dark reddish brown pour with decent tannish head, dissipates quickly. smells fantastic. like floral, dark fruit (plum, cherry).  great body, smooth/rich mouthfeel. the taste is quite alcohol-y, with like cinnamon, caramel, and then the smells.

good stuff. i would so have it again.
Bottle 33 cl. Poured dark brown in colour with beige head. Aroma is dark fruits as raisins and plums. Flavour is sweet, mostly plums.

Bottle / Trappist glass. Pours a dark brown with a one finger tannish head. Aroma of caramel, plums, raisins, and yeast. Taste is quite complex with raisins, plums, caramel, dates, jam, toffee and floral notes. Great, great beer!

This was love at first taste! Bottle 33 cl. Color: red/brown, hazy with beige/red head. Aroma: Cookie, Chocolate, drop, raisin, plum, alcohol. Initial flavor is lightly sweet with a bitter aftertaste. Also in the taste touches of Alcohol, drop, red candy cane, cinnamon, mocha. Texture is light creamy. Amazing beer!

Very dark redish brown beer,with a nice smoothy biege head.Smell roasted malt,creme brulee,caramell,rotten figs,alcohol,Pine,fresh wood.Strong amazing taste,sweet,roasted,caramel,light chocoolate,alcohol,roasted almonds,wood,dry figs,bread.Amazing palate,Long lasting finish.I found this beer so drinkable,I know that many people dislike the 11% alcohol.Not by me. i was drinking it and trying to stop of me not to drink it so fast.I think that God has listened the prayers of the monks and added sth in this beer.Δόξα ἐν ὑψίστοις Θεῷ καὶ ἐπὶ γῆς εἰρήνη ἐν ἀνθρώποι& εὐδοκία.

Bottle @ Home. Pours dark brown with a small offwhite head. Aroma of raisins, plums, dades, sweets malts, bit of caramel and brown sugar. Taste is massive with dark fruit, sweet roasted malts, hints of licorice, chocolate, yeast, warming alcohol finish allready at first sip. Full bodied, soft carbonation, silky mouthfeel. Awesome beer with balanced huge taste. 170111
Bottle. Pours red with a quarter inch cream head. Aroma is cherry and fig. Flavor is also cherry and fig with a little apple. Delicious.

Three-year old bottle aged by yours truly.
Date on bottle is the date of exipiration, exactly five years from the date of bottling. The date string reads 230113 (d/m/y), i.e. January 23rd, 2013. We deduce this was bottled in January 2008 and as such is now three years old.
Pours a deep dark brown almost black color with tiny light-brown head. The aroma is as strong and potent as ever, with a delicious bouquet of dark fruit engulfing the nose. Plums, raisins, and sweet dates. Such a beautiful, complex, assertive aroma... Surprisingly, after three years, carbonation is still very strong and prickles the tongue. The flavour seems to have lost a bit of its complexity. It has certainly softened over the years but still is an extension of the basic notes of the aroma... plums, raisins, dates. What is new is a less hidden taste of alcohol that has a distinct strong liqueur taste to it. Whether fresh or aged - Rochefort 10 is one of the best beers in the world.

Pours a very murky dark brown with a fairly large fizzy head. Head retention is impressive but leaves minimal lacing.

Aroma is a veritable buffet of dark fruits including raisins, plums, figs and grapes. There are notes of caramel accompanied by yeast, molasses and some brown sugar. It is an incredibly complex aroma that took me several minutes and a dozen sniffs to dissect and I still think there are more notes to uncover.

The flavor is a rich combination of the same notes in the aroma. I taste some chocolate that didnt stick out in the nose along with the raisin, plum, fig, grape, caramel, yeast, molasses, and brown sugar. You can barely taste the 11.3% ABV hidden amongst the flavors but you are reminded it is there with the pleasant warming feeling the brew brings as you swallow. I would describe the beers dominant flavor profile to be sweet rather than bitter. The mouthfeel is medium bodied and smooth with medium carbonation.

I find the beer goes done smoother and smoother as it warms to room temperature. A stunning combination of flavors are found in this beer.

I would again highly recommend this beer to any beer nerds out there. I am creating quite a streak of amazing beers this past week. Probably because I just decided to do this blog and have been buying all the superstars.

One caveat to note  this is a big beer. I wouldnt be serving this to any beer newbies. You need a developed appreciation for beer before you should tackle this giant.

12oz bottle served in a snifter poured a dark root beer brown with one finger of fizzy off white head and very little lacing except a white ring around the brim of the glass that lasted the duration. Nose was a complex bouquet of dates,figs,raisins,plums,malts the list goes on. This brew was very carbonated almost like drinking a soda except it has the ability to impair the senses rather quickly with a big abv. Taste was much like the nose with the exception of a delicious taste of honey and booze in the finish. this is a fine brew and the second time Ive had it. I could drink much more but think i would go broke seeing a case at a local distributor runs about two hundred and thirty dollars and that gives it kind of a salty taste.

Poured into a goblet.

4.0 A: Opaque dark brown color. Light brown head with good retention and lots of lacing.

4.5 S: Raisins, plums, dark cherries and a bunch of roasty toasty malts.

4.5 T: Tastes like it smells. Raisins, plums, dark cherries (dark fruits). Some roasted malt. Very good, but not significantly better than other quads Ive had.

4.0 M: Medium body. Fizzy carbonation from Belgian yeast. Somewhat creamy.

4.0 D: This is probably a little over-rated, but good nonetheless.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 04-25-2009 21:17:37

11.2oz bottle, best by May 16, 2012, this has about 3.5 years under its belt.  Served at cellar temp.  Pours murky brown with a fair fizzy-looking off white/tan head that holds a small cap but doesnt leave much lacing. Aroma is a lot of dark fruits, raisins, plums, figs, currants, grapes, good caramel along with toasted bread, yeast, some chocolate, a bit of molasses, candi/brown sugar.  Very good strength and I seem to pick up something new each time I take a whiff.  Flavor is a rich combination of dark fruits, plums, figs, raisins, black currants, as well as chocolate, toffee, brown sugar, caramel, molasses, toasted bread and yeast.  No real alcohol in the taste, but a touch of heat as it goes down.  A bit of sweetness, not much bitterness.  Mouthfeel is medium bodied, creamy and lush, medium carbonation.  Drinks all too well for such a big beer.  Its been a few years since Ive tried the 10 and to be honest I wasnt blown away the first time...felt it was a bit on the watery side but this bottle certainly isnt.  Very rich, complex and delicious.  Definitely holds up well to some age.

UPDATED: APR 2, 2012 Pours a deep raisin brown, leaving a creamy off white head with little retention. It already showing signs of amazing texture.. Aroma of dark stewed fruit.. Obvious plum, currents and a little fig. The higher abv not coming through on the nose. Palate is tremendous, succulant and creamy and smothering every taste bud. Flavours of sweet malt, dark stewed fruit that follows from the nose, balanced bitterness and nicely intergrated higher alcohol. For a hop head like myself its pushing me to try more trappist beers. Solid.

Side by side with the 8, still a gorgeous beer, great tan head, a bit darker than the 8, a very sweet aroma, caramel, and maybe a bit boozy. Raisins, some banana, roasty, its nearly double what the 8 was. It puts it to shame. First sip is sweet, a bit boozy, dark fruits, grapes, plums, banana. I might have poured it a bit cold. The sweetness grows on me, it seems like it changed with every sip. Great stuff. Top stuff. Excellent. Near Perfect.
Pours very dark reddish brown with a full beige head. Aroma of wine grapes with a dark fruit flavor like prune or plum.

Bottle. Dark brown with beige head. Aroma is very chocolaty, some dark fruit, burnt sugar, dark bread. Taste is also very chocolaty, prunes, roasted malt, caramel. Theres a lot going on in this beer. Warming alcohol. Sweet, rich, lovely. Dessert in a bottle.

UPDATED: JUN 23, 2013 9th October 2007  Warning! Early amateur rating! Thick dark beer. Mild carbonation. Complex beer. Subtle fruit, trace of root beer. Malt and biscuits. More malt. No bitterness or smoke notes. Very nice.19th June 2013Hazy amber - red beer. Pale cream coloured head. Palate is smooth and dry. Fine carbonation providing a little sting. Creamy malt. Mild bubblegum esters. Coca cola and a trace of lactose. Mildly bitter yeast. Little spice. Finishes semi dry.  Well joined up and tasty beer. But it aint the 2nd coming!
Bottle courtesy of Bierkrug - thank you Sir! One of my favorites before exposure to Struisse, Alvinne and DeMolen. Still, great balance of raisins, caramel and sugar. Nice overall.

Rochefort Trappistes 10. Wow. Pours out a dark brown hue. The off white lacing had  decent lacing but a little bit lower on the retention. The aromas was slightly roasted but more along the lines of dark fruits like plums. The flavor is where this on shines. Its extremely complex. Definite malt flavor as well has a vanilla and caramel sweetness. Above those were the flavors of the dark fruits and floral undertones. You can taste the hops but its very balanced and works well with all the other notes. Great smooth body as well as creamy. Being an 11% abv beer you dont get a hard alcohol hit. Its well hidden under the rest of the beer. Amazing.

11.2 oz. bottle.  Smooth and delicious. Alcohol is somewhat noticeable  under the raisin and dark fruit notes. Still quite drinkable and like having a dessert in a bottle.  Those monks know what theyre doing.

Provare una di queste bottiglie che abbia fatto almeno 2 anni di invecchiamento significa aver avuto il privilegio di provare una delle migliori birre al mondo.
