Colore tonaca di frate, al naso è intensa complessa come poche la mondo. Il gusto è deciso, di frutta e tostato. La migliore birra che abbia mai provato in assoluto.

One of the my favourite Trappist beers.
The first taste I noticed is the malt. I appreciate a lot this beer style. This is, for me, the classic beer to taste in front of a fireplace. I feel a very flat smell and the froth is persistent.
Very good.

Il colore è un tonaca di frate con cappello di schiuma persistente. Laroma è un concentrato di frutta, malto e tanta abbondanza. In bocca è superba, pulita, equilibrata, calda, potente, secca, e con un finale che va oltre ogni aspettativa.

Bottle. Pours a hazy, dark reddish brown with a firm beige head. Aroma: floral, vanilla, a bit creamy, sweet, perfume (not in a bad way). Taste: floral, sweet, malty (caramel or toffee?), a bit spicy, warming alcohol, hard candy, dried fruit, liqueur, hints of chocolate and licorice. Full and soft mouthfeel, with soft bubbles, moussy or creamy. Classic!

Beautiful color and mellow malty aroma.  Taste is fantastic combination of slightly sweet maltynes and spice.  Very slight alcohol at the finish, amazing for a beer this strong.  Creamy enjoyable palate.  Overall a fantastic beverage.

Bottle/11.2oz - Pours a dark reddish brown in color with a medium light tan head that stuck around to produce some really nice lacing on the glass.  Aroma is heavy with caramel/brown sugar/candy sugar and slihtly sweet.  Fruity... dark fruits mostly.  Flavor is medium sweet with lots of caramel, plenty of dark fruits (dates?).  Undercurrent of a quite vinous character that lasts well into the lingering finish.  Alcohol produces some nice warming, but is very well hidden.  Perhaps a bit sweet for my tastes, but this is clearly one of the best beers that I have had.  Awesome!

Brown, cloudy pour, head dissipates quickly.  Broad caramel aroma with a hint of spice, with strong hit of caramel in the taste.  Long finish, almost winey. I really like it, though its one for enjoying rather than just drinking.

Sweet, rich, complex, and never cloying, about as good as you can get within this style.  There are fruity flavors and rich sweet caramels.  A bit too sweet for me to love it though. A 4.1 is a good compromise between realizing the extremely well-crafted beer in front of me and the uncomfortable amount of sweetness.

From notes, 05/2009.

A dark mahogany red-brown body meets a nice, thick two finger barely tan head. Fantastic head settles (especially for such a big beer).

Vanilla, candied dark fruits, some dark sugar, some spice (cinnamon?). Smooth and beautiful blend of malty goodness on the tongue: prune, caramel sweetness, hazelnut, decent alcohol presence on the finish. This one bites the tongue. Fantastic.

Warming. Sufficiently thick, superbly creamy, and heavily carbonated. Great for the style. 

A wonderful end to what was a wonderful evening. Drink this one at the end of a great day and youll go to bed satisfied.
Smooth and delicious. Alcohol is hidden under the dark fruit notes. Exceptional drinkability and pairs well with a dark chocolate dessert. Alcohol shows itself after you stand up! Belgian classic!

Bottle. Poured deep red black with too foamy beige head,  Aroma is plums, raisins and sweet malt. Full flavour, plum, raisin and caramel. Sweet finish with no alcohol burn.  This is a baie lekker dessert beer.
user_location: Munchen an der Willamette, Oregon, USA

text: Bottle pours a nearly opaque muddy brown with a thin beige head that effervesces quickly down to nothing.  Aroma is bready, dark fruit, and chocolate.  Flavor follows, with some mild bitterness at the end.  For the level of ABV, Im getting zero alcohol in aroma or flavor; so smooth.

very good beer overall pours a non tranparent black, small cream head the aroma is grape/fig like with some alcohol notes, starts with a sweet almost grape like flavor then goes to a dry alcohol flavor and at the end leaves you with a suprising sweet flavor in your mouth, overall a very deep complex beer
ps if you live in littleton colorado tipsys has many of these also the eight and six platos as well

Szándékosan karácsonyra tartogattam már egy jó ideje. Szinte már feketébe hajló sötétbarna színű, nagy és krémes, hosszan tartó bézs habbal. Illata is sokat sejtet már: pörkölt maláta, karamell, nagy mennyiségű aszalt szilva, mazsola, édeskés fűszerek és gyógyfüvek. Az íze az, ami igazán lehengerlő, van benne minden: aszalt gyümölcsök (szilva, füge, mazsola), érett banán, alma, karamell, rengeteg fűszer (szerecsendió, szegfűszeg, fekete bors...) és még hosszan lehetne sorolni a különféle összetevőket. Édeskés, de finoman kesernyés is hozzá, érezni a komlót is. Testes, nehéz, összetett sör, szerintem ez egy önálló fogás is lehetne, magas alkoholtartalma ügyesen el van rejtve, de azért érezni, hogy ez ebből a szempontból is a komolyabb sörök között van. Szándékosan kritikusan álltam elé, mondván, hogy nem minden arany ami fénylik. De ez fantasztikus egy ital, igazi sörkülönlegesség, és megérte várnom vele.

Bottle poured into chalice...a Schlitz chalice to be exact. Dark opaque brown with thick tan head that quickly dissipates, but a thin veil of bubbles remain. Aroma is of burnt carmel and dark, sweet fruit. Some alcohol but not as much as you would guess from 11.5%. Lively and creamy medium mouthfeel. Tastes of rum raisin cake, overripe plums, figs, spice from the yeast and alcohol, but again, not to a fault. Good malt presence. Hop bitterness and alcohol balance the sweetness. Sour cherry and maybe tobacco in the very very long lingering finish. Firm alcohol warmth in the belly after a few sips. What a beer! Has to be one of my all time favorites...makes me want to be a monk...if only my wife wasnt so hot.

On the tenth day of Christmas......Thanks to Chalsk I enjoyued a bottle of 10.  Pours a deep brown.  Aroma is dark fruit, earthyness, caramel and belgian yeast.  Taste is sweet with earthy finish.  Overall one heck of a brew.

Bottle.
Dark brown with some tan head that lingers. Aroma is fruit, apple, raisins, light earthy note, bit of caramel and figs. Light sweetness up front and lots of fruit on the palate. Very smooth, bit of malt on the palate. Very good, but I think my expectations were a little bit high and it didnt quite live up to them.

33 cl bottle from Systembolaget. Dark brown/black colour with small to medium, off-white head. Nice lacing. Smells of dark fruits, malts, chocolate/coffee and some alcohol. Taste is sweet with many notes of dark fruits and ends lightly bitter. Medium bodied with a warm, alcoholic touch. Very nice overall, great beer.

UPDATED: SEP 3, 2011 A really delicious, drinkable beer. You can almost pickout and identify the grains and enough hops to make it interesting. This stuff is 11.5 abv which kinda precludes drinking too much at a time but you really want to once you start

Sampled from a 330ml bottle. Pours a dark brown (not unlike a cola), with a small white head that disappears immediately. The aroma is of raisin mostly with some other fruit. Tastes again of raisin, plum and vanilla. Its smooth like velvet. One of the best for sure.

Friday night beer.  Pours an unpenetrable brown with thick tan head that quickly settles.  Tastes of fig, plum, raisins, and other dark fruits.  You get molasses, wine, chocolate, and slight yeast.  Kinda sweet and dry and very delicious

Pours a murky brown with a thick cream head that quickly settles down. Smells of wine, prune, dates, and honey. Initial taste is of sweet yeasty fruits with a light yeasty ending. Very sweet and really a dessert beer only. Alcohol is very well incorporated and unnoticeable until the temp increases. Not a huge fan of this quad, but I can appreciate its complexity.

UPDATED: NOV 6, 2011 Smell of dark fruits. Typical quad appearance, a nice muddy dark brown. Taste is very sweet and rich. Berries, raisins, spices and probably several other fruits. Not getting much yeast. Alcohol is there, but very well integrated. Great beer.

Just  amazing that after 2700 + ratings, Rochefort 10 is rated over 4.3.  This 11.3 percent behemouth pours a dark brown with a head that fizzled away like a cola.  The aroma is dark, sweet fruit and the flavors are a complex array of dark fruit, raisons, vanilla, caramel, sweet dark malt and yeast.  This beer is a huge, earthy, giant  that hides the alcohol quite well.  This beer makes any dull moment an occasion.

UPDATED: DEC 14, 2014 Pours a very dark brown with a light brown head. 
Aroma has a lot of sweet yeast esters, sweet malts, raisins, dates, some spices and some danish candy called "flagermuse".
Taste of caramel, dark fruits, sweet yeast esters, some alcohol and dryness at the end along with some gentle spices. This fits December perfectly, alot of christmas vibes in it and with a delicious balance! Yeah!

UPDATED: MAR 24, 2014 From a 330ml bottle on 8/12/2010. Pours dark brown and cloudy, with some yeast sediment floating around. The aroma is raisins, plums, port and a touch of chocolate. Surprisingly, its relatively straight forward flavour wise. Dark fruit dominates, and its extremely sweet - a real dessert beer. Its also quite smooth and drinkable for a beer thats 11.3%, thought he alcohol comes to the fore when it warms up. The carbonation is low and it finishes with a modest bitterness. Very nice, though perhaps a tad over-rated. Rating 3.9.

Re-rate on 24/3/2014. Thought it was time to give this another try but on doing so, I remain thoroughly perplexed at the ridiculously high rating for this. Dont get me wrong - its nice enough but its falls a very long way short of being great. It lacks a bit of complexity and this bottle was over carbed.

UPDATED: FEB 14, 2011 pours purplish dark brown with a fizzy off white head and no lacing.  aroma is sweet plums, figs and alcohol.  Carbonation is light, body is medium-full with a syrupy feeling on the lips.  Taste is very complex.  rich berry, plum and fig notes dominate with more alcohol at the end.  This beer begins sweet and grows bitter.  the finish is long and warming.  This is a truly great beer!

A murky brown beer thats got some floaties in it. Low, tan head that does not last long. A wonderfully complex aroma of sweetness, dark fruits and some alcohol. Very little hop aroma comes through. Carmel sweetness, dark fruit, low bitterness. Full bodied and long finish that gives away the 11% ABV.

Bottle 330ml @ home
Pours murky dark brown with a tan head. Aroma is sweet with notes of plums, raisin, alcohol and caramel. Taste is very sweet. Texture is oily with soft carbonation.

Bottle poured in snifter.  Too cold at first, but taste didnt change much as it warmed. Med.-dark translucent brown, small tan head, medium carbonation. Very fruity aroma: raspberries, chocolate, toffee. Taste very well-balanced between prunes, raspberries, caramel, chocolate, faint hops, and alcohol warming. Medium body, not too sweet. Alcohol never seemed too strong. This has been my first trappist beer in a while, amazing!

Very dark brown almost black, like muddy water.  Alcohol on the nose.  Creamy white head.  Warm and malty flavor.  Smooth and thick mouth feel.  Not sweet, but very malty, coats the tongue.   Wonderful flavor with little alcohol heat.  A great winter beer.

Very dark murky brown with medium head. Aromas of yeast, dried plums, alcohol. Slick, winelike mouthfeel. The taste begins yeasty, sweet with dried fruit and burned sugar and finishes with powerful alcohol notes and warmth. The aftertaste is malty, even bready, with some more alcohol, sugar and dried fruit.  A great beer to drink on a cold winter evening.

Dark brown with a medium tan head.  Pretty intense and complex stuff.  Lots of d ark fruit and yeast on the nose with candi sugar and plenty of alcohol.  Taste in line with the aroma  full bodied and full flavored.  A little too boozy for my tastes but still pretty damn good.

Pours murky hazelnut brown with the most gorgeous egg shell white and very pillowy head. Aroma is huge on the malt and yeast. Intense nutty caramel, sticky sweet belgian quad yeast, dark fruits like prunes, plums, figs, dates some cake crust, hints of berries, roasted walnuts, cocoa. Lovely aroma.
The taste is just massive. The belgian yeast is very obvious, flowery, a bit stinging actually, dark fruits, caramel, it has some port like notes in the sweetness combined with a bite from the yeast. Spices, perhaps cinnamon. Gentle coffee in the after taste along with dark fruits. Massive body, quite some alcohol taste.

How did I go these years without trying this brew.11.2 fl oz. bottle from Mesa wine and beer.  Cola-brown with quickly exiting tan head.  Small amouth of suspended chunkies.  Nose is sweet, sharp alcohol, and a bit of darkness.  Taste is big dark fruit sweetness to alcohol sharpness.  The lingering afters move all around.  Ill have to try this a few more times, and see if I can tell what all the fuss is about.  Not in my top 10, thats for sure.  Very good, but not world-beater.  Not this bottle, at least.
330 ml bottle a dark brown colored beer with a white head aroma fruits dry fruits raisins spices caramel and some alcohol taste fruits and dry fruits spices caramel and some alcohol hints

Bottle, 33cl. Pours a clear and brown beer with an offwhite head. The aroma is malt, sweetness, dried fruit and yeast. The flavor follows the nose. The palate is sweetness. Overall a really good beer.
Rich and complex, almost tastes like a fine wine. Definite plum and raisin flavor. Strong and earthy aroma.

Bottle, 3 months old. Beautiful dark colour, large creamy beige head. Really sticks to the sides of the glass. Aroma of figs, plums, some wood, tobacco. Fairly complex and heavy smells, got better when the beer warmed up. 
Full body, lots of alcohol warmth, medium carbonation. Intense sweet notes and beautifully complex aftertaste that lingers quite a bit. 
This beer is often compared to its trappist brothers, so Ill try to compare it to the Westvleteren 12 which I had recently. Its definitively heavier, less well hidden alcohol, more pronounced hop bitterness, more astringent aftertaste. Overall, a more bombastic, less balanced beer than the Westvleteren 12. But an excellent beer nonetheless.

Bouteille 33 cl de Bier Bienne (CH). Bière couleur café, la mousse tient peu et le pétillement est important. Nez de malt torréfié, orge, caramel, alcool et moka. La bouche est superbe donctuosité, le corps est présent et très profond. Notes de poire, chocolat, porto, prune, raisin, caramel et moka. CCest une gourmandise fondante, une bière qui se mâche, alcooleuse mais fascinante et exceptionnelle.
Cloudy brown color with foamy tan head. Strong malt, dried fruit and yeasty bread aroma. Warming alcohol, fig, and biscuity flavors. Nice warm lingering aftertaste.

Bottle. Pours very dark with creamy head. Lovely aroma of dark fruits and sugars. Very creamy smooth palate. Flavor is amazing...rich and sugary but somehow not overwhelming, with some complex fruit flavors. Slightly warm but alcohol is well hidden overall despite high ABV. This is the best Abt/Quad that I have tried, with St. Bernardus Abt 12 being second place to this I think. Outstanding.

Coca-cola pour, with cola/Jaegermeister aroma. I agree with shameus_burp: whats the fuss for this $8 bottle? Heavy small-buble carbonation with vodka nose. Mix of Newcastle and imperial stout with a touch of ethanol for the finish. My low "overall" represents my feelings for paying more for one bottle than I would for a six pack of this. The flavors were uber subtle to the point of silence. In a blind testing, I would give it a 2.5, but I felt I had to look for more than was there, hence the higher rating

Dark ruby with a medium beige creamy head. Aroma is fantastic, dark fruits, raison, caramel, chocolate, Full body with average carbonation. In mouth is sweet, dark chocolate raisin and caramel. Kind of porto like too. One of the best.

G: 12-ounce Chimay goblet. Bottled on January 23, 2008.

A: Pours a thick, finger-and-a-half head that is cream colored and has a medium number of carbonation bubbles visible on top. The color is a very dark brown. 

S: Dark sugars and fruits; mild alcohol.

T: Very sweet with fruity flavors on the initial sweep. A mild raisin flavor, filled with cream and perhaps a touch of caramel. 

M: Smooth a creamy, eventually revealing slight alcohol warmth, which really hits the back of your throat on the swallow. 

D: Quite good. Even with the additional alcohol feel, I think this is more drinkable than the Rochefort 8.

from an aroma point of view it is absolutely fantastic.
from a food pairing point of view is axcellent with "salty" cheese
sometimes too sweet

(bottle, 3/25/10). Cloudy brown color, with amber hue. Medium tan head, which is mostly diminishing. Sweet dark fruit aroma. Sweet malty/dark fruit flavor with licorice, and with moderate alcohol. Avg duration. Moderate alcohol finish. Creamy/slick texture. Moderate carbonation. Spare lacing.

Pours with almost a grayish brown hue, small head if any. Nice coffee aroma with a slight sweetness to the smell. Very flavorful beer, has a nice sweet flavor, not to overbaring, espically since I do not like sweet beers. This beer has a nice blend of hops and fruit. Really good beer, dont think I could handle large quanties but for a really outstanding taste when you are limted with the amount you can drink, you will not find a better beer.

It tastes really good. Pretty sweet for a brown beer. Not that common... It has a great caramel taste (they use rock sugar, candy sugar). Even a little hint of bananas.  Just by smelling it, you already want to taste it!
Pours brown with no head. Aroma is caramel, dark fruit, raisin, plum and alcohol. Flavour is caramel, dark fruit, raising, plum, black currants and burning alcohol.

0.33l Bottle.  Appearance is color of deep molasses with a beige head that quickly dissipates.  Aroma is rich and complex dominated by dried fruit and sweet malt.  Taste is also heavily dried fruit especially raisin and grapes.  The malt comes out a little more in this beer than in other Belgian ales, which I like.  It provides a good companion to´the fruity flavors.
Bottle 33cl. Little head, light foam. Tastefull aroma and aromatic taste. Palate wonderful silky.

Bottle at The Beer Authority, poured a huge pillow head that dissipated quickly.  Couldnt see through a dark hazy plum color. Aroma a dried fruits.  Heavy and thick on the palate with no bitterness and a long lasting finish.  Flavor was very sweet but no hint of its 11.3% alcohol.  Very good sipper!

Poured from a 330cl bottle a rich dark brown color that reminded me of dark chocolate. A very small tan head formed but dissapates quickly. Aroma is intense and  complex suggesting notes of raisins, malt, brown sugar, candy, fruits,and alcohol. Taste is also very complex and at first a little sweet, reminding me of a barley wine style ale but after a few sips the sweetness is not as noticable and detect hints of malt, raisin, sugar and alcohol. A very complex beer from start to finish. A very good Bulgium beer that should be drank in moderation because of its high ABV of 11.3

Always a go to favourite of mine. Easily available, very cheap and just insanely packed with flavour. Sweet candy sugar, thick, yeasty, luscious, velvety with the alcohol showing through in a good way. Quit big differences between bottles though, Ive had ones Id rate a 4.9, or ones Id rate 3.9, but never an unpleasant experience.

Dark brown color. Small head, which does not last long. Smell is yeasty and alcohol comes through. First sip gives loads of aromas. Fruits, alcohol, raisin, eggs, some basement/ground aromas and I could swear theres some nuts and roast. Oh goodness, oh grace. Very slick to swallow. And after taste is as rich as first. The only reason why full score cannot be given to this beer is that you really cannot have more than one of this per evening. Risk of aroma overload is just too great.

Bought at Drankenhandel Geers.
Very pleasant discovery and rightfully so voted as one of the top beers around the world. Heavy, solid, black-brown trappist with plenty of candy sugars and accordingly sweet (though definitely not overdone), a hint of something roasted or bitter "fondant" chocolate and a very long-lasting aftertaste, though one would only wish it stayed forever. This one easily waltzed itself into my personal list of favourites and once again its only confirmed by thousands of other beer enthusiasts around the world.

Brown muddy ale with thin film of light tan head. Lots of raisins in the aroma. Tastes of plum, cream and a bit alcohol. Feels creamy on the palate. Every mouthful is an explosion of different tastes. Fabulous beer.

This fine ale poured a murky brownish color with a thin film for a head. Aroma of fruits and malts. Flavor was deep, rich and layered with dark fruits, raisins, mildly sweet malts, toffee, and a slight hop tinge at the end, almost unnoticed when the beer warms. The alcohol is well hidden to the point where you dont even realize the strength of this beer. I cant wait to see what this tastes like after letting it age for a year or two. This is an excellent ale!

11-11-2010
33cl bottle at home. Murky dark beer with a light brown head that dissolved quite quickly. The aroma is pretty intense, and the taste is very complex, sweet and a little bitter. Nicely balanced! The aftertaste lingers in your mouth for quite a long time.

Pours a mysterious deep mahogany, hazy with sediment, with shining orange spots in the sunlight. A gentle head quickly fades, but given its high ABV this is expected. The aroma is distinctly wine-like revealing a complexity of fruits, specifically grapes, plums, and raisons. Huge alcohol lift in the nose.  

Right away I know Rochefort 10 is an impressive beer. A plethora of delicious flavors immediately charm you. Dark fruits as mentioned in the smell, also including molasses, toffee, and oak. Every sip seems to uncover something different, as you peel back layer upon layer of flavor. Alcohol is not overwhelming at 11.3%, but feels rather natural and warming like a fine wine would. Many Port like characteristics are on display. A luscious mouth feel with a very dry finish. Rochefort 10 is rich, elegant, and full of depth. It is obvious why this is highly regarded as one of the best beers in the world. I would love to see how it tastes with a few years of age (this bottle is only 7 months old).

The Best Ale I have had to date!! Dark Brown in color with a egg-shelled colored head. Chocolate and cherries aromas fly out of the snifter. Same flavors on the palate, but it is the Silky texture that sets this Ale apart I have never experienced this level of flavor and texture in an Ale. Just wish it came in 750ml bottle formats, too.

If I should identify the perfect beer probably I woul say Rochefort 10...personally its the mosto complete beer in the world; she has a great mix of smells and flavors but no one of its components is more or less intense or important. Is really rare to find a beer of more than 11° that doesnt makes the alchool its first aroma.

Dark Brown with 1/2" lite brown head. While pouring I immediately smells vinuous dark sweet grapes. Put my nose to it and got brown sugar, prunes, raisins and more going on here.. Taste is Vinuous, Prunes, berries, some bready notes, some hop bite and bitterness...this is very complex. Swished it around in my mouth and got cherries and berries as well. Medium plus body, nice zesty carbonation, medium alcohol warmth, decent bite and dryness. A definite brew to savor and explore. A lot of character in this one!

What can you say about this fantastic beer...So full of taste,every single pinch felt like a mouthfull of live brewing in your gums...Much alcochol but doesnt really seem so much while you taste it...Full  body,perfect sweetness and astonishing finish...Lived 100% up to my expectations...
Very fruity.  The sweet taste of the beer is what I enjoyed the most.  I dont normally like lighter flavored beers, but this I like.

Pours dark brown with ruby tones against light, nice brown head leaving some lacing on the glass. Aroma is full bodied, sweet caramel, malty, raisins, fidges and alcohol nicely mixing into the other aromas. Just perfect. Flavor fills my mouth from the very first sip. So lean and full bodied, caramel sweet, fruity and the alcohol raising the flavor another step. Palate feel is very lean and full bodied. Finishes sweet fruity with nice touch of alcohol turning into a malty and slightly hoppy aftertaste.

Drinking this side by side with Westvleteren 12 for comparison. 11.2 oz bottle into tumbler. Pours even murkier than the Westy; more brown, less orange. Looks like mud. Has a medium bone-white head that dissipates in a few minutes, leaving a blanket of foam. Lots of sediment. Not as pretty as the Westy. Aroma is strong in caramel, some funky smelling yeast. More pungent than the Westy. Taste is all sweet with no bitterness. Not as sweet as the other beer, though. Both beers remind me of apple pie. Raisins come out in the flavor; reminiscent of blackberry brandy. Full-bodied, softly carbonated; a little creamy, but not near as much as the other beer. I like the Westvleteren better, but neither even crack my top 20 beers of all time. In my opinion, both are overrated.

Pours brown/red with a good carbonation. on the nose it is really fruity, like plums and raisins, it has a port like quality as well as cranberries or something along those lines. very complex. big boozy mouthfeel with more raisins and fruits. It is a very nice brew. a bit boozy but hey its a rochefort!

Bottle. Red-brown, hazy with tan foam. Aroma is caramel, butterscotch, dark fruits and a little perfumy vanilla. Taste is even more fruits plum,raisin etcetera... a little alcohol warming. Medium body, slick feel, average carbonation, long plum-like bitter finish. This is good, time for me to rediscover the trappist beers. I

11.2 oz. bottle. Pours pitch black with an ample tan head. The aroma is sweet dark fruits, specifically dates, black cherries and plums, apricots, molasses, and licorice. There is a faint note of tannin. The taste is delicately sweet with a minimal bitter undercurrent. The body is very heavy, and the palate is a little acidic, crisp and slightly astringent. The finish is very clean, a feat for such a thick beer. The ABV comes through with a pleasant warming. A truly excellent beer, even for the price.
this one is the best. the older the better, but not much more than 8 years. full of flavour and perfect for a late night tipple buy the fire.

Bottle purchased from Salut in Kalamazoo, Michigan.  Disclaimer: this is my first time drinking a trappist ale and was quite unsure what to expect.  Had I not paid $8 for an 11-ounce bottle, it wouldve been a drain-pour after the first taste.   I literally choked this beer down.  Having said that, this is clearly not my thing.  It is quite apparent by all of the previous ratings that many people consider this to be a fantastic brew; different strokes for different folks.  I say "cheers," but will probably pass next time.

The aroma is an enveloping dark fruit and rummy malt character, no noticeable hops.  A deep umber color, earthy, hazy.  Light brown and very fine head, medium carbonation.  Coats my whole mouth with tingly malt/rum/molasses.  Sneaky alcohol hides in a perfect blend of CO2 and round malt.  Warming finish.  Fantastic and complex.  Yay beer!
The aroma is complicated.Soooo many fruits come up when you open it.The same taste as aroma.So cute beer.

UPDATED: MAR 6, 2011 33cl Bottle @Bir&Fud beershop (Rome). My personal best experience since now. Same impression of the 8 version, but the taste is stronger and better balanced. Deep and dull brown aspect with some orange and red reflects, quite dark. Intense aroma of caramel, cherry, with some brown sugar and chocolate. Incredible taste, deep, intense, endless. Great body, strong, creamy, great end. Perfect.

330ml bottle.  Pours a hazy, very dark brown with a large, non-lasting head.  Aroma is licorice, dark fruits and alcohol.  Blackcurrants start.  Lots of fruity malt on the finish with toffee.  Sweet aftertaste with some alcohol burn.

Bottle: Pours a very dark brown with light beige head in a trappist glass. In comparing 8 to 10, the first distinct difference is the heavy carbonation in comparison. Certainly a bit darker, and the sediment is here of course, but I had to put it right on a light just to see it. Aroma is just wow - heavy dark fruits, obviously, a bit of sweet breads as well. This brew is sweet, to be sure, but it masks the alcohol content far better than its cousin, 8 as far as booziness goes, imo. Flavors seem to mesh better - wonderful dark fruits again - as per the description, the plums and raisins are right there, a bit of toffee, sugars, sweetbread, and yes the vinousness is there to be sure after a handful of sips. Wonderful brew.

Pours a deep murky brown with small tan/brown head.  Nose of sweet raisins, molasses, and spice.  First taste is extremely sweet, also, I notice the large amount of carbonation right away.  Follows up and finishes with a taste of spice, raisins, and even some grapes.  Full bodied with a strong finish.

Just out of scale. A brown beer with a beige foam persistent. The aroma is intense, complex, malty, with hints of fruit (prunes), cherries, slightly spicy, winey. The taste is sweet with a balanced flavour. Slightly bitter finish and long lasting. Fantastic.

UPDATED: APR 2, 2011 A: Dark brown color with a big light tan head good retention.

S: Coffee,dark fruits and bread. 

T: Malty sweetness with good balance; earthy hops; Raisin, plum, cherry notes. Very complex.

M: Excellent smooth creaminess!!!!

D: Drinks like a wine; must sip and savor the wonderfullnes!

Serving type: 330 ml bottle dated 030215

Serving type: bottle

330 ml bottle.
What a beer! I think the best trappist with Westy 8. Dark brown colour with a nice head. Aroma/Palate: at first caramel, after dark/reds fruits, and hints of chocolate. Wonderful! Medium sweetness, full body, creamy, soft carbonation.
Gout très liquoreux et sucré ont note la présence de caramel le houblons est présent quoi que bien dissimulé derrière le goût dalcool. Jai bien aimé.

Pours dark brown with a very light head. Aroma has hints of coffee and chocolate along with the roasted malts. Flavor has much of the same with lots of other flavors I cant recognise. You can taste the strength but not in a bad way. Simply awesome.

UPDATED: APR 3, 2015 330 ml bottle. Vintage 2013 and 2008 parallel tasting.
2013: 
Dark reddish brown colour with a small off-white head. 
Dark fruits, raisins, caramel, mild sourness, mild alcohol, sherry and a hint of chocolate in the aroma. The flavour is a carousel of dark fruits, plum, sugary sweetness, mild sourness, caramel sweetness and sherry. Complex. Smooth, rich and warming. A great brew. 
2008: 
Dark brown colour with a huge load of floaters and a small tan head. 
Dark fruits, raisins, plum, caramel, sugary sweetness, mild chocolate and mild sherry in the aroma. 
The flavour is fudge, caramel sweetness, sherry, mild alcohol, dark fruits, plum and some vinous notes. Complex. Even smoother than 2013 vintage. Rich and warming, Truly a great brew. Intoxicating.

UPDATED: DEC 29, 2010 Bottle:
Small off white lacing on top of a dark brown to brown black beer.
Smell dark fruits (raisin), spices, sweets, hint of malts and slight hint of hops.
Taste is a delicious mix of fruit (raisin), brown sugars, dark dried fruits, hints of hops and toasted malts.
A slight warmth of the alcohol, and a flowerish hoppy aftertaste.
50/50 bitter and sweet: first sweet, than turns slightly into a more bitter beer, still sweet.
Perfectly balanced with carbo, yeast and other ingredients.
And dangerous, too delicious and taste no alcohol.
user_location: Best of E-Town mit 2 Brauhausen, NETHERLANDS

text:
A- Poured into my Snifter dark brown, woody in colour. Somewhat Cloudy. Nice creamy head with Decent Lacing. Thick look to it as it poured but it did not pour thick which was unexpected.

S- Earthy, very natural smell to it. Can really pick up the malts they smell very roasted. Very Dark caramel, almost sweet hints with some Vanilla. Can pick up the hops in the back as well they smell very floral. Very Enjoyable

T- Wow, so much flavour in one drink. Very sweet taste to it. The Malt flavour is so wonderful, very roasted but not overpowering at all. The Dark Caramel flavour comes out here very much, but the flavour is perfectly balanced with the hops. They are full of flavour here, floral and earthy with very little bitterness. As I drink flavours of dried fruits (Raisins, Apricots) comes through. Very nice to detect very little Yeast flavour. As the drink warms I can also taste alcohol is isnt surprising cause its 11.3%. Also as it warms a nice bitterness becomes prevalent which compliments the sweetness it started with very well.

M- Very very smooth and creamy. Wonderful to swirl around and let it sit in my mouth. The warming from the alcohol is also very invited and makes the whole experience very different, but I like it.

D- I love this beer. Way different than what I was expecting so that was nice. Everything about this beer seems to compliment it. The sweet and bitter, the colour, smell. Everything is in balance with the beer. As it warms the feeling changes to going from the sweet to the bitter and warming more and more. One of the best beer experiences Ive had as of yet.

03-10-10 Bouteille dans un verre westmalle et 2 ans vieillie: Belle apparence brune foncée, opaque, avec un beau collet blanc-beige qui demeure. Premiers aromes sont ceux de cassonade, de raisins muris et de sucre. Très douce en bouche et asser sucrée. Saveurs de cassonade, de fruits rouge, de raisins verts et de mures. Bière réconfortante  par une alcool bien proportionnée et de plus en plus présente alors que la bière réchauffe. Très bien balancée.

UPDATED: SEP 16, 2014 In bottle; very good beer. Aroma of plum, dark fruit, raisons and chocolate. Very easy drinking beer given the alc %. Taste was smooth with similar notes as the aroma ... I look forwarding to buying some of this at home now, I think this is my favorite beer so far.

Good beer overall.  Color is more light brown (rootbeerish) than other Abts.  Carbonation is very apparent and masks some of the flavors.  Very earthy tasting with a distinct citrus aftertaste.  An accurate advertising campaign for Rochefort 10 would be, "The Mimosa of beers".  Given the choice Id much rather enjoy an St. Bernardus APT 12.

wouldnt pay $8 for 11oz. of this again, but it was worth a try. very dark in color, dark fruit in taste. lots of carbonation. slight medicinal taste. easy to drink for 11%. enjoyable. very good, but im not busting nuts all over it.

Poured into a brandy snifter. The carbonation of this beer is magnificent. The 11 ounce bottle filmed a 24 ounce snifter. The beer itself is a dark brown, almost black. The head is tan and has dark brown specks throughout it. The head stays atoll the beer through the end and leaves somewhat splotchy lacing. Aroma is of malts, dark and dried fruits, spices, and hops. Taste is kind of a sharp fruitiness with a slight alcohol burn. The alcohol is not that big of a deal though and is covered up well with everything else there is to taste. This beer is relatively smooth to drink but is one that should be sipped due to its complexity. I like this one a good bit and look forward to trying rocheforts other offerings.
This is one of my all time favorites. Best commercialy available beer. Dark as hell and looooots of aromas.
such an awesome beer - havent had recently so will come back for full review - on of the GOATs

Gift from awiseman01.  Pours a deep caramel brown with a small pale head.  Aroma is more like wine than beer, with some rich dark fruit notes.  Lots apples and spice.  Alcohol heat becomes quite apparent as it goes down.  Full-bodied and smooth.  This is quite an excellent beer and Im sad that Ive overlooked it for so long.

UPDATED: DEC 1, 2015 Bottle. Dark brown and hazy. Aroma has toffee, vanilla and sweet fresh fruit. I wish the taste would have that light vanilla-like freshness that the aroma has. But instead it is very intensive: lots of sugar, prunes, sweet malt. I think its a bit too heavy for me to fully enjoy. I can see the appeal here though. 2015 re-rate: 2013-12 bottle, almost two years old. Chestnut brown body; the first pour is almost semi-clear now. Later pours are well murky. Aroma is still incredible with lots of toffee, vanilla and dried berries. Along with other Rocheforts, this is one of the best smelling beers that Ive had! Taste is not too much different from the fresh bottles - cellared samples (this one and some older bottles that Ive had) seem to have a less alcoholic and more rounded taste. The influence of oxidation is small and the carbonation level seems unchanged. This is definitely a good beer to cellar.

Bottle from Alko. Poured very dark brown color with a brownish head. Aroma is raisins and yeast, these come first to mind. Flavor is complex with caramel , plums and yeasty notes all blended well together. Alcohol is nicely hidden, only showing as a warming feeling as it goes down the throat. Sweet finish. Excellent as a nightcap and with some dark chocolate.

2003 vintage 
head: very thin 
colour: dark caramel/brown 
smell: blue berrys, dairy, caramel, malts, candy 
taste: alcohol, anis, malts, toffee/ dutch drop , coriander, bit of grassy hops, dry/oily end

Poured in the original Rochefort glass. Dark brown in colour with only a small tan head. Aroma is sweet, some espresso and dark bitter chocolate, dark fruit (plums and raisins). Taste is complex, spicy and sweet (soft brown sugar), with some woody flavours as well. Very rich mouthfeel with a soft and mild carbonation. Perfect beer for the cooler days.

A: snifter. pours a deep, dark rich mahogany with some flaky sediment floating around. nice tan head on top with a good retention rate and a good amount of lacing.

S: nice fall fruit aromas, apples, figs, plums. some spices as well, mostly clove and nutmeg. some strong alcohol esters.

T: strong flavors all over this. plums, raisins, some bananas and tons of clove. only downside is that the high alcohol is really coming through in the flavor.

M: mild to high carbonation. medium to heavy body. very smooth though for 11%.

D: very nice trappist beer and belgian quadruple. Absolutely worth a try.

Bottle.  Pours very dark with considerable sediment left in bottle.  Has a large lumpy tan head of fine bubbles.  Very dark aromas, plum, prunes, liquor, etc.  Extremely complex flavors that settle nicely on the tongue.  Expresses more flavors as it wams.

UPDATED: SEP 29, 2010 Bottle. Has a date on the label of 030215 which I am guessing is the best on date 5 years from now. Pours an opaque, murky brown with red highlight color. Fluffy tight tiny bubbled 1 finger head that coasters. Sweet smelling with aromas of fruit, especially dark cherry and plum. The taste is very good, sweet, but good. Nice medium creamy mouthfeel. The taste is a very nice blend of subtle spice, plum, raisins, and dark fruit. I get a lingering caramel flavor as well. Very solid overall, nice and clean. Subtle hint of alcohol is present throughout.

UPDATED: JUL 4, 2014 Bottle courtesy of Hopper...  Is it sacrilege to fill your Chimay glass with this murky brown monks libation??  I say OH NO..  So unless you been living with Ted Kaczynski in some remote Montana cabin.  You should know by now that this is second highest quad on the planet, AND rightly so.  A sensational blend of dark fruits, carmel, brown sugar, and alcohol............
Second rating of a 2006 vintage. This Belgium quad held up well....

330 mL bottle from Sams Quik Shop in Durham.  Muddy brown pour with a thick, creamy off-white head.  Aroma of grape, sweet plums, and Belgian sugar.  The flavor is fruity and sweet at the same time with just the right balance of each.  The flavors that come to mind are raisin, prunes, and apples with rich brown sugar.  The alcohol is noticeable but only in warmth.  If you dont like this beer this style isnt for you.  Spectacular.
This is wonderful. One of the best beers I have ever tasted. A great balance..wonderful aroma...perfect head....love the prunes....

UPDATED: SEP 14, 2013 330 ml bottle. Rated @ 27.4.2009.
Deep brown colour with a long lasting brown head. Very fruity on the nose with raisins, Belgian yeast and banana. Same thing on the flavour too; banana, alcohol and caramel all in a good balance. Sweet, dry and warming finish. Excellent.
Rating after numerous 6 month, 1 year, 2 year and 3 year old vintages.
So, finally I manage to write a compilation of all the (vintage) ratings Ive rated of this beer. If it ages, it gets better. But only for the first two years. After that the sweetness takes over, the fruitiness disappears and the yeast gets rather boring really. If you want to taste this at its best, have a 2 year old vintage. Its settles down nicely and brings you the best R10 experience. A 1 year old vintage is a bit raw, and the yeast is slightly overwhelming. Nevertheless, the blackcurrant notes on 1 year old vintage are just awesome, as on the 2 year old vintage. Honestly, this is much better than W12, in aroma, flavour, price and overall-wise.

Poured from a bottle.  Color is deep, murky brown with a large off white head. The head lasts for a while, too.  Aroma is sweet with raisins, anise, and molasses.  Flavor is fruity, with raisins and plums, some grapes, and sticky sweetness in the finish.  A little too much on the sweet side, but otherwise good stuff.

Pours a very dark reddish brown. The aroma is packed with bold notes of plums, raisins, and yeast. The flavor is likewise a bold combination of dark fruits that is easily the most potent of any of the quads or Belgian strong dark ales that I have tried. The flavor starts getting quite sweet as the beer warms, though, and the texture is largely unremarkable and does not provide any relief from the sweet fruitiness of the flavor.

(11.2oz bottle).  This bottle is 2 years old.  Pours muddy brown with a tan head.  I poured the entire contents into the glass rather than leaving the yeasty leftovers because I had a gushing issue.  Aroma has lots of caramel and milk chocolate to go with some butterscotch.  Maybe even some caramel corn.  Taste is malty sweet (but not as malty as when its fresh).  Most of the hops have subsided as well.  Full bodied and creamy/sticky texture.  Finish is smooth and the alcohol is warming.  This is a superb beer-truly world class.  Ive been drinking this beer for about 10 years and the more beers I taste, the more I realize how special this beer is.

Pours an opaque brown with large off-white head.  Immediately noticed lots of "floaties", mmmm.  Aroma is simple, slightly sweet.  Taste is complex, malts at the side on the tongue, slight bitterness on the top.  Mouthfeel is viscous, finishes with mild bitter aftertaste.

Quite possibly the best beer Ive ever had.  Hints of dried fruit, brown sugar, and what I can only describe as a "smokey" aroma on the nose.  Great mouthfeel; creamy with a perfect amount of carbonation.  Flavours of fig, and dried fruit and brown sugar again, mild banana taste likely from the tannins on the aftertaste.  Complex, sweet, incredibly smooth for an 11.3% ABV ale.  Delicious!

Aroma is very rich. Dark fruit, plums, brown sugar, molasses....oh, and alcohol. Its a very boozy and deep aroma.

The initial taste I get is of sweet dark fruit...raisins....even some grapes. This is followed by a very thick brown sugar/molasses taste that goes through the body and into the finish. The high ABV is certainly noticeable on the finish, but could certainly be worse considering what the ABV is. It does cause a bit of astringency on the swallow, though. Some sweetness hangs around after the swallow, but all in all seems pretty dry.

0.33 l bottle.
Nearly non-transparent, deep dark brown coloured pour in my chalice with a finger-thick beige cream on its top.
Robust smell of in alcohol-dipped fruits.
The start is tiny sharp, mouthfeel becomes after that slick and very smooth.
The flavour is of toffee and dried fruits.
The complex middle brings caramell, light roasted malt,, citrus, raisins and spice along.
Finish is spicy, warming up alcoholy and dry which remain in a spicy aftertaste.
In spite of the high ABV, its relatively easy drinakble and the alcohols not pushing in front.
Overall a very fine one.

11.2oz bottle in a Trappist glass.  Pours deep brown with a lacy, beige head.  Aroma of dark fruit, caramel, Belgian yeast, and alcohol.  Flavor mainly of the dark fruits and candy sugar at first, with the hops, nuts, and alcohol coming in for the finish.  A very complex flavor.  The closest beer to Westvleteren 12 there is.

A Dark Chocolaty Brown pour with a nice tan delicious head.  Flavors or caramel, amaretto, plum, and alcohol.  Not a beer for the first time beer drinker but a great one for someone who wants to try new styles.
Buena cerveza, considerando que es la fuerte de la familia, el aroma es increíble, mucho cuerpo y mucho sabor!!!!

UPDATED: OCT 13, 2010 Very nice heavy caramel smell. Gives a full dark beer taste with a very sweet caramel taste
Rochefort of 2003 (7 years old): very sweet and a dusty aftertaste.

330mL bottle pours dark brown with thick creamy tan head. Aroma is caramel, yeast, alcohol, plum, and raisin. Taste is sweet and malty, dark fruits, yeast, spices, bread in the aftertaste. Smooth and enjoyable, nice balance of flavors, alcohol is only apparent as it is a warm mouthful, but not overpowering.

11 oz Bottle- Pours a nice dark brown and thin creamy head. Great lacing on my Duvel tulip. Rich aromas of raisins, yeast  and cherries. The bready flavor is dark fruit, deep and full bodied. Smooth and fulfilling finish. Alcohol is well hidden. A very tasty Belgium brew. Wish it were cheaper.....

Very dark brown slightly amber colored pour. Nice dense foamy tan head that dissipates somewhat quickly leaving little lacing around the glass.

Aroma is strong - lots of dark fruity notes with a little bit of funk and some alcohol. Flavor is HUGE. More dark fruits, some slight caramel, malts and booze.  Very complex with lots going on here.

Very nice and bubbly mouthfeel for such a dark and hugely flavorful beer. The alcohol content makes you want to sip it, but the carbonation and overall feel make it easy to drink too fast. My advice - take you time and enjoy this one; its a great beer.

Recommended!

Very deep red pour and u could smell it as soon as it hit the glass. Nose is complex with phenols, spices, fruits, plums, grapes, and no hop aroma to speak of. Taste surpasses the nose with wonderful malts, sugars, plums, raisins, wood, wine, and a little alcohol warmth and quite sweet. Not an overly thick body and noticable carbonation. Very rich, very enjoyable.

Pours dark murky orange/brown with a medium off-white head.  Aroma of fruits-sherry-plum-raisin. Quite sweet and malty, extremely smooth. Excellent finish with nearly no evidence of the high alcohol content.  A brilliant beer!

Dark chocolate colour, heavy sediment beige head. Currant aroma, subtle but there. Strong black currant  flavour. Fantastic texture to the palate, leaves a warming, fruity tang. Alcohol is perhaps a little overwhelming. Cracking beer otherwise.

Bottle Code 260814 08:46


Mostly loosely patterned head dying quickly with minimal lacing, streaming carbonation, bits of compacted spent yeast are taking joy rides in this one


Deep, dark orange brown body


Smells of piles of ripe plumb with chocolate caramel and alcohol rounding out, dark cherries


Taste is alcohol soaked cherries and plumbs, chocolate, cream


Mouth is medium to heavy, but really very light for an 11.3% brew, carbonation is lively


Alcohol is present and makes this a more challenging drink, no question some age would do wonders for the 10, cant wait to taste it after at least 4 years in the basement

Overall this is one of the best Ive had - a complex Trappist with as much character as you could expect from a beer
UPDATED: SEP 1, 2010 One of the best beers I have ever had. The rich sweet yet potent flavors were everything I could have asked for out of a 12 ounce bottle of beer.

Bought from The Milk Bar, Orlando FL. Bottle. Poured into a trappist glass. Great colour, off-white/light brown eggshell head, dark and opaque from the bottom, dark reddish brown and slightly more translucent near the very top.
Dark fruit is evident as described, sweetness all throughout, lovely malt.  Satisfying and so glad I was able to try this fantastic biere.

Murky brown with yeast and trub.  Light off-tan head.  Possibly one of the best looking beers Ive ever had.  Aroma is quite layered mix - cabernet, sherry, plum, raisin, and almost a sweet/sour finish.  Flavor is smooth in every way - sweet raisin, plum, brown sugar, merlot.  Explodes on the palate.  No alcohol flavor even in the slightest.  Flavor lasts forever.  Not my style of beer and probably will never have again, but very worthwhile to experience.
Rich flavoured and complex beer
Rich beer (too much sugar though) with nice toasted flavours and a beatiful head time and time again
UPDATED: JAN 20, 2015 Fantastic stuff.  One of the worlds classics. Very complex. Dark, rich and delicious. Serving: Bottle
Poured from 12oz bottle, pours a dark color with a nice white head that has some floaty sediment in it, aroma is very sweet and malty and the taste is amazing, wow Im glad I could try this one!

Ditto! This is a stellar brew well deserved its high ranking. I am happy that this quality is so high with such a fantastic availability. Deep caramel, zest and caramel in the taste.. thick, enveloping mouthfeel. Warming alcohol which pulls velvety clean through the whole experience. I pulled fig and dried fruit  in the nose with similar notes in the taste.

330 mL Bottle at the BierMarkt near Union Station in Toronto. Pours a deep dark brown with an average tan head that fades fairly quickly. Medium carbonation. Aroma is a complexity of spiciness, roast malt, and a slight yeasty whiff. Taste is perfectly smooth, a subtle mix of numerous flavours (black currant, plum fruitiness, strong sweet malt/chocolate/alcohol character,hint of yeast), that are extremely well balanced. Finishes crisp, with a sharp aftertaste. A wondrous beer.

330ml bottle.  Inviting looking beer with its very dark brown hue, a thick asteroid belt of sediment sinking and swimming, small coffee crema looking head. A complex array of beautiful aromas and flavours: ripe dark fruity notes especially raisin, chocolate, medicine, brown sugar, caramel, vanilla.  Each mouthful I want to keep until I have to swallow it such are the wonderful flavours, goes down velvety smooth.  Warming chocolaty spicy smooth finish of long duration.  I liked this as much as the Rochefort 8 both are a masterpiece to me.

Bottle. Dark red/brown small white foam lots of sediments. A sweet, malty nose. A thick, malty, alcoholic sweetness taste with notes of nuts, toasted bread, chokolate and yeast. The finish is has a faint sour touch that balances the sweetness quite well. This beer is one of the best I have had within the trapist style (Im not a fan of the style).

I love this beer!  This is my second time having this, and its better than the first time.  Such an incredible flavor... I really dont think I could describe this better than anyone else on here, so Ill just say, if you havent tried this, do so as soon as possible.

Aroma: caramel, resin, butterscotch.
Appearance: amber, brown, black, cloudy, minimal head, tan foam.
Taste: medium sweetness, lightly bitter.
Palate: medium body, thick, average carbonation.
Overall: This is one of the most exquisite Belgian ales Ive ever had. The flavor is rich and complex. The caramel and malt character dominates. The carbonation has a lot of bite to it. The unfiltered sediment imparts a thick mouthfeel. The 11.3% alcohol content is disguised well.

All over the place; St. Stephens, Bishops collar, Belgian Cafe, Monks.  Bottle.  Never have had it on draft.  

Havent had Westvleteren 12 but if its better than this then it deserves its #1 ranking.  

This is a gem of a beer; an absolute treat.   I wouldnt pay $15 for a beer if it wasnt amazing.  Rochefort 10 is an amazing beer.

Poured dark and cola colored.  Huge thick and rocky head, took a bit but it faded enough to pour the rest.  Good retention, left tons of lace on the glass.  Aroma was first of some fruity bubble gum, caramel malt, a subtle nuance of booze, and some wood.  Just wonderful so far.  Flavors also consisted of some fruity bubble gum, then faded to some caramel and a lingering bitterness.  I am quite new to Trappist ales and am very impressed so far.  This stuff is just crazy good.

Tasted from bottle purchased at Famous Lombard.  Pours a muddy amber brown with a fizzy but thick white head that recedes to lace on the outside of the glass.  Nose is sweet dried fruites (raisin, fig, prune) with caramelized malt and light citrus.  The alcohol is definitely present on the nose.  The flavors are not quite as dark, with the malt and yeast taking over.  The fruits are a little more acidic, and much juicier, not as dried, on the palate.  The plum flavor really comes through.  The body is full with light, but somewhat stinging carbonation and a long fruity and burning finish.  It is easy to understand why this beer is as highly rated as it is.

Bottle from 16th St. Liquor in West Vancouver. Dark, dark red in colour with a large tan head. Lacing and retention is nice. Simply beautiful. Aroma is malty, sweet, musty, and toffee-ish. Flavour is mildly sweet, turns doughy and slightly alcoholic. Theres some fruit notes; fig, cherry (?) and some mysterious complexity that is hard to distinguish but easy to appreciate. Finish is long and malty. Very smooth and slightly resinous on the tongue but not cloying. Alcohol superbly worked in. Masterful.

Is this my favorite beer in the world? Maybe. Its that good. Dont serve it really cold it ruins it- rather buy yourself a trappist glass and enjoy. More flavorful than the six or the eight and worth the very high price you will find it in the states.

what can I say about this beer that hasnt already been said? A fantastic beer, truly worthy of its lofty admiration. Rarely is a beer so universally agreed upon, and this beer seems to charm everyone. Anyone calling themselves a beer geek/lover/aficionado/hunter owes it to themselves to try this beer. Easily earns my vote as best (relatively) available beer. Go out and buy it now.
This is a decent beer with a very very dark appearance.  Best served very cold.  A solid taste with a few flavors, although its raison that really shines through.

Bottle.Pours a murky dark brown with a big beige/light brown head. Slightly tart aroma; just the perfect tartness; marks its presence without overdoing it. Subtle sweetness with spicy and creamy notes, as well as notes of alcohol in the background. As it warms, citrus notes blends with the creamy notes giving notions of lemon jello with whipped cream. Didnt find the aroma really fantastic in itself (the different notes), although still good, but its well-balanced and has no flaws, which makes for extra points. Full-bodied flavour which is dominated by the alcohol, although it still manages to hide the realatively high content. Sweetish and with notes of hops behind the alcohol. Some brandy-like similarities as it warms. Finish is sweetish with notes of alcohol and lingering dry hop and citrus notes. Same things as with the aroma, goes for the flavour; not fantastic in itself, but again  well-made and with no flaws. Only drawback is a bit too much carbonation, but otherwise overall a really well-made beer. 02.08.10.

UPDATED: AUG 16, 2010 Poured into a Westmalle chalice.

First of all it was a beautiful dark brown coffee like pour with a one inch head that stood there for a long time, I let the beer sat for a little bit. There were a big off white lace.

The smell I got hints of raisins, some chocolate (the again my nose isnt very expert in this), the taste gave was kind of sweet with the presence of the raisins, a little bit nutty, alcohol was very present in the taste (thats the only thing that threw me off a little bit) the again its a 11.4% ABV, I got also some carbonation feel.

I would have again (but in fall or winter, it was a little bit hot yesterday, lol)

Serving type: bottle

Nice foamy head and I like how the carbonation stuck to the side of my Trappist glass; not much lacing though. I detected chocolate in the aroma.  Excellent carbonation and I barely noticed the high alcohol content. It tastes a bit like some imperial stouts that Ive have. I was extremely impressed with the taste. It was kind of burnt and smoky, and it had a pleasant, bitter aftertaste.  It really doesnt get much better than this, which explains why this beer is so expensive.

900th rating. Bottle as shown. Pours a very dark brown with a medium creamy beige head that lasts awhile leaving spotty lacing along the glass. The aroma is a sweet malt and alcohol with plum and caramel. Thin mouthfeel with a sweet malt with caramel and light roast. Alcohol present but not too overpowering. Really enjoyed this one. A very complex and amazing Quad from Rochefort.

Dark with a head of fine bubbles.  Aroma like milk chocolate or toffee.  Taste is of brown sugar and dark fruits such as prunes or figs, and with a silkiness to the palate.  The finish has a bit of chocolate flavor to it which really doesnt last long enough for me.  A great beer.
Very full flavour. Reminds me a bit of Westvleteren but is less pronounced. I dont really like the colour and Im not a fan of the massive amount of yeast. NEvertheless, this is a great beer!

Pours a dark brown with a small off white head.  Aroma is raisins, plums, black currants.  Taste is again the purple fruits with a lot of complexity.  Such a nice beer.  Made this one last most of the night.

UPDATED: OCT 25, 2011 Had to rerate from a 2.5.  Just tried another bottle that had been aged for about 2 years, and It was absolutely sublime.  Pours a deep brownish-purpleish-red, and smells like plum, vanilla, childrens cough medicine, and a little potpourri.  Very enticing. Then the taste comes and its perhaps one of the best Belgians I ever put my lips on.  Theres tones of vanilla, plum, raisin,  molasses, candy sugar, with a full rich velvety body, sweet with a mildly bitter aftertaste.  Loads of vanilla and dark fruit, on a huge body.  Pure joy in a glass.
Dark reddish brown with a decent head. It has a sweet and spicey smell. It has a strong Belgium taste with a mild taste of spice.

Poured from a 11.2 oz. bottle (dated 071014) into a Chimay goblet.

Appearance: Pours an opaque chocolate brown with a 2 finger thick and foamy tan head with a large amount of sediment in the head and throughout the beer. Nice lacing throughout.

Smell: Obvious smell of alcohol mixed with dried fruits and just a hint of malted sweetness.

Taste: Very complex flavor which mixes sweet dried fruits and spices up front. Hints of malt and caramel in the middle and just a hint of something medicinal. The alcohol is fairly strong at the finish and provides a nice warming sensation.

Mouthfeel: Full-bodied with a high amount of carbonation and a distinct alcohol bite.

Drinkability: Very high drinkability, especially considering the very high ABV. This is one to drink slowly and savor.

Overall: A top quality beer all around. There is a reason this beer is rated so highly. If you see it, buy it.

pours deep cola color with lots of floaters - dense impressive head that stayed nearly through the entire drink - roasty chocolate flavor but couldnt hide the immense alcohol content - best enjoyed on a cold winter night as an after dinner sipper

(Bottle)  Stoutragious a/k/a QuezXLV beer pick of the week. Pours to a thin head with very little lacing.  Dark brown in color, semi-clear with mild carbonation. Unfortunately, I did not pick up on any aroma. The taste is of prune and dark cherry, sweet malt and alcohol with a pleasant bitter after bite.  Work well as a dessert beer.

Bottle. Poured a muddy dark brown with little bits of yeast floating with a large frothy tan head that was quickly dissipating and had fair lacing. The aroma was of a roasted bread malts, light herbal hops and a doughy yeast with notes of molasses, plums, figs and raisons. It tasted wonderfully malty-sweet at first with a hint of molasses and finished a bitter-sweet with notes of dried fruit and had a mild alcohol twinge. Mouthfeel was med to full in body and quite creamy in texture with a soft carbonation. Overall an outstanding strong ale, defintely worth trying!!

Tasted 7/14/10.  330ml bottle.  030215 & 09:37 on the bottle.  Activated pour produces an opaque brown hue.  Finger width of loud and quickly dissipating off-white head.  Aromas of soggy breads and dark esters.  Toast and berries.  Mild fig and raisin note.  Faint flair of alcohol hits the nostrils.  Full bodied with a great mix of sweet breads and tart fruit.  Then the effervescence hits and the tingling carbonation adds a new dimension of tart and tangy to the palate.  Dark berry notes, both fresh and dried.  Raisins and a touch Port wine.  The alcohol is noticeable, but it only adds yet another dimension to the already wonderful complexity of the palate.  This is truly a great beer!  I know that I have had it sometime ago, but never bother to jot down a note or two.  Fantastic!

Bottle.  Pours opaque dark brown with considerable light brown debris suspended, topped by a medium light brown head.  Aromas of plum, raisin, grape, champagne, molasses, brown sugar, berries, cocoa, and port.  Flavor is soft cherry and berry, cocoa, sugar cane, and candi sugar, with an alcohol, berry, and yeasty finish.  Medium/high carbonation, and very warming.  This is really good.  A great beer, very complex.
Purchased at QFC in Lynnwood, WA.  Pours a very dark brown.  Aroma:  Plum, raisins, dates and other dried fruits.  Flavor:  Same as the aroma, with a hint of chocolate.

UPDATED: MAR 1, 2013 A: Rich espresso brown body.. khaki head theat lingers and leaves thick lacing behind.

S: Mostly caramel, raisins, alcohol, dark cherry and coffee.

T: Similar to the nose but much more complex and discernible. Large dose of caramel, chocolate, and coffee. Accented by raisins, plums, dark cherries and a healthy dose of alcohol. Yeasty tones are throughout.

M: Rich flavoring in a creamy-smooth presentation on the tongue. Moderately carbonate. A nice finish with lingering belgian yeastyness.

O: Spot on for a huge quad.

UPDATED: JUL 31, 2012 Bottle, 0.33l. Dark color with creamy white head. Plum aroma. Taste cherry and plum, strong in alcohol. Smooth finish. One of the best beers, I ever had. Made for slow drinking enjoying all components of beer.

Wow, just wow.  Dark pour from bottle.  Pillowy head.  Taste is plum, prune, figs and raisins.  Layer of alcohol is certainley there, its just so well hidden.  Complex, yet perfect in many respects.  Bought this on a whim and so very glad I did!!

Pours a muddy dark mahogany, with a fluffly creamy head. Smells of sweet plum and raisins. Big nutty raisin taste with a deep plum and currant finish. Wonderfully put together. Despite the 11.2 abv there really isnt any alcohol heat present. This is a phenomenal beer.
I was excited to find this at Decatur Wine & Spirits. Strong, thick, sweet, malty, with an alcohol kick.

12 oz bottle. 06/28/10.
Pours a deep, dark brown with slight red/purple hue and minimal white head. The nose is enticing with dark purple grapes, bananas foster, clove, plum, spice, black currant, dark cherry, and caramel. The taste is dark cherry and black currant mixed with grape juice at first, followed by caramel, toffee, bananas foster, pepper, and bubble gum. The palate is creamy thick, and a little oily. The mouthfeel is a little bit velvety and really great. This is the best quad Ive ever had. Thank you Trapiste monks. Great brew!
P.S. The 11.3 % sneaks up on you...

Soft aroma, cant quite put my finger on what it smells like though. may need to drink three or four more bottles. very easy taste to it, sort of reminds me of Smithwicks, just better. doesnt leave a bad after taste like some ales ive had. over all im definitely buying more of this.

Best Quad I have ever had.  On the nose, grapes punch you in the face.  Additionally there are nice of dark fruit.  Color is a dark brown with a fluffy white head.  Taste is grape/ raisin.  palate is smooth with persistant carbonation.

Buonissima birra trappista di colore tonaca di frate ha una schiuma molto cremosa e persistente di colore nocciola.Al naso si apre con profumi di frutta secca (fichi),caffè,liquirizia e pepe.In bocca è forte,corposa ma vellutata.Il suo gusto richiama quello dei migliori cioccolati e lascia in bocca sentori maltati e amari.Ottima

Pours a deep red/light brown with a good two and half finger head. Its bottle conditioned and thus unfiltered. I went ahead and dumped most of the yeast into the beer since its a Belgium Quad. A nice light brown head leaves good lacing. It smells of sour fruits and earthiness with a lot of yeast esters and alcohol.

I get a lot alot of alcohol warm immediately with dark fruit flavors that have a bit of sweetness. But this is my no means a sweet beer, there is enough bitterness in the back end to keep it balanced. This is my first Quad so I dont have much to compare it to. Carbonation is on the high side, giving it bit of a champagne-like quality. Definitely a dry beer that doesnt leave much after its hit the tongue.

This is a remarkable beer that deserves all the recognition given to it.  Without doubt a top ten.  Its an autumnal brown and wears a lovely fluffy head that lows to a lacing that goes on and on.  A swirl reinvigorates the head and leaves a pattern on the glass that remains throughout.  The nose is roasted brown sugar, caramel, a bit of spice and some alcohol.  This beer is heaven in your mouth.  It covers everything in a thick honey texture and leaves a heat at the back of the throat, reminding us of its 11.3% ABV.  But a beer like this needs a little heat.  Taste is of brown sugar, malt, sunny figs and oozy dates.  There are raisins, some banana like notes and a bit of a earthy or grassy hops in there for good measure.  Mainly its the Belgian candy sugar that wins out, going on for a superbly long finish.  A true classic that guarantees I will not be the first, nor the last, to consider a monastic life if it means getting closer to this heavenly creation.

Ive had this beer many many times in the past but never thought to rate it. Bottle from liquor shop around the corner. Poured into a WestMalle glass. Pours an opaque dark brown colour, with lively carbonation and a nice lasting white head. The sediment doesnt fall to the bottom of the glass, but stays in there floating. Funny. 

The scent is, like most quads, very complex. A bit like sour cherry, alcohol, spicy yeast, and above all, fruits. 

The taste is very similar to the smell, but went above and beyond. Incredibly complex. Wow wow wow. What a beer. Roasted and caramel malts, chocolate, fruits (plums, raisins and maybe some citrus??), mildly spicy yeast and some tones of alcohol (surprisingly low for a beer with more than 11% alcohol content). 

The mouthfeel is fantastic too. Rich and creamy, impressively balanced. Medium-high carbonation.

Overall, one of the best quads out there! It is important though to let the beer warm up a bit, so all the flavours are fully released!
alcohol, butterscotch, raisin, smoke, vanilla, woody, licorice, resin, chocolate, coffee, roasty, nuts, caramel,

Pours almost opaque dark brown with huge bubbly head.  Beautiful roma of chocolate, maple syrup, cake batter, raisin - almost along the lines of a dopplebock.   Sweet and velvety taste.  Amazing, but hard to describe.   Oily mouthfeel.  Tastes of...maple syrup, atrace of smokiness/  Theres so much more to it, but I cant put myfinger on it.  The taste is extremely smooth, the individual tastes are so well blended together.  Alcohol is barely evident in a slightly peppery finish, otherwise the 11.2% is extremely well hidden.  Not much of an aftertaste.    Wow, what an amazing beer.

Bottle - Pours deep, dark, and hazy brown with a small light brown head. Smell is of dark fruit, plums, raisins, honey, booze, and a bit of toffee, tobacco, and lots of sweet malt. Wow...so complex. The taste is a bit of a letdown from the nose, with toffee, caramel, and vanilla. Its rich and malty, with a bit of hop presence in the finish. Warm and boozy going down. Its a bit thin and watery, surprisingly, but creamy nonetheless. A fine beer, but I was almost expecting a religious experience.

Dark brown with nice head. Aroma sweet malty and dark fruits such as date, figs, raisin. Taste is the same and some caramel, molasses and a noteable warm alcholtouch. Full body, text slight thick. Carb fizzy. Finish with some chocolate bitter.

Sweet malty aroma, notes of roasted malt and alcohol.  Very creamy, full bodied, smoooth, strong plum notes.  Long finish with a bitterness almost sour touch.  Overall this is an impressive beer that demands slow sipping.  Prost!

Served from bottle into a Chimay goblet.  Pours a nice dark brown with a nice three-finger head that lingers througout with a dusting of brown sediment on the top.  Lacing is excellent throughout.  The aroma is comprised of fruit and alcohol.  The flavor is full of fruit, malt, nuts, and big alcohol notes.  It was medium on the palate with high carbonation.  Overall I am glad I got to try this and am happy it is readily available to myself.  The aroma and flavor of this brew is nothing short of awesome.  Definitely try this given the opportunity if you have not yet.

Bottle at Le Baron in Eindhoven, NL. Pours a dark brown color with medium tan head. Aroma is bread, raisins, dark fruits, candi sugars and yeast. Flavor is very bready, but balanced by a nice sweetness and dark fruits. Slightly boozy, but not bad. Very tasty!

Pour is a very dark umber with a slight reddish hue. Nice thick lustrous head with decent retention. 

Huge malty nose, tons of caramel, molasses, toast, chocolate, all the usual suspects plus a bit of citrus as well. 

So much malty goodness in the taste! Big raisinated fruit, baking spices, caramel, nut, just awesome. Nice lingering finish with chocolate and a hint of fruit as well.

Palate is perfect. Literally.

Overall just a stellar beer, hits every note well, super drinkable, super tasty, super well made.

12 oz bottle from Tournament.  Deep dark brown pour with some sediment floating in the beer, about a finger of tan head.  Aroma is slightly boozy, intense rich flavor of dark fruit.  Lively mouthfeel, tastes dance on my tongue, complex, rich dark fruit flavors with a nice sweet finish.  Amazing beer, glad I finally got to try one.
The Belgian quad. I think theres enough reviews for this one already. Just try it!

This was my first experience with Trappist style beer. The sweetness through me off somewhat at first. However I would not say overly sweet. I really enjoyed this beer and will definitely buy again.
I am new to reviewing beer, so I cant offer a more descriptive account. I can only say what I like and dislike at this point.
Really amazing - loved this beer  - strong but great complexity of flavor and very good for the soul

Bottle.  Pours a deep, dark brown/black with a thick, tan head and lots of sediment.  Nice plummy, malty, citrus aroma.  Flavor is what the nose indicates - dark fruits abound along with some bready malt and a warming alcohol flavor and some bitterness lurking in the back.  A very full-flavored beer with a lot of distinct notes blending together into an impressive whole.
Barley nose, spicey taste but warm on the palate. It was my first rochefort so ill try the other two.

bottle.  pours brown, cloudy, with tan foam and lots of sediment.  Aroma of alcohol, chocolate and raisin.  medium sweetness and full body, slick feel, average carbonation and long finish.  This beer really grabs you from the first sip with its distinctive flavor.  Like I once said about about single malt scotch: its goes down smoothly and it hits you hard.

Bottle from Csakajosor.hu. Poured black with a light beige, lacing head. Licorice, bubblegum, dark fruits, anise, chocolate in the aroma, overall surprisingly fruity. Dense body with high carbonation. Sweet taste, alcohol is present but not so much in the taste, more on the strong kick on the palate. Warms one up quickly.

A maroon brew, on the viscous side, with an ok tanned head. Mild fruitiness intermingles with the malt in the bouquet. Touches of apricot arise. Mellowed body of aged malts and hops with an undercurrent of cider and aged wood. Ok, but nothing extraordinary. Alcohol is extremely well masked, yielding no significant off-flavors or ethyls. However, other than its remarkable staying power, this brewer has failed to impress.
Wow, great beer!  I thought the smell was a little soso and somewhat harsh to non-existent.  However, this brew was perfect on the tongue with a great start to finish and excellent overall taste!

Bottle, in a Chimay goblet. Pours a deep brown/black with a small light tan head and lots of floaties. Very raisiny and sweet nose. Flavor is just plain impressive: loaded with raisins, grapes, plums, nuts, a little caramel, spices, currants, and a pleasant amount of alcohol. Palate is pleasant and smooth. I could drink bottles and bottles of this beer and still be impressed by it. In fact, I wish I had more, because Id be very happy to have another bottle right now...

UPDATED: AUG 11, 2010 33 cl bottle, dark colour with a decent creamy head, aroma is plums, raisins and alcohol, taste is sweet consisting of dark fruit and malt caramel with a hint of alcohol, long smooth finish and a nice mouthfeel, some sediment, fantastic beer.
very dark brown beer, slight transparent liquid, very tasty, goes down smooth with a rich taste, has a bit stronger taste than its contemporaries, very good

Pours a nice dark brown with a nice frothy head. Smells delicious - malt, raisins, a little yeasty.  Tastes about the same. Little sweetness that gets a nice counter with the alcohol. Getting it close to the source really makes a difference as the ones Ive had in the states were not close to this good.

Bottle procured at Vintage Estate on 09 Xmas Beer Trip with Nate.  Bottle marked 290414.  Pours rich, chocolately brown with floaters, producing a fizzy, light tan head dissipating to a rimming and filmy 1/8 of an inch.  Some OK lacing.  Alcohol, raisin, grape, brown sugar, molasses and maybe some maple syrup.  Tastes is dominated by dark fruit, plum, dates, raisin and red grapes with brown sugar sweetness and a touch of molasses and caramel.  Nice alcohol burn with a moderately full mouthfeel.  Its reputation preceeds it, and this beer lives up to it.

UPDATED: AUG 19, 2011 Sweet smelling (grapes?) aroma.  Pours an off white head.  Alcohol is present but subtle.  Many flavors present yet not overpowering.  Tastes of grapes, blackberries, and other such flavors.  A tasty beer indeed.
8/19/11 Pours a brownish color with a light brown head.  Pretty stoke about re-trying this one.  Smelling yeast and grapes.  Bit sour.  Taste is sweet.  Sugary dates.  Hard to pinpoint what is in this beer.  Might bump up my original rating slightly

UPDATED: JUL 23, 2010 Poured a hazy red/brown with a foamy tan head.  Aroma is sweet with lots of spices and caramel.  Some alcohol present.  Taste is very complex with a good blend of malts and spices.  Some orange/grape flavors.  This is probably the most complex/balanced beer Ive had.

UPDATED: JUL 10, 2010 11.2 oz bottle, poured into Knings Hoeven trappist glass. Has a murky dark amber/mahogany color with a short lived fizzy white head. Nose is brown sugar, alcohol, molasses, and raisins. Taste is the same, additionally with  chocolate and licorice. Mouthfeel is fuzzy with a slight cloying finish on the back of the tounge. Overall, my appreciation for this beer has decreased since I got into imperial stouts, but it is still an excellent brew.

Aroma is of light berry, dates, caramel, and malt. Pours a dark, murky brown with a solid, firm, thick, tan head that lasts.  Taste is light fruit, nut, and some muted bitterness with a chocolate finish that gets to you.   Thick, and cotes the mouth very well.  Not quite enough to make this truly outstanding.
Bottle.  Aroma of alcohol, raisins and plums.  Flavor is more of the same with a sweet and lasting finish.  A great beer with a multitude of flavors.

Good one, but there is nothing special to say about it. Fully diminishing fizzy head. Aroma is perfect: strong plum notes. Rich fruityness in the flavour, black currant also present but a little bit one-dimensional with this. Full and alcoholic body. It didnt manage to hide the alcohol. Pungent palate.Ive expected more from my 100th grade.

I recently tried this beer and was so impressed I chose to join this web site just to let the world know...seems the world already knows. This is pure decadence bottled. Decided to shout myself a carton (24) on my birthday. Very impressed with how subtle the alcohol taste is for such a strong beer.

Scored this little ditty at the neighborhood utah state LQ store.  I know, right?!  Damn fine spirit.  Grown-up root beer with absolutely no funny stuff.  No lacy panties or head, but sometimes you dont need those things for a good time.

Very carbonated on first pour, but settles quickly. Very thick head that lingers to last sip. a little on the cloudy dk brown in color. Is a little thick and heavy but the flavors of raisins and plum will knock your socks off.  FANTASTIC BEER

Sweet, subdued candy aroma with a slight dish soap tinge.  Huge brown head giving way to low, steady carbonation.  Caramel, malt, well-hidden alcohol and a quick, near-sour twang on the finish.  Buried fruit; earthy.  Light wine-type accents.  Slippery smooth down the hatch.  Certainly a good beer but fell short of the mark of my personal tastes and preference.
330ml bottle-cloudy and yeast brown pour-creamy tan head - nice ,lacings-aroma and taste of dried fruit,roasty, raisin, -tonge numbing bitter alcohol finish

Very lively carbonation initially, lots of bubbling and fizzy.  Given a chance to calm down, the flavors really come through and palate changes to an almost creamy texture. Delicious aroma and flavors of dark fruit, prunes, raisins, spice, malt, figs, and even chocolate.  Delicious!
Simplement la meilleure que jai bu  jusquà présent ! Je la conseille à tous !

A masterpiece of a beer. A absolute treat, one of the true greats,has the perfect blend of malt and bitterness.Tastes of fruit and spice. Alcohol not that noticable in taste, but definitely in effect!Overall, this is a unique and incredible beer! This one poured a very large, foamy head which took a while to settle.
