Sweet and complex, a wonderful brew.Smooth, creamy, and as close to perfect as a beer can be.
caramel, cereal, licorice, brown, frothy, tan foam, light sweetness, medium bitterness, medium body, thin feel, lively, long finish, bitter, alcohol,

UPDATED: MAY 24, 2010 Fresh bottle: Almost sizzling when poured. Dark russet brown, head diminishes immediately to a tanned foam ring. Tons of dark dried fruits in the aroma. Raisins, plums, figs and dates are all in there. Also some licorice, spices and just a hint of yeast. Taste is not as sweet as I expected, finishes rather dry. No appaerant bitterness. Warming alcohol, but still smooth mouthfeel, though not creamy. All those dark fruits lingers in the aftertaste for a while. Body is medium, thinner than I thought. A solid beer!

2003 bottle at Kulminator: 
Aroma: 6 Appearance: 3 Taste: 6 Palate 3 Overall: 13
Dark russet brown with almost no head. This one has developed a flavor of cough medicine and some menthol that just disturbs me too much to enjoy this beer. There are also some raisins and chocolate.
Bottle. Pours a cloudy dark brown beer with a small head. Raisins, licorice, chocolate, berries and a little caramel. Full-body. Taste is sweet and yeasty. Really liked this one.

11.2 oz. bottle- Pours the darkest of the three (#8, 6, and 10) with a thin head and great lacing, aroma is raisins and cherries. The flavor is the best of the three, alcohol hidden very well and is smooth as can be, this is the best Belgium beer ive had in a long time, would have to compare with Chimay blue and St. Bernardus Abt. 12 side by side, but right now this is perfect.

Poured into my Chimay chalice. Had this a few weeks ago and decided to post my notes today.

A- Dark cloudy brown body with bright red hues where the light strikes it. A beautiful tan creamy head fades rather quickly and does leave behind a nice collar. Some bubbles can be seen rising to the top and little to no lacing is left behind in the glass.

S- Nose is strong of dark fruit-particularly grapes and cherries with hints of chocolate and sugar.

T- A well balanced dose of cherry, chocolate, grapes, and sugar is upfront with a big malt backbone. Very sweet and reminiscent of cherry cola or root beer with chocolate. The finish is as complex as the initial taste with a big phenolic taste added to the mix. What lingers is a big alcohol afterburn and some sugary sweetness.

P- Amazing and one of the best mouthfeels I have ever experienced. Medium carbonation with the creamiest body that has ever come across my palate.

O- This is overall a decent beer. Great complexity and mouthfeel but it isnt amazing like I thought it would be. I do like it but it is not one of my favorite brews and I was slightly disappointed by this. The big alcohol presence makes the drinkability average. This is borderline barleywine. I would have this one again but I am not in love with it.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 10-05-2007 16:37:29

Pours murky brown with small off-white head; aroma is earthy with notes of dark fruits, dark chocolate, hints of licorice and even creamy vanill; full-bodied and smooth; slightly hot on the palate, powerful flavor gives notes of sweetish caramel, ripe fruits, spices, dark chocolate and licorice ending dryish spicy with a long spicy aftertaste that gives also notes of some earthy hops.

Bottle.  Pours a deep cloudy brown.  Nose is very complex and spicy.  Some candy sugar, fruits - especially raisin, black cherry - yeast.  Taste is equally complex.  Nice earthy malts, doughy yeast, more spices and a hint of licorice.  Great beer.

This poured a very cloudy and sediment rich brown, with almost three fingers worth of foam on top. The lacing is very sticky and rich. Aroma brings up notes of dried dark fruit such as prunes or even figs though the only complaint is that they are not particularly strong. Taste gives a warm mixture of dates, raisins and even a bit of the belgian signature candy sugar. Of course, the sweetness is kept to a check and not overdone as is more common with the lighter belgian ales. On the aftertaste, there is a distinct taste of caramelized malt in addition to just a touch of  alcohol. The alcohol becomes a bit more noticeable as the beer warms up. A superb belgian for any suberb occasion.

33 cl. bottle.  Pours a dark earthy brown with sediment noticeable, kind of frothy fizzy tan / creme colored head, which sticks around with great lacing / bubbles.  Aroma of plum, fig, grape, blackberry, subtle notes of butter, burnt sugar, toffee as well.  Really unbelievable silky, soft, smooth mouth feel, and the 11% is only noticed as a warming sensation after the sip. Full bodied with a fair a little less carbonation than expected but still noticeable.  Taste reveals at first a spiced bite of candied fruits, which progress to a very long finish that begins with a molasses feel, then goes to fruits, but possesses at some points a sort of dryness but ultimately leaves the breathe of plum and raisin.  I think I like st. bernardus abt. 12 a bit better, though rochefort 10 is certainly deserving of its status as one of the top tier beligan abts, this is really just as good as it gets.

33cl bottle. Poured a large head of light brown creamy fins bubbles and an opaque cloudy dark brown yeasty slightly carbonated body. It has a strong caramel malt aroma with a complex flavor of roasted malt, spices and caramel notes. The alcohol content was noticeable, but still well hidden. Overall, an excellent beer!

33 cl bottle. Poured a dark brew with a white. Complex aroma of spice and roastiness. Taste of spice is complex and alcohol taste is subtle even if the beer is 11.3%. Body if full and support well the mix of spice from this beer.

The aroma came out more as I continued drinking and was pleasantly fragrant. The appearance wasnt what I was interested in but reminded me of black ebony wood. The taste had hints of raisins and wasnt too straight forward. I enjoyed the way it settled nicely in the back of my throat and expanded a warmth to my stomach. This may be the best beer I have ever tried and I would recommend it to any enthusiast!

UPDATED: MAR 25, 2011 Bottle from Capones. Strong plum and raisin presence, though not overwhelmingly so. Basement aroma, clove. Not bitter or sour. Moderately sweet. Extremely mellow and smooth. Deserving of the high ratings its received.

Bottle pour into trappist glass.  Aroma was not heavily present initially, but came through more and more strongly as I drank...over ripe dark fruits, yeast, very pleasant.  Pours a murky brown, cider like as many have noted.  Small tan head that quickly dispersed but made for nice lacing.  The alcohol flavor comes on quite quickly, but each sip is better and better, plums and currants rise to the occasion.  Drinks like a fine wine.  Carbonation and alcohol make for a warming sensation.  Every sip is better than the last.  What began as a bit of a letdown came through to be a fantastic brew experience!

330 mL bottle from Premier Gourmet in Buffalo, served in a Trappist glass. A young bottle, expiry 01-10-13. Pours cloudy mahogany with a small tan head. Head fades quickly, leaving trace lacing. Aromas of raisin, black currant, roasted malt, maple and yeast. Aroma becomes more vinous as it warms, with notes of brandy. Flavour is sweet throughout, with a lingering peppery alcohol finish. On the palate, medium-full in body with a syrupy texture and lively carbonation. Quite astringent. As the carbonation settles, it becomes fairly smooth. Overall, another excellent beer from the monks at Abbaye Saint-Rémy. It is an incredibly complex, ethereal beer with beautiful malts and an aroma that beckons from across the room. Definitely one to savour. More aromatic and complex than Rochefort 8; fruitier, at the expense of floral notes. Stands up to Westvleteren 12. A side-by-side comparison between the two will be necessary. 2010-04-16

The liquid is brown with some deep purple highlights. The head is a light beige and leaves excellent lacing. Brown sugar, dark stone fruits and Belgian earthy complexity. The flavors combine in a very appealing fashion. Its a really great beer. There are just a ton of flavors. Lushly creamy and smooth. Warming.

From Bottle Barn, Santa Rosa CA. 
Poured a deep brown with a light tan clumpy/pillowy head into my Duvel glass. Fizz was very audible. Beautiful head but disappeared quickly.

Color was dark brown with a faint ruby backdrop and was impermeable to light. Had tight but lazy carbonation.

Nose: Dark fruit, raisin, bread. Alcoholic heat that cleared my sinuses. Little to no aromatic hops.

Taste: Malty, alcoholic opening with slightly roasty notes in the middle, more alcohol, then a very slight hop bitterness in the finish. 

Mouthfeel: medium bodied, vinous and slightly oily with a mild alcoholic burn.

Overall a very tasty warmer, but was not quite as complex as I was anticipating. For the style I prefer Gulden Draak which is slightly more complex and has a longer finish.

found at AJs while on vacation in Phx;  biggest feature is the aftertaste.
Toooooo much hops (belgian) and/or carbonation - honestly not fun to drink;  not even close to st. bernadus 12 in my book

UPDATED: OCT 17, 2010 33 cl bottle.  Pours a dark reddish amber with a small white head leaving almost no lacing on the glass.  Aroma is sweet with raisins, alcohol, and bready yeast.  Initial taste is sweet with raisins.  The finish is bready and warm with alcohol.  Light bodied.  Low carbonation.

Pours a deep purpleish-brown color, like raisin juice, with lots of floating sediment from the 330ml. bottle and topped with a soft, light beige head: A wonderful bouquet of aromatic notes includes dark plum, rich vanilla, soft yeast, black currants, raisins, chewy figs, and other dark ester-y characters. Delicate/fine carbonation, medium-bodied. A bit sticky. Flavors of dried prunes, plum, black currants, a good amount of raisins, figs, and candied sweetness. A pleasant lingering finish awaits, full of vanilla and alcohol heat. Drinkability: With one sip, Im taken into another dimension. A really good one to relax with. Perfect for a Sunday evening. Pairing: Abbey cheese, lobster, creme brulee. Rebuy: Yes. #385 on 09042010, DG.
Dark Rich Brown pour with out much head very aromatic. High 11.3 ABV is well hidden. Overall an amazing brew

Bottle, from blankboy. Dark murky brown pour. Aroma is just awesome. Blueberries, black currants, sugar cane and a slight wild aroma, kind of earthy/wet hay. Taste is fruity and sweet with a slight herbal bitterness towards the very end. Palate is hot and full of alcohol and it lingers and lingers to no end bringing back all the enjoyable flavors.

hhhhmmm good beer pours a cider color with a nice white head and good lacing. aroma and flavor is belgian yeast, plums, and dates. nice mouthfeel, but a little lighter than i was expecting. a little hot from the alcohol, but expected a little more burn which was good. overall a pretty damn good beer, and did not expect it to be as light as it was. personally i like the 8 a little better, but still i can see why it is highly rated.

Poured from a bottle into a tulip glass
A: chocolate brown, almost looks like cider. large head, calms quickly and sticks to the side of the glass.
S: light fruit, malt and molasses or toffee
T: warm, sweet, caramel, with good carbonation. 
fruity, peppery finish which lasts
I was aware of the alcohol, but less than the ABV would have you expect.
M: medium. some burn but not overpowering
D: except for the price and the ABV, gimme, gimme, gimme!
One of the best out there. Full-bodied, rich head, notes of blueberry and plum.

UPDATED: JAN 23, 2013 Bottle. Appearance is a dark oak brown color with pulpy particles and seed fragments settled at the bottom. Retains a thick and foamy light brown head with excellent lacing. Aroma is slightly earthy and yeasty with plenty of dark fruits, bread, herbs and caramelized sugars. The taste begins with brown sugar, toasted malt and Belgian yeast followed by dates, currants, toffee and medicinal herbs. The body is thick and creamy with full carbonation and a dry, candi sugar aftertaste. Alcohol flavor is present throughout and warms the belly but never overpowers and definitely doesnt feel like 11%. The overall flavor is incredibly complex with all sorts of complex dark sugar, fruit and yeast notes working together in harmony.

Bottle tasting at home, provided by trade from a very generous source whome I have so callously forgotten, I appologise!
  Wow... what an experience.  Going into it, I was expecting a good beer from all the hype, but wow.
 Dark amber/brown pour with a big head that sticks around for the whole experience, amazing lacing that glues itself perfectly to the side of the glass. Full, heavy, creamy body with a lighter than expected carbonation after seeing the head.  Expansive fruit flavors that keep playing with your palate... rasins, plums, something else - just a hint of tartness that adds so much to the experience. This big boy has a bite at the end that perfectly finishes the experience.  So hard to stop myself from taking one drink, then another, then an...

I picked this one especially for my 1000th rating.  The aroma is gorgeous, plums, raisins, candi sugar, vanilla.  The appearance is an equally beautiful deep brown, reddish hue, large off-white head.  Particulate matter is visible in the beer.  The flavor is a nice dark fruit/berry experience, alcohol, slight roast.  The finish is sweet, then moving into a pleasant piney hop bittering.  Medium/thick in body, slick mouthfeel.  Almost flawless.

11.2 oz. bottle from The Party Source, though Ive seen this everywhere- which is awesome, given this beers rating and reputation.  Tried side-by-side with the 6 and 8.  Pours a murky dark brownish plum color with a big beige head that settles into a nice, creamy cap.  Aroma of caramel malts, dark fruits (plums, raisins, figs, cherries), cream, yeast, candi sugar, alcohol, and a little bit of a metallic note.  Nicest aroma of the three- best balanced, by far.  Flavor of sweet caramel malts, candi sugar, dark fruits (same as above), yeast, cola, alcohol, and the same metallic note I picked up on in the aroma and flavor of the 8 and 10.  Maybe thats the kind of thing that would settle out over time, and this was a 2009 vintage.  One thing I love about this is that it smells and tastes different with every sip; the 6 and 8 do the same, and it makes for a really interesting drinking experience.  Medium-bodied, with gentle carbonation and an alcoholic finish, though the finish didnt seem stronger than that of the 8.  Great beer.

Tasted a 6 year old one i had stored.

Aroma:
Very malty, and roasted taste with a hint of caramel.
Appearance:
Clear dark red-brown color, with a noble and humble tanned head.
Taste:
Heavy sweetness, and medium bitterness.
Palate:
Full body, creamy texture with a soft carbonation. The finish is long and a little sour.
Overall:
I enjoyed this beer listening to music and writing notes to this review. I would definitely recommend that you store some of these every year to taste them later. Remember to mark them so you can see what year they were bought.
Brown and hazy, with a bit of a tan head. Alsmost too sweet. Also a bit sourin the finish.

33cl bottle. Opens with a little gush and pours a darkbrown to black beer with a huge creamy beige to lightbrown head that leaves some nice lacing. After pouring the full bottle in the glass there is some floating sediment. Aroma has some notes of malt, dark chocolate, fruits and alcohol. Taste is full of sweet malt, dark chocolate, bitter coffee and some sweet fruits like pears, some light hoppy bitterness and a nice alcohol warmth. Mouthfeel is as soft as silk and the drinkability is superb. A magnificent quadrupel with an extremely rich palate and compared to Westvleteren a great availability!

Perfect Trappist Quadrupel. Rich malt, brown sugar, and plum. Both strong (11%) and tasty. At 10 oz per bottle, it would be easy to imbibe many, but at $10 per bottle, it would be easy to stop. Worth every penny though.
bottle to snifter. Pour is thin brown with a solid inch of bubbly head. Aroma is sweet malt and caramel. Palate is very fizzy feel and sweet dry finish.

Trappistes bieres seems to have their own unique carbonation.  The fizz brings out the 1 finger light brown head.  The head soon disappears for good.  Smell is coffee, dark fruits, vanilla, spice, and one of kind belgian malts.  Taste is strong and brought out by the carbonation, dark fruits, coffee, tart and smooth at the same time, delicious.  Sediment in the bottom is all good for me!

Firm and rich beer, first burnt CO2-enlivened coffee beans & nuts, then sour cream and finally dark chocolate aftertaste. Every sip is a feast for the whole mouth. I prefer to drink it from the bottle, as the taste lasts longer.
Very beautiful, dark pour with nice creamy head.  Strong hints of espresso with a wine-like finish.  Alcohol is rather prevalent but doesnt overpower this quad.

In WoW terms: 1337, or for the rest of us: ELITE!
Beer doesnt get more complete than this. Never mind all the weird stuff thats written in the tasting notes - Its freakin perfect. Never mind the ABV, it tastes like an 5.0%!
Thank you, Belgian Monks!

Bottle served in a snifter at Bullys.  Pour was cola with about 1 finger of slight off-white head.  Nose is sweet cherries, prunes, raisins, alcohol, and malt.  Taste was the same but the malt was more pronounced.  A very tasty brew, but not one I would drink often, yet I cant site a reason for that really.  Despite frequency, one cant go wrong with this brew.

Pours a cola brown. Lots of sediment in the bottle! Beige head with no lacing. Nose of caramel and dark fruits. Plum, raisin and black cherry. Malty. Very complex aroma. Extremely complex flavors. Sweet prune flavor. Cherry, vinegar, a little boozy. No hops at all. Medium body on the palate. Good carbonation levels without stinging. Coats the mouth and linger. Overall an amazing beer. With the huge distribution, I didnt think Id like it this much. But this is fantastic!

Sweet and creamy beer. Although it has 10° alcohol, ist very easy to drink.
Aftertaste is slightly bitter. A must drink!

UPDATED: APR 16, 2010 Bottle pour a dark red-brown with a thick yellow-brown head.  Great aroma of dark fruits.  Taste of currants, plums, brown sugar and malts.  Palate with a lingering alcohol bite that I enjoyed.  A keeper.

aroma is dominated by yeast.  big fluffy head and a nice fizziness in your mouth.  A wonderful mix of flavors and a satisfying aftertaste. very strong alcohol taste... maybe a little too strong, and the typical quad esteriness is very mild.  I tried this from a bottle but im sure I would like it even more on draft.

Pours a deep, dark brown with a thin head
Earth, wood,  dark fruits, caramels are pretty dominant in the nose. 

The taste is amazing. Thats strong but also...smooth. Candy sugar and grapefruits are there. Very rich and complex like a good old wine.
11.2oz bottle. Pours a very dark almost chocolately color with a tan colored head. Smells of dark fruits, plums, almost cloyingly sweet upon first taste. Not a big fan of the mouth feel. Too sugary.

my favorite !
appearanc, not clear.
taste : good in balance : malt bitter sweet

Bottle.

A - Deep, mahogany brown with a good sized tan head

S - Lots of dark fruit and rum scents, along with a bit of spiciness (both from alcohol and spices)

T - Full of dark, run-soaked fruit (raisin, plum, fig, dark cherry). There is also a good amount of spiciness to it with peppery and clove flavors (amongst others). Really reminds me of a Christmas Pudding, which is a good thing. Good balance of those sweetish/fruit flavors and a full bready feel. This beer has a warming effect but the alcohol is pretty well hidden.

M - Creamy and smooth. The body is medium to full, but could probably be a bit fuller. No real major complaint though.

D - Really good beer for sipping. Might not be one that I would drink more than one a night, but one that I would definitely drink again.

Notes: I really enjoy this beer, well balanced and pretty complex. Really wonderful to sip on during a winter night.

Brownish black pour, red glow. Large creamy tanned head.
Aroma of sweet fruit, yeast, raisin, liquorice, hops,
Flavour is very thick, full and complex ranging from bitter to very sweet, smooth ride with fruits, raisin, liquorice and much more.
Awesome beer.

330 ml bottle.  Pours a dark brown with a big tan head.  Head reduces to a nice looking film on top that leaves some intricate lacing around the glass.   Aroma is alcohol, bread, strong plum and raisins, and some spices.  The alcohol is very noticeable in the taste, along with the many other flavors similar to the aroma.  Very complex and balanced.  Sweet with a light bitter finish.  Creamy and medium bodied with a good amount of carbonation.  Overall an excellent beer and one to be thoroughly enjoyed.
dark bread, malty,sweet,black,  lightbrown foam, light sweetness, lightly sour, medium body, creamy, lively, long finish,
Una cervesa espectacular, però que sha de guardar pel seu moment. Que et tomba.

Bottle. Pours with a huge brown tan head over a very dark ruby body. Aroma of bread, plums, and spices (coriander, carraway) with a sweet solventy earthy touch. Tastes sweet, with dry spices and solvent elements. Finished with an earthy subdued bitterness. Light bodied and spritzy. Complex.

Provdatum: 2005-06-04 
En av dom bästa. Måste höja till en 5:a 
Den är så perfekt att ja inte vill sätta något verbalt omdömme - du måste prova den!

Sampled from a 330ml brown bottle in a trappist glass at Pub Italia in Ottawa. High expectation being a top beer on this site. Poured a dark brown colour with red highlights and a creamy tanned head. This left a film coating on the beer for the remaining drinking time. Some lacing was left also. The nose was mainly of raisins and plums with hints of almonds. The scents were very light though. The taste on the other hand was very strong, but not much on the alcohol side... considering its content (11.3%). Some oranges (like Triple Sec) and plums. Spices in the aftertaste. The mouth did drop fast though. In most of the strong brews (I have tried), this is probably the one that taste the less in alcohol. Easy drinking.

Very close to a perfect beer. There is loads of flavors and multiple layers of flavors, dark fruits, yeasts, roast malt, etc. But whats amazing is how balanced and smooth it is, all that flavor packed into a somehow subtle brew. Delightful.

Has a somewhat bitter, smokey coffee type aroma. Appearance is dark, cloudy with a tan head which dissipates quickly. Taste is medium bitter with a light sour aftertaste to go with the smokey aroma. Has a creamy texture with a fizzy after finish.

A reasonable beer, but not to my liking.

This is one of the behemoths of the beer world. A monolith in the art of brewing. One of the absolutely best beers from Belgium, if not the world. Trappist ale Rochefort 10 was one of the first truly awesome beers I ever tasted, and one of those seminal drinking experiences truly opening my eyes to the world of Belgian monastic brewing and its intricate mysteries. It pours a deep caramel brown which turns almost black in the glass, with a thin off-white head. Rochefort 10 smells like a whole treasury of flavor, all blended exquisitely: raisins, plums, figs, bread, grapes, booze and bakery yeast. The aroma and taste follows: delicious dark malts and a rich tapestry of various fruit and hops, delicately wrapped in a significant layer of alcohol - Rochefort 10 is one of those beers intentionally using alcohol as an integral part of the overall flavor. And it works for me; this monastery ale weighs in at 11,3 % ABV, warming my body up with each jagged little sip of pleasure. Mmmmm. This is what a full-bodied beer is all about. The only reason I dont give it the full score is due to its matchup with "big brother" Westvleteren 12, which manages to take me all the way to beer heaven. Make no mistake though, Rochefort 10 will take you to the pearly gates. And then some.

330mL bottle.  Pours a murky dark mahogany with suspended sediment and a thin layer of light brown froth that soon dissipates entirely.  Aromas of dark fruit, spices and toast.  The flavours are of dark fruit and a bit spicy leading to a dark vinous character.  The alcohol is noticeable throughout.  Full bodied, quite soft carbonation, smooth on the palate.  The finish is fairly dry and reminiscent of a good port.
Bottle. Aroma is sweet. Pours a rich deep brown. The taste is a real treat. Hints of almost candy. Caramel, raisons, chocolate. This is a good beer.

11.2oz bottle that Ive been sitting on for about 2 years. Pours a cloudy, brown colored body with an amber tint to it. Just a few trace pieces of sediment. Finger-width, creamy and frothy, tan head that dissipates fairly quickly and leaves lots of lacing on the glass. Aroma is much richer than either the 6 or 8. Tons of deep caramels, chocolate, and toffee. There are also heaps of dark fruits to accompany the vast array of malts. Not as floral as the 6 or 8, but loaded with prunes, raisins, dates, plums, and definitely some black currants and other black berries. A bit of a syrupy sweetness, banana bread, thick yeasts, and some peppery alcohol. Very big, thick, dense, and complex aroma. Flavor is more the same. Heaps of caramel and chocolate, dark fruits, and some molasses-bread. Raisins, dates, prunes, plums, and a nice berry-like, black currant taste with just a pinch of sharpness. Syrupy sweetness with some more banana bread, peppery spices, nuts, earth, and a somewhat salty alcohol. Finishes rich, warm, and layered with a solid bitterness that slowly dries with a lengthy aftertaste. Full body, very smooth, and a soft, creamy carbonation. Overall, I tasted the 6, 8, and 10 side-by-side and I wanted to like the 6 or 8 more than the 10. I was HOPING this beer was overrated, but this beer is awesome. Big, soft, rich, and complex, I have nothing to complain about here. This beer is spectacular and anything but overrated. Wow.

Bottle.  One of my favorites.  Dark brown but creamy pour with nice creamy head.  Very complex.  Chocolate, nuts, caramel, earth, and a lot more.  Brown sugar, plum, nuts, and raisin.  Nice bitterness that makes this very enjoyable.

A beer that we have enjoyed so many times but never have rated. Poured a hazelnutty dark brown with a café von lecce coloured head. The nose has a lot of caramels and chocolate along with some roasted notes. The taste is massive with a lot of sweet malty notes. There is marzipan, plums in madeira, brown sugar and some bitterness. Its huge its godzilla-like and quad-wise you dont get it much better.The mouthfeel is medium to thick with a sweet and long lasting finish. This beer is epic
What else can be said about it?  The classic quad ... in my book.  One of my gateway beers.

An amazing onslaught of flavor, although it is hard to describe.  Some cherry, chocolate, a bit of hazelnut.  An amazing malt base, and the alcohol is clearly there, but it isnt offensive.  A strong flavor and a strong beer.  Excellently made.  Worthy of the high rating.

Thanks to my buddy Keith for the beer. Popped this open after a great beef tip mushroom dinner. Pours a beautiful Clear Mahogany, candies are a little faded, but nice yeasty finish. Picking up nice plum flavors and great carbonation. I could drink another.

UPDATED: JAN 7, 2013 Bottle.  Fruit, raisin and alcohol aroma.  Deep dark body with medium, lasting head, nice lacing.  Flavor is filled with plum, molasses, raisin with hints of caramel and chocolate malts.  Slightly tart, but balanced with sweetness, with a dry finish.

Creamy coffee like in appearance.  Malty aroma with some fruit.  The flavor is predominately fruity with alcohol background.  A pleasure to drink and savor.  Fruit, malt and alcohol are very well blended making this offering a real treat.

A: An opaque dark brown with a thin layer of white foam.

S: Chocolate, figs, sugar, raisins, and vanilla.

T: Chocolate, figs, and raisins with a nice sweet finish.

M: Good body, a bit of fizz, dry.

D: Wonderful beer. Im not normally a big fan of Quads, but I am doing my best to try all of the Trappist ales, and this is one that has definitely lived up to the billing.

Pour is a very thick dark brown with a large beige head. The aroma consists of carmel, toffee, and dark fruits. Taste is of dark fuits, raisins, malts, syrup, with a big alcohol kick at the end. A really complex beer, but very nice especially on a cold winter night.

botella comprada en spain
aromas a malta, frutos secos, higos, canela, flores, y notas dulces en gral., notas de alcohol tambien.
color marron, turbia, toques dorados.
buena espuma color beige, poca carbonatacion, muy buena retencion y muy buen encaje!!
dulce en paladar, con cuerpo, avinada al final, seca tambien.
notas dulces intensas debidas al alcohol y no, pero las debidas al alcohol nada molestas.
notas de chocolate, jerez y whisky, cerveza fuerte!!...cañera!!
para despues de comer...ideal!

Took a lot longer to find this then my friend Walt and I both hoped for, but the pay-off was well worth it.  The aroma is dark fruit, prunes, raisins, and figs.  The appearance is wonderful with a beautiful purplish deep raisinlike brownish color with a complimentary off color tannish head.  The beer left a darker spot from its sedimentation.  The taste is again full of everything from figs, black currant, plum, raisin, candy, and alcohol.  The finish is long with a full body, a sticky texture, a fizzy carbonation, that is not too much.  The long finish is amazing.  Thank you Rochefort and Walt.

From the bottle, pours a very dark red with a thin off-white head.  Berries and alcohol in the aroma, similar taste.  Lightly sour finish, but exceptionally smooth throughout.  Just look at the ranking, go try one.
UPDATED: DEC 17, 2013 Bottle. Hazy cola brown pour. Thin white head. Aroma was sweet grapes. Taste is fig, earth, wood, and alcohol. Awesome.

Pours a opaque dark brown. Small beige head that fades to lace quickly. Aroma of fruitcake soy sauce alcohol wood. Fruity dark rye bread flavor. Smooth, almost creamy with a alcohol kick. Clean finish, very little aftertaste, but a oily feeling on the lips. Overall a excellent brew. but if the ABV was turned down a bit it would be even better.

this one hits you. With aromas of dark/brown bread, a bit roasty, paired with  resin, and hints of barnyard. I sensed it to be earthy, showing traces of alcohol, raisin and plumb.
The appearance is a hazy brown with tan foam. The taste is showing a medium-heavy sweetness, punching with a full body! A rather likable oily/slick texture feel with soft lively carbonation and a solid long finish.
sold at wallingford wine on rt 5 for just under 6 $ a bottle. worth every penny.

Pours dark brown and hazy with a very nice beige head. It has a very complex aroma consisting of dried fruits and berries. Flavors of sweet roasted malt, syrup, raisins, dates and blackcurrants. Very complex right through-out. Alcohol is quite noticeable but I have to say it to be well balanced. So much going on here, but truly amazing.

Deep brown beer with a nice reddish brown head. Nice fruity aroma. Good balance of sweet (fruity like raisins and sugar / caramel) and the slightly bitterness of the hops. Nice boost afterwards caused by the large amount of alcohol. A small downside is the eventual appearance of a somewhat sour taste.

Pours a cloudy dark tea color with a thin tan head and a lot of yeast sediment.  This beer has a wonderful sweet candy smell along with malt and spicy fruit aromas.  The flavors are sweet and fruity, including Belgian yeast, malt, candy sugar, vanilla, figs, spices, and brandy.

I really enjoyed everything about this ale, the aromas, flavors, the creamy mouthfeel, and the warming alcohol finish.

UPDATED: MAY 13, 2012 Some beers gets close, but none can keep me surprising like this one. Everytime i open a bottle, the aromas that comes towards my nose are excellent. The beer looks even great at the glasses that are specially made for it. Normally ive always Rochefort 10 at my home, but still, I only drink it at special occassions like a birthday, or if I had a REALLY good day. I wont ruin the taste by drinking it like on a regular base. This beer is one you mostly just love or hate... some of my friends dont like it at all... 

Edit: Tasted at 2 oct. 2010 a bottle from 7 years old. Dark redish, small head that leaves a lace. Very nice fruity-sweet, caramel smell. Caramel comes up even more then at a fresh bottle. Like the smell for sure. A bit darker red coloured substance it seems. Very nice sweetness, the fruits still comes up so nice, but its a bit earthy-dusty cause the age. Red fruits and caramel comes up some more. This beer ages beautifully for sure.

Pours very dark brown with an off white head.  Aroma is amazing and very complex.  I smell malt, alcohol, carmel & banana.  The aroma is fantastic.  Taste is very malty and sweet with a strong alcohol presence and a lingering fruity aftertaste.  This beer has a lot going on.  Very good but not for the faint of heart.

Dark brown to black with thick, soapy lasting head. Nice rich malts, mildly sweet, fruity notes.  Clean and full mouth with bright carbonation. Complex mix of chocolate, pitted fruits, malts and spice with a mild alcohol and bitter finish . This is a fantastic ale.

Nose is sweet and doughy, like walking into a French bakery in the morning. Nice dark color, with copious sediments (mostly left in the bottle) Fluffy whitish head. Although stronger in alcohol than the Rochefort 8, this example is better balanced and the flavor of alcohol is much more subdued. A smokey/woody flavor comes through with a crisp finish.

Bottle. Pours hazy brown, lively body, lots of lumpy sediment, small off-white head. Body starts with slight acidic and bitter-sweet taste, has a bitter finish. Palate is lively and creamy. Complex aroma has licorice, raisins, fruits, herbs, malts, chocolate. Aftertaste lingers and has balance of warmth and bite.

Pours dark, deep ruby/dark bown with a big, off-white head that fades slowly with some nice lacing. The nose is full of dark malt, deep fruits (prunes) hints of dark chocolate and some light sweetness. Taste is amazing with more deep fruit, some chocolate, toffee, spices, some rum character, some alcohol and some sweetness on the back end that does a pretty good job of masking the alcohol... The mouthfeel is medium/smooth.

Bottle from Kenny Road Market, poured into Chimay trappist glass. Pours a solid, translucent brown with a finger and a half of tan head. The aroma is outstanding; fermented grapes, apricots, and dried dark fruits, alcohol, and earthy yeasts. It tastes vinuous with notes of dark bakers chocolate, plums, currants, and caramelly malts. Palate is full bodied with slightly bitter finish (but not overpoweringly so). Great stuff.
( 330ml bottle best by 1-10-13) Pours clear brown with nice lasting head. Nose of sweet bread, alcohol, and Belgian yeast. Taste of chocolate, alcohol, raisins with a creamy finish. Great beer.
Bottle 33cl. Not clear, coffee-like colour, sent of dried apricots and prunes. The taste is round, mouth-filling, very nice!
Bottle 33cl. Dark brown/red with beige head. Complex aroma sweet fruits (pear, peach?).  Wonderful sweet long lasting taste. A very complex, fantastic belgian ale at it´s best.
A very nice colour, dark with a nice head. Very complex aroma and taste. Waw a real degustation beer. A lot of different flavours comming right at you. Nice one. (Bottle 33cl)

Trappistes Rochefort 10
11.2oz bottle 11.3ABV
Pours hazy brown with a reddish tinge. Small thin tan head with lots of floaties. Sweet floral aroma mixed with grape hard candy. Some fruity alcohol on the nose, almost winelike. It sort of smells of wort.  Effervescing mouthfeel due to the constant bubbles. Flavor of alcohol, red table grapes, some yeast, and roasty malt. Warming finish due to the alcohol. Balanced, but not overpowering. Darn good, but still not great.

Pours out a very dark red with thin beige head,  I can make out some dried fruit and wood notes on the nose but those are overpowered by alcohol.  The taste is not so much like beer but more like whiskey, as Im not a whiskey fan this is offputting.  Not to mention the pure ethanol aftertaste.  I can see why people would like this but it just doesnt do it for me.

Very dark red/brown color with a lasting beige head. Good lacing. Lots of sediment in the bottom of the bottle. Aroma: Dark fruits, plum, raisin, figs. Some blackcurrant, bread, grain, sugar, yeast and hay. Taste: Very good balance. Sweet, vinous but also with some bitterness. Warming alc tickling the tongue. What a beer.

Very dark brown with a thin, but lasting beige lace. Complex aromas of prunes, bread, candied fruits, almost nutty. Full body, lots of malts flavor, caramel, some bitter chocolate, very satisfying mouthfeel that rapidly make way to a warming alcohol presence. Aftertaste is mostly alcohol with malty notes. i think I prefer the 8 over the 10, but still a unique and very good monky brew.

Pour was a dark brown with some ruby when held to the light.  Poured into a trappist glass with a pretty thin white head.  Aroma of dark fruit- plum, fig, dates, currant, and booze.  Taste was smooth on the palate with date/currant coating the palate and some alcohol on the back.  Pleasing and not overpowering.  Theres not much out there that beats this.
This beer is simply the best trappistes beer on the market. It has a delightful full flavor with a mouth feel and flavours of dark fruits and subtle chocolate.

UPDATED: NOV 20, 2010 Murky dark brown, rather pale beige head is a bare coat. Complex fruity aroma - berries, orchard fruits and citrus are there but they meld together. Some earth/ forest floor smells too. Taste starts sweet and then explodes. Alcohol is very noticeable, but is completely integrated into the flavour of the beer - its like a warm burst towards the end of each sip. A little tartness and some residual yeasty bubbles combine to leave no thick sweetness at the end, just lingering flavours and aromas. A lot of things and yet just itself. Beautiful. [4.5] This one is even better - lovely thick head that lasts in a Trappist glass and laces beautifully. So big, but so easygoing. Complex and harmonious. [4/10: 4.7]Coat of a head but it never quite disappeared. Distinct blackcurrant and chocolate in both aroma and flavour that were less obvious in previous bottles. Alcohol feels a little heavy but is never hot.

Pours dark red, and smells kinda like grapes, plums and spices. Tastes sweet, yet sugary and it definitely hides the alcohol content VERY well! Finishes with a little bit of spice.  Overall a fantastic Belgian that is an absolute must try.

Very dark reddish brown cloudy pour light head aroma of dark fruits ..... what a taste!! definitely dark fruits plum, raisins ..... a perfect mellow fruit taste .... very well balanced with a nice spicy kick for a finish ..... this is one amazing beer with awesome flavor and no trace of the 11.3% when your drinking it

As far as I am concerned, the only problems with this beer are the price and I wish it lingered longer.  Pours a cloudy dark brown/red with a large two finger head that fades quickly with no lacing.  The aroma is fantastic - malt, yeast, plums, raisins, alcohol, and some merlot and faint hops too.  The taste is amazing with huge brown sugar sweetness that is balanced with just the right amount of hops.  Its has a large malty/sugar component that lingers on the plate as you get mouth warming.  This definitely better than the 8 is probably one of the best beers I have ever had.  Its best cool and then allowed to warm some.  Once the beer warms you get all the wonderful complexity and taste released.

UPDATED: JAN 31, 2011 Earthy and vinous Dark beer with yeast suspension. Rochefort is one of the best trappist beer on earth. You got too drink it slownly, like a heavy wine. Perfect in wintertime it will warm your entire body. More than a beer, an experience.
Bottle.  finger and a half tan head that fades after about a minute.  Smells of caramel apples, vanilla, and pears.  Thick dark mahogany body.  Sweet and rich.  Smooth and an all around great quad.

Had from bottle at the Rochefort Brewery.  Take your time to smell the aromas in this one, malty caramel, toffee, nutty, toasty, sweet, yet raisiny licorice, vanilla in the nose, the taste is ever better, unbelievable flavors, need to drink more and more to identify them all, easy to drink, yet worth sipping, probably my favorite beer ever.

The beer pours a beautiful dark brown color.  Has a thin creamy head to it.  Initial aroma from it is an intense dark coffee/chocolate smell.  After that it had a real nice burst of fruits to it.  The taste of it is a real nice smooth blend of fruits and a hint of vanila.  Very good beer that I am glad i tried.

Finally decided to pick this up. Pours a muddy brown body with a big kinda fizzy dark tan head in my Chimay glass. Some nice lacing also. Really good aroma of plums, sugar, raisins, yeast, and berries. Flavor is very similar with dark fruits, just the right amount of sweetness with a nice dry balance. Super smooth and easy drinking. Alcohol is no where to be found, even at 11.3%. Great beer.
Dark brown, thin head that dissipates quickly. Heavy malt aroma. Very fruity and caramel flavor with some alcohol aparent. Overall great. One of the best Ive ever had.

333 mL bottle pours a deep, dark tobacco brown with minimal head and nice lacing into a chalice.  Aroma of brown sugar, sweet malt, plumbs, raisins, date, yeasty esters, bit of noticeable booze.  Starts plumby with a continuous malty/brown sugary sweet backbone.  Finishes yeasty, spicy and sweet with a good spot of noticeable alcohol burn (pleasant).  Soft mouthfeel with low carbonation; full bodied.  Exceptional sipper that warms beautifully as you drink.

Dark brown with a 3 cm pale beige and creamy head that settles into a very nice layer of foam on top of the liquid.

The smell is nicely layered and rich. Chocolate, coffee and rye bread. Vinous fruits and a pleasant spicy character. Some notes of alcohol.

Plenty of roasted flavors of coffee and toast. Very good taste of chocolate. Some wood and earth. A quite restrained fruitiness (plums, cherries, black currants). Quite a lot of warming alcohol in the finish. Some spices, hints of oak and vinous fruits rounds everything up. A very rich and sophisticated taste overall.

Full body, very smooth despite a slightly sticky texture. Very pleasant mouthfeel. Phenomenal.

A high-class beer for sure. Well balanced, rich and powerful.

Serving type: bottle

(Copy of old Beer Advocate review)

Bottle provided by thirdeye11. It is beer No. 999 that I have tasted.

Pours medium brown with a beige head. Aroma is some alcohol with dark fruit. Also get some brown sugar. Flavor is alcohol, dark fruit and some brown sugar. An outstanding quadrupel and one that I will seek out again.
Pours a very dark brown with tan head. Aroma consists of malt and dark fruits. I taste a lot of malt and dark fruits similar to the aroma. Goes in bitter and out sweet. Great beer.

Wonderful deep, dark brown colour with lasting tan head. Aroma is strong and of fruit and malts. Flavor was also strong. Tasted malty with fruity notes. Not particularly bitter, sweet or sour. Well balanced. Finish was of a strong alcoholic kick though perhaps not as strong as one might expect. Overall this was good but I really did expect more particuarly given what I paid for it. Still I recommend.

UPDATED: JAN 18, 2010 This beer pours a nice dark brown colour with a medium beige head. The aroma is is of chocolate and coffee malts with fruity undertones mostly raisons. The taste is sweet at first with hints of the chocolate and fruit, then there is a little alcohol taste in the finish. The carbonation is quite nice too. Overall this is a great beer that is a must try.

Luxurious nutty brown aroma. Looks like it belongs sitting on a cafe table in Belgium amid passers-by. The overall taste and palate are stellar. They are fairly gentle aside from the more potent (noticeable) amount of alcohol, which is not completely balanced with the rest of the brew it would seem. One of my best Christmas presents. Delicious.
Aroma is sweet like candy with lots of malt. Pours dark amber, with a medium off white head. Extremely complex with lots of dark fruit, malt and yeast. A really nice beer.

Bottle.

Cloudy dark brown color with a small thick head. 

Earthy aroma with a hint of alcohol also dried fruit and spices. Complex and very inviting. Flavor was fantastic! Dark fruits, sweet malts, juicy,  complex and with some warming alcohol. Great mouth feel, smooth to drink. A fantastic beer!

Poured dark brown into glass with long lasting multi layered head.  Aroma fueled by carbs, yeasty and chocolaty. Sediment suspended in fluid. Bitter taste complexed with a medium sweetness from caramel, fruit, and malt. The alcohol content is very high, but is well layered into the flavors. A little too stouty for my taste. This is basically a much better produced/brewed 1554  Excellent beer, but I guess I prefer Chimays drinkability and slightly lighter bitterness.

Pours a hazy brown with a decent sized tan head, very viscous.... Aroma is dominated by cherries and dark fruits, subtly sweet, with a booziness to the aroma... Flavors are quite complex, subtly hoppy, with notes of dark fruits and sweet malts coming through differently each sip... Very carbonated, with a dry finish, medium bodied... The high level of carbonation was a bit of a turn off...
Pours a hazy brown, with a nice head. Rich fruit notes, with a clear alcohol bite. Smooth and Strong. Fairly complex, and it does pack a punch. Thumbs up on this one....

Aroma is crisp, strong, fruity and malty with just a whisper of sweetness. It pours a hazy, barely translucent, dark coppery brown with a very thick and pale tan head. Flavor is malty and fruity with a hint of caramel and a fierce but not overwhelming alcohol bite. Texture is very smooth, yet quite fizzy and tingly, leaving a satisfying and lip-smacking finish with fruity and caramel hints as well as a touch of sweetness.

poured with a thick creamy tan head that didnt move. lasted like budding sun rays on the 8th hour of a gloomy, cloud swarmed day hahahahaha. seriously tho, this brew has a rich, extremely ark brown colour, and the head shows the evidence of its sediment throughout. smell boasts fruits all the way, and are complimented by incredible hops, with a hint of alcohol. the taste. incredible sweetness. i cant pick out the complexities of the taste, but all i can say is hot damn! can taste a bit of alcohol in the sweets, but not at all overpowering. insanely smooth and creamy. lacing is great, and man, that head just wont vanish.

A very cloudy dark brown color.  Aroma is yeast, alcohol, and some sweeter spices.  Flavor is of dried fruit, alcohol, yeast, and raisins.  Has a sweeter yet strong alcohol flavor in the end.  It definitely lets you know that you are consuming a real beer.  Good stuff.

Enjoyed from an 11.2oz bottle in a whiskey snifter.  The beer pours a deep brown color, with a thick light tan head.  A very strong alcohol note greets the nose up front, followed by more mellow aromas of raisons, prunes, and slightly burnt caramel.  The palate also features alchohol, although in the finish, and proceeded by a splendid melange of malts, and a perfect level of carbonation.  Overall, worth the wait and hype, and surely a beer that would continue to improve with age.

Bottle. Not sure why I never got around to this but....  Pours a cloudy rich mahogany with no head. Nose is sweet with belgian yeast and candied sugars.Lightly carbonated and  Richly flavored with dark fruits and candied sugars. Refined and sweet with a hint of the abv. A must try. A beer that others are judged against.

330 ml bottle. Pours with an enormous and thick light tan head, beer is cloudy, very dark brown colour. Complex aroma: oak, port wine, dried fruit and spices. Taste is spice, raisins, port and oak - toffee sweetness is well balanced with hops. Long lasting aftertaste.  Delicious

UPDATED: JAN 29, 2011 Refrigerated bottle poured into a trappist glass.  Pours a dark brown completely opaque with little head that disappeared quickly.  Nice lacy and unbelievable mouth feel.  The aroma is earthy with a hint of alcohol.  The taste is wonderfully complex and is pretty easy to drink considering the ABV.  The flavor is malt (tone is mostly molasses), dried fruit (tones of figgs, plums etc.), and a hint of spice.  Best quad I have had.
Earthy  aroma.  Beautiful creamy, thick white head on a rich dark brown pour.  Palate is a clear 5, bright and coating.  Flavor is complex and delicious  - dried fruit and nuts.  mmm mmm mmm.

Very delicious beer.  Roasty, floral aroma.  Great thick chocolate like appearance, with a thick foam.  Malty flavor with hints of caramel, roast, malt, sublte coffee notes.  More of a flat feel on the palate, but still full, with a long malty finish.  A unique beer that warms you.

33cl bottle $7.19, I have been meaning to try this for a while. Turbid brown despite my attempt to keep the yeast out, almost black, flimsy head. It smells like vinegar and pickles at first but as it warms up it becomes sweet candied spices. the flavor has a quad-like sweetness but it also has a strong black licorice quality to it. The alcohol is not blatant but I know it is there because I can feel it. Overall I liked Rochefort 8 more.

If Carlsberg made proper  beer they would probably make this one. Slightly murky appearance, but a strong head that lasts leaving lacing on the glass. Heady sweet aroma, and intense initial taste of plummy sweetness. Satisfyingly full mouthfeel without being heavy, silky. Fantastic.
Bottle from Berts Bierhuis. Pours dark brown with off-white head. Smell of plums and caramel. Taste is also of dark fruits and caramel. I love this beer!

UPDATED: DEC 26, 2009 What can I say? Figgs; caramel. brown sugar, roasted malts and vanilla. One amazing beer. Folks if you want a cheaper alternative to Westy then go for this. I love this beer. Poured from bottle into my old yellow emblem Rochefort glass. Good times. I just want to compare this aged. This beer is a quad but I feel the alcohol irrelevant as its evocative and pulsating and makes lifes problems forgetable. This is holy.

From a 330ml Bottle 06/12/2009
Floral aroma. Dark strong in alcohol and malty. Smooth on the palate with a hint of dryness and bitterness in a warming finish.

een leuk donker bruine body met een zeer licht bruine schijn in het moes achtig schuim.een mooie samen loop van zachte grane smaak en hop en een zeer zachte licht droge afdrong waar je ook een hint van granen in terug vind. kort om een zeer lekker zachte trappist goed vlot te drinken ondanks het hoge alc. gehalte

UPDATED: JAN 19, 2010 Pours dark opaque brown with a huge frothy tan head that lasts until the beer is gone. Aroma- molasses, cherry, plum, raisin, grain, toasted malt and mild alcohol. Taste is sweet and rich and very smooth. Alcohol is pleasent and mixes well with the complexity of the rest of the beer. Medium body with a smooth carbonation. Would be better with years of age but is still fantastic.

UPDATED: OCT 30, 2011 330mL bottle, pours a dark brown with a big beige head. Outstanding nose of black currant, raisin/other dried fruit and dough/yeast. Very, very complex flavour - raisins, plum and spices. Wonderful. My favourite Quad.

UPDATED: OCT 26, 2011 opq-dk-br, creamy-tan-head/lace, high-co2, full-bod.

dark-fruit malt bittering-hops bready-yeast alchl silage toffee oaky aroma. 

fruity malty vanilla-oak T1, alchl-warm T2, whiskey roasted-malt T3, lots of sticky sweetness.
^warm through, dozens of flavors filling my senses. one of the better dark abbey ales ive had, though im really not a fan of the style in general.

UPDATED: JUL 22, 2013 Bottled 10/08. Nose is pure heaven. Dried fruits, freshly baked bread and winter hearth. Maybe a little pumpkin and onion like aromas. Incredibly complex. Sweet on the palate and fairly smooth. Finish lingers. A true work of art, seems to be peaking, but I would still like to see how they improve over time.

tasted side by side with the westvleteren 12, bad mistake.  the westv put this one to shame which i thought before was a decent beer.  it poured a nice maroon/purple color smelled boring and tasted sweet.  alchohol is hidden but you can taste it

bottle courtesy of bmartin08. nice extra! pours a thick brown, fairly cloudy with some floaties. aroma has some figs and prunes, and a lil dough. the taste is a lil odd and i cant tell if its oxidized or is just hot and needs a few more years. it full of all the goodies, just slightly askew. but the after tasate is amazing, deep and complex. id like to try a different vintage now and get more of an idea of how it ages and develops.
Bottle from The Trappist. Pours a thick brown with beige head; fluffy but stays for some time. Aroma has notes of raisins, bananas and figs. Flavor is sweet but finishes dry. Excellent Quad!

Pours a dark maroon with an off-white head and nice lacing.  Fruity nose.  Taste of raisin, banana, pear, and plum.  Notes of molasses.  Alcohol is astoundingly well hidden, virtually no notes of alcohol in the taste.  Thick full-bodied mouth feel.  Sweet, fruity finish.

Smells a bit bready but also a bit like something that was stored in plastic too long...?? Quite dark, nice head and lacing, not really black or able to see particles though, just dark. Big bold bread and malt flavour. The biggest part is at the mid palate and the aftertaste, it fades away nicely. Very nice, though as I drink more I can taste that extra alcohal, maybe a lesser one would be better for a regular drink.

Pours almost black with a thick creamy off-white head. Aroma of earth, basement, raisins, dark chocolate and even a hint of red wine. Very warm full bodied sweet flavor of raisins, plum, and spices. Very long lingering bittersweet finish that has my mouth tingling. I really like this fabulous beer.

Aroma of black pepper and earth tones.  Reminds me of a dark cellar.  Very nice.  Reddish/copper in color with a very thin head that lingers.  Great mouthfeel with a lightly bitter aftertaste.  Very complex in flavor but awesome with earthly grains, fruit and a nice hop kick.  Very warming.  Great beer.

Pours a deep brown with medium head.  Aroma of yeast and fruit. Slightly sweet, fruit flavor running through the malty caramel and alcohol. Medium body with a smooth texture.  One of the most noteworthy beers Ive had the pleasure to drink.

Those priests do know what it is all about. I was somewhat anxious for this one, because the other two Rocheforts had impressed me quite a bunch. Well, the older sibling gets along with the family. 

It poured dark, blurish brown with a fine forming and lasting beige head. Some uniform carbonation at the bottom. 

The aroma flew into me right at the opening (as did Rochefort 6s aroma) with pomegranate, plum, some raisins, oat, wheat, bread and a few dried dark fruits. 

As I turned it into my mouth, the strong licorous taste, such as a ruby wine, got all over my mouth with no shame of the alcohol it beared. Berries, wood, some clove, little banana, fading coriander and a hole lot of raisin and dark dried fruits sweetness. The bitterness came up slowly and fading with the aftertaste.

Altough it is unbalanced to the sweet, it only bothers in higher temperatures. This beer must be drank at the right temperature - if its lower, the alcohol comes ou too much, if its higher, theres too much sugar. But, at the right temperature, the right aromas and tastes flourish grealty.

Amen.

bottle - pours dark brown with tan fizzy head, very lively. The aroma is chock full of spice, raisin, plum and a slight trace of alcohol, this is followed by a bit of earth, leather, fruitcake, caramel and brown sugar (not necessarily in that order ;) ) The flavor was sweet, nutty, spice bread and raisin with the warm alcohol feeling spreading as it went down (maybe just a tad too much).
Excellent beer....

Bottle. Beautiful beer, big dense chunk of sediment lodges in the neck, floaties galore in a nearly opaque brown. Nose is belgian yeast, dark plums, figs and slightly vinous. INitial flavor is the yeast and dark stone fruit, transitioning to a really complex mid-section where more caramel and toffee show up along with a grilled meat kind of character. Really nice. Slight but pleasant alcohol on the finish. World class.

Im very inexperienced at this beer rating game.  This is the first beer Ive tried that seems worthy of discussing on this website.  It is wonderful.  It smells good and it tastes good.  Im not experienced enough yet to distinguish the separate aromas and tastes but the way it comes together is a very satisfying harmony.  Im not saying it is the best beer out there but it will make you happy while you are hunting the best down.

very dark, hazy brown pour with plenty of sediment. medium-sized, but not very lasting head. medium sweetness, fruity aroma. plums, raisins, currants. nice alcoholic sting. paradise bottled: Rochefort responds to Milton. yes, not very clever or funny.

UPDATED: JAN 1, 2013 Bottle. Poured a slightly cloudy muddy brown with a thick light brown head. Aroma has a hint of alcohol, but more present are notes of dark fruits (plums and raisins) as well as some caramel. Flavor presents many notes with only a bit of alcohol, most present are plum, caramel and hazelnut.

11/22/2009:  Trappistes Rochefort 10...  Aroma:  Dark honey and caramel; dark fruitsl; suggestion of alcohol; smells deeper, richer, and more complex than the Rochefort 8; fortified red wine qualities.  Appearance:  Reddish brown color; opaque; thin darker beige-colored crown.  Flavor:  Tastes very much like the Rochefort 6 and 8 only a little more sweet and stronger overall; dried and dark fruits (date, fig, plum, raisin); some creamy vanilla notes; hints of hazelnut liqueur; borderline oxidation being noticable; the alcohol is there, but actually not as forthright as expected for being over 11%!  Palate:  Medium-full body; well-carbonated yet still fairly smooth.  Overall:  Quite good, but I am not really overly impressed; three years ago I used to think that this beer was expensive at $6.99+tax/bottle!
e33 cl bottle ( ALC. 11,3% VOL. / Consume before: 19 05 09 ) from Rivers Bend Wine and Spirits in Maineville, Ohio.  Rating # for this beer. Score:  8/3/8/3/17 = 3.9
Bottle thanks to Cavie.  Muddy brown pour, again.  Aroma is alcohol and chocolate.  Flavor is yeast, malt, and alcohol.

330ml bottle into a Chimay goblet. Now this is a beer to *savor*. Gorgeous dark color in the glass with a wonderful head that remains a long, long time. This incredible beer has a complexity of flavor that is quite intense, so it may be offputting to some..but not to me! The strong alcohol content exhibits itself in the taste, too. Its a heavy beer that needs respect. Sip some in and breathe in some more air to really get this beer dancing on your palate. A top class beer.

Bottle courtesy of BückDich. Hazy reddish pour. Smells of heavy fruit. Dark fruits with heavy wine and alcohol. Powdery perfumey smell. Definite fruit on the taste. Plum that eases away slowly. Tastes chalky with hints of hot malt. Not a top beer for me at all.

Pours a cloudy chestnut w/ heavy foamy head, aroma is lightly dried fruit w/ some syrupy alcohol notes, fig & date flavor w/ carbonation tinge/warm alcohol finish, little heavy on carbonation, pleasant resilient alcohol/carbonation warmth @ back of throat
Bottled. Brown in colour. Nose of caramell, plums and vanilla. A bit of dill maybe? Tastes of herbs and caramell.

Another milestone. Celebrating rating no 150 with the mighty high priest of the Trappists. Pours a hazy dark brown color with a large beige head. Aroma with loads of chocolate, plum, port wine and a caramel sweetness. Flavor explodes with all of the above plus some rum and dark berries in liquor. Presenting a thick creamy texture with a really full bodied mouthfeel and warming alcohol.

UPDATED: JAN 13, 2013 Pours a cloudy dark brown color with tan head.  Sweet malt aroma, lots of caramel.  Taste is dark fruit, raisin and caramel, bread dough.  Some nice bitterness to balance out the sweetness.  Creamy palate; alcohol very well hidden.  Sweetens and mellows as it warms.  One of the greatest.
Great beer. Smells like ripe fruit, bananas. Alcohol is very warming. Hints of port. Very, very good.
Pours dark golden red brown with complete opacity and subtle and sweet aroma. The Flavor is dominated by dark fruit flavors balanced with slight sour, bitter, and alcohol components.

Bottle 330ml. A masterpiece. Aroma has raisins, port, and caramel; with earthy yeast tones getting strong as we go. Flavour is warming and sweet, with bitter notes and a long finish. Palate is syrupy, full-bodied, and the finish is alcoholic. Dark brown colour, cloudy, with a fizzy head that disappears.

I had this at Three Floyds back in the summer! A dark beer with high alcohol content that can not be tasted. The beer is extremely balanced from aroma to the flavor through the finish! This is an excellent beer that I plan to enjoy for many years to come!

UPDATED: JAN 3, 2011 33cl Bottle. Poured a deep, dark murky brown color with a thin dark beige head. Great aroma and taste - both are complex but balanced. Very smooth beer for 11.3%. - the alcohol taste is almost hidden. The carbonation is very mild. This is a great beer. I was very happy to find one of these and it was as good as I expected it to be.
Re-rate: Had another bottle on 01/01/2011 that was about 2 years old. Aroma: big dark fruits, plum, raisin, Belgian yeast, deep malts, mild caramel and booze. Taste carried out the aroma: flavors are all very mellow and very balanced. This beer is so easy to drink: smooth and warming.

Poured from a bottle into my Duvel tulip. Color is dark brown with a cream-colored head. Awesome smell of sweet fruits and molasses that beg you to drink it! Taste is great, fruity with dark chocolate and a small amount of spice with a very small hint of alcohol. Im surprised I cannot taste more of the alcohol since its a 10.5%er. Mouthfeel is light-medium bodied with a good amount of carbonation. Very smooth and has a nice clean finish. I could drink this beer over and over again but then Id probably be asleep by 6pm every night from drinking too much of it!

Intens dark brown with small beige mousse. Aroma is fantastic, sweet, caramel, bread, some roasted touches, fruits and some hop. Taste is superbe ! Rich, sweet ( Spices ? ) malts ,caffee, chocolate and hops. Its is like a mix of Pannepot and Westvleteren 12. Wow what a great Trappist

UPDATED: DEC 28, 2014 Aroma is somewhere between fingernail polish remover and fruit.  The beer looks how a beer should look, no issues there.  The flavor is smooth -- something like a light stout mixed with a citrusy ale.  The mouthfeel is a little fizzy.

Overall awesome, its very smooth for 11.3%, but too pricey to be a regular.

Bottle poured into glass. Very dark brown with lots of tan head.  Taste of spice and fruit. Alcohol blends in with other flavors.  I wouldnt guess it to be 11.3% though.  Mine was fresh, with a date of 29/04/14, so just a little over 6 months. I cant wait to pull one out with a few years on it!

bottle..Hazy dark brown pour,thin off white head , some lacing. Aroma of  spice ,fruit and yeast .Flavor is a subdued fruitiness and yeasty with a complex mix of dark fruits ,caramel,chocolate and a smooth bitterness.Well balanced ,smooth and very well done.Alcohol is present but very well hidden .Carbonation is low to medium.

33cl bottle from Westholme Stores, Goring. Muddy, treacle coloured with a dense beige head; complex aroma, port wine, blackcurrants, plums, richly roasted malts; at first, soft and syrupy in the mouth, heavily laced with rich fruity malts, but then suddenly sharp and penetrating; the finish is soft and fruity again, releasing alcohol pleasantly to warm the mouth, rather like a good sherry. An accomplished sipping beer.
Nice and smooth. Pours dark with sparse off white foam head. Aroma of dried fruit and bread. Surprisingly smooth. One of my new favorites.
Poured into a trappist glass, aromas of caramel and raisins with a lacy head. Initial flavor of raisins and plums, with a slight malty end. Very good beer.

33 cl bottle from Bieropholie, served at cellar temperature in a tulip glass. Lot L120912 11:42.
App.:  Very, very deep brown with a large tan head.
  
Aroma:  Lots of sweet smells, plenty of dark dried fruits, some nice wooden rum notes, a bit of vanilla, some minty herbals, molasses, a little alcohol, caramel/toffee, maybe a touch of butterscotch?, a bit of chocolate, some yeast/bread dough.
  
Palate:  Medium+ body with moderate effervescence and a few sharp bubbles.
  
Flav.:  A little nutty, quite sweet and fruity, plenty of minty herbals, molasses, a bit of vanilla, wood and rum-like flavours, the fruits lend themselves a bit more towards berries than dark dried fruits, some light yeast notes, definitely some alcohol; fairly sweet with enough bitterness to balance, quite a bit of warming, almost stinging alcohol and a pleasant licorice/molasses/wood/sherry finish. 

Quite the beer.  Very complex and quite enjoyable.  Gotta be honest though, the alcohol presence does detract from the overall experience.

The brew is a very elegant looking one with an opaque, brown coloring. You can still see the yeast in the bottle seeing as it is bottle-brewed. The head does also last quite a while in a nice off-white tint. This is a very complicated brew though. The smell was a mix of pretty much everything and I couldnt pinpoint one single thing. It had hops and yeast in the nose as well as being a little sweet, though. The first taste is the taste of air in the carbonation followed by a brown sugar taste. There is also a very prevalent taste of the hops in the brew and an alcoholic ending that was evident, but not overpowering. The texture was all you could hope for in a brew like this. Smoothness is top-notch. Every flavor follows through smoothly between each other and even though the brew is very complex, it finds some way to make everything work.

Light earthy nose mingled with rain.  Thinner tan head sits upon a cloudy brown.  Cinnamon upfront in this spicy and tingling medium bodied brew.  Dark fruit swirls about the mouth making me feel dizzy.  Props to the Bonster for the bottle.

UPDATED: NOV 27, 2009 Pours an opaque caramel-brown color with a thin head. The alcohol is very apparent initially in the aroma and flavor.  They tend to wane (as your senses dull?). Such a complex array of other aromas and flavors.  The fruity bouquet is soothing as an aroma, and titillating on the palate.  This is a beer that got better as it went on, new flavors and aromas becoming apparent in each subsequent sip.  A great beer.
love this beer. syruyp, crisp, fruity, Rich brown with good head and sediment.
UPDATED: AUG 4, 2011 Maybe not as good as it once was and it rarely retains a head these days, but still always excellent and a long time favorite.

Ok, this is not my top all time favorite beers, but it is one of the two or three most challenging beers I have had. And dont get me wrong it is excellent and I would have again at any opportunity (or as long as I was not driving).

Apperance is a thick dark brown, and poured a two finger head which held up on a vigorous pour.

Aroma was very complex, in the end the earthy and oaky smells were dominant accompanied by some limited fruit tones. There was also a distinct traditional Ale yeast smell to the beer.

Taste was very well balanced. The earthy/oaky aroma was noticeable in the taste, along with some sweet fruity flavors. You never lose track that this is an ale, with the yeast in balance and control of the flavor. There is very limited if any hops flavor, and balanced bitterness at the end.

Mouthfeel was unexpectedly think and somewhat dry. Very pleasant.

Drinkability: This went down very smooth, especially for a quad. I did not notice the alcohol in the aroma nor taste. I did notice it in my head a little later.

Bottle. Deep dark brown. Plenty of yeast sediment causes some cludiness. Large coffee coloured head that  slowly fades to leave some lacing. Aroma is a little sweet and sour Lots of malt, dark fruits, vanilla and candii sugar, but also a little vinegar. Plenty of alcohol and fruity esters from the yeast complete the picture.. Flavours are very much in line with the aromas. Dark fruits, malt and heaps of alcohol on the finish, Extremely well balanced. Great beer.

Bottle -- Deep, dark brown appearance.  Drinks with a thick malt syrup character, rich with alcohol and dark fruits.  Piles of candied sugar as well.  Exceptionally well rounded classic.  (#3712, 10/24/2009)

dark chocolatey brown pour, slight off white head. Aroma is of dark fruits, dark sugary fruits; dried plums and raisins and lots of booooze. Flavor is just as smoothy and yummy, still the dark fruity flavors of the raisins and plums or figs, nice smooth sweetness to counteract the booziness but still has that heat with a lil spice. Very nice.

Dark Brown pour with a slight beige head.  Aroma is dark candi sugars, plum fruit and booze.  Brown sugar and some Belgian yeast abound.  First Taste is a shock of brown sugar and yeast, some booze follows.  Slightly effervescent.  The fruit is mostly plum  and raisin, very vinous in nature.  Incredibly complex and yet simultaneously simple and refreshing.  A perfect Abt if there ever was one.

This beer is well balanced with malts, fruits, spices, hops, and candies.  The carbonation is excellent.  The small bubble tingle.  The alcohol content is masked with the combination of flavors, but is present when you breath in the beer over your tounge.

This beer would go great with a leg of lamb!!

Bottle at pub in Belgium. Wow, this made my trip to Belgium worth it. This was an awesome beer. From the pour which was dark brown color with a nice creamy head with lots of lace left in the glass. The aroma was bold with plenty of malt. The taste was well balanced with malts and hops with Belgium sugar.

Drank it just two hours after bottle was turned upside down during travel home.  Murky mahogany appearance; clouded by bottle yeasts but who care?  I was happy to HAVE those yeasts!  Great head! Impeccable balance and CLASSIC Belgian notes.  Nuances of dried stone fruits, chocolate.  Deep malty background with distinguished fruity ester notes in aroma! Outstanding!  Wish I could afford to drink two of THESE everyday...

UPDATED: DEC 4, 2009 Enjoyed this beer with my brother-in-law, Bigguns22 and father-in-law, Fistfull.  I cooked my first Belgian dinner which included a Flemish beef stew which we savored with the full flight of Chimay and three Belgian cheeses (two of which were Chimays)!  Malt, cherries and pear on the nose complimented a beautiful milk chocolate (think Hersheys) appearnce with a medium tan head.  Huge malt coats the palate and tones of cherries, pears, bananas and malts were perceived.  Overall a great one-of-a-kind beer that I only wish I could drink daily!  Awesome!

UPDATED: DEC 4, 2009 Re-rated after awesome Belgian dinner cooked by Twindog and tasted with Fistfull.  Pours medium chocolate brown with dense, tight bubbled foam head - tan in color.  Aromas of candied fruit, slight banana (like Bananas Foster dessert) and strong malt aromas.  Tasted for a second time courtesy of Fistfulls generous $45.00 six pack comprised of the whole flight of Trappistes Rochefort - 2 bottles of each!  Better his coin then mine - good to marry into the family (I hope hes not reading this...).  Flavors of chocolate malt, honey cake and dried fruits.  Overall, one of the best beers ever experienced!  Nuff said.

Dark brown and highly carbonated, hardly any head. Aroma is very deep and complex. In order of decreasing prominence: Dark fruit, alchohol, leather, cigar smoke, licorice/aniseed. Ripe fruit is more prominent in flavour. Vanilla becomes present. Very thick and warming. Alcohol becomes slightly cloying. Idealy it should be consumed with/as a desert.

Bottle. 11.2 oz. Split with Sean and Dave. Pours murky brown/amber with a thick, cloudy beige head. Aroma of raisins, figs, vanilla, chocolate, and traces of alcohol. Fuller bodied with a warm finish. Very good quadrupel.

100th RATING!! i am a virgin to this holy beer and have waited a while for this one. it is not disappointing me at all!! Pours a deep, dark murky brown with lots of yeasty floaties and a nice beige head. aroma of alcohol, raisins, plums, pears, prunes, and the list goes on. tastes mostly like the smell minus the alcohol is well hidden until the somewhat burn of a swallow. notes of vanilla, flavored malts, and figs also. wonderfully balanced and super smooth. lives up to the hype for sure!!

Pours red to brown hazy with a nice tan head, aroma of fruits like pinapple, apple, apricot and citrus with some marmalade, complex full flavor of sweet caramel, toffee and apricot, finishes with cinnamon, clove and nice dry fruit sweetness. Rich full bodied. Excellent beer

Bottle. Pours chocolate brown with nice tan head. Aromas of fruit and wine with a faint alcohol hint. Flavors very rich, sweet raisin and fruit, with a bit of alcohol burn. Gentle bitter aftertaste, but lots of sweet, too. Thick, velvety mouthfeel. Looks great and tastes great too.

Wow, crazy Robust-Aroma! Smooth on the way down and then, BAM, it hits you. Very powerful aftertaste. Lots of flavor, warm alcohol feel, but not overpowering. It was like there was a party in my mouth. I wanted to take a break after each drink...and party! Ive never had a beer like it. It definitely is an experience thats worth the price. I split it with a friend and trust me, half a beer was plenty! Like an old Batman episode. Pow!

Bottle- Had this in the fridge for about 6 months.  Poured with a slight haze rich amber brown, quickly vanishing head with just a light ring around the edge.  A bit of a berry roast n the nose.  Palate happy with a smooth brewed texture.  Aged quality of berries on the vine and an excellent blend of alcohol.  I drank it cold at first then let it warm up towards the end.  What a great brew and worth the wait.
Kings Share- Gathered up the milky brown bottom bits.  Like dark chocolate milk with a slight bitter milky/chalk texture.

Unfiltered dark brown (cola). Quickly disappearing head.

Generous aroma - as described; plumbs raisin. Very VERY nice.

 Not as much flavour symphony as Id hoped. Nice, a little alcohol. Quite well balanced.

 A very nice beer. Mostly in aroma and palate unfortunately.

 Great palate. Thin, fizzy.

Purchased in Kihoskh

Pours a dark clear mahogany with ruby highlights and large fading tan head. Just like the commercial description - plums, raisin, and currants.  Has a decent bit of alcohol warming but totally understandable for the abv.  Too expensive though.  Very good, but Overrated imo.

33 cl bottle, Fargo, ND, USA. Slightly muddy cola colour, no head, some faint carbonation at the edges. Very mild prune aroma, sweet alcoholi flavor with some nice prune mellowness. Lingering burn on the finish nicely completes the experience.

Best beer Ive had!  Dark with a thick eggshell colored head, mild alcohol taste.  Lots of fruit flavors, raisins & prunes, too many to comprehend.  Wow.  Lot of malty flavor.  Like I said, best beer Ive personally had  Tremendously smooth for such a high ABV.

Bottle. What an amazing brew! Beautiful murky dark nut brown color, with thinning light beige head. Very nice lacing. Rich malt aroma. Exceptionally well balanced, extremely complex malt flavors with hints of fruitiness. Booze is dangerously well hidden; very smooth. Enjoying this beer is an experience, one that will leave you dumbfounded over its awesomeness.

Thanks to Rich at Bellport Beer.  I was avoiding this for some reason. I spent about $85 and Rich said its about time you try this, and threw it in. 
In a word, Outstanding! I was really impressed by this. Dark with a thick head, not too much alcohol taste, lots of fruit flavors, raisins & prunes were prominent. Lots of malty flavors, I just couldnt identify them all. Just a smooth & delicious beer I would highly recommend!
A very complex beer almost reminiscent of a fine port.Probably the best trappist ale, but takes second banana to Westvleteren 12 because of its wider distribution.

UPDATED: NOV 3, 2009 Deep dark brown in color with an initially thick head that stabilizes at about 1/8" to 1/4", tan. A distinctly raisiny flavor with a bit of bubbly zest. Not so subtle tinge of carmelized sugars, singed almost. Lots of underlying subtleties...plum, perhaps a hint of cherry, several types of maltiness... Finish goes on.  That said, I have trouble liking this. It is certainly good, but perhaps a bit too raisiny for me.

At 11.3%, I expected this to be a harsh beer, but the alcohol is hidden quite well by the intensely complex flavors. The pour is a dark brown almost purplish black tone with a bountiful tan head. Aroma of fruits and earthy maltiness. Taste is unbelievable- smooth and malty with undertones i cannot distinguish. A slight alcoholic aftertaste. Very smooth for a high ABV beer. Overall, probably the best of one of the best beers I have ever had the privilige of tasting.

This beer surely lives up to its reputation.  Ive waited a long time to try this beer and all I can saw is WOW!  Please refer to the other ratings, I am just speechless.  This is better when sipped slowly at room temperature in a nice tulip glass.

best beer i have ever had in my life, hands down.  tons of flavors attack my taste buds all at once.  i can definitely taste the plum, chocolate, raisin, caramel, coffee, and alcohol. there are at least 10 more flavors in this beer to enjoy as well.

UPDATED: FEB 28, 2010 The 330 ml bottle pours quickly with its long thin neck, leaving a sizable tan head.  The large head dissipated quickly, leaving a short layer of small durable bubbles and a fair amount of lacing.  The body of the beer is quite dark, but reveals a rich copper hue when held to light.  The nose is complex.  Earthy and musty aromas mix with caramel and molasses notes.  There is also a strong alcohol component.  Palate entry is dry and lively, but there is a strong malt backbone giving the beer a medium to full body.  Mid-palate and finish reveal expected dried fruit flavors:  fig, raisin, prune and date; but, there also is a hint of clove.  The high alcohol content 11.2% ABV) is very well-balanced and adds to the enjoyment of this of this Trappist ale.

UPDATED: NOV 2, 2009 Bottle shared with friends. Pours a muddy brown with a creamy and fluffy head. Dark aroma of mixed fruits, chocolate, and malt. Many flavors jump out at me and it seems the character changes with each sip. The sweetness and alcohol are apparent but I think they balance well. A good amount of sediment settled in the glass.
