I was really looking forward to trying this one and it definitely did not disappoint!

Rate date sept 2009. Best before date 070513 (i.e. bottling date may 2006): Pours dark brown with large lightbrown long lastsing head with some lacing. Aroma of dried prunes, raisin bread, caramel and some herbal hops. Complex sweet malty flavor of caramel glazed raisins with a long lasting bitter sweet finish. Outstanding!

Bottle.  Poured rather fizzy with a lot of carbonation and a lot of head.  Dark brown in color with lots of sediment and flakes floating around.  Smell was bold fruitiness with a noticeable alcohol presence.  Taste was dark fruits, plums, malts, and a little bit of butterscotch taste as it warmed up.  A little hard to drink at first due to all the carbonation, wasnt very pleasant at first until it settled down.  Noticeable alcohol heat when drinking.  Overall pretty good though.
This one is good. A bit strong, but the soft fruitiness balances well with the alcohol. Sweetness comes through. Drinkable.

Bottle from Utobeer market stall. Pours dark brown with a beige head. Aromas of bananas, toffee, vanilla, juicy fruit, caramel. Flavours of toffee, caramel, dark fruits, coffee, chocolate. Wow! Finishes big, bad and bold with a wonderful sweet warming finish. Holy smoke! This was a fine brew!

Inutile spendere molte parole per questa birra, conosciuta da tutti. Una delle mie preferite. Scrivere una recensione su questa birra è come farlo per Dark side of the moon dei Pink Floyd.... non serve..
Da provare assolutamente

Bottle. Pours dark, murky brown with big foamy beige head that fades slowly and is noticeably unfiltered. Initial aroma is a lot of chocolate, some coffee and belgian yeast. Taste is nice roasted coffee, some dark chocolate undertones, and throughout the glass I got a hint of wintergreen. Very complex, smooth, and sweet. I didnt really taste the alcohol, but I felt it after the second sip Ƒst beer of the night). Very pleasant brew.
Dark color. Taste of chocolate, dark malts, oak, fruit and caramel. Nice aftertaste. Good beer to finish off a meal.

Bottle...  Poured deep, dark reddish/brown with a thin, light brown head.  Aroma of dark fruits such as plums and raisins with a big ester/yeast quality.  Thick, full palate with a delicate carbonation.  Noticeable vanilla flavors up front for me.  Not much going on with hops here, dark malt sweetness with some fruits.  A wine-like booze character in the finish.

My Goodness! Perfection!

Pours a beautiful dark cloudy brown, with a bit of tan head, some lacing. smell is of fermented fruits, grains, almost brown sugar, with warm alcohol notes. taste is artfully balanced between the grains, yeast, and fruit notes. Mouthfeel is full-bodied yet not too heavy. Probably the most flavorful and well balanced beer that I have ever had! aftertaste is pleasant and warm.

Pours a dark brown color with a lots of yeast in it. A medium big beige head. Aroma is sweet with nuts, burnt sugar and some banana. Flavor is sweet with dryed figs, raisins, vanilla, caramel,  toffee and anise. After a while even some hops. Palate is nice with a sweet fizzy feeling.

33cl Bottle. Official Rochefort glass.
Very dark, medium head. Very perfumy aroma: fruits, doughy yeast, caramel, plums, woody honey. Flavours: light caramel sugar and spices. Explosion in the mounth.
What a superb beer ! 
Im from Belgium and must admit I have rediscovered this fabulous beer. Only one negative point: too much alcohol ... its jumping to the head. You always feel something after driniking a Rochefort 10.

Bought from Swedish "Systembolaget" where it is part of the permanent selection, and is sold for $5 a bottle.

Very dark pour, head disappears in seconds (unfortunatley).
Nose of alcohol, yeast and plums.
Complex taste of raisin, chocolate, dark malts, oak, apples and caramel. Excellent carbonation with tiny bubbles of yeast.
Love the aftertaste.

A very nice beer, and the best one among the Rocheforts 6/8/10 (and the 12).
UPDATED: SEP 10, 2009 i have nothing to say about this beer... I  just prefer to drink it ... Cheers!!

UPDATED: SEP 28, 2009 Bottle poured into a trappist glass at Union Jacks Inn on the Manatawny produced a thin tan head with brown body.  Not quite as sweet as the "6" but still one of the best beers around in my opinion.  Unfortunately, this was served ice cold which I believe took away some of the aroma and taste.  It became much better as it warmed.

came recommended from a flemish shop owner in Brugge as his favorite abt.  pours a deep copper and can be clear if you pour all but the bottom 1/4" to prevent the yeast from entering.  If you like the yeast the clarity is sacrificed (ive had it both ways and both is tasty) medium to strong carbonation at first but I let it sit for about 10-15 before pouring.  Aroma really is bubble gum and caramel with slight alcohol scent.  Flavor remains slight bubble gum at first and then turns to caramel, then raisin, then finishes chocolate.  Very complex. My favorite beer hands down.

Very dark copper pour, large head fades quickly.
Very perfumy aroma: citrus fruits, apples, doughy yeast, candi sugar, plums, rose-like alcohol, peach blossom, woody honey.
Flavours are quite sweet: candi sugar, caramel, golden syrup, figs. Silky alcohol merges with a light bitterness to create an impressive finish that builds up in the first few seconds after swallowing.
High carbonation (too high in my opinion). Some alcoholic tingling on the sides of the tongue, but not harsh in any way.
Superb.

Tight when its first poured, this beer will open up aromas of lavender, caramel, various berries, and brown sugar if left to breathe for a few minutes.  \a pleasant bitter taste complimented by oak, smoke, toffee and cloves.  The carbonation makes this beer feel very mouthfilling, like taking a can of cool whip and jetting it straight into your open yaw.  Swirl it around in your glass, youll be amazed by its super cool sheeting action!

REally sweet and mad strong, caustic alcohol flavor and nose. Like a bowl of fermented prunes with some licorice thrown in for good measure. Great flavor, but not as enjoyable as the Chimay Blue, in my opinion. Bottle thanks to Brenda.

A: Poured with a large, off-white head... that surprisingly diminished to about 1/4 finger size over a minute or two. Body is cloudy and murky, with a dark brown color. Some lacing, but not as much as Id expect.

S: Aroma is of some light, bready yeast, clove, and light alcohol as well. Some other things in there I cant put my finger on, but very pleasant overall.

T: Wow... lightly sweet at the beginning, with spices present (cloves?). Continues to change as it finishes slightly warm due to the high alcohol content. Taste stays for a long time and continues to kick.

M: Full-bodied and creamy, with average carbonation. Excellent.

D: A fantastic sipping beer... the alcohol content luckily keeps it from being TOO drinkable, but its an excellent beer to sit back with and let the flavors come out even more as it warms.

Bottle. Murky dark brown pour with a big thick beige head. Boozy, malty, fruity aroma. Sweet, malty, dark fruits, complex, slight chocolate taste. This is a rich filling beer but it is also a classic. Probably one of the best beers in the world.

Thick brown body coupled with a lasting half-inch thick tan head and heavy lacing.  High octane aroma with distinctive red grapes, figs and prunes.  Lots of sweet bran and other rich dark malt notes.  Filling and rather sweet, fairly boozy and hot.  Toasted malts galore with some nuttiness as well as a mild chocolate characteristic.  Fermented, sweet, dark fruits and thick molasses.  Musty yeast and a big alcohol burn.  Really nice, but Ill take St. Bs over this any day.

Aroma: Plums, dark fruit, caramel, yeast. Appearance: Dark murkey reddish-brown, thin lasting head that leaves lacing. Flavor: Rich dark Fruit, chocolate, sweet caramel, yeast, a little spice. Palate: medium body, creamy, lively, astringent, with some alcohol. Overall Impression: This beer is the best out of all Rochefort 6/8/10. It is full of the flavors that make the 6 good, and the 8 better, but I dont have to struggle to try to taste the goodness b/c there is so much there.
The best trappist beer id ever tasted! Love the city of Rochefort too..

beautiful dark body with a tan off white head which sticks around and does not disappear.  its lacy and stick to the edges of my tulip glass.  great maltiness across the tip of the tounge with almost a hint of sweet candied chocolate in the back of the palate.  co2 level is excellent for this style of beer and is not filling and wish i could drink more.  sip slowly and enjoy every bit of this beer on your tongue before consuming.  this is a great beer and i think a lot of people would really get into this one.

First impression is a very positive one as a very nice thick white head forms.  It is controlled, and not the head bomb I have seen in several belgians.  Liquid is a very dark and murky, muddy brown.  A little backstory, out of the big three quads, this is the only that I have never tried.  I much prefer Bernardus to Westy, in this style anyway.  Lets see where this one stacks up.  In the aroma department, we are looking complex.  Dark fruit, floral characters, grapes, banana, and light breadiness over booze.  A good scent that reminds me of something in between the Westy 8 and 12.  Extremely complex, but very welcoming.  Taste is surprisingly good, already ahead of the overly clovey Westy in my book.  Not overpowering but immense and complex in its own right, Rochefort 10 starts clean with a lot of the characteristics of the aroma dancing around the palate, most notably dark fruit.  This isnt as heavy as the Westy, but no less complex.  Palate is medium to thick in body, medium to high in carbonation.  Extremely impressed with this one.  Ill have to do a side by side with Bernardus 12 to see which I prefer in the end, though initial thoughts is that Rochefort is the more fulfilling beer.

Bottle pours murky brown in color with a thin beige head.  The nose has a lot going on, but what mainly stands out is raisins, brown sugar, bubblegum and a slight bit of alcohol.  Flavor follows with the same, but also adding notes of black currant, apples, and a certain "yeasty" quality.  The overall body is full and well rounded.  Top class beer for sure.

Pours balck with a tall beige head. Aroma of dark roasted malts, yeasty and slightly alcoholic. Great flavour with notes of fruit, yeast, I taste bread in the mid palate and chocolate in the finish. Rather dry and very alcoholic really nice, but too alcoholic tasting.

33cl bottle poured into a Rochefort Trappist glass.  Very dark brown with half finger tan head.  Aroma is very strong bubblegum and slight alcohol.  Flavor is complex.  Begins with bubblegum/candy.  Earthy, toasty malt notes.  A lot going on there I dont know how to describe.  Finishes equal parts sweet and bitter with some warming alcohol.  Very interesting beer.  Almost too sweet for me though.  Definitely a "special occasion" beer.

(Bottle at Great British Beer Festival) Dark with tiny off white head. Smell was dark chocolate malt with coffee and burnt toast. Big, rich. Taste is strong dark roasty malt, super saturated mouthfeel with a little alcohol aftertaste. Warming. Wine and brandy notes with more grapes, chocolate - brilliantly balanced. Some coffee too. Excellent. Perhaps served a little too cold, but not the beers fault.
330mL bottle into an abbey glass.  Strong alcohol nose with a nice flavor that grew on me as I went through the glass.

Bottle 330ml  marked L290812    08:44. A dark muddy brown color body with two fingers of fluffy light tan lasting head , loads of sheeting and lacing , lots of tiny carbonation bubbles. Aroma of dark fruit ,grapes and berries , earthy hops,toffee and caramel ,and wood. Flavor is sweet ,and spicy , lots of earthy roasted malt hops and  bread dough ,rasins ,plums and apples . very complex and well rounded . Full body with a creamy yet lite mouthfeel , mildly bitter and dry at the finish . Very drinkable and good is all areas .  Nice

Bottle. Amazing beer. Massive in every aspect. Pours deep dark brown with beige head that lasts a while. Caramel, toffee, brown sugar, fresh bread, lavender and cinnamon are all present on the nose. Flavour is pretty sweet but it packs so much in: starts out with caramel, vanilla and raisins, then running into bready, yeasty tastes before finishing with a bit cinnamon, nutmeg and coriander. One of my favourite beers. Cannot recommend highly enough.

14.08.2009, 0,33l Bottle. Maybe one of the best beers in the world. Dark brown colour with off-white head. Rich malty aroma. strong alcohol taste gives a rich full body. Spicy, bitter and sweet. Very nice beer!

I know I should love this but I didnt. Maybe I had it too cold but it was too strong on the nose (even in a big Duvel Glass). Pours and looks beautiful and even finishes nicely. Will have to try this again as I feel like I must be missing something!

Dark brown body with off-white head. Multiple ripe dark fruits, spice, wood and alcohol  in the nose. Flavor is spicy, semi-sweet, some bitterness, and noticeably boozy. Somewhat thin with moderate carbonation. Good but quads just dont stand out for me.
Bottle pours hazy brown with a beige head. Aroma is lots of sweet malt, dark fruits, and spicy alcohol. Flavor is sweet, raisiny, with boozy notes. I actually preferred the 6 and 8.
Pours hazy dark amber brown with a thin tan head.  Aroma is yeasty dark fruits, raisin and hints of toffee.  Flavor is dark malts, candi sugar, currant and a little bit of warming.  Great stuff.

330 ml bottle:  The overall impression I received from reading countless ratings is far from what my bottle poured. The aroma was moderate and undefined. alcohol was noticeable but not in a good way. The appearance is good but you cant judge a book by its cover and the flavor was disappointing, with so many rating on this beer already I just wasnt pleased with what was in my bottle.  I will have to give this beer another shot and hope next go around things are better.  The St. Bernardus Abt 12 is truly a much better beer all around.
09-08-10 330 ml bottle. reddish brown colour. creamy head. taste is sweet herbale with alcohol.

The wife says this was everything she wanted it to be. Kinda like a wine. I tasted, frowned and moved on to a real beer. Wine like scent, lots of sweet fruit. Pours off brown/tan with light head. Rating is the wifes!

Deep dark brown, light head.  Smells so sweet, so good, dried figs, brown sugar, coffee, some cocoa notes, spicey.  nice on the palate, almost like a thin syrop, medium carb. tastes fantastic. tastes very sweet, toffee, sweet spices, sweet finish. one of the best trappist beers for sure.
Bottle. Dark murky brown appearance with a tall light brown head. A heavenly aroma of spiced and sweet fruit and imbued with the same great flavors. Best marks for the aroma

Bottle at Beer Bistro, in tulip glass? Must have ran out of clean Rochefort ones, theyre usually very good about proper glassware. Aroma is extremely similar to wine, except with all sorts of funky fruity notes. Pours opaque brown, almost no head. A slight bit alcoholic, which would have been very pleasant on a cold day, was the only loss in points for this wonderful beer on a warm day. The flavour was, quite frankly, too complex for me to comprehend. Huge burst of flavours, sparkly mouthfeel, and a aftertaste that doesnt leave.

My 150th beer!

Sweet fruity aroma: raisin, chocolate, dried persimmons, licorice. Very complex and fruity. Flavor: nutty caramel, figs, raisins, cinnamon? Alcohol. Sweet but alcohol balances, plus a bit of burnt malt. Full but rather light in the mouth, and very fizzy. Bittersweet burn left after the swallow. A delight, as always, though I prefer it a little better aged. It was still a little young and harsh, with very strong alcohol.   .
Bottle at São Paulo (Brazil) and also (a confirmatory one) in Brussels - dark beer, with a little head, dried fruits aroma and taste... a little coffee aroma as well... well worth it beer for sure.

Wow.  It is possibly as good as they get. I had this beer with a variety of pork dishes, and what a combination it was.

The beer is dark like Coke with just a little head.  Slightly sweet, caramely taste and not much bitterness.  Definiltely hard to have two of these in one sitting because it is so heavy but it is well worth it

I shared a bottle of this with BeerBaron617, and it was a good thing to do so.  Now, I really do enjoy a Belgian style beer, but this one had something different going on with it.  It certainly had a strange murky looking body - a dark raisin brown with a lot of sediment hanging around in the glass.  It had a small light brown head as well.  Aroma was really fantastic.  Certainly a lot of dark fruits, rum-raisin, plums, dates, sweet brown sugar... Taste was quite a bit like wine...but not really?  I dont know, it was almost like a cola, very carbonated and it had a bit of a syrupy mouthfeel.  Overall, it was definitely a good beer.

Split an 11.2 oz bottle with merelikesbeer, which came courtesy of my pops. Well, this stuff is definitely worth the hype. Its not the prettiest beer, but it was incredible. Lots of plum, raisin, and even some brandy/cognac notes. Very very tasty. Cant wait to try more from this brewer. Cheers!

Dark brown hue, with a small light brown head that is mostly diminishing. 
Aroma is of chocolate, raisins, alcohol - tequila, and caramel.
Flavor is of coffee, and dark fruits that lends to its spicey sweet flavor.
Medium - Syrupy mouthfeel. Light carbonation.

Deep dark in colour, slightly hazy due to my inability to retain all of the yeast at the bottom of the bottle upon pouring. Thick lacey had that waffs the aroma up nicely.

Nose has a resemblance to anejo tequila, raisins, and baked desserts.

On the palate dark coca, roasted malt, tawny port (not to be confused with ruby!) and reduced calorie maple syrup. Body is a little on the thin side but it enhances the drinkability.

Finish is peaceful and gradual in flavor dissipation. I notice a caramelly and light cinnamony peppery sweetness that fades into a pleasant malt extract-like cloying sweetness. Nice.
Nice spicey aroma of dried fruits and caramel malt. Sweet flavor of dried fruit, alcohol, vanilla and maybe a little chocolate. Damn, this is good stuff.
11 oz bottle.... this is perfection... if you find one buy it.... you will not be disappointed..... 11 per cent ? no way..... superb.... bliss in a bottle

330 mL bottle at St Veronus.  (Perhaps unfairly sampled just before a Westy 12).  Dark brown, nice head, lots of sediment.  Lovely aroma with lots of dried fruit and caramel, alcohol and yeast.  Flavour is not as full and complex as the Westy, but it is still an incredibly powerful beer, with dark roasted fruit, caramel, licorice, alcohol, and yeast.  Mouthfeel is full, but not as velvety as the Westy.  But by any other comparison, this is an outstanding adult beverage.
Ive had a lot, but this one stands above all! You start off with a trilling sensation, but above all, the tang finishes it all of.

My oh my.. This is such a pleasant beer. Deep burgundy color. 
High carbonation helps form a huge foam that dissipates in a vevetty off-white layer. 
Dark toffee sweet smell and tastes. Palate is somewhat thin, and finishes velvetty with perfectly balanced bitterness. A huge array of aromas and tastes, feels like a candy shop! Amazingly, the alcohol is barely noticeable.

UPDATED: JUL 12, 2015 --- 2009 ---

33cl bottle, dark brown color, medium brownish and creamy head, strong and complex aroma of raisins and licorice with caramel, yeast and roasted notes, spiced sweet flavor with hops presence, medium body and carbonation, big finish with spices and warming alcohol, wine notes aftertaste, really amazing beer, more than expected

--- 2015 ---

33cl bottle, hazy brown color, medium persistent beige head, caramel and raisins aroma with citrus and yeast notes, sweet flavor, medium to full body, spicy (cinnamon) finish, licorice aftertaste, amazing but I think the bottle was still young
bottle, black clear liquid with creamy head. very complex though very drinkable brew. this is good stuff

UPDATED: SEP 28, 2009 Pours very dark with a soft off-white head forming atop leaving a thin white layer over time.  The aroma is fantastic!  It smells a bit like jam from the huge aromas of plums and theres a brandy aroma that is equally as strong and amazing.  These aromas really strike out and grab your attention.  Other sweet dark fruits like figs and dates really come together nicely alongside the deep rich caramel and nutty aromas.  The nose is just incredible!  I could sit and take in whiffs of this all day long!  

The carbonation is rather lively on the palate.  Again, the taste is very plumy and the other dark fruits are very noticeable.  The brandy comes through a little as well, but the rich nuttiness and the sweet dark fruits really come out.  Its rather soft on the palate and a little sweet in the finish.

Pours dark brown with massive head. Aroma of dark fermented fruit. Taste of the same with a lot of complexity that is hard to put a finger on, I did get a slight taste of leather even though I do not know what leather taste like, but it was in a good way.

UPDATED: OCT 3, 2009 Aroma of apricot, fermented fruit and cherries. Appearance is very dark brown with a nice head. The flavor is sweet, prune, liquorish and alcohol, also a bit sour aftertaste. This is a real classic. However the different bottles seem to differ a bit. This was not the best bottle Ive had.

Bottle at Winking Lizard Crosswoods location.  Opaque brown pour with a huge tan head.  Sorta of tart aroma that is also very creamy and yeasty.  Notes of alcohol and dark fruits as well.  Creamy and yeasty flavor with a touch of sourness and alcohol.  Dark fruits and a bit of chocolate in there.

Bottle. Appearance: Dark cloudy beer with small particles and a lasting white head. Aroma: Malt, plum, dark cherries, alcohol. Flavour: Dark fruits, spices. This beer is really creamy and well balanced. The alcohol is nearly not existent. You keep good memory of this beer after taste it. Probably the best I have drunk so far.

Finally tried this classic brew after seeing it come and go too many times from my store. Dark cloudy brown, almost black. Nice thick head that appropriately coats the glass. I was surprised by the nose. The aromas were more of dark fruits like cassis, plum, dark cherries, and raisins. I was expecting more maltiness, brown sugar, and molasses. Pleasantly surprised. The mouth feel was my favorite part of the beer. Rich and creamy with impeccable balance. For 11.3% the alcohol flavors are almost non existent. I think this bottle was young though, because the complexities were not quite there yet. Still a wonderful brew. Great experience. Drank next to a Avery Reverend (quad as well). No comparison what so ever. The Rochefort blows it away.

From bottle. Cinnamon, brown sugar and malt make up a rather rich aroma. Deep walnut colour with a frothy tan head. It looks fantastic and formed how you would like a beer too. Rich syrup like texture. Full bodied flavour. Spices, fruit and hops. This beer is like sitting next to a fireplace. It makes you fell warm and content. Its like a fine sherry or port. Its complex smooth finish makes for a fine ale. Its almost perfect. I love this beer.

UPDATED: OCT 2, 2011 7/10/2009: Pours cloudy dark brown with lively carbonation and a lasting off-white head.  Considerable yeast at bottom.  Aroma is sour cherry, alcohol, yeast, apple, soggy toast.  Very carbonated feel.  Burnt, especially in the finish. Considerable alcohol, with those dark fermented fruit tastes infused slightly.  Finish is fairly short, little bitterness.  Bit of banana.  I think of the concept of darkness when I drink this beer.  Perhaps Ill turn the light off.  Now I think of silence, so I turn the music off.  This is a beer of muted senses, belittlement beneath a vast black sky of stars.  A deeper swig reveals a more complex flavor with fruits coming through in the middle. Once the alcohol begins to hit you, the flavors and the aroma dissolve together into a very favorable final impression.   I like it, but I would still says it does not live up to my expectation- perhaps I do not enjoy a good quad as much as a stout.  Still excellent beer.  Update 10/21/2010:  This has since become one of my all-time favorite beers, and Ive been on a quest to brew it.  It is the breadiness (found more clearly in the 8) that makes this beer so wonderful and appetizing.  I think it allows people to appreciate the darker fruits of the crystal malts/sugars more (kinda like raisin bread).  Yum!

bottle @ home. great, great beer. Liked this one better than the sint bernardus abt 12. great aroma. coudnt stop sniffing the beer. great mouthfeel en full aftertaste. To bad that is a bit expensive. Will surely drink this one again!

UPDATED: OCT 21, 2012 Re-Rate:
Bottle. Very dark brown with tiny off-white head. Aroma is malt, yeast, dark fruits, plume and chocolate. FLavour is malt, dark fruits, medium sweet, plume and chocolate.


33cl bottle. Murky brown body with medium size tan head. Flavour is malt, yeast, sweet and fruit.

Original review date 2/18/2008

Pours like a good root beer - 2-finger frothy, velvety head with nice lacing. Good carbonation. Not so thick its opaque, rather a little translucent.

Spice profile is surprisingly subtle - needs to warm/open up. Mellow molasses aroma mixes with yeast & malt. Some ginger emerges.

Everything on the nose comes out in a well-balanced, mellow package - a little ginger, hearty yeast and malt without any bitter taste or comforting stuff. Extremely well-balanced - like a warm blanket on a camping trip.

Feels like soothing ginger beer with very mild carbonation. Delightful, relaxing mouthfeel.

This is wonderful, easy-drinking stuff thats not too heavy for the style. Incredible quadrupel!

Happy #300!  Drinking it now.  Dark reddy brown color.  Tan head.  Smells sweet and malty.  Tastes really dark fruit, like dates and raisins and some slight dark cherry tanginess.  Nice carbonation, really really good.

UPDATED: JUL 12, 2009 opaque with picture perfect head that sits quietly minding its own business like a well trained dog crouching, awaiting command. aroma is immediately sweet, nearly of roasted malt, followed by the standard pit fruit -- raisins, and even grapes in front. flavor is strong of prunes that come with (or cause) more of the mystery sweetness from the nose.  what a sudden yet relaxing beer.  it sneaks up on you but only to give you a hug or a caress. molasses with a hidden heat source (massive ABV) comes next to greet you, like the anesthetist asking you to count backwards from 10.

11.2 oz. bottle.  Pours a cloudy dark brown with a foamy, light tan head.  Ripe fruit, dark cherries, horse blanket, and yeast make up a complex nose.  Highly carbonated with a medium-light, slightly dry mouthfeel.  Boozy fruit, grass, hay, and a slight vinous note make up a complex palate.  Sweet, but light and enjoyable.  The alcohol is almost completely hidden.  Light caramel and brown sugar notes emerge as the beer warms.  Medium-short finish with some lingering caramel notes.  This beer has great balance all the way around and is truly one of the best beers Ive ever had.  Dangerously sessionable, but better reserved for enjoyment after dinner.  I will definitely keep this one on hand at all times.

Almost as good as Westvleteren. I enjoy almost all Trappist beers for their complex tastes, for their history but also for the fact that you do make a difference when you drink one, certainly for Westvleteren and Rochefort as these are the smallest, less commercial breweries.
Nice head, tastes of caramel and dried plums, raisins and just a touch of maltyness. Very good moment

Near black with a thick beige head.  Even with the glass a few feet away, the aroma is evident.  Smells of deep dark stone fruits, raisin, toasted malts and a peppery hop.  Slightly syrupy on the palate, not unexpected with such a high alcohol content.  Taste is of raisin, malt, bittersweet chocolate and caramel, with a bit of a bitter finish that does not linger or overpower.  Quite complex.

.33l bottle. Wow! I expected to be disappointed because of the hype I see in the ratings on this website. What an impressive beer.
Dark brown body with a nice cream head. Sediment actually didnt fall to the bottom of the glass which was weird to me. It stayed where it was throughout the body as if it were a gell and not a liquid. This was really freakin cool. The aroma was about the same as the 8R but the taste went above and beyond. I got cocoa and caramel on the front and bitter on the back. I loved it. I also tasted the raisin and current but only slightly. Great drink that Ill enjoy again and again!

I cant even begin to describe this beer, it is so wonderful.  It pours a dark brown with a large, thick head.  Taste is malty, fruity, chocolaty.  It is a dry semi-sweet beet, not overpowering like some.

Appearance: Deep murky brown.  Thick off-white head.  Smell: Spice, fruits (raisin), melon.  Taste: caramel or molasses, spices, mixed fruits, and warming alcohol.  Yes, the alcohol is in the taste, but its complimentary.   A bit peppery.  As it begins to warm there is a chocolate note in there, and it gets a little sweeter.  Tingly carbonation up front, but not too much.  Lingering touch of sweetness in the finish.  Just enough hop presence to thoroughly balance the brew.  Mouth feel:  Creamy, rich, smooth on the palate.  I get a slight drying effect as well.  Drinkability:  This is a wonderful beer!  Absolutely top notch.

330ml bottle into Trappist glass. An opaque dark brown beer with a creamy off white head that dissipated quite quickly providing fair lacing. Rich malty aromas of dark fruits (cherries, plums), banana, toffee and dark chocolate. The palate is thickish and fruity finishing with a gentle spicy hop presence and a soothing alcoholic warmth. The finish reminds me of an after dinner port wine. There is definitely candy sugar in there but it is not too sweet and the flavours are wonderfully integrated. Top class. Definitely one to sip and savour.

UPDATED: OCT 17, 2011 I drank this beer from 11.2 oz bottle that I bought from the Abbey in Rochefort form a 70 year old Monk.

The pour is outstanding with light brown head huge that stays forever.  When it does fall it does so in chunks and is beautiful.  The lace is great and sticks all over the glass.  There is yeast all over the glass and adds to stunning look.

It smells or dried fruits, alcohol and chocolate.

The color is deep amber.

The taste is phenomal.  It is a balance of chocolate, coffer and alchol.

This is the best beer in the world.

Great beer, but its a little bit overhyped. The St. Bernardus solidly beats it down in the category. Still, plenty to love...dark as the night, some raisin bread and the warmth of a higher ABV that fits just right. Drink up, just dont expect to some sort of shamans journey to the center of the spiritual earth.

UPDATED: JUL 17, 2010 small frothy light brown head. mostly diminishing. fair lacing. aroma: dried fruits, alcohol, chocolate, malt, mild coffee, toffee. initial flavor: moderate sweet and bitter, ff: moderate sweet and heavy bitter. . palate: medium full body, lively carbonation, moderate alcoholic finish and watery texture. lots of particles. strong alcoholic warming. reminded me of a BDSA at some moments. tastes like chocolate and also like a distilled beverage. 180s

Smells and drinks like a wine. Pit fruits (grapes, plums, cherries) and malts dominate the flavor and aroma. Alcohol is well hidden and will sneak up on you by the end of one of these bad boys. Overall I didnt find it as fantastic as its billing suggests but Ill gladly drink another anytime. A truly unique brew.
A nose of cassis, alcohol and chocolate. Taste is very subtle and vinous and contains plums, chocolate and a little bit alcohol. Its smooth yet complex, but not really as fantastic as I remember it.

bottle.  raisin colored.    Perfect level of carbonation.  Every drink seemed a different variation on a mildly spicy with stronger plum / raisin taste.

from fathers office

Bottle. Brown colour with a beige head. Sweet, malty, berries, dark fruits, dark sugar, yeast, alcohol. Phenolics and spiciness are keept on a medium level and not too dominant. Smooth mouthfeel. Need to re-rate this one.

bottle thanks to thirdeye11.  dark chocolate with a cream head. nose is apple, alcohol, pears and various other fruits.  smooth on the palate with a nice tart fruity flavor that is smooth on the way down and well carbonated.

very dark cloudy red with thick nutty fruity aroma that pours with decadent heavy smoothness . well rounded wine like aroma and tastes of maple vanilla raisins with mild chocolate afternotes. taste changes constantly , being one of the most complex brews i have had . succulent and delicious one of the best
The worlds perfect dark beer in every way - including distribution. Great nose, great look, brilliant warm taste of dark fruitiness and wood. Excellent mouthfeel.

UPDATED: SEP 30, 2009 As you crack open the "big daddy" of the Rochefort trilogy, foam leaps out of the bottle and youre urged to pour this hazy dark red/brown liquid of joy into your chalice. The sediment never really settles and the head is stable and thick. A vinous aroma welcomes you immediately, accompanied by dark, dried fruits, nuts, dark chocolate (no, not trail mix) and woody and caramel/vanilla overtones - no booze.The mouthfeel is velvety smooth, full, with little carbonation, this goes down sooo smooth its incredible - and no booze anywhere. The flavours are of dark roasted malts, spices, coffee, chocolate (fantastic!) and almost anything you became acquainted with in the aroma. Everything is well balanced by aromatic hops, but they dont play the leading role. The finish is long lasting, with a spicy burn, as if youd enjoy a hot, well seasoned meal - and thats a good thing to me. Absolutely great, wow!

Pours a dark, chocolate (almost black) with a lovely head. Maple, black cherries, and pears on the nose. Prunes, molasses, brown sugar, vanilla, raisins, oak, and alcohol with a round, sweet, and lingering perfection. Subtle, distinct, diverse, and sweet. As the glass warms, so does the body.

330 mL bottle from Whole Foods in Hillcrest (San Diego, CA).  Pours into Chimay goblet a brown color with plum highlights.  The downright noisy effervescence produces a large fluffy tan head which is quickly reduced to a thin layer.  Good alcohol (bourbon?), light yeast, wood, sweet grains, dark fruits, and other stuff are present in this very complex aroma.  The flavor is equally complex with wood, sweet syrup, brown sugar, raisin, light chocolate, a certain "vegetable" quality, and a host of other flavors that are hard to pin down.  A little bit on the sweet side, but far far from cloying and well balanced with a small amount of bitterness.  Very smooth and the high alcohol is well hidden except for that warming sensation.  I almost feel like Im still too amateur a beer drinker/rater to properly experience this very highly praised beer.

Bottle 33 cl. Apperance; Dark brown with a nice rocky but small lightbrown head. Nice fruity, dried fruits, sweet malty. Flavor; Sweet malty, fruits and alcohol(almost too much). F... too cold, Ill wait few min. Aha, much better flavor! Less alcohol flavor, more and more taste! Plum and dark grapes.

Small bottle. Dark brown, hazy colour. Cloudy small beige head. The aroma is extremely complex. Coffee, toffee and more sweet stuff. Taste sticky oil with liqurice. Very foramy, long bitterness in the finish.
Bottle form Joes Place.  Color was muddy brown w/ a cream head.  Aroma was of cinnamon and caramel.  Flavor was with cherry, bown sugar, and caramel.  Drinkable beer on oaccasions!
Dark beer, strong full taste. First time taste is too strong. Second time drinking, taste is better. Third time you want more...

Bottle. A complex mixture that certainly lived up to its reputation. Alcohol is not apparent when tasted, and the carbonation is perfectly balanced. Full aroma with the taste of black plums, hints of carmel and an accent of dry white grape. Its a pleasure to savour slowly. . . and thoughtfully.

Bottle drink by 12/31/13, so it is only about six months old. Very dark but still translucent, with a thin but persistent white head. A lot of fizz but feels soft. Very rich and very long tasting ale. Dark fruits, chocolate cake, anise. The booze does come through and warms the ribcage. Havent tasted it side by side with R8 to see which I prefer.

I found this bottle at a local Beer and Wine distributor in Delaware.

I recalled excepts from this brewery awhile back and was quite astonished to find it.

It poured nicely a dark amber color relinquishing a thick beige head.  After letting it settle for a minute.

inhaling and tasting the aroma rich flavors of fruits and herbal intoxication.

The alcohol is well hidden from this 11.3% ABV blend though creating a soothing and warming sensation on its way into the depths of my body.

A top-notch, creature.

bottle from joes place.  poured a murky brown with a great beige head.  aroma of bread, caramel, prune, brown sugar, and plum.  flavor was brown sugar, plum, alcohol, and caramel.  full body with high carbonation.
amazing, one of the best beers, great beer, great aroma, strong. feels like a coffee, chocolate, raisins.....

UPDATED: JUN 11, 2009 Poured from bottle with a slightly redder-brown color than the bottle color itself.  Massive head to begin with that slowly settled to around a 1/4 inch.  Aroma is boozy dried apricots/juicy prune.  Wow, this is my first Rochefort, so smooth on the palate and that 11.35 abv is dangerously well-hidden.  Enjoying this delightful beer with dark chocolate covered orange peels, perfect which pairs nicely together.  It reminds me of a more floral aroma version of the Duchess de Bourgogne.  Nice warming alcohol finish.  Yum.

Beer just doesnt get any better than this one.   Have had on tap in Brussels numerous times and from bottles here in the States and each and every time the taste, aroma, feel and drinkability just knocked my socks off.  This and Westy 12 are the definition of great beer.

Pour is lake water-murky brown with large tan head.  Aroma is dried fruit, raspberries, sour malt, touch of alcohol, and a hint of brandy.  Flavor is a sleeper.  It starts slow with bubbly subtle malt.  Then a complex earthy fruit flavor emerges from underneath.  Its dates, raisins, prunes, cinnamon, cloves, and alcohol; strong alcohol.  A bit of brown sugar in the finish.  Solid, but not quite all I was expecting.

Bottle.  Nice trappist-brown cloudy pour with a medium light brown head.  Aroma of caramel and raisins.  Great taste of plums, dark fruit, figs and caramel with faint hints of brown sugar and yeast.  Slight warming alchol finish.

Great brew.  Completed my series of having 6,8, and 10 in a row.  Aroma is some fruits, both dark and citrusy, with floral and chocolate notes.  Flavor is just full of various flavors, fruits, chocolate, coffee, sugars.  Good stuff.

Tasted blind with savvy1982 vs Dieu du Ciel! Rigor Mortis, Westy 12, and Chimay Blue. Pours a reddish brown with a nice tan coloured head. Aroma is bright and fresh. Floral perfume, lemon, grapefruit, herbs, and banana. Tastes chocolaty, with plums, citrus, flowers, cherry, apple, molasses, cloves, anise, and bready yeast. Palate is very nice, builds as it sits. Very, very good beer. Was surprised this was my second favorite behind the DDC, and miles ahead of the Westy and Blue.

Bottle. Tasted blind with hobbersr against Dieu du Ciel! Rigor Mortis, Westy 12, and Chimay Blue. Pours a gorgeous red/brown with an off-white head and spotty, pretty lacing. Cascade-style hops, rich caramel, buttered toast, plum, roasted fig, bright, fresh, perfume, chocolate, coffee, green apple peel, preserved salty lemon. Palate is big, effervescent, rich and wonderful. Flowers, berries, mocha, tartness, rumcake, syrup, chocolate. Best Trappist yet, and loads better than the Westy 12!
My favorite beer.  The sweetness really rounds this beer out and gives it an edge over Chimay grand reserve and st bernardus abt 12.  Not much more to say than its like beer-crack forged in heaven.

Exceptional example of this style of brew. Not sure if I like it as much as St. Bernardus Abt 12, didnt strike me as quite as full a flavor. Had this in an 11 oz bottle poured into a small chalice style glass.

Easily the best beer Ive tried. Light and refreshing. Pleasantly carbonated despite the dark color. Doesnt sit too heavy, so definitely lends to drinking multiples. I wish they sold it near me. Id probably be a poor man though.

Pours a dark dark brown with a bit of head and seems to be nicely carbonated.  Big full bodied quad here.  I am getting banana, candied fruit, some malt and spices on the nose.  It seems though as it is warming up there are more nuances coming through.  On the palate I am getting all the fruit(berries, plum, raisins) that nuance of banana in there as well, along with some nice spice flavors.  Also some orange peel on the finish there.  Excellent Quad, highly recommended.

Pours a dark brown with a lasting off-white head and appears to be highly carbonated. The smell is overwhelming: brown sugar, dark malts, cinnamon, coffee, this beer has everything. And even though it sits at 11.3% alcohol it can not be picked out by the nose. The taste is pure heaven and very smooth to boost; it is dark, hops-filled, with brown sugar notes... it is extremely complex. Overall the beer works wonderfully and I would recommend to anyone.

WOW!!!!!!! What a great beer. This beer was amazing, the only problem I had with it is I didnt get enough three of us had to split one bottle. The beer poured very dark very little light penetration when held up to the light, with a creamy head that disappeared quickly. The strong scent of bananas and other sweet fruit starts the mouth watering in anticipation of the first sip. I found the feel in my mouth to be so very soft and full like whole cream blankating my mouth, but it still was very smooth. The first tast was way sweet and malty. There was a strong flavor of banana that covered up a minty taste in the background. The after taste was bitter but very short-lived. I love this beer, I just cant buy it here dammit."

UPDATED: JUN 2, 2009 330 ml bottle in Belguim, This is not the type of beer I normally like. However that being said it had a nice brown color with a light brown head with perfect lacing. Aroma of brown sugar. Alcohol not well hiden but it grows on you when you drink it. Over all a great beer but not something that I want to drink all of the time. I enjoyed the 8 much better.

Pours a cloudy, murky, dark brown colour with a thick, foamy cream coloured head which thins out and leaves a nice lacing. Yeast particles are visibly floating about. Has an aroma of sweet malts, plums, raisins, chocolate, and cherries. Tastes of malts, bread notes, plums, raisins, chocolate and cherries. Unique, hard to describe flavours that linger on the taste buds. Incredibly smooth feel.

Best beer Ive ever had - no question - even better than Old Style Pilsner. Even better now that I can appreicate beer more. Simply amazing. Almost a port. Hard to judge the head considering this most recent tasting was a three way split, but nice brown none the less. Get ready to be punched in the face with the aroma of fruits - plums, apricots, bananas(??)and the most interesting hops ever. Aromas softened during carefully sipping trying to avoid polising it in one shot, but it defenetly got way more complex along the way with the fragrence of bananas holding out strong. Had a zippy bitterness to it with great carbonation. Found a decent collection of sediment at the bottom of the glass. Felt like a thousand hot supple blonde chicks on my tongue. I need a towel. This is the real thing. One of the greatest beers on the planet.

Bottle from BevMo.  Pours a deep murky brown with a small beige head.  Nose of raisins, plums, black currants and booze.  Flavor was also filled with dark fruits, sweet malts and more booze.  I was expecting much more from this brewery from its world renown reputation, wasnt for me.

UPDATED: JUL 15, 2009 Bottle dated 2014
Pours murky dark brown with a nice beige colored head. Nose has great balance, raisin esters supported by choc/caramel malt with some spicy phenolics as well. Palate is full and creamy. Raisin, choc & caramel malt all have great synergy. Nothing sticks out of place to dominate. Finishes with significant belgian yeast spice. Brilliant balance and mouthfeel despite big abv! Hops and alcohol an afterthought. This sample was quite fresh and in top nick. Easy to see why this is a classic, but to be honest i think i prefer the 8. Regardless, awesome beer! Should probably head back and get a stack of this batch for the cellar!

POOR THIRSTS A PERFECT 10 !
Appealing bottle, and taste and smell do not disappoint. This is a beer that defies its 11.3% strength. Dark creamy stoutlike appearance with brown fizzy head. Complex chewy malty chocolatey. Its got everything. Rated highly for good reason , but pricey !

Beautiful Beer. Aroma: slightly dry base with LARGE fruity, estery overtones. Flavor is more complex than the female psyche. Deliciously sweet. Would never know this beer is 11.3 abv. slightly hazy pour but otherwise wonderful. First time drinking. instant top 10 list

12 ounce bottle enjoyed the day I received my final grades from college. I was very excited for this brew because it is my first Quad and it is very highly rated. Pours a dark brown/mahogany color with a huge tan bubbly head that lingers through the duration of the beer. I have never seen a beer pour like this before... it was quite impressive. It also had a good amount of carbonation that continuously bubbled from the bottom of my glass. The aroma was very complex and consisted of plum, raisins, grapes, malt, and some booze. The taste was a wonderful mix of dark dried fruit, plum, raisins, malt, with a slight alcohol warming in the background. It had a medium bodied mouth feel and left a nice lingering taste of plum and dark fruit. Overall, an exceptional beer! This is making me interested in trying more quads...
Amazing that this is available in such wide distribution.   Deep and layered.   Dried fruit, fig, candy sugar, many spices, coco, toffee.  Big and rich, finish just goes.

UPDATED: JUN 17, 2010 Bottle at Flying Saucer, Raleigh. Great stuff and insanely complex. Rich nose of raisins, smoke, and brown sugar. Flavors run the range from blackberries to leather to licorice to grapes. Theres so much going on in your mouth, this is a beer to be savored and appreciated. It would pair amazingly well with flavorful meats.

From bottle. Cinnamon, brown sugar and malt make up a rather rich aroma. Deep walnut colour with a frothy tan head. It looks fantastic and formed how you would like a beer too. Rich syrup like texture. Full bodied flavour. Spices, fruit and hops. This beer is like sitting next to a fireplace. It makes you fell warm and content. Its like a fine sherry or port. Its complex smooth finish makes for a fine ale. Its almost perfect. I love this beer.

The best beer!  Drank 2 bottles of this for my birthday.  Next day I had Westvleteren Abt 12.  Both are equally as good, but this one is a little cheaper and easier to find.  Cant get any better than this.  Have someone take a picture of you drinking and enjoying this, not a beer to drink alone at 2am while watching QVC.  Drink it with your friends. Let them have a little sip (very little) , then save the rest for yourself and let them continue drink their beer, knowing that your lips are kissing ecstasy.  Let your friends finish drinking his/her PBR.  Little pieces of heaven await for you on the bottom, sediment is delicious.  Warm chocloate with a hint of vanilla, those monks know what their doing,

why i have to repeat things that are written in other comments?

this beer its just fantastic for me. and thats all :)
vanilla, smoth, smells like rye, looks little bit cloudy but nice, warming the lipps, soft carboneted, perfect conformed to this style
UPDATED: FEB 6, 2016 Bottle. Dark brown colour, aroma of bitter chocolate. Malty, taste of candy sugar, chocolate, coffee. Great finish with a kind bitterness. Drink slowly and enjoy!

Pours cola-color with a LOT of styrofoam-cotton head.  Aroma is dark, rich, bitter raisins, spice, and grapefruit.   Maybe a hint of ripe banana?  Wow, flavor is strong alcohol, I may be drinking this at too warm a temperature. Spice and raisins are still there, but the alcohol overwhelmed that first sip.  A follow up gives a hint of anice and spice, but the alcholol still pervades.  Very warm boozy finish, not as well disguised as I would have hoped for.  I think this is a better beer to start your night on, not so much as a closer...

I preferred the westy 12 over this. just something that didnt do it for me.
had access to all I wanted on a recent business trip and passed. it has the spice, clover, raisin, cotton candy  dark fruits. Was good but not better than westy 12

Pours a deap dark brown to black color and a light brown havy head.  Aroma is of roasted malts and some spices.  Flavors are complex, very spicy with caramel and a strong alcohol hit, ripe fruits like banana and figs, but very smooth and a little pleasant sweetness.
It has a very warm finish, but there are soo much pleasant flavors it is a real peasure to drink, it is really a gastronomic drink, its really one of the best beers.

Extremely complex and wonderful aroma. Can smell mango, pear, apples, a bit of strawberry even. Pours a cloudy brown with a thin head. Taste is very spicy at first taste, but the more you drink it, the most you are able to recognize and appreciate the more subtle flavours. Even 10-20 seconds after taking a sip, I am still picking up different flavours. Fantastic beer

330ml poured into tulip

Pours a reddish brown with a gigantic thick and creamy head.
I cant get much on the nose of this one. Light yeast and apple.
First sip sucked.
Second sip isnt too bad.
Alcohol is just not good. It tastes like a quad that someone poured isoprophyl alcohol into.
Nice mix of spices, but to me they just are too much.
I might be one of the only people on earth that prefers Chimay Blue to Roch 10.
Tastes like it needs 3 - 4 years on it.
ok, just took another sip. just dont like it. damn :o(

Pours a murky brown. Fruits, nuts, malts, some alcohol nose. Tastes of raisin, belgian yeast, dark fruits, roast malt, dark candy sugars and plum. Mouthfeel is rich and smooth. Oily. I LOVE THIS BEER!

330 ml pour into chalice.  Moderate, yeasty off-white head.  Very deep, dark brown pour.  Definite aroma of dark caramel, ripe banana peel.  Malt, caramel and alcohol on the nose.  Wow!  the alcohol hits you at the very end of the sip.  Smooth beer, very flavorful.  Drinking this around 60 degrees.  I think Im having a religious experience here.  The flavor of this heavenly brew is simply - OUTSTANDING.  All I know is I have come a very long way from the macro brews I consumed 6-8 months ago - CHEERS and God Bless the Trappist Monks!

Bottled. A wonderful nose with fruit of banana and fig. Little off-white head. Very nice brown colour. Flavour with burned carame and well balanced between sweet and bitter (is maybe to the sweet side). Lovely alcoholic bite. Sweet, alcohol and slightly bitter finish.
love this beer, nice dark color and full of flavor. pours a thick white head. a little expensive but worth every penny.

Bottle Pour.Dark brown color with an off-white head.Sweet fruit and malt smell,Tastes the same as it smells sweet toffee,raisins,and malt.Alcohol is not overly present and easy to drink.Really good beer,will drink this again.

UPDATED: JUN 18, 2009 This is possibly the best beer Ive had.  Pours a hazy dark brown, with a thick creamy head that grows a little then hangs with the glass all the way down.  Has a nice sweet aroma with hints of coco.  Wonderfully sweet taste with a slight bitterness, leaves the throat with a warm feeling.  This brew is very deserving of its score.  Everyone should try this brew.
black, hazy, light sweetness, full body, thick feel, lively. Great beer recomended to everyone.
Dark pour, raisin and spice in aroma, as well as flavor, with added burnt figs. This one is dry with distinct stiff finish (bicarbonate in water?).

Bottle, served in Orval chalice.  Poured a cloudy dark brown with a bubbly off-white head.  Large champagne-like bubbles eventually broke down into much smaller ones, leaving a velvety thin head.  Appearance takes a hit for the odd combination of floating bits and strange lack of lacing.

Fruity aroma with a touch of alcohol in the nose, like any big beer.  Roasted malt and fruits stand out amongst the complex and subtle flavors, especially plum.  Great creamy palate lasts from the first sip to the final drops.

Thin white head, cloudy, ultra dark ruby color when held up to the light...dark brown without the light.  Smell of toffee, candy sugar, and dark, ripe fruits...rainins, figs...touch of dried cherry.  Taste matches aroma, with a hint of brown sugar.  Small tight bubbles and tingly mouth feel.  Alcohol is dangerously well hidden, and balances out the sweetness perfectly.

floral, raisin, reddish-brown color, clear, tan foam, frothy, medium sweetness, medium bitterness, medium sourness, medium body, thin feel, initial soft mouthfeel into fizzy stinging sweetness into abrupt bitterness

bottle: pour with a large off white head.  Smells of raisans and a sour something.  Taste was sweet, slightly alcoholic, and toasted malts.  Medium mouth feel.  Overall: smooth from the beginning to the end.  I can see why this rates so high, but it isnt my favorite, but its up there.

UPDATED: JUL 27, 2009 Lightly sweet, lightly floral and awesome aroma. Thick, opaque dark brown with a good head. Tickly mouthfeel and warmth from the alcohol. This beer is extremely consistent... every bottle has been perfect. UPDATE: got a couple bottles which seem to have been pretty recent/fresh. Alcohol was pretty hot on those.

Bottle shared at tasting.  Thanks!  Pours a dark caramel color.  Smell is raisin and alcohol.  Fairly nice nose.  Taste is malty with sweet raisin, a touch of alcohol but not too hot.  Medium body and carbonation.  Enjoyable, but not incredible, I thought.

2008 Bottle from Lees Discount Liquor...Dark Brown with dissipating beige head.. Smell is dark fruits and kinda boozy.. Taste was more of the same but lingered with you.. I kinda felt that it was overcarbonated I should have let it age longer, maybe I would have liked it more... I havent had too many quads so Im not sure if I dont like the style or If Im not fond of this beer... I dunno just didnt blow my skirt up like i thought it would.  Freakin monks and their shitty beer... LOL

I rated the similar St.Bernardus 4.8/5 and I like this one probably as much, at least.  It is a little sweeter and fruitier, the texture seemed even thicker and the whole product, more balanced and of a higher quality.  So Rochefort, you force me to lower my St.Bernardus rating!  Youll get that 4.8 now because you are an absolutely outstanding beer, with an amazing depth of tastes that I truly appreciate more than almost any other I had.  But you are a he** of an ugly beer with your black clogs, let me tell you that!  But dont change, stay as you are, we love you that way!

UPDATED: MAY 27, 2009 Pours dark brown with lite-brown head and adequate lacing. Smells of light chocolate, with a significant amount of alcohol. Warming reveals stronger scents of chocolate and light yeast, but nothing else. The flavor begins with plenty of dark fruits like plum and raisin, which then switches to chocolate, light wine, and finishing out with toasted malts and an astringent flavor that really lingers well after drinking.

Dark dried fruits, apples, very sweet pears and berries in warm aroma. Sweet, dark fruity flavor with raisins, pears, apples, candi sugar and orange peel in the not at all bitter finish. Creamy mouthfeel.

Pours a very dark, cloudy brown with lots of floaties, and a thick tan head.  Aroma of dried fruit, chocolate, and alcohol.  Taste included the same with yeast and roasted malt also.  Mouthfeel was creamy, but not oily.  Overall wonderful.

This poured a hazy brown with a fat tan head and lots of lacing. Nose of ripe fruit. Very creamy mouthfeel. Lots of action in the flavors with chocolate, raisins, and some sourness from the yeast. Dry finish. A simply divine brew.

Poured cloudy brown with a quickly dissipating head. Sweet berry fruit and a sugary scent. Sticky and well carbonated. Sugars, some lemon and otherwise not dissimilar to a red wine. Not much malt discernible. Nice but a bit too rich for me.

UPDATED: DEC 18, 2010 Poured a deep dark brown with a long lasting beige head. Aroma seems to come through more as the head retreats; chocolate, toffee, dark fruit, raisin, white wine, sweetness from the malt, and just a fine hint of alcohol. Holy shit!!! The taste is remarkable. Flavor is similar to aroma, except for mellow hops and stronger malt presence. Surprisingly, high abv not detected until tail end of the clean, slightly dry finish. This stuff is magical.

I figured Id use my first rating to rate one of my favorite beers. A fantastic beer. This is one of the few big beers where the alcohol tastes like it is specifically there to add to the overall depth. Not an afterthought, but a necessary addition to the overall complexity of the beer. It really needs to be tried multiple times to truly appreciate all the different flavors that are hiding here, which (wallet willing) I am happy to do.

Cola colered pour with a tan head that exploded during the pour. I served the beer at 45F. At first The aroma was masked and the taste was slightly sweet with a noticeable alcohol presence. I let the beer warm up in my hands and everything changed for the better. The aroma of fruit presented itself, the taste came out in droves, and I felt that now I am tasting a great beer. It had a great aftertaste and mouthfeel. It is/was a tasty beer and worth the effort to get it. The final sip was the best.

Bottle. Intense aroma of prunes, toffee, alcohol and an earthy scent. Dark brown with a big fluffy light brown/tan head. The flavor is full of a sweet caramel and date richness, followed by a tangy sour flavor from the yeast, there is also a very faint alcohol taste. This is a full to medium bodied beer that has a thick creamy texture that is perfectly broken up by a mild carbonation. This is a perplexing beer, very hard to describe, definitely one of the best beers I have had.
Now this is a truly great trappist ale. Very complex flavors. Lots of raisin, yeast and dark fruits. Enough alcohol to warm you up yet not offend in the slightest. This truly is a special beer!

UPDATED: SEP 18, 2010 Pours a dark brown with red highlights and a big light brown head. Looks great. Aroma is toffee malts, vanilla, fruity, raisin/prunes, dates, alcohol, yeast, and more. Flavour is complex. Chocolaty and caramely sweet malts, dark fruits, spices, some vinous qualities, some tiny hints of smoke and wood, with some alcohol heat. Carbonation is lively, but smooth. Feels refreshing, with a medium body. Even better after 1,5 years of age. Mellows out a bit in the alcohol department, and feels more complete.

UPDATED: JUL 27, 2011 The best beer Ive had to this point (March 2009).  Poured a deep purple and brown color with tons of yeast, and almost opaque.  Aroma was full of chocolate and complex, extremely thick and chewy on the palate.  Flavor was outstanding, with chocolate and roasted overtones with an unbelievable amount of dark fruity undertones make this beer an experience. Almost an overwhelming experience.

My mouth was overwhelmed by the many tastes on the first sip.  This is an outstanding beer.  I have had a ton of St. Bernardus Abt 12 and this is easily as good or better.  Very fruity aroma, fruity taste.  But not too sweet.  Grapes, raisins and malts seem to be the predominant elements.  Outstanding.

alright, this here is probably my favorite and also the first craft brew i ever had. this is one BIG mother. once cap is removed this one is off and bubbling almost out the top. pours VERY slow to allow for the head. nose is deep rich red candy fruit, leather, tobacco, and malt sweetness. flavor is very big and elaborate and a pleasure to sip and break down. rich malt lends a very strong back bone to the heavy yeasty deep leather flavors. almost a smokey tobacco acompanies and finishes strong showing its high alcohol. simply an amazing brew. thank you rochefort

Simply the best beer Ive ever drunk (although Ive not tried the Westvleteren 12 yet). Its like a flavour explosion; the taste is sweet and strong at once, reminds me generally to fruit. And what about the colour... impressive, extremely dark and the contrast with lather is perfect.

Bottle.  Poured a murcky brown/purplish color with very thin white head.  Aroma was is sweet, strong with dark gruits, raisins, cherry, and malts.  I detected hints of brown sugar and sweeter spices.  The malts really come out when it hits the pallet.  The texture is cabonated and creamy.  I prefer the 8 just because the alcohol doesnt stand out as much, but this is still a superior beer.

UPDATED: AUG 7, 2009 This beer has dark fruit, some boozy undertones, and a place in my heart. Big creamy mouthfeel.  Its downfall is some what of a coca cola mouthfeel midway through drinking it.  But then again, I dont know what the fuck Im talking about.  Im too busy pumpin iron and jammin to bone thugs and harmony

A: Beautiful! Its a plum purplish brown sort of color with a wonderful small light fluffy head that leaves behind a beautiful pattern of lace. 

S: Believe it or not, I smell bubblegum. It has a wonderful nice sweet aroma that reminds me of a freshly opened back of bubblegum, grape Hubba Bubba perhaps? 

T: Like most quads it has a winy taste about it. Reminds me of a wonderful port wine. It has such a nice sweetness about it. I taste dark fruits like raisins, plums, mixed with brown sugar. The malt backbone that this is brewed around is exquisite. 

M: Creamy, Milky, Ultra Smooth. Rochefort got this one right. 

D: I have to be honest one and I am done, this is not a slight, it is common with most quads that I drink.

UPDATED: JAN 25, 2010 WOW!
I was stoked for this beer, I thought I might have over hyped it a bit in my mind. But no, this stuff is the bees knees of quadrupels. The aroma is deep and complex, lots of anise and licorice, with big fruit notes, lots of dried cherry, grape, and plum. The flavour is equally as complex, a light touch of licorice at first which seems to be the throne of that all the other flavours of this beer sit on, plum, raisin, a bit of black currant tartness, brown sugar,  ends on a big licorice note. The palate is almost perfect, nice and foamy mouthfeel, my only qualm would be maybe just a touch too much carbonation, other than that, this beer is almost perfect. Very satisfying.
Bottle. Look.Red brown, off white head. Smell: Sweet. Citrus, fruity, sugar, spicy. Surprisingly fresh. Taste: Vinous. Spicy, choclaty. Peppery aftertaste. Overall: Shy but complex. Smooth.

Pours chunky dark brown with tan head.  Aroma is bread/yeast, fig, and booze.  Taste is raisin, burnt figs, caramel, alcohol, some spice.  Dry finish.  Pretty good but not sure if it stood up to all the hype.

I have had this a couple of times, and it is a very good beer. Tonight I am drinking it watching X-factor with the family while considering an exclusion of a member of our beerclub.
What could be more appropriate?
Dark brown with high beige head. Sweet smell of al things good, but also a lot of alcohol.
I have a slight cold today, is that why the alcohol is so present?
The mouthfeel, the long aftertaste, and the complexity is awesome.
I woiuld really like to taste this with some years on its back.
This is not the second best beer in the world in my book, but maybe the second best avalable beer in the world.

Have had this many times, but Im rating it against a Westy 12 and Koningshaven Quad.  Good company, and unfortunately the Rochefort cant quite hold to the Westy.  Then again, what can?

Dark fruits, slight belgian spiciness peaking through.  Delicious and warming.

This was the beer I chose to consume on Nov 4, 2008 which was the greatest day of my life, which should give you some idea of the esteem I hold it to.

330 ml. bottle. Pours medium mocha head of long duration, with attractive lingering lacing over a dark brown (SRM 20) slightly cloudy body.....nose heavy of fruit primarlly cherry, plum....tastes of rich sweet fruits raisin, cherry, plum finishing slightly dry but with lingering fruits including pineapple....mouth feel is medium, carbonation is with a light hand. Alcohol is well hidden. This is really a great beer.

Bottle - solid brown pour with light brown head. Aroma of malt, yeast and bread. Taste is complex and hard to describe all things encountered. Noticed coffee, chocolate and a hint of licorice. Some bitterness. Great beer, but in general I enjoyed the 8 more than the 10.

this only my second trappistes ale iv tasted. the first being westmalle dubbel. which wasnt as good as expected. but i heard good things about the rocheforts. so i gave in again to try this. and well. not disapointed AT ALL. poured into a wine glass. which is the closest thing i had to a trappist glass. very nice pour butl there is alot of carbination in this. dark brown with a off tan head. smelled of malts. and almost bread like. tasted of chocolate. coffee. plums. raisens. grapes. was kinda thin mouthfeel but the 11.2% abv was very well hidden nice bitter finish that leaves a malty fruty taste in your mouth. over all an excellent beer. one of my faves so far!

UPDATED: NOV 30, 2012 Bottle. Pours black with a big quite compact, light brown head.
Smells of malt and belgian yeast. The aroma is kind of stoutisch and vinous at the same time.
Chocolate, coffe, rosted malts and some sweetness.

UPDATED: JUL 3, 2009 Bottle.  I do not have a palate for Belgians, but I see why this gets so much respect.  Pours a deep hazy brown color with a big white head.  Aroma is very complex, and hard to describe.  Taste is great, hints of malty sweetness, chocolate, and has that Belgian bite that I am not accustomed to just yet.  However, I did really enjoy this.

Aroma is like a kaleidoscope of fruits: ripe plums, tart apple, grape and so much more. High amounts of sediments, not opaque, but a nice dark brown with generous, carbonated head. The initial flavor almost reminds me of a sour ale, but with all the complexities of a quad. Sour apple, brown sugar, licorine and perhaps even some well hidden citrus near the finish. Palate did not make any attempt to hide alcohol, but has a nice spice filled finish. Worth the accolades, but I also understand why Westvleteren is ranked higher.
Poured dark brown with tan head. Aroma of fruit, spice, and malt. Excellent smell. Flavor started off with some fruit and sweet malt and finished with a spice kick. Complex and smooth.

Poured a dark brown with a big thick brown head. Smells of yeast and fruit. The taste is initially sweet and fruity followed by yeast, a little alcohol and a smoked finish. Very complex taste, very well made beer.
Had this one out of a bottle.  Opaque with a ruby tint.  Gorgeous, sturdy head.  Numerous fruit notes.  Roll this one around on your tongue a bit, theres a cascade of flavors coming.

A dark brown hazy appearance with a substantial light brown head. Aroma is very complex with hints of various sweets, dried fruits, yeast, and a bit of alcohol.  Flavor follows suit, but is much more intense.  Ive had other beers this complex, but none are nearly as well balanced as this-they just do it right.  Very impressive, a good one for my 50th review.

UPDATED: JAN 21, 2012 Bottle. A cloudy dark brown beer, with an average sized, frothy, mostly lasting off-white head. The aroma is moderately malty (caramel, chocolate, biscuits), lightly yeasty (basement), with notes of banana, brown sugar, raisin, cinnamon, licorice, plums and figs. The flavor is heavily sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter. Medium to full body, velvety/creamy texture, average/lively carbonation, very long finish with light to medium bitterness, moderately alcoholic. Fantastic, truly a world classic, virtually perfect in every department, complex, reasonable alcoholic feel, warming and exciting.
10 is it! Gets you going with the intriguing aroma and then keeps you with the full body mouthfeel! WOW!
Finally, a beer that lives up to the hype. Cant believe it is 11%. But beyond that, there are flavors here I didnt think ive tasted in other brews. Excellent!

Im not breaking any new ground here, but this is simply the best beer Ive ever had. Words can hardly describe... but here I go anyway. It pours a dark purpleish brown with a towering fizzy brown head that collapses quickly. The aroma is something special. Fruit basket. Apple, pear, plum, raisin, slight notes of banana, cherries. You name the fruit and its probably in there somewhere. The taste is amazingly complex, super fruity like the smell. Sweet, spicy, dusty yeast, licorice, chocolate, overipe fruit. I can taste every great beer Ive ever had in this one. It absolutely met my expectations which is saying something, and I was seriously bummed out when it was gone.

Colore marrone,con schiuma quasi bronzea.Aroma di malto, caramello, spezie, frutti scuri e pane.Il gusto è di malto, di caramello e di spezie,con sentori di banana e cioccolato.Lalcool è bene nascosto rendendola facile da bere.Un paradiso per gli amanti della birra

impressive production from rochefort.it has a good but hardly distinguishable aroma in which i found traces of dark fruit and caramel.brown coloured with a tan head.sweet but not too much and with a particular taste of malt and bitter hops.medium body with creamy consistence.it leaves a moderately bitter taste in your mouth.the greatest quality of this beer is the way alcohol is hidden,making rochefort 10 an easily drinkable beer,despite being 11%.a must for every beer-lover and one of my all time favorites

Bottle. Pours a cloudy red brown. Very carbonated, almost like a soft drink. Aroma has some hints of fruit and spice. Very hard to classify the flavors. There are a lot. Malt, hops, fruit. The 11.3 ABV is totally hidden which was a surprise. Very tasty and complex.
UPDATED: MAR 18, 2009 Not very distinguishable aroma. Nice dark beer with a nice head. Very nice bitter taste which lasts pretty long. Overall an awesome Trappist!

Pours brown with a frothy tan head. Lively carbonation. Aroma if malt, caramel, spice, dark fruit, and bread. Taste is of malt, caramel, spice, lots of banana, and chocolate. Has lots of breadiness to it. Mouthfeel is light, and heavily carbonated. Body is light, yet very creamy. Lingering fruit sweetness. Alcohol is very well hidden, making this an easy drinker. I dont recall this beer being this drinkable.

Dark reddish brown. 1/4 inch of offwhite dense head. Aromas of bubblegum, chocolate and banana. Taste: Dark chocolate, bitter hops, vanilla, and a wood finish. Mouthfeel: Thin but not too thin. Overall: Very balanced and complex.
Huge flavor, Should drink it slowly i didnt but will next time.. Aroma was great.. the 11% doesnt even comeout in the taste.. Great beer!!

wow, this isnt my fav style, but an amazing beer. i had to try it because of all the hype, and it definitely didnt dissapoint. i drank it over the course of an hour to really enjoy it and what you read is true, one of the best beers ive ever had.
Not my favorite but had to try it because of the good rating.  Very dark color, tastes of raisins and plums with a hint of vanilla

UPDATED: JAN 16, 2010 Tested with two other belgian ales. Great brown colour with alive yeast on foam and bottom of class. The taste explodes with a round, coffie and fruity taste in perfect balande of each other. Colourful fireworks in your mouth. Extremely pleasant finish with taste of slight bitterness but mostly fullnes with the properties of a belgian ale. The alcohol strength of this beer goes without notice.

Gooood shiite. Nice dark brown pour with a good head. Smell is dark fruit and maybe bubblegum. flavor is dark fruit all the way with hints of molasses and toffee and....bubblegum. not sure on that. Im picking up a slight nut/chocolate flavor as well. Alcohol? what alcohol?.....its not even a little bit noticeable. Very well balanced.
Everything seems to come together really well. Bit of a tinge at the end.
Good stuff

More old memories... Pours a clouded brown color with a quickly dissapating tan head. Sweet, fruity, bready aroma, with a hint of alcohol.  Great body, well carbonated, chocolate, caramel, creamy almond smoothness. No alcohol on the palate, easy drinking.  A top choice.
Bottle. dark brown/black color with a thick off white head You wouldnt even know it was over 11% alcohol unless you looked at the label.
Pours brown with a light tall cream head.  Slight alcohol taste with dark fruit and caramel/malt.  The aroma matches the flavor very well.

dark brown with big fluffy cream head.  strong raisin and dark fruit aroma.  flavor is malty with lots of dark fruit and then becomes very dry and slightly bitter.  thin mouthfeel and a little alcohol taste

Bottle. Poured a motor oil color with a 1 to 2 finger off-white head. Aroma was very fruity with a semi strong alcohol smell. . Flavor was similar to the aroma. Started off sweet and fruity (raisin, fig?) and ended with a noticeable alcohol burn. Drinks more like a wine than an ale. Very complex and  tasty. Still undecided whether I prefer St. Bernardus 12 over this or not. Tough call.

Poured a dark brown/black color with a thick off white head and lots of yeasty chunks floating.  Aroma is molasses, brown sugar, prune, a slight vanilla hint and kinda woody aroma.  Flavor is pretty sweet and smooth.  Notes of brown sugar and molasses hit first moving into a very mild vanilla, some coffee bitterness toward the end but finishes with a very sweet mildly dry finish.  The texture of the beer is thick and semi-chewy with a very effervescent feel to it from the high carbonation.  The alcohol is pretty well hidden as you could definitely not tell it was at 11.3%.  Overall a very good beer, well worth the money and a very complex, smooth beer with lots to offer.

Black colored with subtle ruby hues. Stable creamy tanned brown, fully lasting with excellent retention. Very complex fruity, vinous aroma with tons of sweet black currant and tart red currant, plums, ripe fruits. 
As you conditioning in the air its getting more complex. Perfectly smooth, balanced flavor with dark chocolate, mild coffee , tart and sweet blue or black berries. Vineous finish. Full bodied without being harsh or heavy, its extremely smooth bodied with smooth oily texture and smooth carbonation. The beer of meditations. I cant express myself how much i respect it. Word class. I will definitely taste it in matured versions.
Great beer.  Very complex flavor with many different layers.  Cant really get into details.  Dark with a nice head and fruity flavor.

Check plus! A wonderful quad from a wonderful (non-profit?!) brewery! Murcy, dark and opaque in appearance with a ~1 finger head. Dark, fruity aroma and a delicious flavor of nuts and sweet dark fruits. A lovely hint of sugary sweetness as well.

Apperance: Very, very, dark brown with a finger-sized head.

Aroma: Toffee, Molasses, Ripe fruit, Spices, Sugar and roasted malts.

Flavor: Candy sugar, Dark caramel, Toffee, Spices, Ripe fruit, Raisins and alcohol.

Palate: Very smooth and sweet with a bit of pleasant burn from the alcohol.

One of the best beers in the world. Period.

Nice, though not very outspoken aroma.
Taste is great. Bit peated, caramel.
Great aftertaste that lasts.

UPDATED: JAN 11, 2017 In a Rochefort goblet.   This is the best beer on the planet.. Its official because I said so. Dark brooding fruits soaked in booze... insanely complex malts touched by your favourite monks after being on their kness and feeling Jesuss salvation... Ive drunk this beer millions of times... complexity and simplicity .  beautiful.

UPDATED: MAR 3, 2009 Location: 12 oz. bottle at Waterfront Ale House NY, NY


Aroma: Slightly fruity, excellent

Appearance: Dark brown, great head, kind of off-white

Flavor: Wonderfully full, strong, complex, enjoyable

Palate: Full body, slightly syrupy, but really, this beer just makes you love beer

Overall Impression: This one was really excellent, seriously great, I wanted to give it a perfect score, I had heard great things, and when I saw it at the Waterfront Ale House, I couldnt resist...glad I didnt. Honestly, this is probably my favorite beer in the world.
bottle.  dark brown color with small cream head. Nose: caramel and alcohol w/ a hint of fruit. Flavor: full bodied, yet a very drinkable beer for its strength
this is the beer i have around the house for special occasions. think of it as the dom perignon on beer
Served at 35 F in Czech Pilner on 2/22/09. Excellent beer.   It had a great flavor, very easy to drink and a good taste after.  Not bitter, tinge of sweet.
My first rating.  Excellent beer.  Great aftertaste. Slight alcohol flavor that is to be expected for a high percentage beer.

Wow, A freind gave me two of these and what a friend I have. This beer is amazing. It begs you to drink more. Chimay glass. Dark brown colore with a nice head that stays through the duration of the beer. Good amount of lacing on the glass. Flavor is complex but screams for you to drink more. Alcohol content is hidden by the awesome flavor...it will sneak up on you. A truely great beer, a must have.

I tried 8 and 10 back to back. Nr 10 is definitely better. It got similar taste but its smoother somehow and for some reason it feels less alcoholic despite its high percentage. A truely top notch beer!

Lucky #100!  

Been saving this for a while!  Pours a dark brown with a lot of particulate, light brown head that sticks around.  Nice lacing.  Earthy nose, caramel, bready, with some sour fruit, cherry maybe?  Taste is similar, with a lot of carbonation.  Alcohol is barely present, amazingly smooth.  Oh boy this is a good beer!
Damn Belgians!  What a beer.  Complex flavor and knocks you on your ass.  Go time.

My special birthday beer.  11.2 ounce bottle in Chimay glass.  Dark brown with lasting head and some lace.  Toasted caramel port wine wood earth yeasty bread aroma.  Rich warm caramelized brown sugar raisin tobacco port wine slight alcohol warmth.  Medium-full body and low carbo (and warm) makes for a perfect soft mouthfeel.  An amazing beer.
