Colour: A/ deep-dark brown (reddish hue), hazy, thick dense creamy head, stable and going down lacey; B/deep-dark brown, foxy shine; cream-coloured head nearly immediately reduced to rim [4] Nose: banana, chocolate, toffee, ripe pear, hops; B/ caramel, toffee, liqueur, madeira [8] Taste: A/ nearly overly rich taste + mouthfeel (undivisible) with chocolate, double cream - that sounds as mole sauce?, enriched with vintage port, raisins and aromatic wood, enlivened with sugar-syrup and a bitter-peppery rootspice (horseradish, daikon,...) B/ Sweetness as from liquorice mixed in a port or dark apéritif wine (maybe a great vintage Pineau des Charentes). Alcoholtouch retronasal is from Armenian brandy. Tartness somewhere. Strange - I expected this one to be more mellow, but it is really much more severe. A beer that doesn't give a damn whether you like it or not - take it or leave it. "Complex" doesn't even start explaining [9] Mouthfeel& aftertaste A/ Lots of alcoholburn, as said very rich and chewy. Woody, really tart aftertaste on a velvety roasted maltbed B/ Rich again, but the esters, oxidation have made it less chewy - even when "light" is about the last word to come to mind. Aftertaste with walnut, crème de noix-flavour [5] Make no mistake - two quite different beers. Yet the points attribuated are exactly similar - for different reasons. Drinking this young or ageing it, in this case, is clearly an open "Geschmackssache"

Bottled. Dark brown with a crimson hue. Light beige head that settles down to only just be lacy. Sweet, sweet aroma. The sweetness was typically forward, then the alcohol through the middle, then finally a salty finish. Not the best as far as Im concerned.

First of all, thedm and I compared this to the Westy 12 and I very, very much like the Westy 12 over this brew. I just could not acquire a taste for this brew as I was hoping to. That said, it poured a large invigorating tan head with fine-small bubbles into my glass. The lacing was good on all sides of my glass. It had a sweet aroma to it and a cloudy brown body. There was carbonation observed with this brew. It kept leaving me with a tingly, burning sensation in my throat that was not to my liking. Give me a Westy 12 anyday!!

This brew poured a large head of light brown creamy fins bubbles and an opaque cloudy dark brown yeasty slightly carbonated body.  Its receeding head left a most excellent lacing and was very long lastibng.  It has a strong caramel malt aroma with a complex flavor of roasted malt, spivces and caramel notes.  The alcohol content was noticeable, but still well hidden.  What a most excellent treat for Father's Day!  We also had a Westvleteren 12 on the side for comparison.  The results were:

Appearance:    Westy
Aroma:         Rochfort
Flavor:        Westy
Palate:        Westy
Overall:       Westy
Bottle design: Rochfort
Bottle cap:    Rochfort

All in all we thought the Westy was better based mostly on its smoothness and better flavor!

Aroma is sour and pungent with a hint of spice and sweetness.  Appearance is cloudy brown with a light brown head and nice lace.  Flavour is magnifigant.  Subtle, sweet with big malt taste and sweet finish,  Little or no hint of alcohol.  A wonderful trappist.  Gets better with each sip! Great.

UPDATED: JUL 18, 2003 New Rating:  7/18/2003 - Huge grapey smell!  wow!  at each swallow i taste a huge grapey/plumby whallop.  i want to become a monk so i can make this.  Old Rating:  Normally i don't like raisins or plums.  but this stuff is pretty darn good.  very complex flavor with a very pleasing aftertaste.  i like it!

Beer only slightly chilled.  Beige head with dark body.  Smells doughy and of sweet yeast, also some cheesy notes.  Slight rush of alcohol to the nose, but very very subdued and controlled for an 11.3% beer.  Wonderful Belgian dark strong ale profile, with dark fruits and a moderate sweetness.  Definitely a world class beer, and to be honest, not terribly different from so many of the other top rated beers in this style.  I will say that I believe the Westy has a better, more developed mouthfeel.  Nevertheless, well done.

UPDATED: NOV 15, 2005 Head is light brown, initially large and frothy(pillowy!?!). Dark brown, full and creamy body. Sweet, malt, chocolate, fruity, vinous aroma... which describes the taste as well. Complex and balanced. Only downside is that the alcohol sometimes shines through too much.

Wow, this is beer! It tastes a lot of banana. Appears dark and cloudy. Has nuts, banana and dried fruits (plum, raisin) and a scent of chocolate. hmm...would taste fantastic with chocolate and fruits as a nice finish to a meal.

This poured a cloudy dark brown, with the thick head that seems to be a trademark of this type of beer. Scent is vinous, maybe plum and banana as well. Tastes of...well, I don't really know what this tastes like. Can never pick out flavors in the Belgians. Salty though, I know that much. Good too. I'd be happy to drink it again.
nice dark brown color; rich taste with a pleasantly bitter, very long lasting aftertaste

Full marks. There's no excuses for me trying this one so belatedly (I'm a 58 year old woman). It seems to be really easy to get over here - even Vintage Cellars have heaps of bottles. I finally bought one because I wanted to culture up the yeast for homebrewing, and was pretty amazed at the pour off... Aroma of filthy alcohol and rotting prunes; taste has caramel all over the place with slaps to the back of the head by some greased up bodybuilder who's taped deep fried mars bars to his palms. It conveys an overall feel of really decadent and fatty candy with sultanas and aero bars jammed in there and juicy patties from cows fed on belgian chocolate and ford pills. As others have said, room temperature is ideal. This was a total lip smacker that made a complete joke out of the Coopers I drank after it. I only hope the yeast gets going...
Like a fruitcake in a glass. Molasses, fruit, plums and alcohol meld beautifully together. A classic Trappiste Ale

I've made my choice, and beer 100 goes to Rochefort!  Upon pouring (at room temperature), notes of banana were apparent in the aroma.  Deeper inhalation yielded raisin, cherry, and alcohol.  Pours dark brown (much like a dark apple cider), with a dense, thick tan head of tiny bubbles.  Upon first sip, I was surprised by the inviting mouthfeel lent to this beer by the tight carbonation.  Flavors include raisins, cherries, toffee, cider, and a hint of chocolate, all balanced against nicely warming alcohol notes.  Hops notes are unsurprisingly light.  Overall, a very well-balanced, sweet, malty palate.  The tart, warming aftertaste says "go ahead, take another sip," and is not cloying or annoying.  Overall mouthfeel is full without feeling viscous.  Rich, complex, warming, and smooth, this one belongs on my "elixir" list, which includes such brews as Celebrator Doppelbock, Bells Expedition, Double Cream, and Kalamazoo Stouts, and Stone Old Guardian Barleywine.  Thanks to those ratebeerians who made the suggestion!

UPDATED: APR 30, 2004 I tried this against Westy 12 this evening. It wasnt as good as the almighty Westy but it sure did hold its own. Aroma is of a freshly cut tree, caramel, and raisins. Appearance is a dark brown with even better lacing on my glass than Westy. Flavor is amazing. DO NOT drink this cold. It was nothing special at all before it warmed, but baby when it warms, BAM! The flavor explodes on you. I swear its two different beers served cold and at the correct temp. Heavy on the chocolate note, apricots, caramel, spiced fruit, and raisins. It has a noticeable alcohol flavor but for a 11.3% ABV beer it is hidden quite well. Palate is rich and chocolatey with an almost smokey earthy feel to it. Its tied with Abbaye De Rocs Grand Cru as my 2nd favorite Belgian. It should have the same reputation that Westy 12 does because its certainly as good. Get this beer and enjoy a night of blistful sipping!

I think the name Rochefort is pronounced "Rocket" because this is what this brew is. Pure indulgence by the master brewer in making a ABV brew more atuned with a red wine than beer. Heavy, dark and spicy. It hangs together well, with a less than smooth finish, but is not short on flavour nor on aroma. I'd been waiting a long time to sample this one, and was not disappointed.

Intense fruit and wood aromas. Dark brown, slim tan head. Superb fruit, plums, prunes apricots and nuts, fine bitterness. Complex, incredibly smooth and so well balanced. Magnificent! Thank You for sharing joey _capps!

Creamy head, dark brown, a bit cloudy. Of course you could notice some alcohol but beyond that you find raisins and medium roasted sweet malt. I like its softness, which made interesting compound with its richness. Dig deeper and you will find some of the roasted malt, dark coffee and at the bottom some organic plums.
Tasting the yeast separately highly recommended. Great palate with a sweet, moderate finish. Ranks well against westie 8

UPDATED: JUL 26, 2003 Finally able to taste this beer! I hope to make this rating as informative as possible, but this is obviously one of the top beers people are willing to try. I bought and tried the Westy 12 because it was ranked so highly...and I recommend it to everyone I see, it is still the best beer i've ever had. So, with that said, here is the review for the Rochefort Trappistes 10. First things first, the temperature of the beer is 63 degrees Farenheit. Dark black colour with a slight tan head and zillions of small bubbles rising up on the side of the glass...very neat looking. The beer is almost completely opaque and even as you stretch it at the sides, no light shows through. Smells of ripe dark fruits, such as raisins and black currants dominate the aroma. Malt and chocolate also show through in the nose, but very minutely. A very complex smelling beer, which definately leaves your mouth ready to taste the beer. And the taste? Complex at first...but almost exactly the same as the smell. Hints of chocolate and malt undermine the taste, while ripe fruits dominate the flavour of the beer. Plums, Raisins and even cherries are in the taste. A very malty beer with that being a definate character of the overall taste and palate. The aftertaste leaves you wanting to taste it again, to see what other flavours and characters you can find in the beer, and this one always keeps you guessing. A very complex beer, both in the smell and in the taste, but done very well. Some hop character, but definately malt overwhelmed. The alcohol is somewhat noticable, but not in a bad way at all. A great texture in the mouth...very carbonated, yet coats the inside of the mouth and the tongue very well. I poured this very slowly down the sides of the goblet until a major amount of sediment came out, then I stopped the pour with probably only 5 to 10 millilitres of liquid left in the bottle. After a few sips, the sweet characters shine through in the aftertaste: chocolate (the major player), roasted flavours, ripe fruits all team up very well to make it a pleasant aftertaste. Due only to personal preference, I believe that the Westy 12 is more of a 'perfect' beer, but that could be only because I like hoppy, lighter, less-malty beers more, but this is still one of the best beers i've ever had. On a quick side note, the inital flavour I had in my mouth after tasting the first sip reminded me very much of the 'meatyness' of the Sam Adams Triple Bock (which I HATED), but those memories quickly faded with the good characters of this beer. If someone asked me what the best beer i've ever had was, I would still say: Westy 12, but this one ranks very close to that. I bought this bottle at Beers of the World in Rochester, New York and the price was $10 I believe. Definately worth a try, especially if you want to sample some of the best beers in the entire world!!!
Nice dark brown liquid with a light foam.  Sweet roasty aroma with some malt hints.  Nice alcohol evident in nose and taste.  Warms.  Good texture.  Good subdued sweetness.  A wonderous beer.

Pours a soupy brown, like a rancid Pepsi, with floaties. Head is dissapointly thin and disappears quickly. Peppers on the nose. At this point I was preppared to be let down, but wasn't. Overwhelmed by flavors. Black Pepper, alcohol, raisins, applesauce, cinnamon, caramel, even some rosemary, perhaps, and an incredible spicy finish.

I was very exited to find this in my local liquor store. While pleasant, I didn't find the beer as dramatic as the reputation. 

Yes, the raisin, plum and choclate flavors are there. The mouth feel is VERY smooth. And, considering teh strenght, the alcohol was relatively subdued. But I don't know if I would spend $8 on it again.
Much like the Rochefort 8, this was a good beer, but a bit too much alcohol in the taste for me.  I liked the 8 much better.

Dark burgundy in colour.  Aroma is malty, sweet, of chocolate.  The flavour is of chocolate, caramel, cherries, quite full.  Finishes slightly sweet and bitter with a long aftertaste.  Thanks to Adam for this birthday gift.
UPDATED: MAY 1, 2004 This beer is a proof. There is a god watching over us, What more do I have to say.If you have the change to taste this beer, please do so, Amen. I drink alot of it.

UPDATED: AUG 19, 2016 Wow! what a beer! I am very tempted to give this a perfect score. It poured a very dark color and a quite thick head. The smell of the beer was close to perfection, so many things going on in my nose when I smelled that, next was to have nice mouthful of this, and that was something to remember. I dont know quite to describe it. There was a party of taste in my mouth and everybody was invited!! a bit chocolate taste, hints of fruits and raisins, this is something to have again and again. You cant feel the alcahol,very well masked, but this something that should only be enjoyd as a night cap or a dessert. Thanks to Eirikur to introduce me to this fest of a beer!
Wow.  Those Belgians don't mess around.  Thank God for Ohio changing its beer laws.

On a Sunny Sunday arvo at a Belgian Beer Cafe in Melbourne, I stumbled upon one of the holy grails of Beer, this one! But I was well let down by the hype of this beer. Its pours a lovely dark brown color and beautiful looking head, sweet smelling aroma, tastes of plum and raisin and the ABV is excellently masked in this brew. The flavors came through better once it warmed. The price for this drop was ridiculous. I would love to try it again, maybe while watching my AFL team the "Swans" kicking some other teams butt, while not being in such a critical mood.
I had been waiting for quit some tim before tasting this great beer. Unfortunately I can't say it's my beer. Nevertheless there is lots to smell and taste. Perhaps i should ry it some other time.

Spongy, tight packed head.  The head is light brown/tan in color.  It looks like it will stick around for a little while.  The aroma is yeasty with hints of raisins and plums.  Overall, a fairly sweet aroma with an undertone of alcohol.  The color is fairly dark brown, like a monk's robe.  The alcohol in the flavor is concealed well.  There seems to be a residule film in my mouth that diminishes quickly.  There is a sweetness in the brew that is just right, not too much or little.  This seems significantly different than the Rochefort 8, a little heavier.  Overall, this ale is great, but still not a Westy 12, in my opinion anyway.

UPDATED: FEB 19, 2004 Thick tan head, stuck around for the duration of the beer.  Aroma has a strong alcohol note along with raisins, green apple and plum.  Sweet dark sugary notes as well.  The flavor also features an agressive alcohol taste.  Roasty biscuit amd apple peel are also plesant.  Finishes with some chocolate bitterness.  I don't see what the big deal is about this beer - too much alcohol flavor for not much depth of flavor.

This beer poured a very dark brown color and formed an light tan bubbly head that left some lace. An aroma of malt, plum, raisins and spice. A flavor of malt and spice with some fruit element plus you can detect the presence of the alcohol and it's warming effect comes through in a tart finish that hints at heavy carbonation being present. This is by far the best of the three of theirs that I have tried. Thanks again to the Ohio lawmakers for letting us get this.

UPDATED: APR 1, 2003 Beautiful dark ruby color with a nice off-white head. The aroma was bursting with all kinds of fruits...plums, apricots, grapes. Behind the fruit was a nice vanilla/ bubble gum, sugary sweet character. The flavor was very sweet...fruity (more plums)...vanilla...very subtle peppery/spiciness. I really didn't notice the alcohol at all. Wet feel with a long aftertaste. Wonderful experience!

First thing I noticed was its sizzle. Best sounding beer I've had it a while. Otherwise: thick, opaque chocolate brown w/ powder-like sediment &  lively beige head. Wonderfully complex nose with bubble gum, cookie dough, & toffee. Soft, full-bodied feel.  Flavours are equally as complex as aroma if not more so. I'm getting cocoa, sweet dark fruit, brandy, toffee, cookie dough, pepper & vanilla. The alcohol is noticeable (perhaps not as well hidden as in the 8) and the finish is sweet yet dry w/ a lovely hint of hops.

Muddy orange brown color with a dense haze of carbonation and particulates. Off white head with light brown blotches. Boozy, rum-raisin aroma. Somewhat sticky and a bit thinner on the palate than I had hoped for but soft, smooth carbonation helps to make up for it. Nice candi sugar sweetness. The thing I notice most is the medicinal alcoholic burn on my toung. Looking past that, there is a certain magic to the chemistry between the vinous raisiny quality and the subdued hop bitterness in the finish.

It's good but smells and tates way too much of alcohol. I liked the dark and thick pour and almost no head retention. Malty and caramely but that damned alcohol taste wouldn't go away. Would be great if I were out camping, warmed up my insides real nice. Got better as it warmed up but still, that alcohol smell!
Very alcoholic, kinda like dropping a shot of vodka in a chimay bleu.  Ok, not that bad, but is a very heavy & strong ale.  Dark black/brown in color.  Again, let this belgian warm itself up...

Amazing..the pour was dark dark brown. The head was light and quickly disappears. The smell of alcohol is very present with underlying hints of raisins and toffee. The finish is dry and slightly bitter.  Worthy of is rating.

Had from bottle on March 2, 2003An amazingly complex beer, it pours with a dark brown color, completely opaque.  The head is light brown and disappears quickly, leaving only a small layer of bubbles up top for the rest of the beer.  The aroma is laced with alcohol and fruit - the alcoholic scent was to be expected with this strong 11.3% ABV.  Initial taste is sweet, with a bit of alcohol, and a very light hint of coffee/toffee.  A luxurious beer, the aftertaste is almost the best part - sweet, a tad bit acidic, but very pleasant overall.  I started drinking it a bit too cold, but as it warmed a bit, the flavors really became apparent and the complexity of this gorgeous brew emerged.
Cloudy brown color, small brown disapearing head. Sweet aroma of berries, raisons and toffee. Flavor is also sweet and a little acidic, with caramel and toffee

Finally i got to track down this monster last night at Obriens. This one poured out of my bottle and into my glass a cloudy dark brown with a medium brownish head which did not lace. The aroma was an overpowering smell of alcohol with unidentifiable fruits hidden in there as well. The taste is brimming with carbonation, more so than any other belgian i can remember thus far. Heavy fruit emphasis with raisins, plum and cherry coming to mind. Alcohol flavor and burn is also very common in the taste. The drink actually just has this aged taste about it. I found this to almost have a few port wine qualities to it, given the strong plum and raisin qualities which grew as the drink went down and the aftertaste remained given that lively carbonation level. Nice bittering of the palate and good dry ending. It tries to hide the alcohol as best it can, but 11.3% ABV is a tough order to mask, but Rochefort has done a nice job. Very pleasant indeed.
This was a very nice belgian strong ale.  A very deep and dark color.  Lots of little flavors seep through the thickness of this brew.  Nicely done.

2/10/03:  bottle.  nice, thick tan rocky head.  dark red- brown color.  strong ring of carbonation, lacing.  nose of alcohol and fruit- raisins in particular.  tastes include raisins, other fruit, malt and alcohol.  a bit to heavy of an alcohol taste for me.

UPDATED: JAN 14, 2004 Mahogany brown body. Beige head that diminished to a thin line. Some lacing.
Very fruity to the nose. Having trouble with exactly what I'm smelling. Quite a bit going on including hints of the alcohol.
Very malty first taste with raisins coming in the middle with a smooth alcohol finish. Raisin character really sticks out here. Some woodiness too.
Carbonation was sufficient enough to brighten the deep flavors. The best example of carbonating a big beer that I've sampled yet...

Deep within the oak cask Yorick the yeast pulled his flap cap further down his forehead, licked his stumpy pencil and glared at the junior yeasts assembled before him. "Chocolate?" he barked. At the back a young yeast lifted his hand. "Here, Sir," he squeaked. Yorick made a tick on the clipboard in his left hand, then snarled: "Bread and Butter Pudding?" Two yeasts at the front of the mob lifted their hands together. "Present", "And correct!" they said, one after the other. Yorick continued down the list, ticking off each name as it was called, until he came to: "Alcohol!" There was no reply. Yorick raised his big bushy eyebrows and surveyed the nervous little yeasts in front of him. "Alcohol! I know you're here, I can smell you. Now answer!" There was a long pause, then something began stirring at the back of the crowd, pushing its way through. The little yeasts shuffled and moved sideways making a huge gap through which lumbered an enourmous, hairy ape of a yeast, muscles bulging, and scars all over it's huge body. "What?" he growled as he approached Yorick. "Just checking that you're here, that's all," replied Yorick. The great yeast bent down to stare closely into Yorick's face. "I would have thought that was bloody obvious," he thundered, before turning round to clomp his clumsy way to the back of the crowd.

UPDATED: APR 22, 2010 33cl bottle:  This one pours a dark caramel brown color.  There was quite a bit of a tan head on it that lingers awhile.  A bit of alcohol in the nose, but many other aromas present, all very subtle and blending together into something wonderful.  Definitely some dark fruits, with a hint of raisin on top.  An absolute taste explosion on the tongue.  Some sweetness, with caramel and toffee in there.  Maybe some vanilla and a host of fruits blending together.  A great treat!  Pricey, but I dont mind  buying this one once in a while.  Definitely one of the best.

Wonderful deep brown appereance, with a creamy and persistent foam. This beer has one of the most complex and complete flavour I've ever found in a beer. The flavour is delicate and fruity, with traces of blackberry,plum and raspberry. The finish is very alcoholic (11,3%!!), and the aftertaste is bitter, with a light coffee flavour. Simply wonderful! (Note: this beer doesn't have to be served too cold!!!)

UPDATED: APR 27, 2003 Poured with a thin beige-brown head, dark red-brown coloured liquid. Aroma smelt strongly of alcohol and caramel. Flavours of plum, chocolate, and some wheat(banana). Suprisingly strong alcohol taste, overpowered a lot of subtle flavours. I suspect the serving temperature was too cold. Very smooth full bodied ale. Re-rate 26/4: Served at a proper temp this time. Still a hint of alcohol present in aroma, but much more complex aroma present. Dark fruits come through, along with some spice. ABV was masked much more when the beer was at a proper temp. Lovely drop.

Thin beige head. dark brown color. Aroma is sweet, caramelly, with alchool and banana notes. Flavor is very complex, sweet too with candy sugar, chocolate and raisins tones, ending in a pleasant ricolice finish. Full bodied.

I am always at a crossroads with these high alcohol beers about how much like wine they are.  Can you justify spending $8 for a 12 oz. bottle of wine?  Color in glass is like coffee that has been sitting in a pot all day.  Nice head that returns when swirled to give a new sensation of aromas as it warms.  You must let this beer sit in the glass and warm before drinking otherwise the alcohol taste will be overwhelming.  Complex, but glad I got it on sale.

Had this two seperate times, and it seemed better the first time, but I didn't think to rate it then.  The nose is very sweet and rich with alcohol predominating until the brew is allowed to breathe.  Secondary aromas consist of figs, dates, maple syrup, resin, and pepper.  This brew pours a dark walnut with honey highlights or as my tasting buddy put it murky dogshit brown (he doesn't get out much).  The light brown fizzy head diminishes rapidly with no lacing.  The exceptionally well balanced and deep flavor has a high level of acidity.  The finish is sweet warm and spicy.  The light to medium fizzy dry body finishes dry.  As my buddy put it "This stuff is like Honey Brown to the 100th power".  I don't know about all that but this is definitely an interesting brew.

Poured out dark and mean, with a small stream of bubbles that kept the head to a perfect minimum.  Malt and bubblegum smells called to hungry wolf.  I licked my lips cuz I was ready to win. I brought the glass to my lips for the first angry taste.  Chocolate, bubblegum, butterscotch amid a smooth ricochet of champagne bubbles.  On the hunt tonight for love at first sting.  Here I am, rock you like a hurricane.

UPDATED: OCT 27, 2007 This is one great beer and a wonderful way to start my second hundred.  Rich brown, cloudy, like chocolate soda with a splash of milk.  Dark sweet malt taste and bitter hops, floral hops, thirst quenching acid, bitter chocolate and bitter espresso.  Finishes with hoppy bitterness, sweetness, and sourness all at once.  Probably a great deal of alcohol, but completely masked by the malt and other flavors.  Mouth filling, tannin coating, with a bubbling freshness.  What a great beer.  I had been hoarding the couple I had been able to find, but today I was able to get a case at Beer Yard in Wayne. // Splitting hairs here, but I think I put this a bit too close to perfect when I first rated it.
UPDATED: APR 27, 2005 Rich brown color,transluminate.  Mix of fruit flavor and alcohol, flavor of plums sticks out more than others.  Complex brew. Can I have another!

UPDATED: SEP 3, 2003 Almost as perfect as it gets.  Like Kasteel, but a little more complex, less sweet, and more bitter at the end.  There should be a price catagory in these ratings also because this was rediculously expensive (something like $7 for 330mL).  I can get Kasteel for about $6.49 for a 750mL.  Is it better than Kasteel?  Maybe.  Is it worth paying more than twice as much?  No!

Rerate:  I must rerate this because I had Wesvleteren, and the Wesvleteren was much better.
Beautiful dark colour.  Pleasing aroma.  Unfortunately I burned my tongue this morning, but I still enjoy the very complex flavour.

Dark ruby brown color, thin beige head, left little lacing.  Spicy aroma of alcohol, plum, and a little malt.  Flavor matches the aroma with some sweetness, yeast, and vinousness.  Medium-full body with a dry finish.  More spicy and less fruity than Westvleteren 12, and overall not as complex.

UPDATED: FEB 24, 2003 Very impressive! brown body with a white head that is very small but seems to be lasting through my whole pint.  the aroma is a dream come true for alcoholics that love dark fruits.  alcohol and rich friut come out in the aroma and in the flavor.  the flavor smacks of a very rich combination of plum, raisin and alcohol.  the flavor just never gives up, it is fantastic.  the body is wonderfully round and smooth filling my whole mouth with these wonderful flavors.  i wish i had more than just this one bottle.

the best one !

the only one !

UPDATED: DEC 13, 2003 I couldn't help but make comparisons to the Westy 12 throughout this bottle, which is unfair, but I just couldn't help it. This was actually surprisingly different: nuttier and yeastier with less fruit in the flavor than the Westy. The fruit seems to be more in the alchohol here rather than the malt. Very nice cloying warmth with the yeast. You've gotta love the classic Belgian currant/raisin bliss traditional to Trappist beer, I sure as hell do. Just damn good.

UPDATED: JAN 28, 2006 Very dark and rich. Slight taste of fruit(raisins or maraschino cherries(??)) and spices with maybe a pinch of anise detected. Cant wait to have it again. When I do I will re-rate this one! ***Re-rate: Had this one last night. Wonderful beer! Hazy brownish black in color. Sediment clumps floating throughout. Strong raisin taste permeates the first sip. Followed up by a cherry and candy-like aftertaste. Evident alcohol notes but not overwhelming. Seek this out and drink it now!

Very, very malty and full-bodied. It tastes somewhat plant-like/organic.  Cocoa, and "other complexities".  Yes, this is a very complex beer, and I cannot put my finger on the various flavors that burst into my mouth.  The alcohol is a little too present for my taste.

I had to save something special for number 100, and this was it.  But I must say I was a bit disappointed (though not much).  This has a great appearance - dark, brownish-red with a nice lacing.  The aroma is full of chocolate and plums.  The taste is very vinous, with raisins and dates, and a slight maltiness.  The flavors werent as full as I was expecting, but the soft, dry finish was somewhat pleasing.  The fullness in the body just didnt seem present in this, but the alcohol was decently masked.  It is good, but I was hoping to give this a still higher rating based on the hype.  I actually think Abbaye des Rocs Grand Cru is better than this.

UPDATED: JAN 6, 2003 Very opaque, dark brown, beige head.  Nose has some alcohol and sweet maly aromas.  Front was slightly sweet and tart.  Middle was more complex with a little of that alcholic warmth kicking in.  Finish was more of the sweet/tart and very warm (hiccup).  I know these Belgians are supposed to be highly carbonated, but still too much for me.  Overall a good belgian, but did not live up to the hype IMHO.

UPDATED: JUN 10, 2007 Cloudy dark red/brown color with small quickly dissapearing off white head. Aroma is malty, notes of toasted caramel, figs, dates, red grapes, faint cherry, bit of vanilla and charred oak. Flavor is malty, lots of caramel, hint of fig, fair amount of vanilla, with faint notes of oak and cherry. Finish is relatively sweet. Always a great brew, although this bottle did not seem quite as fantastastic as some have been.

Mild aroma of chocolate and earth.Flavors of chocolate cherries and figs.Missing that dark bread flavor the 8 had.I think the 8 has better aroma, but this one masks the alchohol extremely well and has a unique mellowed flavor for a dark trappist.Kind of reminds me of Fullers vintage ale.

Incredie McDreadie appearence.  Deep brown colour with a creamy off-white head.  Cherry, nutmeg, cinnmaon aroma.  Much more intense than the 6 & 8, but it falls right in line flavour wise.  Sedimenty.
A real fine beer. Good, sweet and strong taste, that last a long time. And a aroma that goes with it. But it has a bit too much alcohol in both taste and aroma.

Great. I could drink this everyday. They should put it in a 40oz for us Americans. Amazingly masked alcohol. So damn smooth and wonderfully aromatic. If Westy is better than this, Im in   for a real treat. This beer rules.
I didnt think Id ever get my hands on this one, nor did I think it would be this delicious.  This is smoothest, tastiest 11.3% one can ever drink.

Pours a very cloudy, dark brown color with a big, tan head. Wonderful aroma of sugary malts and alcohol that make my mouth water. The flavor consists vanilla and malts with a very long sweet finish. No alcohol present in the flavor, but there is a good warming effect from the gut. Leaves a minimal amount of lacing on the glass. Medium bodied, sweet, and delicious.

Re-rate. Nose of raisins and plums, earthiness and alcohol. Dark sugar and molasses. Twizzlers and vanilla. Deep dark brown-black beer with thin lacing off-white head. Medium-high effervescent car with, surprisingly, light-medium body. A clean palate.  Ahh, the taste: maltiness, sweet but not syrupy on the tongue. Mild nutty sweet finish with raisiny after. Cherry wood and vapory. Raisins and plums. Sugary and peppery. Bit of chalkiness from the dregs. Rich and complex, big taste and wonderful aroma.  Hide the 11% alcohol well. A great winter evening beer.

Very strong ale.  Very present taste of alcohol- much more than Chimay.  True to a Trappist taste.  Lots of head and carbonation like a glass of cola.  Yeast, spice, banana, pepper, chocolate, plum,  and rum taste.  Most complex beer that I have ever had.  Its perfect, and will knock you on your ass with its strength and complexity.  Its a bit expensive though, especially because my local shops only have small bottles.

UPDATED: JAN 27, 2006 another very fine ale

taste of strong alcohol if not set down to warm to room temp.

also sits very well on the palate.
hint of malt and plum is noticed in it too.

dark dark with an off white head.   big, lots of lace.  So subtle yet so strong.  Absolutely packed to the limit with flavor.  Incredible. Fruity candy, pepper, chocolate, toffee, nutmeg, I could just list flavors ad infinitum. Incredible beer.  Thank you Kaya
What can I say!! This beer  great..
An absolute brewing watermark.  I wish that I could put into words this wonderful Belgian

Deep chestnut brown. Humungous head of medium and compact bubbles. Tacky lace. Vinegar, fruit(figs, prunes), bacitracin, sweet and sour sauce, blue cheese, tobacco, leather, and alcohol aromas, to name a few. Figs, plums, sour berries, bitter bakers chocolate, Stilton cheese, and an amalgam of spices and flavors I cant put a finger on. Mildly astringent and dry. A mild bitterness creeps down the back of the tongue, similar to the feel of an espresso. Really dry fruitiness as it warms.
Almost the perfect beer
Raisin aroma, dark brown color, small head, strong alcohol aftertaste. Very good but not great. Paid $6.99 at Sams in chicago.

Trying to rate this as honestly as possible. It comes across as a little harsh at first, but once you get used to the alcohol it becomes more pleasant. Quite woody, raisin, and some other things that Im having trouble identifying. I get a lot of coconut in the nose. Im not sure if a lot of the things I taste and smell in this are real or if theyre just olfactory hallucinations brought on by the high alcohol content.

Heavily sedimented throughout, real nice, very erratic lace.  Alcohol prevails in the nose, but of course it should, its 11+ percent!  I think Im going to need  a whole 750 just to get all the words out.  The spices and dried fruits last quite a while.  Incredible incorporation of a whallop of alcohol.  the complexity  and depth round the whole package out.  a wonderful exBEERience!  Its tough to keep in mind that there is actually that much alcohol.  kind of scares me about those monks =)

choclate brown with even head and lots of sediment, strong solid and straightforward like a qb sneak on 4th and 1, subtle spiciness and lots of raisins, absolutely incredible job at masking the alcohol
Finally i get my hands on this beer, and it surely does not disappoint. Amazingly complex and delicious. Alcohol wasnt apparent in my opinion. If only i didnt have to travel 300 miles to get it...

Aaaahhhhh!!!!! 
Lovely stuff, I hope they can resist the temptation to mass-produce this gem of a beer
A very good trappist ale but not the best, but as all trappist ales it rates far above the average beer

impressive aroma
great taste, 
but : somewhat disappointing lack in aftertaste
one of the best, though

WHEN I FIRST HAD THIS BEER IT CHANGED ME FOREVER...THE AROMA WAS SO AWESOME, I COULD HARDLY PULL MY NOSE OUT OF THE GLASS TO TASTE IT. IM GALD I DID THOUGH, BECAUSE THE COMPLEXITY OF ITS FLAVORS WAS AMAZING.DARK FRUIT AND SWEETNESS...IT MAKES ME WANT TO GO GET ANOTHER ONE RIGHT NOW! EVERYONE SHOULD TRY THIS BEER.
Theres been so much said, that I couldnt elaborate.  This is good beer.

UPDATED: FEB 25, 2003 a dark beauty with secret reddness and gorgeous creamy lather.. aroma was a melted bundle of raisins, mildewy cardboard, dust, & dirty socks, with the added pleasure of grape koolaid touched with drizzles of liquid chocolate and sprinkles of cinnamon & nutmeg..a secret party of evil fruit with grapes, plums, raisins, and apples..chocolate hot tubs..dancing licorice..vinous music..and alcoholic strippers..
Truely magical.  I felt the warmth spread through me with the first sip.  Flavors Ive never had before that kept returning even days later.  Truely the best beer I have ever tasted.

UPDATED: JUN 23, 2003 Poured dark brown-amber with big chunks of sediment, which worried me momentarilly, but they settled.  Medium fizzy head, dissappated to a thin ring of bubbles around the edges.  The flavors in this are nearly overwhelming - It's a good thing that I took an hour to drink it, any quicker and you're gonna miss something.  Start of the swallow is a somewhat sharp pear fruityness on the sides of the tongue.  then comes various chocolates, plums, cinnamon.  Later, I got nutty flavors as it warmed.  The finish was dry on the top of the tongue, but the more assertive notes continued to play about underneath my tongue - a new experience.

How do I start? From Belgian to my door, Great head smooth, hops of intense proportion and well I dont think I can say anything that has not been said befor I.  This is a great beer.  Im kinda pissed that people that dont know much about real beer give these great beers poor or avarage ratings. This beer is way better than a 4 anything less of a rating is rookie and disregardful to the true brew. I had this from a goblet, as Rush says- "from another goblet from the cask of 43"
UPDATED: MAY 10, 2003 Looks and acts just like rootbeer with strong alcohol taste.  Great for sipping, but not the thirst quencher I need.  Sweet spicey taste is the only thing that saved it for me.
user_location: Middle of no where, Ohio, USA

text: Big ass rocky light tan head.Big ole chunks of lace hangin on to the bottom of the glass.Cinnamon in the nose with some earthy aromas. Kinda tart.Hazy brown color wwith orange highlights.Interesting spiceyness.Alcohol is well hidden.Fairly spritzy on the tongue.Sweet finish.Good beer, interesting.Much more drinkable than i had imagined.

WoW! What a wonderful beer this was. I paid a small fortune for it but I will do it again. Out of the bottle it is a ruddy dark brown with heavy sedimentation and a small quickly dissapating head. Aroma of sweet dark fruit(ie rasin, prunes etc.) and a hint of the alcohol that lies in wait. Flavors are very subtle and melded together exceptionally well. Starting off you have the same dark fruit that you had in the nose, followed by a chocolate sweetness, ending with a smooth warm feeling yet leaving the mouth clean and ready for another drink. I havent had the oppertunity to try the Westy. yet but this sets the bar pretty damned high.

UPDATED: DEC 9, 2003 Pours a cloudy dark reddish brown with a medium quickly fading head. Nose is brandy, plum and a wiff of cocoa. Flavors complex: Sweet, spicy, fruity, tangy light bitterness. Strong alcohol warming, but not overwhelming. Very drinkable for its strength.

Re-Rate: Ok, I must have gotten a bad bottle. (inconsistent) This isnt as yeasty and has absolutely no sea monkeys. Best at about 50°F. Cocoa notes, plum, softly vinous, fig, head is now a thin layer in arabesques. Finish is medium soft with only a suggestion of what hop means on the West Coast. Alcohol is definitely felt by glasss end but is nto felt with every sip. This is an amazing brew.
 9/1/2001: Im not sure why I feel the need to apologize, but I will. This beer and its ilk of high alcohol and malty brews have done little for me and Im sorry to do this to a world classic. Yes fruit hues emerge but only as occasional accompaniment to the methodic pounding of candy carmel and alcohol.  I am very disappointed.  The tongue is almost all alcohol, flooding and piquant with bits of fruit emerging in the vacuum of the riptide.  Even its presentation was flawed by a big black sea monkey like a mote on the dying head. I wish I could send Edsten Double-Plus to more people. This is a beer with nearly the same ABV and yet 100 times the flavor. Actually there are many beers I could name to beat this one at its ABV.

The first sample of the aroma won me on this beer.  A rich plum/chocolate aroma and malty flavor.  At the risk of hurting someones feelings, I dont understand how it can be rated under the Westvleteren.  This is definitely the beer for me.

UPDATED: JUL 19, 2003 Update:  It hurts to admit you were wrong.  This beer is amazing.  There is simply a ton of raisin and chocolate and this is amazingly complex.  I am sorry for not immediately recognizing  the genius here.  After 14 tries, Chimay still sucks, however.

Old:  I followed Volgon's recommended serving suggestions to the letter on this one.  Boozy nose.  Flavors of pear, raisins, fruit cake, vanilla and banana, with the yeast providing the most interesting flavors.  Unfortunatly, these flavors could barely manage to peek out under the sheer weight of the alcohol.  Unbalanced and fairly disappointing.  Given the problem, I will certainly sample the lower-ABV Rochefort, which I think would be superior.

My bottle was dated 11/14/06. A deep amber color with the floating yeast visible when held up to the light. A wonderfully rich, sweet initial aroma. Full head that dissapated very quickly. Warm toffee-like flavor. Definitely warm going down. Well worth the price of admission.

Anise and almost brandylike aroma initially.  Thick rich deep sweet malt flavor is a whirlwind of flavor.  Liquorice -- check, plum -- check, this beer has a ton of malt complexity.  Elegant and refined, there is a reason that this beer is one of the top rated beers here--sheer quality.  Beer number 500 for me and an excellent, excellent beer.

UPDATED: JUL 9, 2003 Opaque dark brown color with a thick foamy head and lasting lace.  Sweet fruity aroma with an alcohol kick.  Sweet chocolaty malt flavor with an alcohol bite.  the finish is sweet and coffee like.  heavy body, soda like and warm going down.

UPDATED: JUL 1, 2008 Rated: 8/20/02.  Bottle with a 7/11/06 date. A dark night with a light brown sky.  A powerful aroma that almost burns the nose with dark fruit, malt, and raisins. Exceptionally smooth and creamy with vinous fruit, peppery, woody, and malty depth.  The alcohol is up front and present, which is kind of surprising since some of the high class peers of this brew hide the alcohol better.  Yet it is nicely warming and the dark fruits create a complexity and foundation that supports the alcohol well.  Re-Rate 10/29/02 (10 4 8 4 19).  Still fantastic  I had this in honor of a newborn... Aidan John Edward Schmidt.  Re-Rate 06/30/08 with a date of 29/07/07 (probably saved for 5 years) (8 5 9 4 18).  A dark brown color with a rich creamy tan head.  A wonderfully fruit aroma balanced with malts and ginger.  Rich, lively carbonated, malty and well balanced fruity flavors.  This one stands the test of time.
I think the fact that I want to be a Trappist Monk sums it up!!!!!

UPDATED: MAR 9, 2003 A lot more head than last time and a rich beady chocolate and bannana cream in the nose.  Starts with sharp carbonation and cold chocolat coffee.  As the beer continues rasins, bread, cassis, dark berries  and a wine-like fruityness emerge.  Tons of chocolate with an undertone of bitterness.  Long vinous finish that invites you for more.  Gets better with every sip.  If you can find it, stock up.  4.3
rerate  Carbonation has settled down to a nice calm smoothness, vannila and irish cream just waft off this one and permeate every corner of the flavor, alot less wine-like and coffee is no where near as present.  Truely world class.

UPDATED: JAN 11, 2004 Re-rate 2/28/03, bottle marked 16 01 07:  Pours a deep brown color that stops most light.  The aroma is heavenly and contains, plums, sweet malts, brown sugar and some dark fruits.  Robustly carbonated with soft bubbles.  Flavor is a delightful sweetness that is beyond good. The year of aging really helps.  No score change from last time. Re-rate 8/14/02:  While still easily one of the greatest beers on the planet, it lost in a head-to-head with Westy 12.  The alcohol was more noticeable and the flavor less complex.  Re-rate 3/5/02:  Still #1, make sure you get ALL the yeast in it.  Best at room temp. As I say keep in a cool place, not your fridge.   First rating:  (04 08 04 on bottle) A new number one in my book.  Outstanding chocolate doughy fruitiness.  I keep looking into the empty bottle wishing there was more...MORE!!!  This beer does have its downside though.  It is very expensive; $USA7.85, small; 33cl, and...and...I'm ending this rating and going to sniff the empty bottle for a while.

UPDATED: JAN 29, 2008 Bottle... The aroma is moderately malty and fruity (plums). Also hints of ruby port and the high ABV does come discreetly through in the nose. This murky dark brown beer has a tan, rocky head with excellent lacing. Fully lasting too. Bottle conditioned. The initial flavor is pretty darn malty with a lightly sweet and moderately bitter taste on the backside. Full-bodied with an oily mouthfeel. Lively carbonation with a long, slightly sweet finish. Personally, I was disappointed due to this beers extremely high rating. However, its definitely a quality Belgian ale.
wasnt exactly sober when i tried this but it tasted quite ribena-like with some bread and butter pudding. had it slightly more sober and appreciated it more
What a cheer pleasure to sip this fine beer so much flavors going on. The only deterand to drink this daily is the price; i paid $7 for a small bottle , well worth it though

UPDATED: JUN 12, 2003 Deep black color, lacy head, big malty aroma. Malty and expansive. Candy sugar and alcohol. Fruit and spices. Complex flavor, but alcohol predominates. Warms the tummy well. Smooth taste. Excellent flavor. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is malty and dry. Aftertaste is malty and slightly bitter with a definite alcohol bite. Great beer, but I have to say there are better Belgians,  Edsen Double Plus to name one. I am one of maybe 10 people to ever that that ambriosa.

UPDATED: OCT 3, 2009 Sometimes life is beautiful. You come home from work on your birthday, and there it is. A Rochefort 10 served by your girlfriend at the right temperature. Appears dark brown with a huge head, that lasts. The aroma is very spiced and complex. You really want to try this beer. Notes of yeast and maybe corriander. The taste. Heavens. Find it hard to imagine that it gets any better. A remarkable balance between alcohol and the palate of tasteimpressions like chocolate, malt, coffee and other spices. The aftertaste is quite alcaholic but pleasant. This is absolutely the most complex and complete beer ive tasted till today. This I will revisit.
2009-10-03 I drink this temporarily, and are having one right now. It is still one hell of a beer, and I don´t have the urge to change my rating. This rocks big time.

Thick foamy head with light brown color. Beer is dark brown and unclear. The flavour is violent, dark, complex and with hints of chocolate and fruits. [rerate] The second and third i had, tasted better than the first. Not as sweet and the dominant alcohol taste was almost gone! I must admit it grows on you as well, i like it better and better :-)

By far the best Trappist or any beer for that matter I ever tasted. Beautiful colour, strong fruity aroma with a slight bitterness and that great chocolate kick.
This one goes with everything no matter what, simply love it!!!!

Aroma of yeast and hops. Yeast, chocolate, blackcurrant, coffee, alcohol and some roasted malt in the taste. Malty and syrupy with an intense long bittersweet finish. A classic!

After several tastings on the terrace of Café de Engel in Oldenzaal, Ill stick to my rating. With every sample you discover more flavors and aromas.

UPDATED: AUG 6, 2006 BEER CONCENTRATE! What can I say. Strong alcoholic and chocolate aroma, with plum and spice. Taste also predominantly alcoholic but disperses to leave plum skin and pimento biting your tastebuds, chocolate and toffee linger,  leaving you feeling a warm glow. Incredibly good beer!
This is one of the finest beers on the planet.  It is so smooth and so well balanced at 11+%abv.  I have three more bottles of this and will definitely be re-reviewing this gem.

UPDATED: MAR 20, 2006 Re-rate: After the process of formation by visiting the abbeys in Belgium, I really got a new view on this beer! This time I found it very pleasant. Dark nut-brown body with a nice creamy head. The aroma brings remindings of yeast, roasted bread and chocolate. Dry taste of alcohol and chocolate, though well balance between the strong alcohol and the malty hints. High complexity with notes of yeast, raisins and herbs. Warm mouthfeel. A vigor and vinous brew.

RE-rate: well, figuring as i havent had any beers this week, i treated myself to one of these tonight. Lovely mirky deep brown colour, with creamy off white head and nice tight, compact, tiny bubbles. It has a very good appearance. Milk chocolate nose, with a bit of a candy like scent, also has a bit of raisins and bread in the aroma aswell. Big hit of sweet malt at the start, lightly carbonated, with a dry and to my surprise an acidic dry-ish finish, the acid i guess must have something to do with the fact that the use by date is March 2007. This beer has a long way to go!!! i seriuosly have to consider laying 12 or so bottles of this down, for 5 or so years. Lots of candy like flavours, chocolate, pudding, acid. Really creamy and round palate, irresistable!!

Ive never seen anything like this. Such unflitered earthy brown.  The head was a beatuiful tan as well.  First Sip: Refreshing, sweet plum.  Nice.  It really is plum and I wasnt even looking at the description when I thought of it. The alcohol aroma goodness climbs through my nostrils and starts a party in my brain.  11.3%?!  You gotta be kidding me.  Where do they hide it? As the coolness dissipates there is a pleasant bitterness that settles on the tongue. This by the way was my 21st bday present from davhgbrew :) Half way through. Now Im beginning to taste the alcohol, but I stress it is pleasant.

Pretty violent beer, I would not drink it on a warm and hot summerday. However the flavor is very complex and the beer reminds a little about Westvleteren. However it is not the same elegance as the Westvleteren, but if youre looking for a substitude for the Westvleteren (because of its rarity) Rochefort 10 is an excellent choice.

This is the second best beer Ive had. Its strong yet it doesnt feel unpleasent but the taste of alcohol is there if you look for it and it sets this beer back somewhat. Overall its deffinately a good beer and I would recommend trying it. Ive like to note that Ive tasted this beer a couple times and its never tasted quite the same way so it makes rating the beer a litle bit difficult.

A dark and complex beer.  Strong flavors of plums and raisins.  There is an amazing array of flavors happening in this beer, everything from bananas to grapes.  The alcohol is well hidden here.  This is a must have.

Mmmm.  What a nose, one of the best Ive ever smelled.  Wondrous.  Rich, sweet, and sugary, this ones redolent with butterscotch, caramel, cola, and loads of malts.  Reminds me quite a bit of Old Horizontal or, to be safe, Horzy probably reminds me of this one (gotta give credit where credit is due).  Pretty brew, nice dark reddish-purple color.  Had a more prevalent head than expected.  Flavor is very rich and strong, though certainly doesnt seem to be an 11.3% brew--the complexity masks the % quite nicely.  Tasty yeasts, giving a pleasing residual sweetness.  Very fruity, lots of ripe plums, vanilla, and port.  Very vinous, reminding me of a number of barleywines (or, again, the other way around).  Very smooth and a bit creamy.  Incredibly complex brew, and a worthy #400 drunk to celebrate the little boys three-month birthday.
Second favourite trappist ale.  Great fruit, different flavours almost with each mouthful.  Got that broad nuttiness you might find in a really, really expensive red wine.

The color is a somewhat disturbing dark, hazy, muddy brown. Who knows what lurks in this? Only the monks know for sure. I get first whiffs of maple syrup, sweaty socks, cinnamon and alcohol. The head pours thick and quickly clears. This is difficult to describe. I keep getting familiar tastes, but the mix is so complex that I cant pin things down quick enough. Spicy, lightly hopped overtones mix with a complicated, yet subtle, chocolate flavor. Nothing steps on anything else. Lurking behind it all is a big alcohol undercurrent that is masked well. Take your time, enjoy the wonders.

Rerate: They got this at my local bottle shop! so i couldnt resist a rerate. mmmmm...... i wasnt dissapointed. It cant be described how i feel about this beer (the only reason its not perfect is because i dont really want to rate a beer that highly yet). NOTE: a bit hoppier this time (although same expiry date). Still excellent as ever.

Original Rating: (8/21/02)(My 100th Rating!) First of all let me say the I didnt want to get too excited before drinking this brew. After all I had read other peoples rating about how it wasnt that refined and the alcohol was too dominant etc etc. Now let me say: this might very well be my new favouite beer. Black/Brown/Maroon in clour with lovely white head. Aroma is one of the best Ive encountered. And the flavour! much more toffee-y and malty than what I had been anticipating (I was expecting more plums and raisins). Every tastebud on your tougue is tickled in delight as the liquid slides down your mouth. Alcohol is quite noticeable but I didnt find this to be an overly bad thing. Although I dont like to give high ratings on a whim (this will be my highest I believe) I cant help myself with this baby. A fitting 100th!

UPDATED: JUL 12, 2015 One of the best Belgian strong ales around. I recently sampled a 3.5 year old bottle, but to my surprise the ageing effect is not as obvious as for let?s say Chimay. Still a fantastic and complex brew. Re-rate: BB 2008, sampled 2009 (about 6 years old). Obvious aged notes, especially in aroma. However, in flavor this one seemed to be beyond its peak. Relatively thin mouthfeel. Very good beer, but i?m not convinced about its aging potential.

A Trappist with a best before date, well at least its telling me I have until 2007 but Ill finish mine by the time Ive finished typing.

Dark brown color, lots of foam. Vinuous aroma, grapey/appley with notes of chocolate and bubble gum. Smooth palate, lots of fruit but not intense, lightly roasted and nutty with some alcohol astringeny and bite in the finish. Very pleasnat but packed with flavor and character. Great match for chocolate.

UPDATED: SEP 29, 2010 What a lovely beer.. Described quite well by others!
Rerate june 2004. Malty, full aroma with loads of fruit. Cloudy, dark brown coloured with a perfect lacing. Taste is very full, well balanced and complex. Full of fruits (grapes, red fruits) raisins, quite malty and sweet. Some spices present. Overall a great beer with a perfect finish. Everytime I drink this one, its great. 
Rated this one as a 4.8 it was in my top3. I realised that this beer was definately not a top 3 beer for me, as there are so many much better beers.
Strong presence of alcohol.  Elements of red wine or even champagne.  Lovely sweet toasty malt aroma.
More malty than the Westvletern 12 but in the same class.  The only Trappist to add spices, they use a little corriander.

This is just magnificent... began with a citrus and spice aroma and gradually changed to become dominantly raisin-grape then to a dominantly grape... gorgeous dark, slight red-purple appearance with a typical belgian style head. The flavor... well, the flavor is quite remarkable and complex as hell. It starts off with raisin, hint of banana, spice and plum then turns to a more stoutish chocolate, molasses and coffee... still with the hints of spice and raisin cutting through now and then and maybe even some orange. The finish is wonderfully dry with just a small tease of sweetness that makes you wonder if, in fact, you just tasted what you thought you did. A beer like this makes me happy; im so damn excited to try my westy 12 i have sitting in the cellar now... im such a nerd.
Good, but I certainly wouldnt rank it the third best beer in the world.  It is flavorful but I dont particularly enjoy the combination of flavors.  Alcohol is very noticeable and even dominant.

Bananas for everyone. This beers fatal flaw was its port like quality. Now i know most belgians take on port characteristics with age and its a toss up with each bottle you buy and im going by that. It smelled like bananas and the usual belgium spice, but after giving it time to breathe it was just full on bananas. The taste was port (blagh) and the finish was like sour bananas. Very interesting, and also quite complex..lots of tastes rush in and out.
Trappists never disappoint you...

UPDATED: AUG 28, 2004 I finally tried this monumental brew. Even though it cost me $11.00 I am still very impressed. It's not often that I'm drinking a beer alone and say "Wow!" after every sip. Very full bodied and yet it is not a struggle to drink. It has a beautiful balance of alcohol and raisins. (Think Raison Detre except much more complex and much much better) By the time it had warmed I felt as though I was drinking some sort of rum raisin drink. A great desert beer and something I look forward to treating myself to after Christmas bonuses. 
re-rate: I have a number of 2001 and they get better and better every time I open one up.

UPDATED: APR 2, 2006 Foamy dark beer with a lot of complexity. A The aroma is spicy with some bread. The palate is, is wow! Words fail me. What a beer. 1st rerate Aug 16 2002: Aroma -1. The aroma is fresh and a tiny bit sour. This was probably a very fresh beer. Date on bottle 7.02.07. It has the same aroma and flavour tendencies as a fresh Westy 12. A perfectly balanced beer. It has not got the complexity of Westy 12 but that is not a negative thing. It is more controlled but what a control!!
Nothing i could say that hasnt been already. A Top notch beer that is certainly worth its ranking.

Rerate: 15 August 2002 (use by date 27-02-07) Poured correctly produced a royal dark amber brown clear with a few flecks of dark sediment, and a lasting large tan head and lovely lace.  As I said on my previous rate this is a monster beer! It has the bite of a good bitter, the velvety smoothness of top stout, all the aromas of a spice cupboard, and the alcohol content of a red wine. Aroma - this would take all day. Initially I get floral honeysuckle, sweet malt, hops, sultanas more than raisins, then spices and maybe even bubblegum, boiled lollies and rotting wood yeast. The palate is beautifully balanced across sweet and bitter. Body is rich, smooth and full through the bitter/sweet malty vinous middle, finish and aftertaste. The high ABV is dangerously well disguised. Not quite as good as the Westy 12 but  IMHO its equal within the coarseness of the rating scale we use. My favourite beer with chillied pork spare ribs. 

First rated 6 June 2002: 4.9

Theres probably a world-class beer lurking beneath all the carbo and alcohol flavors, but I had a damned hard time finding it. Re-Rate 8/02: Had a much more settled bottle and it was definitely a world-class beer experience. Nose of cherries and coffee with a hint of alcohol; Flavor was semi-sweet, with hints of chocolate, coffee, raisins, and toffee. Alcohol was well masked, apparent only in the warming effect as this fine brew slid down my gullet. Finishes with a sweet, slightly bitter aftertaste.

A very beutiful beer with a nutbrown color which turn darkbrown if you pour the sediment. It has hints of fruit in the aroma and a very good head. It is a very strong tasting beer with hints of fruit but also alcohol. Id prefer it with out the taste of alcohol and likes Rochefort 8 better.

UPDATED: JAN 13, 2012 Beautiful dark appearance. Malty taste, caramel and chocolate hints. You dont even notice the 11.3 % alcohol, which is a sign of a great beer. I really enjoyed this beer, though i can imagine only at the right time, somewhat later in the evening. But what a brew!

I will compare this beer to Westvleteren 12 because they are similar beers. Rochefort is darker and more opaque. The head is a darker khaki. The head composition is unusual. The bottom is big bubbled but the bubbles get smaller the closer to the top until the top layer you cant see the individual bubbles and you just get a creamy foam. Because of the different bubble sizes you get a less creamy mouthfeel , but one where the feel of the bubbles plays a part. The aroma is that of a good porter with some spice and fruitiness. The flavor has a nice toffee maltiness with pears, chocolate and a dessert spice like cinnamon or nutmeg. It also has a brightness to the flavor that the Westy lacked. Like the Westy, surprisingly easy to drink for its strength.

Like liquid rum nraisins, dark, cloudy and light syrupy texture. Light cloyness is tempered with a balanced tartness, just enough to spike the tongue. Alcohol is well hidden and kicks like a mule. Very well crafted. For $12:50(Aus), it should be as magnificent as it was.

UPDATED: OCT 19, 2003 Poured in to a frothy dream, No light shown thru the glass.Fantastic carboniation, smells 0f lush chocolate and fruits fill your mouth. Quality this good reminds me of some of the best Cuban Cigars I have smoked, Cohiba, Hoyo, Romeo y Julieta , and Bolivar. I let this one set out 15 minutes before I started drinking it, and it only improved as it warmed up. Extremely Recommended.
This ale has a nice bite to it.  It has a good balance of fruity and spicy taste to it which you hardly notice the 11.3%abv.  Cause it will definitely  throw you for a loop.Recommended

Pours up with a thick head, light tan in color.  The beer itself is a rich brown, but light enough to suggest amber as the sun catches it.  The aroma is delectable, foreshadowing the yeasty, spicy flavor of the beer to come.  It makes the whole mouth tingle, if not to the extent of the Westy12.  The alcohol is well-masked, yet not completely, which complements the various fruit influences (raisin was the most identifiable in this most enjoyably complex beer).  The head never quite disappears, sheeting down the side of my glass nicely.

The first time I drank this I thought: Its complex, but theres something rotten and cheesy in the aroma and taste, which makes it unpleasant. That was probably just a bad bottle, because since then Ive only had really good experiences with the Rochefort 10. The aroma as well as the flavour is rather complex. It has a spicy and rich taste with notes of Danish rye-bread and a fruity sweetness. The high alcohol content is definately not a negative thing. The alcohol gives this beer its power which makes it one of the worlds real top beers. I can still sense the cheesy thing about the aroma, but its not as overwhelming as the first time I tried this.

Incredibly rich Trappist beer. 144 people have reviewed before me so what can I really say that wouldnt be a repeat? Aroma very chocolatey, bready, malty - and I detect cherries in there somewhere. Sweet coffee chocolate flavor. Also spice/pepper and nut-like flavors. I, unlike so many others, did not find the alcohol conspicuous in a negative way. A bit too rich to have two -unless you share two with a nice lady and let the 11.3 % do its work...yikes, what am I talking about?

The big sweet malt nose has clear molasses aromas and reeks of alcohol. Extremely dark brown color is almost blank. Lacks a good head. Tastes of roasted malt that imparts espresso flavors with spices (peppery). Like licorice. Bitter end. Long profile that ends sweet. Beautiful!

Strong coffee aroma with hints of malt, light chocolate, banana and nutmeg. Black body with no head. Heavy licorice flavor. Bitter initial flavor with a sour finish. Fizzy carbonation. Nice, but I liked the 8 better!

UPDATED: APR 9, 2004 Rerate: 7/24/02: After having the Rochefort 6 and 8, and the Rochefortoise, I think the overall here has to come down a bit because of unbalanced sweetness and high alcohol. Still a great brew. Original: 2/26/02: Virtually no head on my one (sad sniff...) sample bottle. Full-bodied, full blast of sweet fruit, sugar, malts of many kinds. Alcohol...quite...evident. Similar peppery finish to the Westy 12, not as intense, not quite as long. Sweet to the not-bitter-enough-end.
user_location: Łódż, Warsaw, Poland; Michigan, Ohio, USA

text: Deep, dark ruby color with a thick, tan head that lasted all the way down the glass, with great lace.  Subtle sweet aroma with a strong sense of the alcohol to come.  Incredibly smooth.  Complex sweetness with caramel, burnt chocolate and brown sugar notes.  Very sweet but very well balanced with bitterness.  As it warms up the sherry sensation gets stronger.  A truely wonderful beer.

Initially sports a huge, rocky and tannish head that eventually softens up. Body is dark brown to near prune in color. Aromas of raisins, cocoa and some bready notes after the yeast pour. Flavors of bitter dark chocolate, raisins and fresh baked bread (as the temperature rises and after the yeast pour). Very pronounced alcohol presence top to bottom. This beer improves immensely as it approaches the ambient air temperature.

Mmmmm... I had this one during a beer-tasting session, together with the 6 and the 8 - this is by far the most complex of them - not only because of the alcohol content, which makes it almost winey - but most of all because of its dark, almost soil-like rich taste. Rasins and dakr rye-bread in the beginning, then chocolate and onwards towards heaven... 
A MUST try!
Very strong Belgium ale with a fruity bubble gum aroma and flavour.  I was slightly disappointed with the overall product.
WOW, this one is great! Very complex: sweet, fruity, a very good aftertaste. Instead of God bless America: God bless Belgium!

Aroma of grape juice, some alcohol, dark bready maltiness, and punch(?).  Very dark and opaque reddish-brown, with an attractive but not overly large head and some fine effervescence.  Flavor profile is of course complex, with some chocolate cake, a dark berry-like fruity glaze, a slight alcoholic warmth and some spicy hop and yeast flavors.  Herbal, spiced, malty aftertaste with a very prolonged and warming finish.  This beer has a few things in common with the Westy 12, one of which is the myriad of flavors that one gets just sitting and tasting, long after swallowing, even.   Deservedly a Top 10 beer.  Can I get a hell yeah!  Cheers, Scott!

I try to describe beers by the setting in which they would be perfect.  Each beer has a home in some time/place.  This beer would be the perfect post-dinner drink after inviting the woman I love to marry me.  God-willing, if she is the right girl, this beer would be her suggestion.  I could taste a little more alcohol on the nose than some previous reviewers, but its a warm, sensuous alcohol that invites rather than warns.  Perceptible chocolate tones and a strange grassy-ness at the back of the palate.  Lingering warmth.  A fantastic and complex brew.

UPDATED: MAR 18, 2003 Best before 02 03 05. Dark,cloudy,reddish brown color. Minimal head. Aroma leaves me wondering if I am worthy.
Biscuity-cereal like aromas are focus but the fermenting fruit and chocolate flavors let themselves be known also. Perfect carbonation let the complexities of flavor shine straight from the first sip.Starts out with a grape like acidity that coats the tounge while chocolate,raisin,and musty yeastiness hide the alcohol.(Sort of) As it breathes it's body barely weakens but it gains flavors.Especially the finish.This beer has so much flavor and complexity I hate to even judge it.Well worth the money.

UPDATED: MAY 13, 2016 Velvety port wine allusions approach chocolate cake flavorsSensuous licorice develops rich raisins which languorously move into inebriating alcohol warmth...A world-class sipper which rarely disappoints...

WOW! I usually get a little let down when I finally try the high ranking beers. This one delivered on all the hype. Aroma is so complex that you get something different every time you inhale. Pricey but worth it.
Excellent. A somewhat nutty aroma. Nice dark brown color. I taste the 11.3% in this one.

Probably the most complex beer Ive had to date.  Great appearance!  Lots of carbonation on the tongue (too much?).  Striking aroma, notes of licorice and...oddly...a light red Italian sauce, perhaps suggestive of oregano and basil.  That is muted in the tasting, where I get much more chocolate/toffee and a nice balanced level of sweetness.  At the same time, slight bitterness, all in harmony with one another.  And this is 11.3% alcohol?  I can hardly sense it--except when I stand up.
Fruity, sweet, full-bodied and complex aroma and taste. Hides the high level of alcohol very well. A fantastic Trappist.
yes truly one of the greats. it must be drank to appreciate one of my favorites when in belgium

UPDATED: MAY 15, 2003 I had to rerate this; my previous rating sucked. Deep brown, with a beige head that leaves a surprisingly small amount of lace. Dried fruit, caramel, oak. Alcohol is apparent enough to prevent me from drinking this wonderful stuff too quickly, and abundant enough to force me to go back and edit all my typos.

UPDATED: JAN 11, 2003 Deep brown color, with a huge tan head of tiny bubbles, sweet and fruity aroma, sweet and malty, flavors of dark fruit and caremel, full thick robust mouthfeel and some what chewy, just about perfectly balanced. I will have another one.

UPDATED: JUN 22, 2006 Soft & creamy light-tan head. Mysterious dark ruby. Mouthfeel and flavor gets your attention right from the start. First sip bit me like an alligator. A little excessive on the carbonation, which seems to create an unappealing bitterness. Sharp, biting, hot and burning sensation made me wonder if the beer I got was tainted in some way. Alcohol was definitely evident, maybe even some uninvited fusel alcohol too. Other than that, I noticed a rough-edged smokiness that poked through. While I do like many Belgians, and I didnt think this one was too bad, I have to question it... Ill have to get another bottle of this sometime and rerate. Or maybe I just built up my expectations too high. RERATE (2/03): Frothy (interesting, big- and little-bubbled) head. Murky dark brown with a reddish tinge. Malty nose. Smooth and thick on the tongue; occasionally watery almost. Some "hot" alcohol notes pop up here and there. Not overly complex in my opinion. Not a bad beer by far, but I dont like it as much as many others.
A trappist, what can I say? Bitter chocolate-flavour mixed with dark rhum. Great stuff!
a perfect score for the perfect beer. i had this strong ale on my friends front porch. it was 85 outside too. bright and sunny. quite refreshing.

UPDATED: JAN 12, 2012 Bottle (BB June 2016, so 7 months old).

Head is initially large, frothy/fizzy, light brown, mostly diminishing.
Body is hazy dark orange-brown, bottle conditioned.

Aroma is lightly to moderately malty (caramel, cookie), lightly yeasty (cobwebs), with light notes of raisin, orange peel, brown sugar, alcohol.

Flavor is heavily sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter.
Finish is moderately sweet, lightly acidic, lightly to moderately bitter.

Medium body, watery texture, fizzy carbonation, moderately alcoholic.

Watery and fizzy as with the other Rochefort brews.  Reasonably nice aroma and flavor balance for its size, but ultimately its just not that great.
This is very very great beer, so complex in aroma og taste that its a thrill to drink

Second bottle is much more impressive than the first.  A big beer.  Its definitely earns its high rank, but I am not as impressed as I had hoped.  Maybe I built up too high of expectations.  I expected more bready flavor, as well as more plum and raisin palate as it is so described.  The high level of alcohol, for the most part, masked these qualities.  Still, it is a good beer.

Smallish head with medium condition. Initial aroma impression is of stilton cheese followed by a figgy fruitiness with hints of licorice and creosote. Body is very chocolaty with a port like woodiness and yeasty bread flavours. The alcohol only realy becomes apparent in the aftertaste which is sweet and powdery and leaves a sense of dissapointment that youve just finished your last bottle. Damn.
Wow! Amazing. Most people have pretty much covered it but I definatley got the strong malt/banannas/alcohol flavor out of this. Amazingly well rounded and subtle. Quite a brew!
Very nice thick, creamy brew.  Nice complexity in the aroma and flavor.  Already warming after two sips.

This beer was good, but not great.  My bottle had almost no head, and what little did come out, immeadiately disappeared.  Of course, I made the mistake of serving it too cold.  As it warmed, the flavors became significantly nicer.  The alcohol was warming, but I did not think overwhelming.  I noticed a strong taste of apples.  In all, I feel like this beer needs another sampling because I saw hints of extraordinary.  However, it did not have the overall strength I was expecting.

Aroma of Plum, very dark brown appearance, with a creamy brown head that lasted the entire beer. The mouthfeel is almost the consistancy of a smoothy, the palate is consumed with flavors of fruit and spices that are so complex I cant even begin to explain. The finish is long and smooth, I love the afterbreath of this brew. Couldnt taste the 11.3%abv at all, but I started to feel it, OH yeah!! This is my perfect beer, and the only brew truly deserving of a perfect score!
It smells like candy - it tastes like candy - it is candy in a glass!  A very interesting brew -thick and almost syurpy.  This would serve as a good dessert.  Wonderful aroma.
Unlike the Westy I didnt start this one too cold, and I was rewarded. What a great Ale. Like a liquid Fig Newton. Sweet, almost candy aroma. This is a beer to sit back, relax, and enjoy.

Slow paced at the onset, but at the halfway post, her alacrity picks up and that taste hangs round for ages, and thats good. Instant after-pour bubble dispersal to a even natural fermentation fizz!!! (natural aspirated for all you knobs out there) Malty (in case you didnt notice), None of that burnt business, nice sweetness, high tongue oxidisation after prolonged non-libation.
I know the alcohol content is high and all the kids will go for it because of that, but its a top drop irrespective.

According to Aaron, it makes a sound like Alka Seltzer when its poured -- fizzy.  It has a thick head that disappears pretty quickly and LOTS of sediment.  The color is a deep, flat brown (the only comparison I could come up with was Vegemite, but I dont think most will find that descriptive).  The aroma is yeasty, malty and mildly sweet, and the alcohol comes right through.  The flavor is strong and sweetly astringent with some earthy/woody undertones, and its main character is the sweet alcohol-ness.  It finishes sweet and gentle, but leaves an alcohol aftertaste.  This is an after dinner cordial kind of beer.

Curranty aroma and flavor.  Also a caramel sweetness.  Alcohol is noticeable, particularly on the swallow, but not nearly as much as the abv would suggest.  Chewy.  I like this beer, but I clearly dont share the passion for it that others do.

UPDATED: JUN 16, 2003 First aroma that was recognizable was vanilla, but softer, like those vanilla wafers. Dark fruits like purple grapes and plums there,too. The taste is so complex and so many flavors bounce from the tongue that it is hard to put into words. Mine was chilled and the flavors multiplied as it warmed. Like the other belgian strong ales that I have tasted, I am amazed at the odd floaties and how alive they are, and what reactions occur right there on the top of your ale. As it really warmed, the alcohol was much more present. I found only one bottle, and didn't share a drop!

rerate 3/26/03 with a bottle stamped with a best by date of 16-10-07:  Cinnebon was the biggest part of the nose and taste. Very empty otherwise. Thin and almost watery. Sweet raisin and prune aftertaste. This (probably too young) bottle really brought down the rating.
Becareful not to tturn your back on your friends,when you offer then a sip of this sit down beer.

UPDATED: AUG 12, 2008 RE-RATE: Second glass, taken at room temperature (I had tried to chill the first down to the recommended temperature, but may have chilled too much). This is much more complex than glass #1 - please dont chill this beer AT ALL. Its only fair to compare the two giants on the same playing field (I only tried Westy at room temperature), so I have to say that I like the Rochefort 10 at room temperature a little teeny bit better than the Westy 12. Im not going to down-rate Westy, but Ill make the 10 equal to it. RERATE 9/07: Knocking it down a bit due to a head-to-head with the 12.
A wonderfully comples spicy flavor. Rich and dark like a smooth stout yet light and lively on the palate. A great beer.

A nice, dark  brown color, a terrific aroma, a very smooth textured beer with a pronounced head, medium to full-bodied with a sweet, slightly fruity, malted flavor, thick, very dense, like a banana molasses syrup, very similar to Westveleteren #8, but not quite up to that caliber, it simply doesn’t have the same quality of taste, though it grows more intense with every sip, a mouthful.

I mostly agreet with user PTomkinson s review a little lower.
You expect a beer from special quality, and it comes close to that

nutty brown colour, fizzy heads that dissipates too soon.
great aroma,  plums raisins, creme de casis, caramel, chocolate.
taste is as complex as the nose, incredibly for an 11%alcohol beer, the alcohol doe not overwhelm any subtleties in taste.
this beer combimes the best malt features of a nice malty single malt scotch with the complexity of a robust bordeaux or beaujolais wine.

HMMM!  Unfortunately for this one I had it the same night as Westvleteren 12.  A very good effort but the flavor and patate are a spot off.  Perhaps not a fair comparison, but if choosing one over another........
